HEAVY SHELLING IN BOSNIA
Bosnian troops tried to break through Serbian lines in Sarajevo in a day of some of the heaviest shelling in weeks. Among the wounded were five Ukrainian soldiers serving with United Nations troops. 1
 
EUROPE OUTRAGED OVER REFUGEES
Western European governments are facing increasing criticism of their muted response to Serbian aggression and to the refugees made homeless by the Serbian policy of "ethnic cleansing." But officials are reluctant to take a more active role. 5
 
REGRESSION IN PERU
The dark ages have returned to Lima. The city is sheathed in an armor of plywood against the bombs of the Shining Path guerrillas, electricity is spotty, tourists are few and fear is everpresent. 1
 
THE LATIN DEBT PICTURE
The Latin America debt crisis is over, according to prominent officials in the region. But some analysts maintain that the current optimism is premature and nation by nation there are a number of complications in the rosy picture. 1
 
SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW DISPOSSESSED

NEW ALARM OVER TUBERCULOSIS

Like so many communities in rural America, Custer County, Neb., could have already died off. Instead, its residents are pulling together in a rare kind of cooperative effort that has become the subject of scholarly research. 1

NEW CLUE ON SEXUAL PREFERENCE
Researchers said a cord of nerve fibers allowing the two halves of the brain to communicate with each other is larger in homosexual men than in either heterosexual men or women. The researchers believe that the finding supports the idea that the brains of homosexuals differ from those of heterosexuals and that sexual orientation has a profound biological basis. 7

HEADLINE: Small Towns Team Up to Fight Bleak Futures

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARNOLD, Neb.

 BODY:
This is one of the little towns that America apparently does not need anymore. Not in the days of shopping malls and Interstate highways, which never came to Custer County.
As in so many isolated pockets on the Great Plains, the population has been falling, hollowed by a shrinking farm economy. In 1990 the county had 12,000 people, down from nearly 30,000 in 1930. A Rutgers University study named Custer County as one of the dying places that might as well be swept clean of the last remaining residents, with its 3,072 square miles turned over to the bison. 
 But with towns, as with people, the will to survive does not always fade with a bad prognosis. "It's easy to run away, to go somewhere bigger, like everyone else," said Janet Larreau, a 32-year-old native of Custer County who moved home from Denver a few years ago. "But some of us have decided to stay. This is our way of life. And it's worth a fight."
In the exodus from rural America, these are the people who have chosen to stay behind. Using some creative strategies as a slingshot against the Goliath forces of a "bigger is better" economy, the little towns of Custer County have banded together for survival.
In a grass-roots effort to survive, the county residents have put their hopes in an innovative plan to foster a new concept of community that rural sociologists say could be a model: the countywide Main Street. The idea originated about a year ago with a volunteer group called the Nestbuilders' Network, whose members work to foster cooperation between individuals and communities.
Residents agree that none of the 12 little towns in the county can make it alone. They are simply too small. But if they pull together as a county, they might be able to achieve what economists call "critical mass," or the level needed to sustain a community.
If the town of Arnold does not have a pharmacy, for example, people are encouraged to shop in the next little town that has one rather than drive 45 miles to a big discount store in North Platte.
The effort to survive has forced people to set aside the old rivalries that have simmered for generations between the little towns. For years, it was not uncommon to hear a resident of one town boast that he would not set foot in a neighboring town.
"People used to say, 'Oh, I won't shop in Anselmo, say, because they beat us in football four years ago and I hate them,' " said Sandy Hatch, a representative of the Nestbuilders Network. "But people have come to realize: If we're going to survive, we have to stick together."
The civic support does not come without a price. People know they could buy goods more cheaply at a shopping mall. But people like Patricia Crow, who farms here with her husband, Darrell, said those extra dollars would not seem worth it if a local store closed.
"If everybody's going to shop at Uncle Sam's," said Mrs. Crow, referring to the Wal-Mart in North Platte, "then all the money ends up in a big corporation, and we're out in the cold."
Custer County's plan has stirred the interest of scholars who study ways to stem the decline in rural regions. A team of Iowa State University professors recently visited the county to document its approach, which will be used as part of a video primer for other struggling little towns.
"They have learned to cooperate, rather than compete," said Peter Korsching, the director of a rural development program sponsored by the United States Agriculture Department, which paid for the Iowa State study. "What's interesting is that they're doing it all by themselves."
Like the pioneers of a century ago, who braved Nebraska winds and snow in sod houses and earthen dug-outs, their challenge is to find ways to adapt in a changing and still harsh country.
Rather than venture out to a new world, as their ancestors did, their mission is to save the old one.
 
Battling for Life And Her Hometown
 When the old Watson's Grocery, which had been selling goods at the corner of Arnold and Custer Streets since 1946, decided to close its doors last year, people here assumed that another ghost would haunt the business district.
Since 1980, a movie theater, a hardware store and a service station have stood empty.
But Chris Meyer, whose youngest child was about to enter school, turned to her husband, Jim, an electrician for the town, and said, "What do you think?"
Arnold, their hometown, had been a wonderful place to raise four children. If they believed in the town and what it stood for, they decided, they had a responsibility to put some chips on the table.
They invested every penny of Mr. Meyer's retirement fund in the store. And they painted a new sign on an outside wall with a message: "Meyer's Market: Established 1991."
The grocery store will hardly make them wealthy. Just to make ends meet, they keep it open from 7 A.M. to at least 6:30 P.M. Monday through Saturday, and from 9 to 2 on Sundays.
On many weeknights, Mrs. Meyer or one of her clerks is still checking groceries at 9 P.M. When a worried parent calls at midnight, looking for aspirin for a sick child, she goes down to the store and opens up. Groceries are delivered for free. "If we just work hard enough," Mrs. Meyer said, "this town is going to make it."
Mrs. Meyer, 29 years old, knows something about fighting against the odds. When she was 25, she learned she had cancer. "I thought, if I can just make it until I'm 30," she said. "Let me have that much. Just let me become 30 years old."
She looked across the table at her four children, who had met her and her husband for lunch at the Model Cafe. "I've been lucky," she said. She lost a part of her tongue and the use of her salivary glands. But the cancer has not reappeared.
For now, she and her husband are looking forward to the big barn dance and party they are holding on Aug. 1.
"Her brother's in a country band, and he's going to play," Mr. Meyer said. "And he does Garth Brooks better than Garth Brooks. It's going to be one heck of a celebration."
Chris Meyer is turning 30.
 
Brainstorming To Bring in Money
 This is a place where people over 60 eat for half-price at the Model Cafe, where the owner, 83-year-old Marjorie Hagler, bakes homemade pies that draw customers from all over the county. It is a place where slips of paper appeared in every mailbox in town one recent Saturday morning, reading simply, "Althea needs help with her house." By noon, an army of volunteers had arrived at the woman's home.
On Mother's Day, a small-plane crash took the life of a 14-year-old boy, and by dark nearly every one of the town's 671 residents had come with food and embraces for the shuddering parents. Through their tears, the family members wondered what they were going to do with 36 canned hams.
Once a month, the Nestbuilders' Network meets to plot the survival of Custer County.
At the end of each meeting, they have what they call a "wild and crazy" session to brainstorm for new ideas. There are two rules: No one can laugh at an idea, and no one can say, "That won't work."
At one session, they tried to figure out a way to bring tourists to this remote stretch of Nebraska. But what did the countryside have to offer?
"There's plenty of wind," said somebody, half in jest.
"That's it," someone else replied. "Everybody liked to fly kites as a kid. We'll have a kite-flying festival."
The celebration drew visitors from seven states, and the stores and restaurants of the county profited.
At another meeting, it was mentioned that many people here make things as a hobby, like quilts, clocks and bookshelves. Why not pool their creations, someone suggested, and sell them. The Devil's Den, a crafts cooperative, now employs a full-time worker.
And residents of the county have been busy coming up with their own ideas. A farmer who groused about having to drive 35 miles to buy a nail, for example, opened a lumberyard. It now employs three people.
The town governments have started to keep in close touch, finding out the others' needs so they can buy in bulk and save money. Civic and business leaders check around the county to make sure that festivals or special sales do not conflict.
The efforts in Custer County have won praise from the Center for the New West, a research organization that has conducted a study on ways that small towns can survive.
"Rather than wallow and lament about the old days," said John Shepard, of the Center for the New West, "the people of Custer County have discovered that they can make big differences in small ways."
But the people in Custer County say they welcome, indeed recruit, new residents. Mindful that people in bigger places often complain about high prices and violent crime, they put together a brochure and mailed it to every graduate of Custer County schools.
"We sent them a letter that said, 'You can turn your kids loose here and not worry about it,' " said Mrs. Hatch, of Nestbuilders. "You can walk around at midnight with peace of mind."
In a few cases, the brochures have fallen into the hands of people who had never heard of Custer County and are now residents.
 
For Recruiters, The People Payoff
 When they were living in Michigan, the noise and clutter of urban life sometimes seemed about to swallow Steve and Robin Clouse. They had always lived in metropolitan areas, but they yearned for a place with open spaces and with people who didn't seem to be in such a hurry.
"I always wanted to live in a place where people waved at you when you drove down the street," Mrs. Clouse said.
A neighbor, who had lived in Custer County, showed the Clouses the brochure. "This looks like what you're looking for," the neighbor told them.
The couple made a few telephone calls and did some research. They learned that nice houses sell for about $30,000, sometimes less, in Custer County. And they found out that the teacher-to-pupil ratio was 14 to 1. In their 6-year-old daughter's class in Lansing, there were 33 students.
Mr. Clouse, a 38-year-old handyman who builds and remodels homes, was told that a worker could keep busy as long as he did not mind driving some distances between jobs.
They packed and headed for Custer County last spring. On the day they arrived, two people were waiting at the house they had rented to help them unpack. A woman came to clean the carpets. A man with a tractor plowed them a garden.
"I was shocked," Mrs. Clouse said.
"This is paradise," Mr. Clouse said.
So far, he has been able to find work without a problem, though he sometimes has to drive 30 or 40 miles to a job. But he can cover that distance in half an hour, the same time he often needed to go 8 or 9 miles in Lansing.
Mrs. Clouse stays at home with their baby, and neighbors routinely stop to visit and ask if she needs a sitter for a while, just so she can take a break.
And their daughter has already made plenty of new friends. One of them took her home to a ranch last week.
"She even got to watch them brand cattle," said Mr. Clouse, with a note of awe. "I just wish I could have gone."

HEADLINE: BUSH AIDE ASSAILS U.S. PREPARATIONS FOR EARTH SUMMIT

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
President Bush's top environmental adviser has sharply criticized the Administration's handling of the recent Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, saying it was slow to react to crucial issues, late in assembling a delegation and unwilling to devote sufficient resources to the meeting.
The criticism by William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency and the chief of the United States delegation to the Rio summit, was made in a memorandum that he circulated to 12,000 agency employees two weeks ago. The memorandum was first disclosed today by The Associated Press. 
 Mr. Reilly has often been in conflict with Vice President Dan Quayle and other top officials who have sought to temper environmental policies advocated by the E.P.A. director.
 
No Intention to Resign
 Despite the tone of the memorandum and its wide circulation within the agency, Mr. Reilly said in a telephone interview today that he had no intention of resigning.
"I'm just communicating to my own people about something that was a very severe disappointment to them," Mr. Reilly said. "Their concern was how, in a country that brought the best environmental performance record to Rio, did we manage to become the focus of such criticism."
Nonetheless, the memorandum could be read as an effort by Mr. Reilly to restore his standing among environmentalists, some of whom have expressed disappointment with his inability to gain Administration approval for more aggressive environmental programs.
Today, Mr. Reilly chose his words carefully in explaining why he wrote the memorandum. "We prepared for Rio in the midst of political and economic preoccupations that were a distraction," he said. "The preparation clearly suffered. This was a public-relations disappointment. I set out in this memorandum to explain why we received such criticism."
Whatever Mr. Reilly's intent, the memorandum is likely to provide new ammunition for Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and Senator Al Gore, his running mate, who are already pressing an attack against President Bush for what they see as his failure to protect the environment.
Although Mr. Reilly complimented Mr. Bush in the memo for appearing at the summit after initially threatening not to attend, he implicitly criticized him by assaulting the Administration's whole approach to the meeting.
The White House did not reply to several requests for comment on the E.P.A. Administrator's memorandum.
In the memorandum, Mr. Reilly lashed out at the White House decision not to sign the biodiversity treaty to preserve the world's plant and animal species. He said the decision received so much criticism that other ideas put forward by the United States at the international conference were drowned out.
"Why did the United States play such a low-key defensive game in preparing for Rio?" Mr. Reilly asked in the memorandum. "We assigned a low priority to the negotiations of the biodiversity treaty, were slow to engage the climate issue, were last to commit our President to attend Rio. We put our delegation together late, and we committed few resources. No doubt, this contributed to negative feelings toward the United States."
 
'Like a Bungee Jump'
 Mr. Reilly also responded to his opponents in the Administration who embarrassed him at the start of the June summit by disclosing a confidential memorandum in which Mr. Reilly had urged the White House to change its position on the biodiversity treaty.
"For me personally, it was like a bungee jump," Mr. Reilly said in the memorandum. "You dive into space secured by a line on your leg and trust it pulls you up before you smash into he ground. It doesn't typically occur to you that someone might cut your line."
Though Mr. Reilly heads the Government's environmental agency, many experts say his authority has been greatly diminished in recent months and that it has been assumed by Vice President Quayle, who heads the Council on Competitiveness; Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget; Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Clayton Yeutter, the President's domestic policy adviser.
The memorandum is the most biting criticism that Mr. Reilly has publicly leveled at his opponents in the White House. Moreover, it comes as the White House is trying to pull itself together and present a unified message on how it intends to handle important domestic issues in a second term, among them the economy and the environment.
In public, and in private meetings at the White House, Mr. Reilly has argued without much success this year that the Administration's year-old program of halting environmental regulations, proposing to rewrite environmental laws, and weakening existing statutes will not attract the crucial suburban voters in California, the Middle West, and the Northeast who may well hold the key to victory in the fall election.
 
Response to Supportive Staff
 David Cohen, Mr. Reilly's spokesman, said today that the memorandum was a response to a message of support from 3,000 agency employees upon his arrival in Washington after one of the most difficult and emotionally trying diplomatic missions a United States delegation chief has ever experienced. The employees said Mr. Reilly was a "tremendous asset" to the E.P.A. and a "source of inspiration" to his staff.
It is no secret in Washington that President Bush's environmental and economic advisers have been at odds since the start of the Administration in January 1989. Mr. Reilly and his allies, among them Michael R. Deland, the chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality, and Robert E. Grady, the acting Deputy Director of the Office of Management and Budget, agree that economic growth is compatible with a clean environment protected by tough rules.
Mr. Reilly also says ecological problems like climate warming, depletion of the earth's protective ozone shield, deforestation and loss of species are growing worse. Mr. Reilly has been an advocate for strong international agreements to halt global environmental problems that he considers a threat to all life.
 
Administration Hostilities
 Mr. Reilly's opponents in the Administration, particularly Vice President Quayle and the staff of the Council on Competitiveness, believe that some amount of pollution and other environmental tradeoffs are necessary to advance the economy, particularly during a recession. They have sought to weaken some regulations, such as those in the 1990 Clean Air Act, to make them friendlier to business. They have taken a dim view of scientific claims that global warming and loss of species are growing worse, and they have rejected appeals by the environmental community to take much stronger measures in battling global ecological problems.
But not until the Earth Summit had the extremely personal nature of the high-level battles in the Administration broken into public view. When Mr. Reilly proposed in the confidential memorandum in June that the White House change its position on the biodiversity treaty, his opponents, alarmed that he might succeed, disclosed the memorandum.
The disclosure seemed intended to diminish his standing at the Rio conference. But it also had the effect of embarrassing President Bush, who condemned the disclosure and ordered an investigation into its source.

HEADLINE: Census Reveals Changes as It Paints a Picture of Metropolitan America

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
If metropolitan New York seems foreign to the rest of America, that's because it is.
Nearly one in five residents was born abroad. Nearly one in three residents speaks a language other than English -- and almost half of those acknowledge that they don't speak English very well. 
 In Jersey City, a mecca for Cubans, other Hispanic immigrants and people from India, 3 in 10 residents is foreign-born -- a higher proportion than in any other major metropolitan area except Miami. Among residents of New York City and three counties to the north -- Westchester, Rockland and Putnam -- nearly 4 in 10 said they speak a language other than English at home, and more residents arrived from abroad than moved from another state.
More than one in six of the nation's new legal immigrants in the 1980's settled in the New York region. Among all of the nation's metropolitan areas, about 1 in 10 residents is foreign-born.
The Census Bureau also reported Thursday that New York State was the biggest loser in net migration from 1980 through 1988. The state lost 1,399,000 people -- 478,000 of them to Florida, which recorded the biggest gains of any state.
The census figures sketched an exotic profile of a region that sprawls across three states and is changing in measurable ways beyond the most visible one, its complexion.
Although direct comparisons with 1980 are difficult because the Census Bureau reconfigures metropolitan areas every decade, some broad changes can be discerned.
During the 1980's, the percentage of people graduating from high school and from college climbed. So did the proportion of women in the labor force, although it is still lower than the average of all metropolitan areas.
 
Drop in Poverty?
 The overall poverty rate in the region also dipped, but that improvement may have disappeared. The census measured income for 1989, but since then the Northeast has been struck by a lingering recession that has helped swell the welfare rolls in New York City to more than 994,000 at last count -- the highest level in 16 years.
The census quantified broad disparities among the components of metropolitan New York, which in addition to the city includes Long Island, the lower Hudson Valley, Northern New Jersey and Fairfield County in Connecticut.
Median household income -- the point at which half the households received more and half less -- ranged from $30,917 in Jersey City to $57,876 in Stamford. The Government defines a household as people, related or not, living in a single housing unit.
The $38,445 median for the entire metropolitan area was substantially higher than the $32,086 average for all of the nation's metropolitan areas.
Across the nation, 12.1 percent of people in metropolitan areas were living below the federally defined poverty level. In the New York metropolitan area, Bristol and Danbury had the lowest poverty rates, below 4 percent. Long Island and Middlesex, Somerset and Hunterdon Counties in New Jersey were slightly higher.
The highest rate was 17.5 percent in the five counties within New York City and the three counties just to the north, where nearly 6 in 10 female-headed households were living in poverty. Those eight counties reported the lowest percentage of married-couple families -- 41.6 percent -- and the highest percentage of people living alone -- 36.9 percent.
 
Young at 34
 The median age of people in New York City and the three counties immediately north of the city -- 34 years old -- was on the low end for the metropolitan area.
Households were largest on Long Island -- 2.99 people, compared to 2.56 in New York City and Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties. Long Island also had a higher proportion of people born in the state in which they now live -- nearly 9 in 10 -- than the entire New York metropolitan area and than the average for metropolitan areas in the nation.
Stamford had the highest percentage of college graduates -- 43.7 percent -- compared to an average of 25.8 for the metropolitan area. The figure for all metropolitan areas in the nation was 22.5 percent.
New York City and Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties led the nation in the percentage of commuters who use public transportation -- nearly half. Even commuters in the suburbs used mass transit at a higher rate than the 6.5 percent average for commuters in all metropolitan areas. In the entire metropolitan area, though, the proportion of people using mass transit declined to 26 percent from about 30 percent in 1980.
Among the metropolitan area's more than seven million housing units, fewer than 1 percent lacked complete plumbing and fewer than 5 percent had no telephone. There were slightly more houses or apartments with no bedrooms than with five or more bedrooms.
Fully 10 percent of people in the region have lived in the same house or apartment for three decades. About one-third moved into their homes since 1985.
Of the 8.7 million employed in the metropolitan area, about 5.4 million of them were in executive, administrative, managerial, sales, clerical or professional occupations. More than 210,000 were in protective services -- almost four times as many as in farming, forestry and fishing. About the same number -- 1.2 million -- were employed in manufacturing and in retail trades.
The New York metropolitan area's population rose by 3.1 percent in the 1980's -- close to the rate in the nation's non-metropolitan areas.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Outlines Welfare Plan Before California Audience

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVERSIDE, Calif., July 31

 BODY:
President Bush came to this city today to promote welfare reform, an issue his advisers say is hot among the middle-class voters his campaign so urgently needs to reach here.
But the President's own message in a state where he badly trails the Democratic Presidential nominee, Bill Clinton, was markedly tepid. And even his aides allowed that the proposals he brought with him had virtually no prospect of becoming law any time soon. 
 The day's main event, a Rotary Club breakfast before about 1,000 overwhelmingly white listeners, only underscored the continuing fits-and-starts nature of Mr. Bush's re-election bid, as he chose today not to attack the Democrats, as he had done on Thursday. The polls show that the President trails Mr. Clinton by as many as 34 percentage points in California, even as the number of days left to campaign has dwindled to fewer than 100.
On the last day of a two-day effort to repair his ties with California conservatives, the President flew at sunrise to Riverside, about 60 miles east of Los Angeles, to visit an employment bureau and issue a legislative proposal for welfare reform.
His speech largely repeated the Administration's contention that the welfare system locks the poor into a cycle of dependency and that innovation by states and cities -- not more Federal money and rules -- can best break that cycle.
 
Proposals to Trim Welfare
 "Welfare was designed to be temporary, temporary," Mr. Bush told the Rotarians. "But today, more than half of all recipients receive a check for eight years, and we can't afford that."
He pledged to craft a better system that would reward responsibility and tell recipients to "get a job or get off the dole." And he said he supported state programs that would reduce or deny benefits to some welfare recipients who continued to bear children they could not afford to raise.
"I know this is a tough call, a tough system," he said. "But so is a system in which poverty is handed down from generation to generation."
A few yards away, aides handed out a thick outline of Administration proposals to give states more freedom to decide how to spend the $150 billion spent by the Federal government on welfare each year.
The ideas included one to allow states to devise new incentive programs to encourage welfare recipients to find jobs and one to combine cash and Food Stamps for food, housing and Medicaid into programs governed by one set of rules.
The Administration would also encourage employers to hire the poor by allowing employers, in some cases, to pay them less than the minimum wage or union rates. And it would give states more freedom to make welfare seem more like regular pay.
 
Congress Unlikely to Act
 Mr. Bush's welfare expert, Gail Wollensky, said the Administration wanted "to try to encourage changes that will promote and encourage employment, savings, responsible childbearing, families that stay together, making sure that if they don't stay together, the dad pays." She said the proposals would be sent to Congress as a bill within a few weeks.
But Congress will recess in two weeks for the campaign season and is unlikely to take up any new legislation when it returns after the November elections.
The proposal appeared to be intended less to influence lawmakers than to address charges by Democrats and critics in the welfare establishment that Mr. Bush has been urging welfare reform but has never produced a list of changes.
After Mr. Bush's speech, his aides passed out a three-page news release attacking welfare proposals by Mr. Clinton as well as Mr. Clinton's welfare record as Governor of Arkansas. Bush aides contended that welfare administrative costs there had risen 30-fold since Mr. Clinton took office.
Later, Mr. Clinton responded by saying, "It's simply not true."
But that mention of Mr. Clinton was the only one today in a campaign stop curiously devoid of criticism of Mr. Bush's rival.
Only Thursday, in Orange County, Mr. Bush had lashed out at Mr. Clinton's proposals on military spending and foreign-affairs experience. Aides said Mr. Bush's attack on Mr. Clinton in Orange County had been added fairly late to his planned speech at the President's own insistence.
Asked why Mr. Bush had not inserted similar bristles into his remarks at Riverside, one Bush aide replied, "We weren't that organized."
In a small but telling slip today, the President himself seemed to symbolize the uncertainty of his own campaign.
Mr. Bush tripped over a stock line that he uses in speeches these days, reminding audiences that he would jump feet-first into campaigning after the Republican convention in mid-August.
He promised soon "to roll up my sleeves and go after them and tell the American people what is really going on."
"But let me just tell those of you who are interested in politics, you wait two years from now. . . ." Then he corrected himself: "I mean two weeks from now."

Factory orders climbed in June, helped by rising demand for big-ticket items, but personal income was flat, forcing consumers to dig into savings to produce a modest spending rise. [43.]

International

The region is still burdened with more than $435 billion in loans, and the annual interest payments will put a heavy drag on the economies of these countries for years. [1.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Party Chief Assails G.O.P.'s 'Sleaze' Strategy

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Turning up name-calling in the Presidential campaign another notch, the chairman of the Democratic Party today described the Bush-Quayle campaign's recent strategy as "state-of-the-art sleaze."
This came after a senior Republican aide referred to Gov. Bill Clinton as a "philandering, pot-smoking draft dodger." 
 The comment about Mr. Clinton appeared in an article today in The New York Times that described the subtle ways Vice President Dan Quayle and other campaign surrogates have been trying to chip away at the Arkansas Governor's image by reminding voters of the personal accusations that have been hurled at Mr. Clinton.
The comment was by Mary Matalin, the Bush campaign's political director, who was asked whether Bush-Quayle officials were trying to draw personal accusations about Mr. Clinton into the campaign. Her response was: "We've never said to the press that he's a philandering, pot-smoking draft dodger."
 
'Lexicon of Lies'
 Asked in turn about that remark, she said: "That's the first time I've done that. There's nothing nefarious or subliminal going on."
Today, the Democratic national chairman, Ronald H. Brown, issued a statement that stepped gingerly around direct criticism of Ms. Matalin, using the occasion instead to assail Mr. Bush. He said the remark was a deliberate attempt by the White House to divert attention from the weak economic figures that emerged Thursday.
"A few months ago George Bush ordered his staff, in writing, to 'stay out of the sleaze business,' " Mr. Brown said. "Today that statement joins the lexicon of lies that include 'read my lips,' '30 million jobs in eight years,' 'kinder, gentler nation,' 'Clarence Thomas is the most qualified person in the country to sit on the Supreme Court,' and 'Dan Quayle is growing into the job.'
"I'll say this for the Bush-Quayle campaign," he added. "Their tactics are state of the art sleaze."
The Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator Al Gore, also criticized Mr. Bush, saying he had failed to keep his promise "to keep this campaign on the issues and out of the mud."

HEADLINE: Paramount Joins the Theme Park Bandwagon

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
After months of speculation that it would make an acquisition, Paramount Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a group of regional theme parks for $400 million.
Paramount said it would acquire the Kings Entertainment Company, a private concern that owns Kings Dominion, near Richmond; Great America, in Santa Clara, Calif., and Carowinds, near Charlotte, N.C., where the company is based. 
 Paramount, based in New York, will also buy Kings Island, a park near Cincinnati that is owned by the American Financial Corporation and managed by Kings Entertainment, and the 20 percent of Canada's Wonderland, near Toronto, owned by Kings Entertainment.
Paramount said Kings Entertainment was expected to have 1992 revenues exceeding $250 million and earnings of $63 million before interest, taxes and depreciation, an increase of about 10 percent from 1991.
Analysts had said for months that Paramount might buy NBC or make another major acquisition. The purchase of Kings Entertainment, however, is not expected to preclude additional purchases by Paramount, which had revenues last year of $3.9 billion and has a cash hoard of $1.5 billion from the sale in the 1980's of several nonentertainment assets.
Analysts generally viewed the acquisition of Kings Entertainment favorably, saying it would slightly increase Paramount's earnings per share, was low risk and would have little financial consequence.
Investors, however, apparently took a different view. Paramount's stock fell $1.625 yesterday, closing at $45.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"I think the Street is saying that on the surface, it does not have a great strategic fit; it is a nice business, but it does not go anywhere," said Emanuel Gerard, a partner of Gerard, Klauer & Mattison, an investment firm.
"The street was hoping Paramount's cash would be used in a major strategic acquisition that might lead in a new direction," Mr. Gerard said. "And it seems to be getting used in small pieces that have no dramatic impact."
Ray Katz of Shearson Lehman Brothers noted there were also hopes that Paramount would be sold.
It has become a trend for entertainment companies to acquire theme parks. The Walt Disney Company, with its Disneyland and Disney World parks, and MCA Inc., with its Universal Studios parks, have been successful in marketing products and establishing recognition for characters created for their films and television programs. And last year, Time Warner Inc. bought a stake in Six Flags Entertainment, a chain of six regional amusement park.
Paramount has a number of properties that could be used in a theme park setting. These include the "Addams Family," "Star Trek" and "Top Gun" movies; the "Cheers" and "McGyver" television shows, and the Nancy Drew and Hardy Boys books published by its Simon & Schuster unit. Paramount also owns Madison Square Garden and said that its experience in staging live events there gave it the skills to book events at each of the theme parks, which can hold from 8,000 to 13,000 people.
Kings Entertainment has rights to Hanna Barbera characters until 2009. Among them are the Flintstones and Yogi Bear.
Paramount's chairman, Martin S. Davis, said the deal would give Paramount the opportunity to further exploit its film, television and publishing assets as well as to expand its live-entertainment abilities.
Gordon Crawford, senior vice president of the Capital Research Company, whose firm is the largest shareholder in Paramount, with about 4 percent, backed the acquisition. He said theme parks had become an integral part of the entertainment business because they allowed film companies to cross-promote characters they own.
At the Six Flags park in the Chicago area, for example, Time Warner has a new Batman ride, Batman stunt show and a fireworks and laser show. It also owns the rights to cartoon characters like Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck, which have long been featured at the Six Flags parks.
MCA's Universal Studios Florida offers rides based on several Universal names, including E. T. and King Kong. Disney has rides based on Snow White and Alice in Wonderland and live shows based on its movies "The Little Mermaid" and "Beauty and the Beast."
The financier Mario Gabelli, whose Gabelli & Company owns a 3 percent stake in Paramount, said the Kings theme parks were "nice properties."
"They are reasonably steady cash generators," he said, "and it looks like a conservative, financially opportunistic acquisition, but it is not material."
Kings Entertainment parks are regional, attracting mostly visitors from a 150-mile radius. The Disney and MCA parks are called destination parks, because they attract visitors from around the world.
In general, the theme park business has been a good one, although it has been hurt by the recession. At parks run by Kings, attendance fell to 11.2 million in 1991 from 11.3 million a year earlier. The company expects 11.4 million visitors this year.
Paramount is unlikely to pay for the entire acquisition in cash. Mr. Gabelli estimated that the deal could add about 8 cents net a share to Paramount's earnings.
One executive with knowledge of the two companies said: "The parks generate enough cash to cover the interest expense whether Paramount borrows the money or pays out of its own cash. So Paramount has not impaired its ability to undertake any other acquisition."
 
Retaining the Chief
 Paramount said Nelson Schwab, who leads the group of investors selling Kings Entertainment and serves as the company's chairman and chief executive, would continue in those positions in a new theme park unit being created at Paramount.
The American Financial Corporation said its segment of the transaction is expected to be completed by Oct. 1. It bought Kings Island from Kings Entertainment in 1987.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 
NEW YORK CITY
 
CITY OFFERS INCENTIVES TO BANK
The Dinkins administration has offered a range of tax abatements and other financial incentives to the First Chicago Trust Company, a company with close ties to the city's top economic development official, in an effort to keep it from moving its headquarters and 1,000 jobs to New Jersey. Page 27.
 
 DINKINS AIDE TO WORK FOR CLINTON?
Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch Jr., Mayor David N. Dinkins's chief political strategist and trouble-shooter, acknowledged yesterday that he was considering temporarily leaving City Hall to take a top position with the State Democratic Committee, where he would focus on the Presidential campaign of Bill Clinton and other Democratic candidates. Page 27.
 
 STEPPING UP BRIDGE INSPECTIONS
Two days after the Manhattan Bridge was closed to subway trains for the emergency repair of a dangerously weakened support beam beneath the subway tracks, New York City Department of Transportation officials moved to make routine inspections of the bridge more thorough. Page 27.
 
 MAN SLAIN IN SHOOTOUT NEAR BANK
An employee of a wholesale tobacco company was killed and a suspected holdup man critically wounded in a shootout that erupted when several men tried to rob two employees of the company outside a Brooklyn bank. Page 27.
 
Bronx jury hears tape of a murder suspect being questioned by a former girlfriend. Page 27.

REGION
 
 HARD TIMES IN CONNECTICUT
In yet another sign of Connecticut's economic fall from grace, the nation's wealthiest state has seen the number of its residents receiving food stamps nearly double in the last three years. The increase has been considerably steeper than that of either the nation as a whole or of New York and New Jersey. Experts say it is largely a function of the sharp reversal in the fortunes of a state whose economy was booming in the 1980's. Page 28.
 
 SEARCHING FOR KIN
Gordon Clark Ramsey, a 51-year-old professor at the University of Hartford, fears he may be among the last descendants of Stephen Hopkins, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. But he may find out otherwise on a beach in Warwick, R.I., next month when at least 500 people from around the country are expected to gather for a one-day party. Anyone who was ever related to a Hopkins, however remotely, is invited. Mr. Ramsey will attend, searching not so much for roots, he said, as for relatives. Page 28.
 
 PROFILE OF THE METROPOLITAN REGION
If metropolitan New York seems foreign to the rest of America, that's because it is. Nearly one in five residents was born abroad. Nearly one in three residents speaks a language other than English -- and almost half of those acknowledge that they don't speak English very well. Page 7.
 
 RESTORING AN INSURER'S HEALTH
With Blue Cross plans all over the country in financial trouble, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey is fighting to regain the financial health it enjoyed until the 1980's, when changes in the state's system of paying for health care, combined with an explosion in expensive medical technology, threatened to bankrupt the insurer. HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
To Clinton, at Crest of Popularity, Smiling Is Easy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 31

 BODY:
In Bill Clinton's profession, smiling is an essential job skill and an ingrained habit.
Mr. Clinton's smile is one of the best, even by the demanding standards of his line of work. It runs an unusually varied gamut, from a full-beam grin that denotes honest fun, to a slightly quizzical, open-jawed look of modesty, to a small, seductive curve delivered with a shy glance from under half-lowered eyelids, with the lower lip lightly bitten. 
 Riding the crest of his own popularity, Mr. Clinton campaigns most days from early in the morning until late at night, and during most of that time, he is smiling. (He alternates greetings as he goes down the line: "Hi. Hello. Hi. Hello. Hi. Hello.") He smiles as he dandles more babies than a portrait photographer. ("Aw, that's a beautiful baby," he says.)
He smiles in the face of adversity, as he did in La Grange, Ill., on Tuesday, when a young man repeatedly addressed him as "Slick Willie," and in New Orleans on Wednesday, when he cheerfully suggested that a heckler at his evening speech shut up.
This morning, an easy day with only one public event here in the morning and a speech before the National Bar Association in St. Louis in the evening, Mr. Clinton, under the lights and lenses of the cameras, played at playing basketball with a group of neighborhood children at the North Little Rock Community Center. He was more game than his game was good; he hit only 4 of 11 shots, repeatedly forgot to dribble the ball and displayed the reaction time of, well, a large middle-aged man. But he kept smiling.
In most politicians, most of the time, such relentless beaming would seem false, particularly in the case of a politician in trouble (such as Mr. Clinton was during the dark days of spring), when the line between a frozen smile and the rictus of rigor mortis is easily crossed. The interesting thing about Mr. Clinton's sunniness is how appropriate it looks.
 
Easy to Stay Cheerful
 The days since the end of the convention that nominated him as the Democratic choice for President, beginning his great, though possibly evanescent, rise in the polls, have been the summer of Mr. Clinton's content. He seems to be having the time of his life, and no wonder. He is on a roll of historical proportions, and he is spending his days doing what true politicians truly love: talking at length to admiring crowds.
It is hard to say exactly how much Mr. Clinton talks in a given day, but it is a lot. Four half-hour speeches, plus four 15-minute segments of chatting his way through the crowd would give him (at an average speed of 90 words per minute), 16,200 words right there, and that does not count all the talk that goes into lesser events of the day, the interviews and news conferences and fund-raisers. The total for a full 12-hour day of campaigning must run to a minimum of 40,000 words, or about half the length of a modest book.
Yet Mr. Clinton, in his current ebullience, seems to find this hardly enough. In the town-meeting-style events favored by the candidate, he often takes questions for 40 or 50 minutes, and he generally answers each one with a mini-speech of enough length and depth that his questioners generally get tired and sit down well before the end of his answers to their queries.
There is something about the town meetings that suggests a game -- "Ask Mr. Policyman" it might be called -- that Mr. Clinton genuinely enjoys, perhaps because he always wins. He sits with easy confidence in the middle of whatever group his campaign has gathered, apparently secure in the knowledge that he can pull, from the storage files of his mind, enough bits and pieces of past speeches, policy papers and legislation to handle almost any question.
But it is more than a mere grasp of policy that Mr. Clinton displays in this kind of setting. He seems to have, these days at least, a winner's confidence that he can talk his way through whatever the moment brings. When, this morning, a teen-ager asked him to discuss his reaction to "all those allegations about your wife" that had come up earlier in the campaign, Mr. Clinton chuckled and said easily, "Oh, I though it was kinda overdone." Then he moved seamlessly into the thought that "we can spend too much time looking at yesterday when we ought to be looking at tomorrow."
Mr. Clinton's desire to talk even encompasses his previous tormenters, the reporters. Very late Tuesday night, after a 16-hour day, the candidate wandered back into the press section of his campaign plane for a chat. He started on politics, moved to varied matters of policy -- health care, abortion, the economy, industrial planning, the regulation of breast implants, to cite a few -- and went on to discuss his current favorites among books and movies, the state of the American psyche ("very fragile"), his daughter, Chelsea, and her progress at language camp, and other thoughts as they came up in questions or in his mind.
He was offhandedly candid about subjects that would more safely be avoided. He told of an encounter with an adolescent boy at a recent speech. The youth, he said, told him that his father had fought in Vietnam and suggested that he doubted Mr. Clinton's fitness for the Presidency because of his successful efforts to avoid service in the war.
"I said to him, 'I deeply respect what your father did, and I applaud it, but you don't know what you're talking about, and you can't know, 'cause you weren't there, and I hope you never have to learn.' "
The following night, Mr. Clinton made another appearance in the back of the plane, this time after a 16-hour day chasing votes in Louisiana. A reporter handed him a copy of the latest issue of "Weekly World News," the front page of which was dominated by a "world exclusive photo" of Mr. Clinton shaking hands with a slit-eyed creature the publication claimed was a visitor, and Clinton supporter, from another planet.
Laughing, the candidate examined the front page, and said, "I want you to know, I'm broadening my base." He added, "I promised you an inclusive Administration and this means it." Poking mild fun at his own rhetoric, he said, "I mean, we are all one family, right?"
A reporter mockingly accused Mr. Clinton of "intergalactic pandering" to secure the alien vote.
"Yes, I promised them I'd keep the space station," Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Sues S.& L. Auditor for $400 Million

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The Government filed a $400 million suit today against the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company, charging it with malpractice in the failure of a leading Houston savings institution, the Ben Franklin Savings Association.
The suit is the largest ever brought by the Resolution Trust Corporation against lawyers or accountants -- a key target in the Government's effort to make wrongdoers accountable for the multibillion-dollar savings and loan crisis. 
 The R.T.C., the Government's savings and loan cleanup agency, charged Arthur Andersen with professional negligence and breach of contract in auditing Ben Franklin between 1984 and 1988.
Ben Franklin collapsed in 1989 at a cost of almost $1 billion to taxpayers.
 
Deception Charged
 The suit contends that Andersen agreed to management's use of accounting gimmicks to hide a deteriorating financial condition, thus deceiving regulators and failing to alert anyone to the high level of risk.
An R.T.C. spokesman, Steve Katsanos, said the suit was significant because of "the extensive malpractice and negligence found." He said it was filed after months of futile negotiations between the R.T.C. and the Chicago accounting firm.
Arthur Andersen said in a statement that its professional services were not to blame for Ben Franklin's collapse and that the savings and loan's "problems were directly related to the collapse of oil prices in 1986 and other related economic forces affecting the Southwest at that time."
Arthur Andersen had issued caveats to its audit reports in 1986 and 1987 and declined to give an opinion on the accuracy of Ben Franklin's financial statements in 1988.
 
Litigation Increased
 Federal regulators in recent months have stepped up suits against lawyers, auditors and others who advised failed savings institutions. Resolution Trust, for instance, brought a $275 million suit against the New York law firm of Kaye Scholer Fierman Hays & Handler and froze its assets, forcing it into a $41 million settlement.
In the Andersen suit, filed in Federal court in Illinois, the Government contends the firm should have expanded the scope of its audits so it could assess Ben Franklin's risk level. Its parent, the investment banking and commercial real estate firm Security Capital Corporation of New York, which acquired it in 1981, was not experienced in the savings industry, the suit states.
Ben Franklin grew by buying a residential mortgage firm, pushing investments in high-risk adjustable mortgages with graduated payments and teaser rates, buying undeveloped land at inflated prices and lending to out-of-state commercial real estate projects, the suit said, financing all this by offering above-market interest rates to attract deposits.
"Andersen's acts or omissions concealed the true extent of Ben Franklin's financial problems and exacerbated the association's unhealthy condition," it said in the suit.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
McDonnell Douglas Posts 50.6% Drop in Earnings

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, citing sharply higher research spending on a proposed 600-seat jumbo jet, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings dropped 50.6 percent, to $38 million, or $1 a share, from $77 million, or $2.01 a share, a year ago. Revenue in the quarter dropped 1.4 percent, to $4.89 billion, from $4.96 billion a year ago.
Analysts said the earnings were far below expectations for the St. Louis-based company, with many on Wall Street having expected earnings to exceed $2.25 a share. They said that negative factors besides the jumbo-jet project included sharply lower earnings from the C-17 military transport program and unexpectedly low earnings from the MD-11, the long-range civilian jet that competes with strong-selling products from Airbus, the European consortium. 
 The jumbo-jet project, known as the MD-12, was delayed earlier this summer. McDonnell Douglas, short on cash, could not find a financial partner to share the $5 billion development costs, and airlines did not seem enthusiastic about buying a new product while their industry was in recession.
 
Stock Price Suffers
 The market yesterday took 8.4 percent off McDonnell Douglas's stock price. It closed at $36.75 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, down $3.375.
McDonnell Douglas was once the world's second-largest manufacturer of commercial aircraft after Boeing, which has half of the commercial market. But McDonnell Douglas was quickly overtaken in the early 1990's by Airbus, which makes a wide variety of medium- and long-range jets that compete nearly across the board with Boeing. McDonnell Douglas now has about 20 percent of the market, about the same as Airbus, but with a much smaller backlog of orders than the Europeans.
The world's airlines wildly over-ordered aircraft in the late 1980's and in 1990; when the global recession hit, they furiously canceled orders. Much of their present fleet remains idle, making purchases extremely unlikely for some time. With military spending also slumping in the aftermath of the cold war, McDonnell Douglas finds itself in the painful position of trying to develop new aircraft at a time when few customers even want to buy its present models.
Jerry Cantwell, an aerospace analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company, said he had expected McDonnell Douglas to report earnings of about $2.25 a share and was surprised when they came in at $1.
Mr. Cantwell said that 60 cents of the shortfall were a result of lower revenues from the C-17 project, the giant plane that can carry jeeps and other planes for rapid deployment of military forces.
McDonnell Douglas said the $34 million charge it took for the C-17 was a result of increased costs and higher reserves for the project. Another 20 cents a share, or $11 million, came from a write-off in a laser communications program and lower earnings from the space station project.
Most surprising to Mr. Cantwell was the level of spending for the MD-12 jumbo-jetliner project, equal to 25 cents a share, or $14 million more than Mr. Cantwell had expected.
Also unexpected was another 10 cents to 20 cents in what Mr. Cantwell called "missing earnings" from the MD-11, one of the company's two lines of commercial aircraft. "I don't know why MD-11 isn't doing better," Mr. Cantwell said.
In the second quarter, commercial aircraft predominated, with revenue from civilian jets increasing 19.4 percent from the quarter a year ago, to $2.15 billion. McDonnell Douglas worked off its commercial backlog, which totaled $26.4 billion as of June 30, down 20 percent from the level a year earlier. But civilian-jet earnings dropped 62 percent, to $20 million, from the level a year earlier, mainly because of the MD-12 program.
Military aircraft revenue dropped 18.7 percent, to $1.74 billion, and earnings dropped 37.7 percent, to $66 million. Revenue from missiles and space systems rose 4 percent, to $820 million, while earnings dropped 18.6 percent, to $48 million.

HEADLINE: House, Tougher on Trade, Votes High Mini-Van Duties

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
With election-year pressure building in Congress for a more confrontational trade policy, the House voted today to raise the import duties on mini-vans and sport utility vehicles to 25 percent from 2.5 percent by reclassifying them as trucks instead of cars.
If it becomes law, the change would increase the retail price of imported mini-vans by an estimated $3,300 to $4,000. 
 In the Senate, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said in an interview that he planned to reintroduce a comparable measure that was vetoed by President Bush.
Mr. Bush has said he will veto the House bill as well if it is approved.
The lopsided House vote of 273 to 112 reasserted the lawmakers' desires to sound tough on trade. The House separately passed a broad trade bill three weeks ago. That measure would set strict deadlines for the Administration to impose sanctions on foreign countries that refuse to lower barriers to American exports.
On Thursday, the Senate amended this year's energy bill to tighten American trade laws. The amendment would make it more difficult for foreign companies to avoid paying punitive duties for dumping, or selling their goods at unfairly low prices.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, which writes trade laws, had blocked Senate action on trade legislation for the last several months, saying that he needed to consider the issue first and hold a series of hearings.
The Senate action Thursday came on a bill sponsored by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, in an attempt help the Smith Corona Corporation. The company announced last week that it was moving its typewriter manufacturing operations to Mexico from Cortland, in upstate New York. Smith Corona's chairman, G. Lee Thompson, complained then that his Japanese competitors were skirting the dumping laws by setting up plants in the United States, assembling imported parts here.
 
A Broader Measure
 The House bill was part of a broader measure renewing temporary tariff reductions for 240 categories of goods, mostly chemical compounds that are scarcely made in the United States but are needed by American industry to make other products.
Congressional budget rules require that new bills provide for gains in Federal revenues to offset any losses they might bring about. The Ways and Means Committee chose the tax on mini-vans and sport utility vehicles to balance the loss from the other tariff reductions.
Advocates of today's bill increasing duties on mini-van and sport utility vehicles pointed out that these vehicles are classified by the Government as trucks for purposes of emissions control and calculating the fuel economy of each auto maker's fleet. These vehicles also tend to be produced at truck plants on assembly lines also used to build pickup trucks, which are subject to the 25 percent tax.
The bill's mostly Republican opponents pointed out repeatedly during debate on the House floor that the United States would be breaking with an international practice of classifying the vehicles as cars. They also noted that the United States imposed its truck tariff, one of the world's highest, during a 1964 trade war with European countries that were restricting American chicken exports.
Only 23 Democrats and 89 Republicans voted against the bill today, while 206 Democrats and 66 Republicans supported it. Detroit's Big Three auto makers and the United Automobile Workers lobbied heavily in favor of the measure, while dealers in imported cars opposed it.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Food-Stamp Numbers Soar

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., July 31

 BODY:
In yet another sign of Connecticut's economic fall from grace, the nation's wealthiest state has seen the number of its residents receiving food stamps nearly double in the last three years.
The increase in food stamp recipients in Connecticut, which has been considerably steeper than that of either the nation as a whole or New York and New Jersey, is largely a function of the sharp reversal in the fortunes of a state whose economy was booming in the 1980's, experts say. 
 "When jobs were going begging in Connecticut, we had a smaller proportion of our population on food stamps than other states with higher unemployment rates," said Claudette Beaulieu, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Department of Income Maintenance, which administers the Federal program in the state.
While the number of food stamp recipients in the United States dipped slightly in May, according to Federal Government statistics released today, the 36.7 percent increase nationwide in the last three years -- from 18.8 million in 1989 to 25.7 million in 1992 -- has been far outpaced by the surge in Connecticut.
 
76.5% Rise in Connecticut
 In the state, the number of individuals receiving food stamps increased from May 1989 to this May by 76.5 percent. The 203,775 individuals on Connecticut's welfare rolls in May was nearly twice the total in May 1989, when there were 115,480 recipients. By comparison, in New York State, the numbers have increased 29.8 percent to 1,904,663 in May, from 1,467,463 in May 1989. In New Jersey, the numbers increased about 44 percent to 497,077, from 345,271.
Throughout Connecticut, state welfare officials and social workers say they have seen an unprecedented number of new applications for food stamps. They also say a striking number of recent applicants are unemployed or underemployed people who have never been on welfare and feel both desperation and shame at having to apply.
"We see people just like us every day," said Mary Ann Beauregard, a caseworker in the Stamford office of the Department of Income Maintenance. "It's frightening. People say they never would have expected this, and they hate being here."
Officials for the Agriculture Department's Food and Nutrition Service, which oversees the food stamps program, acknowledge that the sour economy is pushing more people into poverty.
But Harold T. McLean, the agency's Northeastern regional administrator, also said there were "a jumble of reasons" for the increase. He said they included simplifying the application process for food stamps, increased outreach by state welfare departments, particularly to the homeless, and changes in immigration laws that make former illegal aliens eligible for food stamps.
 
Qualifying for Food Stamps
 To be eligible for food stamps, net household income must be at or below the poverty level, which is defined for a family of four as $1,117 per month. Food stamps can be used to buy any foods other than prepared foods and alcohol, and the average monthly benefit per person is about $69.
Some Connecticut social workers believe that Connecticut's increase has been, at least partly, a consequence of the steep reduction in state General Assistance benefits that resulted from last year's budget cuts. Last October, the state put a $400 cap on what it would reimburse needy individuals for rent, and as of July 1, the maximum monthly cash benefits for an employable individual were cut to $314, from $515.
"Because aid was cut so drastically, some people may no longer be eligible for state financial assistance, so we tell them to apply for food stamps," said Cathy Gasparino, a senior social worker with the Greenwich Department of Social Services.
But Ms. Beaulieu of the Department of Income Maintenance said that most, if any, effects of the state cuts had not yet been felt.
Although the ranks of Connecticut residents on food stamps increased in every month from November 1989 through April, the largest increases occurred in 1990 and 1991, when the rolls swelled by 25 percent and 22 percent. In the first five months of this year, the number of recipients increased 4 percent.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Food Stamps: Connecticut's Sharper Rise" shows index of change in the number of households receiving food stamps, Jan. 1990-August 1992. (Source: Agriculture Department)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%);

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Fall on Better Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, with intermediate-term securities taking the hardest hits, after a fresh round of economic data suggested that the economy was slowly recovering.
The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond fell 13/32 point, or $4.06 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, was 7.45 percent, up from 7.42 percent late Thursday.
"Some of the numbers are begin 
 ning to look a little more robust," Paul McCormack, head government-securities trader at Chase Securities Inc., said of the economic numbers.
Mr. McCormack said dealers were afraid to be caught with heavy supply. If the economy improves, interest rates would move higher and erode the value of their investments.
Mr. McCormack said the heaviest selling was among the intermediate maturities, where the market has a heavy supply.
 
Factory Orders Rise
 In a sign that the United States economy may be picking up steam, the Government reported a stronger-than-expected 2.3 percent rise in June factory orders. Durable goods for June were revised to a gain of 2.7 percent from a previously reported 2.3 percent.
Personal income was reported flat in June, while economists had expected a downturn. Personal consumption rose five tenths of a percent, about even with expectations.
The Chicago Management Association's monthly index, a measurement of purchasing activity by the nation's companies, rose in July to 59.2 percent on a seasonally adjusted basis from 55.7 percent in June.
Somewhat offsetting those data was a report that the University of Michigan's closely watched consumer sentiment index fell to 76.6 percent in July, revised from an earlier estimate of 77.1 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities fell between 3/16 and 5/16 point, intermediate maturities fell to between 7/16 and 11/16 point and long-term issues were down 13/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all Treasury issues outstanding with maturities of a year or longer, fell 3.54, to 1,262.68.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 3.24 percent as the discount remained stable at 3.18 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 3.36 percent as the discount rose 3 basis points, to 3.27 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 3.60 percent as the discount rose 4 basis points, to 3.47 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, The Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10011/32 , down 1/4 point. The average yield to maturity was 6.19 percent, up from 6.17 percent late Thursday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Decline While Gold Prices Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined yesterday on world currency markets after trading in a very narrow range throughout the session.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery rose 90 cents to settle at $357.40 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $357.50, up 80 cents an ounce. 
 The dollar should have drawn some support from a Commerce Department report that showed orders to United States factories jumped 2.3 percent in June, the best gain in 11 months and a hopeful sign that the economy was maintaining at least a modest pace of recovery. Economists had expected a rise of about 1.4 percent.
But further data proved to be conflicting. The Commerce Department said Americans' personal income failed to grow in June, which caused traders to question the pace of economic recovery.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 127.30 Japanese yen, from 127.77 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it was unchanged at 127.30 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 127.15 yen, down from Thursday's 127.50 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9205, from $1.9185 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.9270 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.9260.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4745 German marks, down from 1.4780; 1.3155 Swiss francs, down from 1.3165; 4.9800 French francs, down from 4.9895; 1,114.75 Italian lire, down from 1,116.75, and 1.1843 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1827.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4805 German marks, down from 1.4825; 1.3185 Swiss francs, down from 1.3215; 5.0040 French francs, down from 5.0045; 1.6680 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6715; 1,119.25 Italian lire, down from 1,120.25, and 1.1842 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1828.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $357.75 a troy ounce, from $356.55 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $357.80 from $356.10. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.08 to close at a bid $357.67.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
New Withholding On Pension Plans

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
PEOPLE who take lump-sum distributions from qualified retirement plans beginning next year will find their money reduced by a 20 percent withholding tax, unless they arrange to have the plan administrator transfer the money directly to an I.R.A. or other qualified plan.
The new withholding, a result of legislation signed by President Bush last month and intended to pay for the extended unemployment benefits that Congress voted, will affect more people than just retirees. Often, people who leave jobs -- whether they are laid off or quit -- choose to take any funds they have vested in pension plans aslump sums to be rolled over into I.R.A.'s, rather than leave money in original plans and receive pensions from former employers at retirement. 
 At present, people have 60 days to roll such lump sums over into I.R.A.'s with no tax consequence. This allows people who have temporary cash-flow problems because of layoffs or job changes to dip into retirement funds, as long as they are able to pay themselves back and get the money into an I.R.A. in time.
But if they fail to get the money into an I.R.A. within 60 days, income taxes, and generally a 10 percent penalty for people under age 59 1/2, will be due. For residents of New York and other high-tax states, that can mean half the money goes to pay Federal and state taxes and penalties.
"By mandating the withholding, the new law encourages people who do not have an urgent need for the money to continue in some type of retirement plan," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company, a New York-based certified public accounting firm. Many people who intend to get the money into an I.R.A. within 60 days fail to do so, he added, creating a problem that could be avoided by arranging a direct transfer.
But for people who need the money, he said, "it requires additional monitoring and planning." One possibility is to arrange to have the retirement-plan administrator transfer the money into an I.R.A., then withdraw money from the I.R.A. for up to 60 days. Annual tax-free I.R.A. rollovers of up to 60 days would still be allowed.
"People who have the option of taking a lump sum distribution this year or next may want to take it before the end of the year, when the rule goes into effect," Mr. Neumark said. "It's a planning opportunity."
Vincent D. Vaccaro, partner in charge of personal financial services at Coopers & Lybrand, cited another opportunity: the new law is more liberal than present law in allowing people who are leaving a job to take part of their vested retirement funds as a lump sum and have the plan administrator transfer the rest, even if it is less than half the total, to a defined contribution plan at a new employer or to an I.R.A.
Mr. Vaccaro added that he generally advised clients to keep money in qualified retirement plans, including I.R.A.'s and 401(k) plans, as long as possible to take advantage of tax-deferred compounding of interest. Most who are changing jobs want to move such funds into a defined contribution plan at a new employer, if possible, or into an I.R.A., he said, so the new law would impose no hardship.
"It's the financially unsophisticated who are going to get hurt," he said, the people who withdraw their retirement savings and then think about where to deposit them.
Mr. Neumark pointed out that for such people, the 20 percent withholding was not likely to cover the total tax liability. A person who is laid off midway through the year, for example, could receive six months of earned income and a severance package, as well as a distribution from the retirement plan. As a result, he or she could well be in the top Federal, state and local tax brackets and would also face the 10 percent penalty if under age 59 1/2. Such people would have to pay any taxes owed by the following April 15.
The 20 percent withholding will also apply to hardship distributions from 401(k) plans, which the law allows for specified needs, Mr. Neumark noted, so someone who needs $8,000 for a medical emergency, for example, would have to take out $10,000 because $2,000 would be withheld.
David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young in Washington, said, "One of the real sleepers is the cost of compliance." Employers have payroll withholding systems in place, he noted, and that means, essentially, that private business is paying accountants, bookkeepers and clerical staff to perform tax collection work.
"That's a very expensive compliance system," he said. And beginning in January, the additional withholding requirement will cause those expenses to grow, which can be significant for people who own their own businesses. Less directly, higher administrative costs will have an effect on how much people receive from defined contribution plans.

HEADLINE: Incentives Offered to First Chicago Trust

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration has offered a range of tax abatements and other financial incentives to the First Chicago Trust Company of New York, in an effort to keep it from moving its headquarters and 1,000 jobs to New Jersey.
City and bank officials said no agreements had been made yet. A First Chicago spokeswoman, Lisabeth Weiner, said the company was actively negotiating with the city, and was investigating alternatives to its headquarters now located in lower Manhattan. 
 She said the company may, in the end, renew its lease at 30 West Broadway, a 15-story building at the corner of Park Place. First Chicago's lease expires at the end of 1994. But Ms. Weiner said First Chicago Trust was also considering sites in New Jersey, downtown Brooklyn, midtown Manhattan and lower Manhattan.
The offer attracted attention at City Hall because First Chicago Trust's parent company has close ties to Barry F. Sullivan, the city's top economic development official. And the offer comes at a time when the city's real-estate glut has made it less dependent on offering subsidies to keep big business from fleeing to the suburbs or other states.
 
Unusual Arrangement
 The situation points out the difficulties of the unusual arrangement Mayor David N. Dinkins made when he appointed Mr. Sullivan as deputy mayor for economic development. Mr. Sullivan, the retired chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, receives a $780,000-a-year salary as a consultant to First Chicago. He has agreed to give his $112,000-a-year city salary to charity.
At City Hall, high-ranking officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said an intense campaign was under way to keep First Chicago Trust in lower Manhattan, or lure it to Brooklyn.
The officials also said the company was being offered tax abatements, subsidized electricity and other incentives that the city has offered corporations since the mid-1980's.
City officials said that Mr. Sullivan was not involved in the negotiations. He was recruited to serve as a deputy mayor by David Rockefeller, the chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank. He began serving under Mayor Dinkins in March, after retiring last year as the chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, which is based in Chicago and ranks among the nation's largest banks.
Mr. Sullivan joined the Dinkins administration with the stipulation that he would remain a consultant to First Chicago, and would avoid any conflict of interest by steering clear from business deals between New York City and his corporate employer. Many New York City business people applauded the arrangement as a way of attracting a nationally prominent business leader to a government job.
 
Pace of Relocations Slows
 "Barry Sullivan is simply not involved in this at all," said Carl Weisbrod, the president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, the city's second ranking economic development official.
Mr. Weisbrod is negotiating with First Chicago Trust. In an interview, he declined to say what economic inducements were being offered to the company, saying only that "incentives have been discussed."
First Chicago Trust is one of the largest companies that processes stock transfers, computes and distributes dividend checks, distributes quarterly earnings statements and provides other corporate services.
If the company leaves New York City, real-estate experts said it would buck a trend, or at least the beginning of one. With rents declining, and landlords offering incentives to potential tenants, the pace of corporations leaving Manhattan has slowed sharply over the last two years.
Indeed, some experts in the real-estate industry have begun to suggest that public incentives from City Hall, an economic imperative of the 1980's, were becoming a waste of tax money in the 1990's.
But at City Hall, officials said negotiations with First Chicago, minus Mr. Sullivan, continued. And at First Chicago, Ms. Weiner said, "we are considering options."
