HEADLINE: To Pick a Sofa, Lift It, Squeeze It and Don't Forget to Sit on It

BYLINE: By EVE M. KAHN

 BODY:
Full of complicated secrets, difficult to keep out of sight and extremely long lived, the wrong sofa can cause as much frustration and as many tears as a neurotic relative who moves in and refuses to leave. Buying the right sofa, with a solid frame, top-quality cushions and a durable, good-looking fabric can involve intensive research, something not many consumers seem willing to undertake.
"People just sit on our sofas and say to themselves: 'Is it comfortable? Do I like the fabric? How much is it? I'll take it,' " said Mark Heidorn, the manager of the Door Store at Lexington Avenue and 53d Street.
 
Consumers Are Getting Wiser
 Only since the recession has the tide of swift sofa decisions shown real signs of receding. Comfort, style and price are still of great importance, but "people are starting to ask more technical questions than ever before," said Jeanie Viars, who works in fabric development and merchandising at Thomasville Furniture Industries, which has its headquarters in Thomasville, N.C. "There are so many things out there that are overpriced. You can put the most dynamite cover on something that just won't last." 
 Sofas vary tremendously in cost, shape, size and fabric. You can spend a few hundred dollars for a simple polyester-covered love seat to more than $10,000 for suede- and fabric-covered custom sectionals as long as limousines. Despite these variables, certain quality standards can be universally applied.
Manufacturers and consumer advocates alike recommend studying the furniture's frame first: long, graceful curves and other generous proportions are costly and tricky to build and thus indicate high quality. Then, lift one end of the sofa, to see if it feels unexpectedly light, or jiggles, sags or creaks as it is raised.
"Those are very bad signs," said John Kozloff, the general sales manager for Maurice Villency, and for Roche-Bobois in New York.
Another bad sign, he said, is the sales representative who cannot answer questions about the hidden construction details of the sofa. The frame should be made of a hardwood like maple or birch at least an inch and a quarter thick. Joints should be put together with screws, dowels and glue. This much strength may sound like overkill, but it will keep the sofa from falling apart during years of intensive use. The legs should be integral to the frame rather than simply screwed or glued on.
The frame should be not only sturdy, but also well padded (to make it comfortable for people to perch on sofa arms or backs and to keep the fabric from wearing prematurely). Squeeze the arms and back; the less frame you feel, the better. Feel for the springs, too; they should be bouncy and close together, whether they are spirals, the most expensive kind, or long S-shaped wires, which are tauter but no less durable.
Cushions should fit the frame without gaps or overcrowding, and should be made of a polyurethane foam, ideally one whose density is at least 1.8 pounds per cubic foot (sales representatives will be able to supply density statistics). Down is also acceptable, but is costly and can require constant fluffing. Shredded foam can lose its shape after minimal use and is best avoided, Consumer Reports said in its January 1989 article on buying upholstered furniture.
But even the fanciest springs and fillings will not always pass the ultimate test: sit on the sofa for a while and see how it feels. Consumer Reports recommends plopping down for up to 15 minutes, paying particular attention to the sofa's ability to support your back without pitching you forward. And be sure that the seats are not so low and deep you have trouble getting up from them.
 
What You See Is What You'll Get
 Cushion covers should fit their contents snugly, without loose corners. Seams and welts should be crisp and straight; so should skirts (ideally with a lining and weights, to maintain good form in the long run). Patterns should be symmetrical, both horizontally and vertically.
If the sofas in a store's showroom do not meet these standards, the sofa you order in some other fabric is not likely to be better.
Your final sofa decision, the fabric, can be the most difficult. Choices include nylon, polyester, cotton, linen, rayon, acrylic, wool and olefin (an especially inexpensive synthetic) as well as blends of any of the above, plus leather and vinyl. Every choice has advantages and disadvantages: synthetics can pill but otherwise wear fairly well; leather can get scratched but feels good against the skin, and vinyl washes easily but sticks to you.
Be sure to ask for the largest swatch the store can provide, so that you can get a good idea of how your fabric will look in sofa form. Take it home. You may even want to try sitting on the swatch to see if it is a pattern you will want to live with for a decade or two.

HEADLINE: A Globo-Cop No Longer

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
It's like what Mark Twain said about the weather. Everybody talks about a coherent new U.S. foreign policy, and nobody makes one. Almost nobody. America's role in the coming era ought to be a lively part of the Presidential debates. So far it has been relegated to the question of experience in the old order, without clear ideas of how the U.S. should act in a world it cannot dominate by itself and cannot afford to ignore. That underlies all the floundering over Bosnia and Iraq.
Three little noticed Senate speeches by Joseph Biden, Democrat of Delaware, lay out a well-rounded concept for how to proceed, with legislative proposals. He starts with the evident truths that "domestic renewal must be the highest American priority" to assure a strong base and that the new agenda must have broad public support. He rejects isolationism and "America as globo-cop" as dangerous and probably impossible. "Our challenge," he says, "is to determine the nature of American internationalism." 
 And that, he suggests, must be a mission "to finish the job that Woodrow Wilson began," with a vision of collective security and of enlarging the definition of security to include economic well-being and environmental protection as well as defense.
Mr. Biden proposes a new definition of "containment," not aimed at an enemy power but at the spread of weapons of mass destruction. For that, he would seek an agreement with Russia on a ceiling of 500 nuclear warheads each (dramatically below levels now projected), and a ban on all nuclear tests and on production of weapon-grade fissile material. France, Britain and China would be asked to join a treaty setting strict limits on nuclear arsenals. India would be offered a permanent U.N. Security Council seat on condition of renouncing all nuclear arms ambitions, which would probably bring a similar pledge from Pakistan. Germany and Japan would also be offered permanent seats upon reconfirming their non-nuclear policies.
A bill on "weapons proliferation containment" would provide for a high-level U.S. official to oversee a coordinated policy against providing international benefits to all states in violation of nonproliferation standards. China would be denied most-favored-nation trade status if it continued arms sales that cause destabilization.
To strengthen security cooperation and help the U.S. generate international support for peacekeeping actions, Mr. Biden would seek agreement to make NATO forces available to the U.N. and the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, in both of which the U.S. has a veto. NATO's integrated structure "constitutes an asset unique in the world," which should be put to new use, not left to atrophy, he rightly notes.
The U.N.'s capacity to act would be strengthened by implementing the Charter's provision for standing ear-marked forces, with 3,000 to 8,000 U.S. troops to be contributed at the President's discretion.
Mr. Biden proposes a National Security Budget Act that would put all foreign policy and defense spending in a single budget category. "Our national security is put more at risk by failing to fund the World Bank than by not buying another Seawolf sub," he said. A combined security budget would permit direct debate on whether arms or aid gave better protection.
The Senator's several legislative proposals add up to a balanced foreign policy committing the U.S. to act with others for peace and prosperity in a regular, predictable way. This is far-sighted. It should launch a needed debate.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Indian Children Work in Family Economic Unit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 9 report on the purported widespread use of bonded child labor in the carpet manufacturing industry in Northern India, though compellingly written, gives an inaccurate picture of the true state of carpet manufacturing in India for two reasons: 
 (1) It relies on unsubstantiated (and unattributed) estimates of the actual magnitude of bonded child labor, and (2) it fails to note that children in India typically labor alongside adult family members in agriculture, carpet weaving and other economic activities, much as children did in 19th-century rural America.
Certainly, there is a problem of bonded child labor in India. However, to state that estimates of the children's work force "range from 300,000 to over a million" gives an impression that the problem is widespread and endemic in the carpet industry.
A visitor to the looms of Uttar Pradesh Province, India's bread basket, will see men, women and children working side by side on carpet looms. The overwhelming majority of the young people that one sees working on looms belong to a local family unit. They are paid a proper wage by their employer (and so are their parents). They go home at night with their parents, attend compulsory school regularly, and when they are not tying carpet knots, they are just as likely to help with the planting or harvesting of crops and the care of farm animals or of younger siblings.
Carpet weaving itself, though perhaps tedious work by Western standards, is neither dangerous nor exhausting (unlike the work you briefly mention that is done in "quarries, brass smelters, glass factories, and match and explosive plants"). No machines or chemicals are used, but only woolen yarn and hand-held tools.
All children in India are required to attend schools, a traveler in the weaving belt sees children in school throughout the countryside. Moreover, the Government of India has recently sponsored vocational centers in the carpet belt, where weaving skills, hygiene and academic subjects are taught.
The Government recognizes, in effect, that carpet weaving is an important and respectable source of income.
 
GEORGE G. BASHIAN JR.
Secaucus, N.J., July 15, 1992
 
The writer is former president of the Oriental Rug Importers Association.

HEADLINE: Census Reveals Changes as It Paints a Picture of Metropolitan America

BYLINE: By Felicity Barringer

 BODY:
Some three decades after the word "megalopolis" started competing with its predecessor, "metropolis," for a place in the American consciousness, these unweildy mixtures of city, suburb and sprawl have become home to more than three-quarters of the American population, or 193 million people.
 While most people know a metropolitan area when they see it, the Census Bureau must apply legal criteria to decide where they begin and end. The legal definition requires at least two urban centers, specified rates of population growth and density, and specified commuting patterns. For laymen, it is enough to think of them as economically linked regions sharing traffic jams, sports teams, television stations and supermarket chains. 
 This week, the bureau released the 1990 census data for these areas, and simultaneously reported on the internal migration flows of the 1980s, explaining in part how the urban areas that dominate their states became what they are today.
 More than a third of the migration during the decade affected five large states -- New York, Florida, Michigan, Texas and California. Among the four regions, the ebb and flow of population was most clearly felt in the South: 11.7 million people moved in and another 10 million (sometimes the same people) moved out from 1980 through 1989.
 Buried in the population report, beneath the news of gains in the South and West and losses in the Northeast and Midwest, may be the kernel of another trend. Year by year during the 1980s, the West and South attracted fewer people and exported increasing numbers, slowing their net growth rates. Year by year, the Northeast and Midwest stabilized or reduced their losses, while the number of people they attracted slowly increased.
 One of the report's authors, Larry Sink, suggested these figures may eventually be seen as the beginning of the end of westward migration, the signature tune of American demography.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 7, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a chart on Saturday about the 1990 census gave differing rates of population growth for the New York metropolitan area during the 1980's. The rate of 3.1 percent, cited in the article, reflects growth in the area when its boundaries are held constant. The rate of 12.2 percent, listed in the chart, reflects growth when the area is expanded beyond its 1980 boundaries, to 1990 boundaries as defined by the Census Bureau.

HEADLINE: The Comeback Trail

BYLINE: By Ian Fisher

 BODY:
IT WAS ALMOST by chance that Patty Galliardo returned to high school. When she was 14 years old her Mexican-American family moved back to Los Angeles after a few years in Mexico, but she did not go back to school. She had forgotten whatever English she had learned.
There were other obstacles, too. Like most dropouts, Ms. Galliardo had a vague notion that she ought to get her diploma. But she had hated school -- the teachers did not care, she said -- and after so long an absence from the classroom she did not know where to turn. Then a friend, also a dropout, told her about an out-of-school program that offered a flexible schedule, a close relationship with teachers and, most important, a clear path to earning her degree. 
 "First of all, my tutor, she was nice and understanding," Ms. Galliardo, now 20, said in a recent interview. "I liked her and I could talk to her and really tell her what problems I had since it was only me and her."
Ms. Galliardo's path to her diploma, one she is still treading, illustrates many of the problems facing students who have already dropped out of school. In an educational system that pours most of its money into dropout prevention, the recovery of those who do drop out is largely overlooked.
But Ms. Galliardo's experience with a Los Angeles program called Options for Youth, which over the last five years has brought in 6,000 students who had dropped out, also demonstrates the potential of innovative school re-entry programs, many educational experts say. They say that the alternative -- ignoring dropouts as lost educational causes -- is both dangerous and costly.
 
A Population Destined for Trouble
 "You have to have the courage to find the funding for both prevention and for young people who have already left school," said Toni D. Schmiegelow, executive director of the City Volunteer Corps, a volunteer service and educational program in New York City where nearly two-thirds of the participants are school dropouts. Unless both prevention and re-entry are attempted, Ms. Schmiegelow said, the young people who are not trying to complete their education "are going to get in trouble and end up in the criminal justice system."
According to the National Dropout Prevention Center at Clemson University, in Clemson, S.C., 83 percent of all prison inmates are school dropouts.
The center's director, Jay Smink, said that focusing only on reaching students who are at risk of dropping out of school can mean giving up thousands of youngsters as lost. "They not only drop out of school," Mr. Smink said. "For most cases, they drop out of society. In the very worst cases they do become jobless, they do run away from home or become homeless, or they are floating somewhere in society."
Mr. Smink said that most students in danger of dropping out can be identified in junior high or before; so most of the money -- he estimates between two-thirds and three-quarters -- is aimed at preventing the problem.
But even with the best intentions, the best programs and the best counseling, school systems have trouble finding students who have left school, let alone bringing them back into class.
David E. Engel, professor emeritus at the University of Pittsburgh, said that when he tried recently to contact 48 dropouts by mail for a study in Pittsburgh, half the letters were returned with the addressee unknown. Professor Engel said that he and staff members could reach only two of the dropouts by telephone. When they finally set up one interview, the young man never showed up and his telephone, researchers found, had been disconnected.
"At that point," Professor Engel recalled, "we said, 'What in the world do we do?' You have to be a private detective to track down these people."
Professor Engel's study, which is not complete, focuses on dropouts who returned to school, or to a General Equivalency Diploma program, through the Pittsburgh Job Corps. He said he found a strong will among the students to return.
 
'Economic Reasons' the Biggest Factor
 "I would say that economic reasons, employment, were the largest single factor by far" that explained this determination to complete their education, he said. "I don't think there were any in our group who returned for the love of learning."
Professor Engel added: "These kids are much more serious in terms of the future. I think that they have begun to learn the good old middle-class value of delayed gratification."
That is why successful recovery programs, many of which are private partnerships with public schools, frequently pair course work with practical training that can help school dropouts find jobs. Some programs, for example, require students to take classes in computer literacy or other vocational training. Many, like Options for Youth in Los Angeles, offer mentoring and independent study for students who may work or have other reasons they cannot attend a regular school.
Of the 2,000 students Options for Youth served last year, 45 percent were school dropouts; others had been expelled, were teen-age mothers without day care or had fallen far behind in course work. At the end of the year, roughly a third had dropped out of the program, but 800 returned to regular school and the balance remained in the program working on their degrees.
The techniques adopted by dropout recovery and re-entry programs are often similar to those used in prevention programs in that they focus on the individual student and try to build self-esteem and confidence. "Really what we do is ask the question, 'Why are you here, why are you on this earth?' " said Pam Hall, a co-founder of Options for Youth. "We help them develop a dream. What we have found is that these kids have not been able to dream since they were 10 years old."
 
Teen-Age Mothers Show Motivation
 Not surprisingly, the programs work best for students who find that dream or who discover a reason to better themselves. One group that does especially well are teen-age mothers, like Elsa Cervantes, now 22, who is married and living in Los Angeles and who wants to attend college. Ms. Cervantes dropped out of San Fernando High School at age 14 when she had her first baby, and returned four years later with help from Options for Youth.
"It was something I wanted for my children," she said. "I didn't want them to say, 'You dropped out of school.' "
Ms. Cervantes graduated in 1990 and made sure her family had a camera at the ceremony. "I wanted proof, pictures and everything," she said.

HEADLINE: Bridging a Gap

BYLINE: By Roberto Suro

 BODY:
IT'S MIDSUMMER, the season when untold numbers of students quietly decide to take an extended, and often permanent, leave of education. Having graduated from middle school in June, they simply do not show up for high school next month.
No educator can reliably predict which students in the spring will become the dropouts of summer, since these youngsters disappear without a whimper and with no warning. And no agency or research group has their measure, since most dropout statistics deal with the high school years. But many middle-school administrators -- especially in low-income areas -- know the reality and have the anecdotes and the data to prove it. 
 "Look at your neighbor," Joe Trevino, principal of Edison Middle School in Houston's dominantly Hispanic East End, told graduating eighth graders in May. "Unfortunately the statistics tell us that between the two of you, only one is going to graduate from high school."
 
A Temptation to Blame the Children
 In response, some school districts across the nation are instituting "bridge programs." The services vary but the object is the same: to carry students through the summer between middle school and high school by bolstering their academic weaknesses, acquainting them with a new school culture and a new style of learning, and sometimes offering them money to stick with school. But these programs are still the exceptions.
"The temptation is to blame the kids, but they are just indicators of how poorly most schools handle the transition from middle school to high school," said Joyce L. Epstein, co-director of the Center on Families, Communities, Schools and Children's Learning at the Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.
There is no way to measure how many students drop out after middle school because most school systems focus on high school dropouts, calculating the difference between the number of youngsters in ninth grade and the number who graduate four years later.
The Department of Education's National Center for Education Statistics will start tracking dropouts from seventh through 12th grades in the coming school year. But several grim estimates already have emerged from a study published by the center in April: Some 6 percent of all eighth graders, and nearly 15 percent of eighth graders categorized as being of low economic status, had left school before completing 10th grade. These calculations were based on an ongoing survey of more than 24,000 students nationwide, which began in 1988 when those students were in eighth grade.
Although school systems are organized in many types of grade spans, nearly three-quarters of all public school students make the move to high school after eighth grade, according to Ms. Epstein. This transition period is attracting scholarly attention, as educators question the structure of a system that often treats students like children through junior high or middle school, then abruptly asks them to act like young adults.
It is a time, too, when "students reach a real break point in their education," said Robert Crain, a researcher at the National Center for Research on Vocational Education, at Columbia University's Teachers College.
"Suddenly they are confronted with a choice," Mr. Crain said, "and given that opportunity, some just decide not to go on." Not going on, middle school administrators add, is particularly attractive to students from low-income and immigrant communities, who are often 16 or 17 years old instead of the standard age of 14, having started late, missed years or been held back.
Mr. Trevino agreed that summer after eighth grade is a dangerous season. "When they come here, they are still little kids, and I think it is hard for them to leave," he said. "But by the time they finish they feel grown up. Over this summer they are so disconnected that it's easy for them to forget about school."
Addressing his school's graduating class in May, Mr. Trevino tried to offer an educational fact of life that would be hard to forget: that society's chain of prerequisites moves from high school graduation to college diploma to a good job. And over and over, he came back with the same plea, "The first thing you have to do is show up when school starts in August."
But for many students at Edison, as elsewhere, jawboning isn't enough. Mr. Trevino said that some will move on from Houston to another American city or back to Mexico or Central America, which is common along the border states; many others will have to work to help support their families. As for others, "I wish I had the answer," he said. "I really wish I did."
 
Half Make an Effort to Curb Dropouts
 A survey of 2,400 principals whose schools include a seventh grade found that about half conduct some kind of program to stop this volatile mass from dropping out, said Ms. Epstein, who helped conduct the study. Most bridge programs involved inexpensive activities: middle-school students visiting high schools for an introduction to the building and curriculum, or meetings among administrators and counselors from both schools, to provide continuity in oversight.
Thirty-one percent of the schools in the study went slightly further, bringing parents into high schools so they would understand what their children face and to draw them into participating in these children's education. Thirteen percent of the schools held summer sessions for recent middle-school graduates at their new high school -- everything from Introduction to High School 101 to highly structured academic programs.
One academic program is conducted in Houston by Jefferson Davis High School and the middle schools that feed into it. For 20 days of summer, up to 150 incoming ninth graders go to the high school for help in math, reading and writing. The visits also enable students to become familiar with the campus and its curriculum. Local companies pay for their fall school supplies, amusement park tickets and a $5-a-day stipend.
For Charles Perez Jr., the inducements worked. A 14-year-old at Houston's Marshall Middle School, he was worried about his weak grades. Now he says: "I'm sure I'll finish school. I'm not worried about myself."
But inducements are not always enough. Charles has at least two friends who won't be joining him at Jefferson Davis in the fall. "One needed to get a job," he said, "and the other just didn't like school because he was 16 already and too old for his class."
 
Some Must Work to Help Families
 Lois Range, director of the program, said, "Believe it or not, some eighth graders have to work to support their families, and what we offer is just not enough." Last year, with an organized recruitment effort involving teachers, local business executives and community organizations, Jefferson Davis drew 132 students, Ms. Range said. This year, without a similar effort, only 49 students signed up.
Since 1985 the public schools in Portland, Ore., have participated in an ambitious bridge effort, the Summer Training and Education Program, developed by Public/Private Ventures, a Philadelphia-based nonprofit organization that focuses on low-income youths. For seven weeks, eighth and ninth graders identified as coming from low-income families spend four mornings a week taking classes in the high school, and afternoons working for nonprofit organizations. Public and private money finances the program and a stipend for students.
Replicated in more than 100 communities nationwide, Step serves more than 20,000 students at a cost of approximately $2,000 per student, and has yielded encouraging results, such as improved student test scores. "Kids do well while they are involved," said Kurt Shovlin, who coordinates Step in Portland. "They increase their skills in reading and math and have a lower incidence of teen parenting. The dropout rate is lower overall while the kids are involved."
But without continued support for youngsters who cross the bridge into high school, the effects of Step fade. "The fact of the matter is that short-term programs do work," said Michael Bailin, president of Public/Private Ventures. "The problem is that there is no quick fix. The environment from which kids come and their circumstances will ultimately prevail."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
In the U.S., Silenzio on the Set

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER; Andy Meisler has written about television for TV Guide and California magazine.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
If "A Fistful of Dollars" and those other Italian shoot-'em-ups were spaghetti westerns, what is "Lucky Luke"? This 10-episode comedy western series, made for Italian television, is based on a popular French-language comic book, used American writers and a mostly American cast (including guest stars like Julie Hagerty, Madeline Kahn and John Saxon), and was produced and directed by the Italian actor Terence Hill, who also stars.
But unlike those old Clint Eastwood movies, which were filmed in Italy, "Lucky Luke" was shot in English just outside Santa Fe, N.M. 
 "I couldn't find a better place to make it," says Mr. Hill, who changed his name (from Mario Girotti) to be seen as an Italian actor with an American connection. Mr. Hill has been a major star in Europe for three decades, mostly for his portrayal, in Italian movies, of prototypical American cowboys, gangsters and detectives. "The people who financed 'Lucky Luke' wanted to shoot it in Spain, but I convinced them otherwise."
Indeed, in the last few years, he and several other veterans of the spaghetti wars have gone straight to the source for their Americanized adventures. Instead of producing American-style films and programming in Europe, some Italian film makers now find it economically wiser to transplant themselves to America. In the bargain they get a chance to match their European views of American culture with authentic American settings.
While there is no single source that counts Italian productions made in this country, the number appears to have grown. According to William Immerman, a film producer and attorney who handled negotiations for "Lucky Luke" and other Italian projects, "Based on the activities of my clients, there has been a great increase in the number of movies and TV programs made here using Italian crews working side by side with Americans. I'm aware of at least 10 in the last two years."
Recent examples include "Extralarge," a detective series for Italian television that was shot entirely in Miami and stars the Italian actor Bud Spencer (formerly Carlo Pedersoli) and Philip Michael Thomas, late of "Miami Vice." "Gilda," a made-for-TV movie about a businessman who buys a Hollywood studio, was filmed partly in Los Angeles. "Un Amore Americano," a mini-series starring Brooke Shields and the Italian actor Carlo Bellepiane, was shot in Iowa and Illinois.
Italian audiences have enthusiastically embraced the hybrids. "Normally, people love these westerns and gangster movies," says Allesandra Comazzi, entertainment editor for the Italian newspaper La Stampa. "Actors like Terence Hill and Bud Spencer are loved in Italy. And the view of the United States makes the appeal greater."
An Italian television network executive based in the United States says: "American culture is very big in Italy. Sometimes I think it's even bigger over there than it is here. And you have to remember that for the last 10 or 15 years, American shows like 'Hunter' and 'MacGyver' and even the old 'Starsky and Hutch' were very popular. By shooting in America, they spin off the popularity of those shows." (He declined to be identified because his job is to interest American television companies in co-producing movies and mini-series in Italy.)
Made-for-Italy productions are usually edited there, where the English soundtracks are dubbed in Italian. "This is not a problem," insists Mr. Hill. "Dubbed American movies are part of our culture."
The phenomenon is not entirely new. Sergio Leone made movies entirely or in part in the United States, as has Lina Wertmuller. But recently, several factors have speeded up the movement west: American films are becoming more popular abroad as the film business grows increasingly international (several Italian film companies have opened American subsidiaries); in addition, business-hungry towns far from Hollywood extend warm welcomes to foreign film crews.
"Europe is very expensive now," says Antonio Avati, a 20-year veteran of the Italian movie business. "So it's possible to make films in America very cheap."
Cheap, of course, is a relative term in film making. Favorable exchange rates, nonunion American crews and cooperative local film commissions enable Italian film makers to export their own personnel and equipment and shoot for about the same amount they would spend in Europe -- with the bonus of authentic American locations. The cost, on average, is $2 million each hour episode, twice as much as Americans spend.
Mr. Avati spends six months each year in Davenport, Iowa, where his company, Duea Films, has an office. In the last three years, he and his brother Pupi, who writes and directs, have filmed four movies for both theatrical release and television in and around Davenport. Why there?
"During the 60's my brother was a clarinet player in a traditional jazz band," Mr. Avati says. "He has this very, very great love for the music of Bix Beiderbecke, and we wanted to make a film about his life." Because Beiderbecke was born in Davenport, the two men went there to scout locations and solicit financial backing.
"Believe it or not, we found that we could buy the house in which Bix Beiderbecke was born," says Mr. Avati. "We shot part of the film in it." Afterward, they left the house as a shrine and set up an office in Davenport.
The American Gothic scenery and the Iowa summer heat add a realism not easily achieved on a Los Angeles sound stage.
Although most of the Italian productions are offered to distributors in the United States, it is unlikely many Americans will ever see them. Networks here traditionally have little use for obscure foreign films or 6- to 10-episode television series (the normal European length).
Also, in most instances, the content wouldn't play here. For example, Mr. Hill's "Lucky Luke," like many of the new hybrid productions, is a slightly cockeyed look at the old Hollywood frontier myths. "It's sort of a cross between 'Cat Ballou' and 'Mr. Ed,' " Mr. Immerman says. Mr. Hill plays Lucky Luke, a sheriff who can draw his gun faster than his own shadow, an ability duly demonstrated via editing. His faithful horse, Jolly Jumper (voice courtesy of the country singer Roger Miller), acts as a narrator of sorts, making wry comments only the audience can hear. Occasionally he bursts into song.
Lucky Luke's girlfriend is played by Nancy Morgan, an American actress who is married to the actor John Ritter. "I met the original artist of the Lucky Luke comic books," Ms. Morgan recalls, "and he told me that when he was a little boy in Belgium he had gone weekly to see Tex Ritter movies." Tex Ritter was Ms. Morgan's father-in-law.
The set felt different from that of most American productions, she says. For one thing, the usual catered buffet was missing. But there were compensations. "Every afternoon at four, the wife of Amadeo, our transportation coordinator, would come over and make vast quantities of espresso."

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
American Dance Festival: A Far-Reaching Beacon

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff

 BODY:
At the American Dance Festival in Durham, N. C., last month, no one batted an eyelash when a young Maori woman from New Zealand joined her American, Norwegian and Czechoslovak counterparts in a work by Liz Lerman, a choreographer from Washington.
Once focused almost exclusively on modern dance in the United States, the festival has lately had a more pronounced international accent. This summer, Americans still dominated the student body and performance series at the festival's home on the Duke University campus: Pilobolus led off the season, and the Paul Taylor Dance Company wound it up last weekend. 
 But there was also an emphasis on choreographers from Spain and Latin America, some of whom were part of the International Choreographers Workshop that the festival established in 1984 with the United States Information Agency. To call the workshop a phenomenal success would be an understatement. In many ways, it is an extension of the festival's historic role.
When Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey and other pioneers of American modern dance gathered each summer at the festival's precursor at Bennington College in Vermont in the 1930's, it was to teach and choreograph in a community of their own. Modern dance was then a burgeoning art form and far from being accepted in the United States.
At the festival in Durham, the interchange is now on an international level. There are striking parallels between American modern dance's early struggle for recognition and the situation abroad today. Choreographers who depart from tradition in Asia, Africa, Latin America and especially Eastern Europe, where ballet has been dominant, often feel isolated and like underdogs.
An Israeli choreographer, Anat Daniely, recently thanked the festival's director and associate director, the husband and wife team of Charles and Stephanie Reinhart, for providing a place where she could be "understood."
The concept of the festival as an international haven for those who wish to choreograph and study is not limited by geography. The festival is expanding its "mini-ADF" projects, in which teachers and companies travel to other locales.
ADF/Moscow (Aug. 31 to Sept. 13), a true experiment, will expose Russians for the first time to a concentration of American modern-dance classes and performances. The model here is the distilled package of companies and wide-ranging classes sent to Japan in 1984 and 1986. This will also be the third year that ADF/Seoul is taking place in Korea (for two weeks, through Aug. 14).
The most unexpected twist in this expanded activity is the new three-week mini-festival (through Aug. 21) in Salt Lake City at the University of Utah. Among the 10 companies will be four Latin American groups, whose choreographers attended the International Choreographers Workshop.
The most striking response to all these efforts occurred last weekend, when the 11 Latin American choreographers in Durham announced the formation of a committee to share information and training among dancers in Central and South America, while remaining linked to the festival. They wrote: "Dance in Latin America is a necessity of expression that has been systematically sidelined, repressed or adulterated according to religious, economic, political or social interests." Expressing a wish to go beyond "forms implanted by Western civilization," the writers said, "we want to rediscover what is ours . . . to recover the authentically Latin American."
The tone was polemical and politicized. The Reinharts, however, view this manifesto as an expression of social activism that is now current in American modern dance as well (AIDS themes being the most obvious example).
The fight against injustice as they see it, the Latin choreographers suggest, can take many forms. One of the signers, Susana Reyes from Ecuador, danced two solos that were clearly in tribute to Indian populations of the Andes. Yet artistry raised them above propaganda. "Internal Beauty of Woman" offered a portrait of feminine strength, an image of an Andean woman in her various aspects: mother, wife and peasant. "Flight of the Curiquingue," which refers to an Andean bird, included fleeting allusions to Indian stamping rhythms. But the idiom was personal and put a creative gloss on mimetic rituals.
Jimmy Ortiz from Costa Rica offered a more direct social critique in his "Historias de Flosculos." A program note spoke of "the internal world of Costa Rica today." But Mr. Ortiz's evocation of a decadent society finally caught in a downpour of sand is a warning to any social elite.
Although too long, the piece was full of movement ideas. Miss Reyes tended to use a conventional dance flow. But Mr. Ortiz and his company, Losdenmedium, fused abstract gestures with technical bravura and rough-and-tumble partnering. Like so much Latin American fiction, the piece had a hallucinatory atmosphere, and Mr. Ortiz's refusal to structure movement logically contributed to this impression.
A footnote: The intermingling of dance cultures that the festival has furthered so innovatively is documented in the powerful photographs that Jay Anderson has taken of foreign and American choreographers since the festival moved in 1978 to Duke from Connecticut College (to which it transferred in 1948 from Bennington). A new festival booklet, "ADF Durham: The First 15," demonstrates again that Mr. Anderson's performance shots are among the best around.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
The Not Ready for Prime Time Conventions

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
Since the producers of the made-for-television extravaganza that opens in Houston this month have the luxury of going second (the only luxury they seem to enjoy at the moment), they have no excuse for not picking up tips from the laggard ratings of last month's Democratic exercise in New York. Here then, in a nonpartisan effort to help the Republicans put on a better show, are some suggestions.
The Democrats' theme of unity was a dramatic disaster. What viewer wants unity in prime time? The most inspiriting moments in Madison Square Garden were produced by supporters of Jerry Brown, the noncomforming, nonsupporting candidate who provided a semblance of news to occupy network reporters for a couple of nights. 
 So when the convention begins, two weeks from tomorrow, the Republicans will want to give some prime time to the debate on abortion. And Republican losers like Pat Buchanan and David Duke can help disperse the smog of gentleness and kindness that might otherwise send viewers to "The Simpsons." Why not invite Mr. Duke's admirers to parade in costume?
On the other hand, prudence and taste suggest that some Republican figures be kept off the podium and, if possible, out of the state. The Democrats were not careful enough in this regard. Even as they were distancing themselves from Washington insiders, they allowed Jim Wright, the former Speaker of the House, whose political career is as bankrupt as some of his acquaintances' savings-and-loan associations, to take a chair in the Texas delegation, where the cameras could catch him.
The model for Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle to imitate is the discreet Mr. Gore, who managed never to be caught within a city block of Edward I. Koch, his chief New York supporter in his unimpressive try for the 1988 Presidential nomination. The Republicans would be especially well advised to make sure that John Sununu, the limousine conservative, is kept off the premises. That could be difficult since Mr. Sununu, who used to lord it over the White House staff, has replaced Mr. Buchanan as a resident noisemaker on CNN's "Crossfire" and so can flaunt press credentials. A glimpse of him on convention nights might stir some irritating memories among taxpayers.
In this season of the outsider, the Republicans, now in the 12th year of their White House incumbency, will have to strain to present themselves as the dispossessed, particularly without the speech-writing skills of Peggy Noonan, who has said she will not serve the re-election team. The woman who turned on those thousand points of light four years ago would have had no trouble dimming a little history.
Enter Ronald Reagan. As the incarnation of the Republican heyday, he will be acclaimed in the Astrodome, where he is scheduled to appear on opening night. But the significant audience, of course, is out there, in front of the television set, and the message seems to have gotten around that something went awry during what Democrats like to call the Reagan-Bush Administration.
No problem. The Great Communicator, who could deny or forget Iran-contra and so much else without endangering his popularity, should be able to ignore unemployment, the national debt and other inconveniences in his famous tube-friendly way.
Family values promise to be the hot theme in Houston. Unlike Mr. Clinton, neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Quayle has come up with a sibling who is a recovering alcoholic. Moreover, they will have to compete with the pictures of the Clinton and Gore clans; all those blonds can really fill a stage.
Unfortunately for Mr. Quayle, his brood (three children) is slightly outnumbered by Mr. Gore's (four), and he is in no political position to deliver a testimonial to family planning. Still, the Vice President can always charge the Gore children with having elitist skills in spelling. That should go over, since so few Americans really like people who can spell.
Mr. Bush has five children to Mr. Clinton's solitary Chelsea, not to mention a dozen grandchildren. But at least one Bush son has been soiled by the savings-and-loan finaglings, raising the question of just what sort of values were passed along in this family.
The safest move here is to keep everybody behind the ample skirts of Barbara Bush, of whom no Democrat dares say an unkind word. For purposes of distraction, a sly reference to Gennifer Flowers (not, of course, by the President himself) may be passed on to a reporter, and that accommodating subject can be counted on to make herself available to any cameras that show up.
With little to celebrate in terms of domestic accomplishments, convention planners are bound to fall back on the war in the Persian Gulf. A stirring short movie can be concocted out of television clips of smart weapons and victory parades, or maybe a made-for-television drama, with Schwarzenegger playing Schwarzkopf. Better still, an air strike on Baghdad, cameras invited, could be scheduled for nomination night.
One final annoyance: the Democrats, in their convention and immediately after, as they sped from east to midwest, projected youth and energy. Mr. Bush, well known for not having noticed the recession until it was a year or so old, has not been a vision of vigor.
What to do? Easy. Show the war movie twice. America is accustomed to summer reruns.

HEADLINE: Focus: Philadelphia;
The Riverfront Plan Shifts to Low Gear

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
THIS city's plan for a single cohesive riverfront development has been ambushed by a recession, slack demand for new housing and the travails of a real estate market in decline.
Instead of high-rise apartment and office towers at the Delaware River's edge, the parcels have sprouted smaller, less expensive projects that go up quickly, like restaurants, nightclubs and open-air markets.
They provide a modest income for some owners of property that otherwise would have lain fallow, as well as jobs in what is emerging as a regional playground and shopping center. 
 Two years ago, a city agency, the Philadelphia Industrial Development Corporation, envisioned not only the complexes of high-rise office and residential towers, but also office buildings and hotels. These were to have bracketed Penn's Landing public space and to have been connected by an esplanade.
But after Willard Rouse, the Philadelphia development company, withdrew in early 1989, convinced there was no way to make the 37-acre project profitable, smaller developers took on parts of the development.
Five new nightclubs or restaurants have opened this summer. And two weekend flea markets have opened, the larger covering an acre beneath multicolored tents at Vine Street and the north side of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge, which spans the river between Philadelphia and Camden, N.J.
The other, the RiverMarket site on the river's edge near Tasker Street and Delaware Avenue, totals 18 acres, not all of which is now used. The market opened during the Fourth of July weekend and has not yet reached its peak.
AT least two planned residential developments have been shelved. One, Portside, envisioned as 286 high-rise condominium units, ran aground for lack of financing even before any physical work was done. And at Liberty Landing, a $300 million mixed-use development that last year was being re-evaluated for the combination of office, housing and hotel elements, weeds have nearly obscured the optimistic blue sign announcing the project, which also never even reached the groundbreaking stage.
The only housing actually built was not started from scratch but was a renovation at two municipal piers, 3 and 5, which jut into the river with a marina between them just south of the bridge.
The former was converted into 96 fee-simple town houses, the latter into 172 rental apartments, by a joint venture of three Philadelphia partners, Silver Harting & Company, the Edward S. Brown Group and the Radnor Corporation. The rentals range from one to three bedrooms, with rents of $700 to $3,000 a month.
Rudy Hanisch, a Radnor senior vice president, said that six town house units were presold and that they got a lukewarm reception when they went on sale shortly after completion in 1990, selling out only after prices were cut to below market value.
"This case is illustrative of the cyclical nature of real estate," he said. "We made the decision to go forward in 1987, real estate values peaked in 1988 and by the time we delivered the units in 1990 the cycle was declining."
Instead of the $300,000 market value the company predicted, the units sold for an average price of $170,000 earlier this year, part of a $1.3 billion write-off taken by Radnor's parent company, the petroleum giant Sun Company, Mr. Hanisch said. From its peak in 1988, real estate values dropped by 30 percent by 1991 in Center City.
Sales of luxury condominium units slowed at the same time, to under 200 closings downtown at more than $150,000, he said.
"We came to the conclusion that we had a disproportionate percentage of the market and had to sell them below cost," Mr. Hanisch said. "I'm personally bearish on real estate values and levels of activity in the Delaware Valley for the rest of the decade. America's appetite for the good life has slowed."
Mr. Hanisch said the grand riverfront plans predicted for 30 years by city officials were expensive and came apart just as demand for new offices and housing was softening throughout the region.
The downtown feeling of Philadelphia neighborhoods like Rittenhouse Square and Society Hall is not available on the waterfront because it is severed from the city by Interstate 95, despite bridges for pedestrians and vehicles.
A brief drive along Delaware Avenue offers many sights that suggest the state of flux on the riverfront. Tropical theme bars look out on dredge barges moored on the New Jersey side and on a state prison in Camden. Orange and tan self-storage lockers line one side of the six-lane street across from the tony Katmandu nightclub.
One pier near Spring Garden Street is used for a trash transfer station and storage yard for city garbage trucks, another is the city's main impounding lot for towed cars.
Still, the Comfort Inn, with 180 rooms at the south end of the Ben Franklin Bridge near Penn's Landing, about a 10-minute drive from Center City, had an occupancy rate in 1991 somewhere above 70 percent, when the rest of the city was in the mid 60's, said a hotel industry analyst, Peter Tyson, of Peter Tyson & Associates.
EVEN the name Delaware Avenue was changed to Columbus Boulevard by the City Council, despite public opposition, to commemorate the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage.
Yet most highway signs still direct motorists to Delaware Avenue and there is no plan to change them.
Highway access has been the lifeline for such projects as the Riverview Plaza, a $30 million retail center farther south near warehouses and plants that once served the city's thriving port and manufacturing, both of which have been withering for years.
Bart Blatstein and Marc Haber, principals of Tower Investment, bought a narrow parcel between Tasker Street and Washington Avenue on the landlocked side of Delaware Avenue knowing that an exit ramp from I-95 would be able to bring motorists to their doorstep.
The 150,000-square-foot center includes a multiscreen movie theater that opened last November and draws people from both states. There are 30,000 square feet of occupied offices space in Riverview Plaza, with a potential for 220,000 more in a vacant warehouse, according to Mr. Blatstein. There is also a Staples office products store and several restaurants, food shops and small stores. Plans have been drawn for a second retail component across Delaware Avenue in a former sugar refinery.
"There were no movie theaters at all in South Philadelphia, so people went over the Walt Whitman Bridge to South Jersey," Mr. Blatstein said. "Residential may not be an important part of the waterfront. The holding actions may be a year, it could be 10 years. If they're making money, why tear it down to build housing?"
Indeed, although planning maps still indicate that Marina Towers will rise where the Katmandu nightclub now stands, the club's owners are fashioning their own long-term expansion plans. Three partners, Stuart Harting Lance Silver and David Preefer, were involved in the Pier 3 and 5 project and said they see potential for new hotel or conference center facilities, but not residential growth.
Among the factors that have fueled growth along the riverfront are Camden's aquarium, which opened in February, and a new ferry service linking the two cities. Most vital was last year's opening of half a dozen new I-95 off-ramps up and down the riverfront and of the Vine Street Expressway, which offers quick east-west travel to the city's other major highways.
Seeing the crowds of cars bouncing over the freight railroad tracks that still rut Delaware Avenue and slow traffic, Marvin Venable started Venable's Philadelphia Water Taxi, using three 26-seat boats to ferry passengers north and south among the clubs and restaurants and the Camden ferry.
Only three restaurants now operate all year, but the success of summertime clubs that close has prompted some restaurateurs to explore year-round ventures. A Texas-based nightclub company, Dave & Buster's, is negotiating to open a recreation center in an enclosed pier owned by Bell Atlantic Properties and, several blocks inland, a 4,000-seat concert hall and an adult-entertainment nightclub are under construction.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Philadelphia's Pier 5 on the Delaware River was renovated for apartments; water taxi takes passengers to riverfront clubs and restaurants. (Photographs by Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Grand Central

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The story on May 3 headed "Grand Central Owner Seeks Broader Use of Air Rights" about the desire of the Penn Central Corporation to reallocate and replan the development of Grand Central Terminal once again highlighted the need for some driving, forceful planner of the style and substance of Robert Moses in the City and State of New York. 
 We have yet to find the counterpart of a Robert Moses who, in today's world, can articulate the long-range vision for major developments such as Lincoln Center, or the state parkway system, or the Triborough Bridge and then have the political, economic and social diplomacy to have these "grand visions" approved by city, state and Federal bureaucracies. So, for several decades now we watch the miniminds and the macro-bureaucracies play their misguided monopoly games with the major center-city development -- the Grand Central Terminal.
Why don't we take the terminal by eminent domain out of the hands of all these competing "fiefdoms" -- Penn Central, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, the Landmarks Preservation Commission, the City Planning Commission among them -- and create an independent, quasi-governmental "authority" like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey?
The Grand Central Terminal Authority, with one roof and one staff, could create a central city development that not only uses the air rights, but develops the ground rights appropriately and for the benefit of all the citizens of New York.
Since such a new authority would require state legislation, I would recommend that the Governor and the Mayor appoint a public-private task force to review and prepare the necessary guidelines for preserving and expanding the use and "quality of life" for Grand Central Terminal and its environs.
 
MAURICE S. PAPRIN
Manhattan
 
The writer is president of the Coalition of Business, Labor and Community Organizations of New York.

HEADLINE: New Haven Seeks League of Its Own

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
GEORGE BUSH played there. So did Ted Williams, who in a pre-season game against the New York Yankees hit a titanic home run that old timers in the New Haven area still talk about. Much later, former New York Mets pitching star Ron Darling performed there before going on to the big leagues.
Since it opened in 1927, Yale Field, the home of Yale's baseball team, has been one of the most beautiful ball parks in the country. Yet, once the Bulldogs' season ends in late April or early May, it sits unused throughout most of the spring and all of the summer. 
 But if Edward Massey, a Ridgefield businessman and Yale alumnus, has his way, Yale Field will become home to a team in the Double-A Eastern League in 1994.
With the university's support, a group headed by Mr. Massey, which includes several other Yale graduates, recently applied to the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, the governing body for minor league baseball, for a Double-A expansion franchise. New Haven is one of 13 contenders for one of the two AA franchises that will be created because of the addition to the National League of two new teams starting next season, the Colorado Rockies and the Florida Marlins. Other applicants include Portland, Me., Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island and Atlantic City.
 
The Best by Babe's Standards
 But as Mr. Massey points out, his group has something special going for it -- a charming, old-fashioned ball park with a covered concrete grandstand adorned on the outside, appropriately enough, with ivy and with a playing surface that Babe Ruth once described as the best he had ever seen. Ruth made his comment after presenting a copy of his autobiography to Mr. Bush, then the Yale captain, before a game at Yale Field in June of 1948, two months before the Babe died of cancer.
"When you have Yale Field to start with, you're in pretty good position," said Charles Eshbach, the president of the Eastern League, who lives in Plainville and would like to see a team in New Haven. "But it would have to be modernized," he said.
Mr. Massey, who graduated from Yale in 1964, said that if his group was awarded a franchise he would spend about $2.5 million to install lights, build clubhouses under the grandstand and install new seats to increase the capacity to about 8,000 from the present 5,300. This is in addition to the $3.5 million cost of the Eastern League franchise. "All of the money will come from the private sector," said Mr. Massey, the president of U.S. Home Care which is based in Hartsdale, N.Y. with three offices in Connecticut. "In making the necessary improvements, we're going to make sure that Yale Field retains its old-fashioned charm," he said. "It's a beautiful ball park and we don't want to change the flavor of it."
If Mr. Massey's group obtains a franchise, it would give the Eastern League two Connecticut teams. Currently, the Boston Red Sox Double-A team is based in New Britain, where it moved in 1983 after 10 years in Bristol. For a while in the 1970's and 80's, the Eastern League had three teams in Connecticut -- in Bristol, West Haven and Waterbury. But the West Haven franchise -- affiliated for eight years with the New York Yankees and for three years with the Oakland A's -- folded after the 1982 season, while the Waterbury franchise ended in 1986.
 
An Economic Boost for New Haven
 In recent years, minor league baseball has enjoyed a revival with attendance increasing in virtually every minor league. As a result, more and more cities have been bidding for minor league clubs and, in the process, the cost of franchises has soared. In the eight-team Eastern League, for example, attendance records were broken in each of the last three seasons.
Ticket and concession prices at minor league games are far cheaper than at major league ball parks. Prices for Eastern League games average $4, Mr. Eshbach said, which is about $6 less than tickets for big-league games. "And we don't charge for parking," Mr. Eshbach said.
A minor league franchise could also be economically beneficial to the New Haven area. Mr. Eshbach said it was estimated that every dollar spent at a minor league game -- for tickets, refreshments, souvenirs and other items -- generates $7 in revenue for the community.
Because of its proximity to New Britain, the New Haven franchise would require a waiver of territorial rights by the New Britain club's owner, Joseph Buzas. However, Mr. Eshbach said that Mr. Buzas had already agreed to waive his territorial rights since he felt that a team at Yale Field would produce an in-state rival for his club.
 
A Turnaround for Yale
 In the past, Yale had not been receptive to having a minor league team play at Yale Field, which is situated directly across from Latham Field House and Yale Bowl on Derby Avenue, which is also Route 34. In 1981, for example, David Goldstein, the owner of the West Haven A's of the Eastern League had tried to move his team from Quigley Stadium to Yale Field, which is also situated in West Haven, near the New Haven City line. But Frank Ryan, who was then Yale's athletic director, opposed the plan, and two years later the West Haven franchise folded.
But in recent years Yale officials have changed their stance about having a commercial enterprise use the the hallowed turf at Yale Field, largely because of the economic climate that has forced Yale to eliminate some sports teams.
"I would like to see it happen," said Harold E. Woodsum Jr., the Yale director of athletics. "It would be great for Yale and for the community. As it is, it sits unused all summer, and that's a shame. In this day and age, we should use such a beautiful facility as much as we can. I've touched all the bases at Yale, and there's a lot of support from all of the senior officials I've talked with. And I don't think we'd have any trouble working out a lease with Ed Massey and his people."
Mr. Woodsum, a one-time star receiver for the Yale football team, said he did not foresee any conflict in playing time between the proposed minor league team and the Yale varsity. The Eastern League season begins the second week in April, but both Mr. Massey and Mr. Eshbach said that the minor league team's home schedule could be arranged so as not to conflict with the Eli games at Yale Field during that month.
Though New Haven is only 75 miles from New York City, neither Mr. Massey nor Mr. Eshbach said they thought that the proximity of two major league teams would affect their attendance. "Because of the high prices and the distance, I don't think most baseball fans in the New Haven area go in to New York for a big league game very often," Mr. Eshbach said. "And we're talking about a situation in New Haven which would be much more affordable to the average fan."
 
Fan Potential
 In addition to an excellent ball park, easily accessible from the Wilbur Cross Parkways and Interstates 91 and 95, Mr. Massey also cited the large population base. "There are approximately 850,000 people in the New Haven area alone, and the market is very strong demographically," he said. "And I think we also would draw well from Fairfield County and other nearby areas."
Mr. Massey's interest in trying to get a franchise for Yale Field came about by happenstance. "Chris Getman, a classmate of mine who is a broker in New Haven, called me and asked if I would help in an effort to renovate Yale Field," he said. "Once we heard that two Double-A expansion franchises were going to be available, we began pursuing the idea of a minor league team."
"We want to bring a wide range of people into the team ownership, including a lot from New Haven and Yale," Mr. Massey said. So far, in addition to Mr. Massey and Mr. Getman, others involved in the venture include Carter LaPrade, a New Haven attorney and member of the Yale class of 1965.
Though Yale Field is in West Haven, the team would carry a New Haven name, Mr. Massey said. That proposal was endorsed by Mr. Eshbach who pointed out that many sports franchises carry the names of cities other than the communities in which they play. "Look at the New York Giants and the New York Jets, who both play in New Jersey," he said said.
 
Seats of Honor
 The Eastern League president said that applications for the two Double-A franchises were reviewed on July 12 by the Double-A expansion committee of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues. After visiting the proposed sites, the committee will make its decision, perhaps as early as next month, but more likely at the baseball winter meetings in December. Mr. Massey said that letters from New Haven Mayor John C. Daniels and West Haven Mayor H. Richard Borer supporting a minor league franchise at Yale Field had been sent to the expansion committee.
Though the relatively narrow wooden seats at Yale Field are scheduled to be replaced if Mr. Massey's group is granted a franchise, one seat would remain untouched. That, Mr. Massey said, is the special double-seat that was built for President William H. Taft, who taught at Yale, his alma mater, after leaving office and before being named an Associate Justice of the United State Supreme Court. Mr. Taft weighed more than 300 pounds.
"If we get the franchise, we'd like to put a plaque on the Taft seat," Mr. Massey said. "After all, besides being a Yale alumnus, Mr. Taft was President of the United States." And, apparently, a Yale baseball fan to boot.

HEADLINE: For Retirees, No Place Like Home

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
WHEN Samuel and Germania Boyd of Pine Brook, N.J., made their retirement plans in the mid-80's, they briefly considered moving to one of the many South Florida adult communities to which, for decades, legions of retirees have migrated.
Instead of moving to the Sunbelt, though, the Boyds decided to stay put; they bought a new home only 70 miles away, in the Greenbriar Woodlands adult community in Toms River, N.J.
"I am a native of New Jersey, and I have come to like the seasons in New Jersey," said Mr. Boyd, who is 69 years old. He and his wife moved to Greenbriar Woodlands after he retired from an executive position at Westinghouse in Newark five years ago. 
 "Besides," added Mrs. Boyd, who is also 69 and also worked at Westinghouse, "we didn't like drifting away from our family and roots."
Despite the significant number of retirees who move long distances to settle in planned adult communities in places like Boca Raton, Fla., and Sun City, Ariz., more of them do as the Boyds have done. They choose locations for retirement that are close to where they lived and worked.
Indeed, in a survey conducted by the American Association of Retired Persons in 1990, 84 percent of those over 55 surveyed agreed that: "What I would really like to do is stay in my home and never move."
"There is a trend to move closer to children and grandchildren, more than in previous generations," said William E. Becker, a consultant in Teaneck, N.J., who specializes in marketing and developing adult communities. "Wanting to move away to a Sunbelt state was more prevalent until the early 1980's."
That assessment is consistent with 1980 census data showing that 75 percent of Americans do not leave home after retirement; 21 percent move within their home state and only 4 percent move out of state. And of those 4 percent who do move out of state, most retire at vacation destinations within their own regions. About a quarter of the out-of-state moves are to planned adult communities in Sunbelt states.
"I wouldn't expect it to change much in the data from the 1990 census," said Dr. Charles F. Longino Jr., a sociologist at Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C., who has studied retiree migration patterns.
This relative lack of migration by the elderly has helped make places such as southern New Jersey and Cape Cod, Mass., havens for recent retirees in the Northeast. Ocean County, N.J., alone has 76,429 retirees living in 48,373 units in 60 adult communities. Many of the county's adult communities -- including Greenbriar Woodlands, a four-year-old village of about 750 one-, two- and three-family homes that cost $159,950 to $207,000 -- are clustered around Lakewood, Point Pleasant and Toms River.
"The most important retirement area in the United States besides Florida and Arizona and southern California is southern New Jersey and, in particular, Ocean County," said Michael L. Tenzer, the chief executive officer and chairman of the board of Leisure Technology of Los Angeles, which operates six adult communities in New Jersey and on Long Island.
ADDING to the increasing number of retirees in the Northeast is the new phenomenon of older retirees -- those 75 and older -- moving from retirement communities in Florida to assisted-living facilities or nursing homes in the Northeast near where they once lived or where their relatives now live.
"A lot of them are coming back from Florida because they have family up here, and it makes life easier for them, having children and grandchildren around," said Edith Weatherby, a representative of Water Ridge, a three-year-old, 94-unit assisted-living facility in Stamford, Conn. "And a lot of them just don't like the warm weather all year round."
Despite the number of retirees staying in or returning to the Northeast, the development of adult retirement communities is not booming these days. "An exception is in the Midwest and some places on the West Coast," Mr. Becker said. "The East Coast is, relatively speaking, dead."
The current housing slump is also making it difficult for many would-be retirees to sell their homes, or is forcing them to sell for less than they anticipated 5 or 10 years ago.
To be sure, many soon-to-be retirees bought their primary housing years ago, and they may be more willing to settle for less than those who bought at higher prices more recently. Even so, Mr. Becker noted, the capital from the sale of these homes often finances the entire purchase of a retirement home in an active adult community.
In some cases, though -- such as those who lived in rent-regulated New York City apartments -- they may dig deep into savings or sell a weekend or vacation home to buy into a retirement community.
"Seventy percent of the people who move here pay cash, and usually it comes from them selling their homes," said Doug Delano, a vice president and general manager at Heritage Hills of Westchester, an 1,850-home adult community in Somers, N.Y., where new one- to three-bedroom units range in price from $160,000 to $380,000 -- roughly what they were five years ago. Resales run from $135,000 to $400,000.
Generally, said Mr. Becker, only 70 percent of the cash from the sale of a home goes toward buying a residence in an adult community, with the balance going into savings instruments that generate income. With this income, plus pension and Social Security payments, the average retiree has an annual cash flow of $25,000 to $35,000, not including part-time jobs, which about 30 to 40 percent of retirees take, either for the extra money or the mental stimulation.
THE price of an average adult-community home in the Northeast these days, according to Mr. Becker, probably ranges from about $100,000 to $175,000 for a 1,200-square-foot, detached, two-bedroom house with a garage. Larger homes, of course, would cost more, and an attached town house may cost as little as $80,000. Annual association fees generally range from about 0.75 to 1 percent of the purchase price.
"They are this inexpensive because they are not built in high-density areas," he said. "You think these communities are for the rich because of the way the developers promote them."
Economics aside, the adult community industry is also facing a demographic decline over the next five to seven years, as the number of Americans who are expected to reach retirement age dips slightly.
These retirees are, for the most part, people now 55 to 65, born during the Great Depression and World War II, when the birth rates were low.
Industry analysts point optimistically to the 32 million members of the post-World War II baby boom, who are now 30 to 46, and the oldest of them are expected to start retiring in less than 10 years. But making such long-term predictions is highly speculative.
Perhaps the biggest variable is predicting what the average retirement age will be in 10 years. Though that age has been declining for the last decade, many believe it may soon start to rise for baby boomers because of increased longevity, declining real incomes, a shortage of younger workers and a variety of other social and economic factors.
Further, no one knows what the laws will be in the next decade concerning issues such as mandatory retirement ages, or whether adult communities will be able to legally deny membership to those under a certain age.
Currently, a community can restrict its residents to families in which at least one person is 55 years old if 80 percent of its occupants are 55 or older; if the community provides facilities or services specifically designed for older people, and if it publishes and adheres to policies that show a clear intent to provide housing for people over 55.
"There is a long-term trend toward earlier retirement, but eventually we see that trend bottoming out," said Dr. Longino, of Wake Forest University.
Then there are questions about whether the baby boomers will seek out the same type of retirement villages as their predecessors.
"This isn't very easy to predict," said Eric S. Belsky, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders in Washington. "But there is a large wave approaching retirement, and you are going to see an increased demand for retirement communities."
In the meantime, adult community developers, such as the Marriott Corporation, based in Washington, are emphasizing new full-service, or continuing-care, retirement communities that offer a range of care and services and cater to those who are younger and seek independent-living life styles as well as those older retirees who need assisted-living facilities or full-time nursing care.
Marriott, which already manages a traditional adult community, Leisure Park in Lakwewood, N.J., and newer full-service retirement communities in Edison, N.J., and Mountainside, N.J., is considering building others in Paramus, N.J., and Wayne, N.J., as well as in other sites in Connecticut and Pennsylvania.
"MOVING is a traumatic event for most retirees, so now they need only make one move on one campus, unless they need a hospital situation," said Darryl R. Callahan, executive director for the National Association of Senior Living Industries in Annapolis, Md.
Developers are also targeting that comparatively small number of retirees that are now in their 50's and early 60's. Many of these individuals, like the members of the World War II generation before them, have the prospect of substantial benefits from private pension plans as well as Social Security. Often they are retiringat a younger age than they had expected or hoped, because of layoffs and early retirements connected to the recession. But their incomes may have risen substantially in the 80's.
"It makes for a unique group of retirees," Dr. Longino, the sociologist, said.
These younger retirees, with spouses sometimes in their early 50's and even 40's, are seeking communities that belie the traditional image of retirement. For example, those who move into planned communities want tennis courts and golf courses instead of shuffleboard and bingo.
"We had people who said, 'Why are you moving to an old-age community -- you're not old?' " said Christine Goodman, who moved to Greenbriar Woodlands five years ago, when she was 52; at the time, her husband, James, was 55, the age minimum for the community. "I said, 'If I don't like it I'll just leave.' "
Though they are less mobile than in their youth, people in their 50's and 60's do move and for a variety of reasons: if their children have just left home; if they become infirm; if they divorce; if a spouse dies; if the head of the household retires.
Often, an adult community becomes an attractive place to move because younger retirees sometimes start to feel culturally and socially isolated living in neighborhoods filled with younger people.
Surprisingly, perhaps, frigid Northeast winters are not a deterrent to these retirees; many of them are "snowbirds," who visit other relatives in Florida or have condominiums or second homes there.
"Most of us are in Florida for at least a month," said Mr. Goodman, who moved to Greenbriar Woodlands after selling his home in Brielle, N.J., about 10 miles away. "And remember, we don't have to shovel the snow here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James R. Goodman, left, and wife, Christine, right, with Samuel and Germania Boyd at Greenbriar Woodlands in Toms River, N.J. (Najlah Feanny for The New York Times)
