HEADLINE: Governors Develop Plan to Help Preschool Children

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 1

 BODY:
The National Governors' Association opened its annual meeting today by issuing a bipartisan blueprint for the states to improve children's readiness for school, the nationwide educational goal that had divided Republicans and Democrats.
The report, developed by a panel of governors and 2 corporate executives over the last year, said the states should meet three objectives: more and better preschool programs for all poor and disabled children; improved health and nutrition programs for preschool children, and improved social services to help parents better prepare their children for school. It did not say how much these programs would cost. 
 In 1990 the governors and the Bush Administration adopted six national goals for the year 2000, saying schools would need to meet them all if the nation was to remain competitive. There was wide agreement that improving readiness was the most important, because so many children start school with health and family problems that hinder their ability to learn and that plague them throughout their schooling. But the governors were divided on how to measure readiness and on what steps to take to attain it.
 
Intense Political Interest
 Today the panel seemingly resolved that dispute with its bipartisan report, which also listed 14 benchmarks the states could use to measure their progress. "Too many children are not prepared to start school," said Gov. George V. Voinovich, a Republican from Ohio and chairman of the committee that produced the readiness report. But he said the recommendations and benchmarks offered in the report were "based on the premise that education and school readiness are the best investments we can make."
The four-day governors' meeting will also address health, fiscal and economic-development issues, but the emphasis will be on education, which has attracted special interest in this election year. The Democratic Presidential candidate, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, was one of the first governors to support legislation to overhaul schools, and he has emphasized that in his campaign. President Bush has proclaimed himself the "education President," and his Administration, with the governors' association, conceived the six national goals.
The five other goals are: to make American students the best in the world in science and math; to improve high school graduation rates by 90 percent; to have students leaving the fourth, eighth and 12th grades demonstrate competency in a basic academic curriculum; and to insure that every adult will be literate and every school will be free of violence and drugs.
 
Most Disagreements Resolved
 In their discussions on the readiness goal, Democrats generally favored programs that would enlist parents in teaching their preschool children basic skills that would help prepare them for school. Republicans said that such programs would infringe on the privacy and values of families.
There was also discord over money, with Democrats calling for more Federal spending on the Head Start program for disadvantaged youngsters.
Although some differences still exist, particularly on how much money should be spent on the readiness goal, Republican and Democratic governors said they resolved their significant differences through a series of meetings.
"The debate was very tough and partisan," said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat who takes over this week as chairman of the governors' association. "But we've moved closer to one another."
Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, a Republican on the panel, agreed. "Governors, both Republicans and Democrats, are trying to get the job done," he said.
 
Efforts Already Under Way
 There were no Bush Administration officials at the conference today, a spokesman for the governors' conference said, but Education Secretary Lamar Alexander is expected to attend the meeting on Monday morning.
The panel's 24-page report, "Every Child Ready for School," listed a variety of programs that states can use to meet each of the three objectives, and it praised states that are making efforts to meet them.
New Mexico, for example, was singled out for increasing state subsidies to programs for needy and disabled preschoolers. Missouri is expanding a statewide program to enroll welfare recipients in a program that helps parents teach their children basics like numbers and the alphabet. And to improve the health of young children, California has expanded services for maternity, childbirth and infant-care services for low-income women who are uninsured.
As for measuring gains, the report urges states to keep statistics on the percentage of children under age 5 who are enrolled in Head Start and other publicly supported preschool programs, and on the percentage who have been inoculated for an array of childhood diseases.
But Mr. Romer acknowledged that more specific benchmarks would be difficult to draw, because there is still some disagreement over what constitutes good measurements of readiness for school.
 
Likely to Cost Billions
 Several governors said the absence of cost estimates was intentional. Virtually all states face budget problems and each state was left to follow the recommendations as their budgets allowed, governors said. But several governors acknowledged that attaining the readiness goal would cost the states billions of dollars over all.
Education policy experts say the states have done a credible job so far, but that their efforts are still far short of what is needed to achieve the national readiness goal by 2000. In a 1991 survey by the Carnegie Foundation for Advancement of Teaching, more than half of 7,000 kindergarten teachers said their students came to school with health, nutritional and family problems that hindered their ability to learn. The same sampling of teachers said the situation had worsened in the last five years.
"The agenda is clear, and the goal is right, but we still haven't shown the energy and organization and frankly the deep commitment that the task requires," said Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation, who has been the most forceful advocate for the readiness goal. Copies of the report are available for $16.95 from the National Governors' Association Publications, P.O. Box 421, Annapolis Junction, Md. 20701.
Besides Governor Voinovich, the panel's chairman, and Governors Ashcroft and Romer, these are the members of the National Governors' Association Action Team on School Readiness:
Gov. Bruce King, Democrat of New Mexico.
Gov. Pete Wilson, Republican of California.
Gov. Michael N. Castle, Republican of Delaware.
Gov. Jim Edgar, Republican of Illinois.
Gov. William Donald Schaefer, Democrat of Maryland.
Gov. George A. Sinner, Democrat of North Dakota.
Gov. Booth Gardner, Democrat of Washington.
John E. Pepper, president of Procter & Gamble.
James J. Renier, Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Honeywell Inc.

HEADLINE: Bank Charges Embarrass the Saudis

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO with JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Early last month, as top officials of the Federal Reserve were about to publicly accuse Saudi Arabia's biggest bank and its manager of violating United States banking laws in connection with a multibillion-dollar fraud, the kingdom's top regulators and their lawyers rushed to contact Fed officials, hoping to settle the matter quietly.
If the Federal Reserve publicly announced its charges, the Saudi Government, the United States' most important ally in the Persian Gulf, would be linked to the growing scandals involving the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, and King Fahd would be personally embarrassed. 
 What is more, the Saudis said, if regulators shut down the American operations of National Commercial Bank, the kingdom's biggest and most prestigious bank, the Saudi banking system would be jolted even as the economy still reeled from the financial burdens of the Persian Gulf war.
 
 
Entreaties Aren't Heeded
 After six days of intense, secret negotiations, the Saudis gave up, going away red-faced and empty-handed. The Fed made the charges public.
The Saudi bank is charged with failing to report purchases of stock in First American Bankshares, the largest bank holding company in Washington, which was illegally and secretly controlled by B.C.C.I. The purchases, made in concert with the bank's former chief executive, Sheik Khalid bin Mahfouz, were made from an affiliate of B.C.C.I. and involved loans from National Commercial Bank to people acting on behalf of B.C.C.I.
American regulators last month ordered National Commercial to close its New York branch. At the same time, the Saudi bank sold off its huge silver holdings in an effort to raise cash quickly, causing silver prices to drop sharply in markets around the world.
In recent months, the B.C.C.I. scandal has grown from a criminal investigation of a huge fraud by rogue financiers -- perhaps the largest financial fraud ever -- to envelop some of America's staunchest allies in the Persian Gulf. And the diplomatic ramifications have left the State Department and some other American officials queasy.
In addition to examining the roles in the scandal of some of Saudi Arabia's most prominent businessmen, many of whom have links to the royal family, investigators are now looking at the actions of members of the ruling family of the United Arab Emirates. Family members were the principal owners of B.C.C.I. when it was shut down last year. While the family members have portrayed themselves as the biggest victims of the fraud, some investigators have publicly questioned whether they helped to carry it out.
 American officials say they are certain that the royal family is deeply shaken, fearful that a scandal could erode confidence in the kingdom's once-unassailable banking system.
"It is obviously a major banking crisis and a serious problem," said one senior Administration official who closely follows the issue, who spoke on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue. "They are concerned about what implications it will have for the Saudi banking system as a whole. We have told them their concerns have been noted and the best thing to do is to clean up the whole B.C.C.I. mess."
At one point, King Fahd took the highly unusual step of calling in the United States Ambassador, Charles W. Freeman Jr., to express his surprise and dismay that a local prosecutor in New York City had indicted Sheik Khalid, a descendant of the esteemed family that co-founded National Commercial Bank. Until recently, Sheik Khalid was its chief executive.
The King sought to distance himself from Sheik Khalid, saying that it was unfortunate that a Saudi might have run afoul of American banking regulations, but stressing that the banker's actions had nothing to do with the Saudi Government and banking system, said senior Administration officials who were briefed on the meeting.
 
 
Ties to Royal Family
 But Sheik Khalid is not just another banker, and National Commercial is not just another bank. Sheik Khalid is viewed as the personal banker to King Fahd; the bank, which is rooted in a decades-old money-changing operation in Mecca, is inextricably linked to the Saudi Arabian economy and its Government.
At one point, King Fahd made an extraordinary request to Mr. Freeman: would United States banking authorities make an official statement attesting to the strength and independence of the Saudi banking system? Mr. Freeman, uncomfortably, had to say no, telling the King that the United States Government could not interfere in a criminal investigation or publicly pass judgment on the strength of another country's banking system.
"The Ambassador said that the individual bank has to be judged on its merits," one senior Administration official said. "You can't give a Good Housekeeping seal of approval to it."
 American officials say they have done nothing to interfere with the investigations of other prominent Saudi businessmen and had nothing to do with negotiations that led to a sudden and dramatic plea agreement on Monday by Sheik Kamal Adham, a former chief of Saudi foreign intelligence.
Dean St. Denis, a spokesman for the Justice Department, said the agency had no discussions with the Central Intelligence Agency or the State Department about its investigations of Saudi businessmen connected to B.C.C.I. Peter Earnest, a spokesman for the C.I.A., would say only that the agency has a policy "of not commenting on the affiliation of any individual or lack thereof with the C.I.A." Through a spokesman, Edwin D. Williamson, the State Department's legal adviser, declined to comment.
The C.I.A. has acknowledged that it used B.C.C.I., but has insisted that its involvement with the shadowy bank was confined to legitimate banking activities. Agency officials have declined to discuss details of the involvement, asserting that public disclosure could jeopardize intelligence operations. The C.I.A. first received information in the 1980's about B.C.C.I.'s illegal control of First American.
 
 
Baker Said to Avoid Issue
 And senior Administration officials and people close to the Saudi Government say both sides are eager to play down the impact of the banking scandal on American-Saudi relations. They note that the issue was not raised when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met privately with King Fahd or when he dined with Prince Saud al-Faisal during a visit to Saudi Arabia in July.
And, these officials say, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador to Washington, has not made an issue of the matter in meetings with the State Department and White House.
 Other officials and people close to the Saudi Government say the issue is so embarrassing to King Fahd that it would be out of character for him to raise it in a one-on-one meeting with the Secretary of State. Family connections may have inhibited the two princes from speaking out. One defendant in the case, Sheik Kamal, is the uncle of Prince Saud and of Prince Bandar's wife.
As a measure of the close relationship between the King and the people involved in the case, the lawyers for Sheik Kamal warned American prosecutors that their client would have to get the King's permission before cooperating with an investigation, one law enforcement official said. The prosecutors were unmoved, and the sheik pleaded guilty to fraud charges and agreed to pay $105 million in fines.
B.C.C.I., which was chartered in Luxembourg and the Cayman Islands and had branches in 70 countries, was closed in July 1991 by banking regulators of various nations, who accused it of worldwide fraud. Liquidators have been unable to find much of the bank's assets, which were reported to be $20 billion shortly before the shutdown.
 
 
U.S. Lawyers Indicted
 On Wednesday, the bank's principal American lawyers, former Defense Secretary Clark M. Clifford and his partner, Robert A. Altman, were indicted on charges of helping B.C.C.I. gain control of First American, and of accepting bribes from B.C.C.I. Both men pleaded not guilty.
Law enforcement officials say the next phase of the B.C.C.I. investigation will focus on other Saudis, including Sheik Abdul Raouf Khalil, an obscure businessman who worked in Saudi intelligence under Sheik Kamal and went on to become a senior member of Saudi intelligence, according to past and present Western intelligence officials.
The Fed has accused both sheiks of helping B.C.C.I. secretly purchase First American. State charges were filed in New York because First American owned a bank there.

GRAPHIC: Photos: King Faud; Sheik Abdul Raouf Khalil; Sheik Khalid bin Mahfouz; Sheik Kamal Adham.
 
Chart: Saudis Affected by the B.C.C.I. Scandal
 
Sheik Kamal Adham
 
This former director of Saudi Arabian intelligence, who pleaded guilty last week to a violation of New York banking laws, was accused of acting as a front man on behalf of B.C.C.I. in its secret purchase of First American Bank in Washington. He has agreed to cooperate with American law-enforcement officials who believe that, among other things, he may be able to provide information on B.C.C.I. connections to intelligence communities around the world.
 
Sheik Khalid bin Mahfouz
 
A former top officer of the National Commercial Bank, the largest bank in Saudi Arabia, and the personal banker of Saudi's King Fahd, is charged with defrauding B.C.C.I. customers of $300 million from 1985 to 1991. He was a director of the bank and is also accused of conspiring with bank executives to mislead auditors and regulators about the extend of his own holdings in the bank and about the bank's financial condition.
 
Sheik Abdul Raouf Khalil
 
This wealthly real estate and electronics investor is described by American officials as a senior officer in Saudi intelligence. He has not been charged with a crime, but the Federal Reserve has moved to bar him from U.S. banking, charging that he, too, acted as a front man on behalf of B.C.C.I. in its secret takeover of First American Bankshares.
 
King Faud
 
During the B.C.C.I investigations, King Fahd summoned American Ambassador Charles Freeman, expressed deep concern and ask that the United States state publicly that the scandal had nothing to do with the stability and honesty of Saudi banking. The American response was essentially that was impossible because its judicial system operates independently. The case is said to have put a strain on relations between the United States and its close Mideast ally.

HEADLINE: High Court Says Haitians Can Be Sent Home

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today permitted the Bush Administration to continue to send Haitians picked up at sea back to their homeland while the Court decides whether to review the legality of President Bush's order to return them.
The Court granted a request by the Justice Department to stay a ruling on Wednesday by a Federal appeals court in New York that had effectively nullified the Administration policy. The stay will remain in effect while the Justice Department and lawyers for the Haitians prepare their arguments on the merits of the case. 
 Justices Harry Blackmun and John Paul Stevens dissented from the decision to lift the stay, arguing that the Justice Department offered only a vague statement of possible harm to foreign policy if the return policy was halted.
 
A Threat of Persecution
 But the justices said the refugees "face the real and immediate threat of persecution, terror and possibly even death at the hands of those to whom they are being forcibly returned."
Lawyers say they expect the Supreme Court will agree to accept the case because two Federal circuit courts have issued conflicting opinions in the last year on whether Federal immigration law required the Administration to extend protection to refugees picked up in international waters, outside United States territory.
In February, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta ruled that the right to apply for asylum applied only to aliens who had arrived in the United States. On Wednesday the Federal appeals court in New York, overturning a ruling in June by a Federal judge in Brooklyn, decided 2 to 1 that that such protection extends beyond American territory.
President Bush issued a directive in May ordering that Haitians fleeing in boats for the United States be halted by the Coast Guard and escorted back to their shores without being interviewed by immigration officials on their reason for fleeing. Since then the exodus from Haiti has largely stopped.
Some 37,000 Haitians had been picked up by the Coast Guard since a military coup overthrew Haiti's President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on Sept. 30, 1991, and thousands were being housed at an American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
But at the end of June, the Administration began to empty the Cuban camp, sending those who qualified for asylum to the United States and those who did not back to Haiti.
Critics of the repatriation policy call it a violation of internationally recognized human rights. The Administration has maintained, however, that the fleeing Haitians are escaping economic conditions, not political repression.
 
Judges Evenly Divided
 Eight Federal judges have ruled on whether the immigration legislation at issue extends beyond American territory and they have been evenly divided, four concluding the statute does apply in international waters and four deciding it does not.
In its action today the Supreme Court gave the Justice Department until Aug. 24 to defend its policy and two more weeks for lawyers representing the Haitians to submit their response. The department has maintained that reversing the policy would lead to a mass exodus of refugees.
But lawyers for the Haitians said today that they intended to ask for an expedited hearing before the Court, given the imminent threat to their clients.
"We're going to ask the Supreme Court to hear the case on an expedited basis because of the daily harm to our clients who are being forced to return to Haiti," said Lucas Guttentag, the director of the immigration rights project in New York for the American Civil Liberties Union.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Anti-Quayle Rumbling Hasn't Ended

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Although Vice President Dan Quayle insists that the issue is closed, the question of whether he should stay on the 1992 Republican ticket remains a major topic at the top levels of the party.
With President Bush having also said repeatedly last week that there would be no change, few senior Republicans are willing to discuss the matter publicly. But promise them anonymity, and a substantial minority of state officials, leaders on Capitol Hill and even Cabinet members readily express their antagonism and especially their wish that Mr. Quayle would take himself out of the running. 
 "The President isn't going to demand he get off the ticket," a leading Midwestern Senator said. "But a lot of us wish he would fall on his sword, go in and tell George Bush he was quitting for the sake of the party."
Such attitudes are fueled by the conviction that something must be done soon to persuade the electorate to give Mr. Bush "a second look," much as Democrats thought Bill Clinton had to do at the Democratic convention. Some dramatic gesture is needed, an anti-Quayle Cabinet member argued, "to take the public's eye off the economy and the tax increase and focus instead on what a second Bush term might deliver."
As Mr. Quayle's defenders assert, that could be accomplished just as well, and perhaps better, by developing programs and a theme for the President's re-election bid, but no new programs are on the drawing board. So the search for a scapegoat continues.
"The real trouble is that they have no strategic plan and no substantive program," said Edward J. Rollins, the former White House political director under Ronald Reagan whose heretical behavior in working for the campaign of Ross Perot has not severed his ties to many top Republicans. "I don't think they're going to get a second look, because Quayle isn't the problem. Bush is the problem, and he's not going to change."
 
'No Strategic Master Plan'
 In California this week, the President seemed somewhat more combative, but his campaigning still lacked focus, and one of his senior advisers conceded, "There is still no strategic master plan in sight for the fall."
The conservative columnist George Will, who has never liked Mr. Bush much, went so far this week as to suggest that the President should say "the heck with it, I've got fish to catch and grandchildren to catch them with." If he does not, Mr. Will wrote in a column that stunned Republican politicians, "he almost certainly will lose, perhaps in a landslide that does considerable damage to his party."
Similar calls came from other strong backers of former President Ronald Reagan who have faulted the Bush Administration for its lack of an ideological rudder. Among them were Burton Yale Pines, a conservative policy analyst, who said on CBS's "This Morning" program that Mr. Bush should "do the honorable thing and abdicate," and Richard A. Viguerie, a conservative fund-raiser, who urged Mr. Bush to step aside in favor of Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d joining him as his running mate.
But the main focus remains on Mr. Quayle. Calls for his removal are fed, especially on Capitol Hill, by fears that a Bush-Quayle ticket will drag Republican senators and others down to defeat. Many of those who want Mr. Bush to keep Mr. Quayle want him to dump either the budget director, Richard G. Darman, or Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady or both. Some of the panic-stricken lawmakers are beginning to talk about the Republican debacle of 1964.
Polls show that as much as 60 percent of the electorate says that Mr. Quayle should go, which gives the continued muttering plausibility.
In that context, an advertisement placed in The Washington Post by L. E. Thomas, an auto dealer in northwest Florida who has been a leading Republican organizer and fund-raiser since the Nixon era, attracted much more attention than it would normally have done. Mr. Thomas, a former state party chairman, urged Mr. Quayle to pull out for the good of the ticket.
Like many others who make such appeals, Mr. Thomas disapproved of the choice of Mr. Quayle for Vice President in the first place. David Beckwith, the Vice President's spokesman, also called attention to Mr. Thomas's support of Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, a Democrat, asserting that Mr. Thomas is no longer "a Republican in good standing."
But Mr. Thomas is not alone in keeping the subject alive and thereby continuing to undermine the Vice President's already tenuous credibility.
 
More Public Advice
 An editorial in the current issue of National Review, William F. Buckley Jr.'s conservative journal, describes Mr. Quayle as "a class act" who would "have made a good President." But it says that his "lightweight public reputation is beyond repair" and constitutes "a liability at a time when a strong ticket is indispensable" to the Republican campaign.
Mr. Bush, the article asserts, should have accepted Mr. Quayle's earlier offer to resign, and it argues that a conservative like Mr. Kemp or Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on the ticket could turn things around even now.
One of the few anti-Quayle senators still discussing the subject publicly is Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, who told a group of broadcasters this week that "these things are always open." He strongly suggested that the Vice President would be removed from the ticket before the Republican convention, which begins Aug. 17 in Houston.
But friends of Secretary of State Baker, who is widely expected to move into the White House this month as a kind of supermanager of the Bush campaign, describe him as "unwilling to push for Quayle's downfall" because it would unleash a firestorm of conservative antagonism, even if another conservative joined the ticket.
Mr. Baker has never had strong links to the Republican right wing, and he cannot afford to strain relationships further if he has any hope of running for President himself in 1996, as many Republicans believe he does.
The conviction remains strong in the party that Mr. Baker will, in fact, take over the management of the Bush operation, despite reports during the last week that the President had told his Cabinet that no decision had been made. If, after so much publicity, Mr. Baker does not come to the aid of his old friend, it would be another blow to Mr. Bush's lagging campaign.

HEADLINE: STATE LEGISLATORS ARE LEAVING OFFICE IN RECORD NUMBERS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
A third of the state legislators in the nation are giving up their seats this year in an exodus that experts say is the largest in more than 30 years.
The turnover, which experts say is sure to be swollen further by the defeat of some incumbents in November, parallels a high number of departures by members of Congress. 
 Federal and state legislators have said they are leaving for many of the same reasons, including a desire to retire or because their districts were redrawn or eliminated as a result of redistricting after the 1990 census. But others blame the recession of the 90's, saying it has made their jobs painful and turned constituents against them.
 
'Uglier and Meaner'
 "Politics has gotten uglier and meaner," said Sam Hunt, 50 years old, a two-term member of the North Carolina House. Mr. Hunt said he decided to give up his seat to devote more time to his family and his electrical supply business in Burlington.
This year's extraordinary turnover was the topic of a major speech and many hallway conversations in Cincinnati, where a thousand legislators gathered last week for the annual convention of the National Conference of State Legislatures.
"I've begun to feel like the singer of 'Bye, Bye, Miss American Pie,' " Paul B. Burke, president of the national conference, told 4,500 assembled legislators, spouses and staff members on Tuesday. Mr. Burke, who is President of the Kansas Senate, quoted some lyrics from the 1971 song, "American Pie,"-- " 'Bad news on every doorstep; I couldn't take one more step' " -- before recounting some likely results.
 
Majorities of Freshmen
 He said that about 40 percent of the legislators in Connecticut and Georgia could be new next year, that a third of Maine's senators who are up for re-election are not running and that a majority of members in the New Hampshire House and the Kansas Senate could be freshmen next year. He said that most committees in the Kansas Senate would have new members as chairmen because the heads of nine major committees had chosen not to seek re-election.
"This is the largest turnover I think we've seen since the mid-1960's," said William T. Pound, executive director of the national conference, an educational and research organization based in Washington.
The conference, which compiles statistics on legislative members, has tracked turnover only since 1979, but Mr. Pound and other experts estimated that the rate has been fairly consistent at 20 percent since 1964 and 1966, after the United States Supreme Court ruled that state legislatures had to be equally represented according to population. The court-ordered changes in districts that resulted caused sharp increases in the turnover rate comparable to this year's.
Mr. Pound said the conference's surveys of its members indicated that 2,500 of the nation's 7,500 state legislators were expected to retire, return to work full time at their businesses or professions, seek other offices or be defeated in races against another incumbent in primaries. The 2,500 seats does not include any estimate for the number of incumbents who might be defeated in the 6,079 legislative races in November.
 
Party Control May Change
 About 20 percent of the legislators are not facing re-election this year because five states have no election and, in most states with races, only half of the senate seats are on the ballots.
Political analysts say the elections could change partisan control of one or, in a few cases, both chambers in a dozen states where one party holds a narrow majority.
The turnover in the state legislatures parallels that in Congress, where freshman legislators may occupy a third of all House seats, according to a projection by Norman J. Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute, who noted that nearly 100 members had already said they were not returning.
Public policy experts say they are not concerned by the large turnover, which was common earlier in this century but add that legislators' declining job satisfaction poses a serious threat to democracy.
"Legislators are getting bashed brutally, and I don't think they deserve it," said Allan Rosenthal, director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. "The danger is that many good people will not run for office, or if they do, they won't stay long."
In two dozen interviews with legislators, including a geography professor from Connecticut, farmers from Kansas and a real-estate broker from Ohio, all mentioned many pressures and stresses, among them time and money.
Legislators complained about missing family events and having to let their businesses flounder because they had to work long hours as lawmakers. Even in states with short legislative sessions, lawmakers said they were busy year-round performing committee work, helping constituents, attending community meetings, raising money and campaigning.
 
Many Cite Low Pay
 Yet, experts say, the pay of most legislators ranks among the lowest for all state workers. Though most legislators' jobs are part time in theory, they say the work has evolved to be full time. New Hampshire legislators are paid $100 a year plus mileage expenses, for example. About 10 states pay legislators under $15,000 a year and about 10 pay them more than $30,000, Mr. Rosenthal said, with the others falling in between. The average is about $25,000.
Many legislators said they faced a financial problem because they could not live on their state salaries. Yet, they said, lawmakers' responsibilities left little time to tend to private business, and when they did make money on the side, it made people suspicious.
"It's impossible to avoid the appearance of a conflict," said Harry Meshel, a Democratic State Senator from Youngstown, Ohio. "If you do some business with a utility, do you separate yourself from utility issues in the Senate?"
Mr. Meshel, who receives a state salary of $44,000 plus expenses, said that he planned to continue in his position but that the ethical questions, as well as time constraints, had forced him to give up most of his real-estate business.
Irving J. Stolberg, 55, a geography professor and a Democrat who has represented New Haven in the Connecticut House for 22 years, including two terms as Speaker, blames news coverage, especially television, for much of the public's cynicism toward politicians. "The drudgery and challenges that occupy 98 percent of a legislator's day are not considered news, but scandal is instantly news," said the veteran legislator, who has announced that he will retire.
Mr. Stolberg, who was a driving force behind the enactment of Connecticut's income tax last year, said he was not seeking re-election largely because his work on the income tax completed his agenda as a legislator. But he said many of the other 53 members of Connecticut's 187-member General Assembly were not seeking re-election because they were "really tired" after two extremely contentious years.
"Most of us had death threats when we passed the income tax in 1991," he said.
New Jersey had a relatively large turnover of about 25 percent in its election last year, with the Democrats losing control of both houses to the Republicans after Gov. Jim Florio and the Legislature had raised taxes by $2.8 billion in 1990. In New York this year, turnover is expected to be about average, with 24, or 11 percent, of the Legislature's 211 members declining to seek re-election.
 
'It Isn't Fun Anymore'
 Mr. Hunt, the North Carolina House member, may have echoed the sentiments of others who have decided to retire: "It isn't fun anymore. It isn't rewarding anymore, and the time it takes is just unbelievable."
Some legislators at the conference said they shared some of the electorate's views about government.
"The people are very angry and frustrated with the system, and so am I," said Carol G. Hanson, a Republican State Representative from Boca Raton, Fla., and who has represented Palm Beach County for 10 years. "A day doesn't go by that you don't read about a legislator taking himself a nice job out of the budget, or about the horrors of the new computer system at the state welfare agency."
Her frustration, Ms. Hanson said, prompted her to join colleagues in vain attempts to abolish entire bureaucracies, including the departments of education and transportation. Ms. Hanson is continuing as a legislator, but she said that the frustration of such failures was one reason that about 50 of the 120 members of Florida House were not seeking re-election this year.
But acknowledging that voters had reason to be angry, she said they shared the blame. "If we could get the public as involved and as informed about politics as they are about Monday Night Football, we wouldn't have as many problems," Ms. Hanson said. "People have to get off their duffs and participate."

HEADLINE: Thanks for Coming! Now, Please Leave!

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
In his carefully orchestrated trip to Staten Island last week, Mayor David N. Dinkins was facing a problem that also bedeviled his predecessors: to address somehow the deep-seated and abiding sense in every borough, including parts of Manhattan, that the central government in lower Manhattan holds them in low esteem and serves them less well than it does other areas.
Staten Island, where the Mayor is also spending this weekend, is the fourth stop in his intermittent yearlong effort to spend a week outside of City Hall in each of New York's far-flung boroughs. He has already visited the boroughs of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. He plans to spend a week soon in northern Manhattan. 
 But the difficulties he faces were particularly apparent on Staten Island, the most physically and psychologically remote of the five boroughs, a place so fundamentally alienated from the rest of New York that most of the island's political leaders favor secession from the city.
Residents of Staten Island have long felt that they are the city's stepchildren, underserved and unappreciated. The Mayor's efforts last week did not appear to alter that perception significantly. Though his advisers said they were pleased with the generally positive coverage of the visit in the local daily newspaper, The Staten Island Advance, random interviews on Friday with local residents showed broad dissatisfaction with city government.
 
'It's Just Politics'
 "His visit more or less is just a show to appease some of these people," said John Bonica, a 41-year-old electrician who has lived his entire life on Staten Island. "I think people are so disgusted with the way things have been going that there is almost nothing he can do to change their minds."
Cynthia Brockdorff, a 32-year-old homemaker, dismissed the Mayor's visit. "It's just politics," she said, "and everybody who lives in Staten Island knows it. It's a little too little, a little too late."
Staten Island's electorate tends to be much more conservative and Republican than the rest of the city. There is a widespread perception that Staten Island is a place where New York puts its most unpopular things, in particular the Fresh Kills landfill. Staten Islanders also resent proposals to build homeless shelters and prisons in their borough, although they tend to ignore the fact that similar city projects are spread throughout the other four boroughs.
In personal terms, as well, Mr. Dinkins was forging into hostile territory. He did worse in Staten Island than in any other borough in the 1989 mayoral campaign, winning the support of only 16 percent of the borough's voters. The Mayor acknowledged all this when he arrived Monday morning, and he stated clearly that his goals for the week were modest.
 
Wants to Show He Cares
 "If nothing else, I hope that I can convey to the people of Staten Island that I deeply care about them," he said at a welcoming reception on a plaza in front of Borough Hall in St. George, the island's downtown, which with its hills and fading buildings feels more like a small but charming town in western Pennsylvania than part of one of the world's foremost urban centers.
"I don't care whether you agree with me on all issues or not," he said. "If you are reasonable people, you have to say to yourselves, 'Well, by God, he does care.' "
Mr. Dinkins's predecessor, Edward I. Koch, tried to convey that he cared about potentially alienated neighborhoods by holding what he called "town meetings." These were essentially 90-minute free-for-alls in which Mr. Koch, about once a month, would take questions from residents in schools around the city, alternately informing, cajoling, debating and berating his fellow New Yorkers.
Mr. Dinkins's strategy is as different from Mr. Koch's as their personal styles. Mr. Dinkins, a mathematician by undergraduate training, prefers carefully planned events to the spontaneous uproar that Mr. Koch usually inspired.
 
Many Meetings, Mixed Results
 So all week Mr. Dinkins shuttled from his makeshift office on the third floor of Borough Hall to ceremonial events around the island. He argued the economic case against secession at a Rotary Club luncheon. He went to dinner with the Chamber of Commerce. He met privately with an array of local groups, from a Democratic club to the Staten Island Council of Jewish Organizations.
Mr. Dinkins occasionally passed out small mayoral goodies, like a new policy of free transfers between local and express buses, and he announced some upbeat news, like a decline in overall crime. He toured the Teleport, a communications center on the western edge of Staten Island that is a major employer, the new Homeport naval base and Fresh Kills, the notorious dump.
Wherever he went, the Mayor was greeted politely, and occasionally enthusiastically. He also met sometimes with ordinary Staten Islanders, with mixed results. He spent time one afternoon strolling with a police officer on his beat down New Dorp Lane, a suburban-like shopping street in the predominantly white, middle-class section of New Dorp.
Mr. Dinkins, New York's first black Mayor, was greeted warmly by shopkeepers and strollers, and he chatted amiably with children checking out books in the local branch library and homemakers pushing toddlers in strollers.
 
Challenge and Support
 One woman did challenge the Mayor, contending that his handling of the disturbances in Washington Heights last month was biased toward the victim of a police shooting, Jose Garcia, and against the police. Mr. Dinkins angrily disagreed. So did another woman, who was listening to the conversation on the sidewalk. She told several reporters, "My son is a detective and he thinks the Mayor is terrific," and she volunteered her name, Rosalyn Sonsky, before the reporters could ask.
Mr. Dinkins's reception was distinctly cool, though, when he appeared a half-hour earlier at the 122d precinct on Hylan Boulevard, a few blocks away. The Mayor walked behind the front desk, and the first officer he encountered, a young black woman, greeted him with a bright smile. But the two white officers in charge behind the desk barely acknowledged Mr. Dinkins's presence. One shook his hand without smiling or making eye contact. The other officer did not look at the Mayor and appeared so cold that Mr. Dinkins did not extend his hand.
Many of the Staten Islanders interviewed at random on Friday appeared hostile both toward the Mayor and virtually all other politicians. "I don't think his heart is in it," Mr. Bonica, the electrician, said of Mr. Dinkins's visit. "I don't think he wants to be here."
Another resident, Benito Alvarez, a 54-year-old high school Spanish teacher, said he was unaware of the Mayor's visit. And Gabriella Sutton, a 31-year-old clerk in the city's Probation Department, dismissed the Mayor's presence in the borough.
"Politics," Ms. Sutton said. "It's all lies. They promise you anything until they get elected."

HEADLINE: Issue in Campaign Is Biaggi's Record, but Which One?

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Mario Biaggi wants to base his Congressional comeback bid on his record, a reputation for championing the working people through unflagging constituent service and legislation over 10 terms in Congress.
Eliot Engel, the incumbent Congressman, also wants to base his campaign on Mr. Biaggi's record -- on the convictions in two trials for bribe-taking, extortion and other charges that landed Mr. Biaggi in a Federal prison for two years and two months. 
 The candidates are vying for the Democratic nomination for the 17th Congressional District, which cuts a swath through the northern Bronx and jogs into parts of southern Westchester County.
Mr. Engel, touching on what is certain to be a recurrent issue, insisted last week that not only did Mr. Biaggi betray the public by the acts that led to his conviction on charges stemming from the Wedtech bribery scandal, but he got his eight-year prison term cut short with a cynical, self-centered maneuver. Mr. Biaggi, who is 74 years old, was released last year for treatment of life-threatening heart and neurological problems.
"He's too sick to serve in prison, but well enough to run for Congress," said Mr. Engel. "It goes to the heart of the man's integrity."
 
Bigger Issues, Says Biaggi
 Mr. Biaggi countered that he was not sent home to die but to recover and that he saw his candidacy as a challenge to a "do-nothing" incumbent and a chance to reclaim an image he said was sullied by an unfair conviction. Steadfastly maintaining his innocence, he called the September primary "an expression of the people's court," where his name and his public service would carry the day.
"We're talking about a nation in dire economic straits, and individuals are worried about getting a job and surviving," said Mr. Biaggi. "Those are the issues. How often can you say Mario Biaggi was convicted? What does that do to alleviate the personal, national and local pain?"
Mr. Engel said that he has focused on constituent service, with a majority of his staff spread out among three district offices as compared with the two Mr. Biaggi had. "The past four years I worked very hard in the district and in Washington," Mr. Engel said. "I consider myself a spokesman for the forgotten middle class," he said.
He said that he has been involved in issues involving health care and the elderly and was an active member of the House foreign affairs subcommittee on trade issues. In a year of heated abortion debate, Mr. Engel said he is "pro-choice all the way." Mr. Biaggi has not made his position public and declined to discuss even his personal views on abortion.
Mr. Biaggi will be running in a district that was redrawn this year and is now nearly two-thirds black and Hispanic, having lost some white ethnic strongholds from the eastern Bronx.
 
District Is Varied
 The Bronx portions of the new district include the towers of Co-Op City, with its savvy senior citizen vote; the Irish working-class enclaves of Woodlawn and Norwood; part of Riverdale; Hispanic communities in the northwest Bronx; black homeowners in Williamsbridge and Wakefield, and heavily Italian Belmont.
In Westchester, the district takes in southwest Yonkers and its working-class black residents, south Mount Vernon with its core of middle-class black homeowners and part of south New Rochelle. Mr. Engel said the increased minority population and the removal of some of the white ethnic areas favored his candidacy, because, he said, he thinks he has more appeal to that constituency than Mr. Biaggi.
While the neighborhoods vary, voters have many of the same concerns -- affordable health care and housing, more jobs, lower taxes and above all, safer streets. And for many, Mr. Biaggi himself is an issue.
Mr. Biaggi is fondly remembered by some voters along the busy streets of the Belmont section.
"People like him a lot," said Luigi Izzo, the owner of the Caffe Napoli on East 187th Street. "They know he's Italian, you know what I mean? A lot remember him helping the community a lot."
Across the street, Patricia Walls sat outside her building with her miniature Doberman pinscher, Babe, resting on her lap. Ms. Walls said she has lived in Belmont for 13 years, and said she was worried that in parts of the neighborhood people feared walking down streets that once were safe.
"Eliot Engel has done nothing for -- how do you say it -- his constituents," she said. "Biaggi was around. If there were drugs in a building, he got it torn down. Whatever we needed, Biaggi was right there."
Tom Newsome said he would break from his past preference for Mr. Biaggi. "Biaggi was already convicted and he got out of jail on a lark," said Mr. Newsome. "If his health wasn't so bad, why did he get out?"
 
Retire, Some Advise
 A similar cynicism prevailed in Woodlawn, where Mr. Biaggi was respected for his stance on Northern Ireland. "He's over the hill," said Bill Brown as he sat outside a self-service laundry. "Where the hell is he going? He should be preparing for eternity."
Mr. Brown, who is elderly himself but declined to give his age, was resolute in his opposition. "He should give some other fellow a break," he said.
Elsie White, a home health aide from south Mount Vernon, said she thought Mr. Biaggi should take advantage of his freedom and retire quietly.
Ask Anne Rocco her greatest concern for her Co-Op City neighborhood and her eyes grow wide with a one-word response.
"Crime," she said. "We need more security."
At 67, William Flippen said he was more preoccupied with the young than with the old. He said drugs have eaten away at his south Yonkers neighborhood, leaving in its wake a trail of violence. A few nights ago, he said, a youth was wounded in a drive-by shooting.
A few blocks away, Jose Montes, 20, stood in the dimly lighted hallway of his apartment building. "The politicians should pay attention to housing projects," he said. "There are so many apartment buildings they should fix them up for the homeless."
Although he said he was a registered voter, he could not recall his party and said he never voted.
"All the politicians worry about is their pockets," he said. "Put money in my pocket and I'll show you a happy citizen. I'll vote all day long, then."

HEADLINE: The 1992 Campaign: Candidates' Record;
Social Programs Grow, but Largely by Neglect

SERIES: The Bush Record/Ninth article of a series.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has been kinder and gentler toward the poor and the disabled, just as George Bush promised four years ago.
Still, the President rarely boasts of his record in this area, partly because he knows he could never satisfy his liberal critics, partly because he does not want to offend conservatives who still revere former President Ronald Reagan. 
 And there may be another reason for his reticence. President Bush's social policy is kinder and gentler than Mr. Reagan's largely because Mr. Bush has given relatively little attention to these issues. And that is a sharp departure from the Reagan Administration, which worked with zeal to reduce or eliminate scores of health, education and welfare programs.
 
Pleasing No One
 The Bush Administration is "less ideologically driven," said Gail R. Wilensky, the deputy assistant to the President for policy development.
In the end, conservatives complain that Mr. Bush's passivity has a darker side because, left alone, the programs have grown, and the eventual costs to the Government will be higher than they might otherwise have been. At the same time, liberals assert that the Administration's neglect has allowed millions of Americans to fall into poverty.
Mr. Bush's record on social policy has become a central issue in this year's campaign. Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, repeatedly asserts that Mr. Bush has neglected social problems, has ignored growing inequality in the distribution of income and has done nothing to heal racial divisions.
Administration officials say Mr. Clinton's accusations overlook Mr. Bush's efforts in 1990 to secure passage of a law that prohibits discrimination against people with physical or mental disabilities.
For better or for worse, domestic social programs have grown much more rapidly under Mr. Bush than under Mr. Reagan. In a few cases, as with Head Start, the Federal program for preschool children, Mr. Bush has proposed big increases in spending. In other cases, social programs have grown simply because the sluggish economy has left millions more Americans in need of Government aid.
Since January 1989, the number of people receiving food stamps has increased 37 percent, to 25.8 million, the most ever. The number enrolled in the largest welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, has risen 25 percent, to 13.6 million -- also the largest number ever.
Mr. Bush is not directly responsible for those increases. In a recession, the programs grow automatically. Still, the President has not proposed cutbacks, as Mr. Reagan did.
Federal spending on food stamps has increased an average of 15 percent a year in the Bush Administration. In Mr. Reagan's first term, which also included a recession, it grew only 1 percent a year.
At the same time, the Bush Administration's benign approach has led to reversals of Reagan Administration policies in some programs. For example, the Government is no longer purging tens of thousands of disabled people from the Social Security rolls. In other cases, as conservatives point out, Mr. Bush has simply not put up much of a fight against Congressional efforts to expand social welfare programs, like Medicaid, that were tightly constrained in the Reagan years.
 
Objectives Not Defined
 If Mr. Bush seems hesitant in dealing with the nation's social problems, it may be because, by his own account, he feels more comfortable dealing with foreign affairs. As a result, he has displayed less interest in social-welfare programs than did Mr. Reagan, who single-mindedly pursued a clear objective: to cut such programs or slow their growth.
For these and other reasons, social programs have been growing at rates not seen since the Carter years. Data from the Federal Office of Management and Budget show these trends:
*Spending on elementary and secondary education rose 11 percent a year under President Jimmy Carter, 3 percent a year under President Reagan, and 11 percent a year under President Bush.
*For Medicaid spending, the annual rates of increase were 14 percent under Mr. Carter, 9.5 percent under Mr. Reagan and 25 percent under Mr. Bush.
*For the Head Start program, the increases averaged 15 percent a year under Mr. Carter, 5 percent under Mr. Reagan and 22 percent under Mr. Bush.
Martin Anderson, a senior adviser to President Reagan, said with regret that there had had been "explosive growth in domestic spending" under Mr. Bush. But Stephen Moore, director of fiscal policy studies at the Cato Institute, a Libertarian research center here, said Mr. Bush received little political credit for the "domestic budget buildup."
"To people on the right, Bush has been a traitor because of his willingness to dump money into social programs," Mr. Moore said. "Constituencies on the left are not satisfied because they want to spend even more."
Experts estimate that 15 percent to 20 percent of the increase in domestic spending was a result of the automatic recession-related growth in benefit programs like food stamps, welfare and unemployment insurance. An additional portion of the increase would have occurred anyway because of the aging of the population, inflation in health care and other similar factors. The remainder, perhaps 40 percent, results from program changes proposed by President Bush or initiated by Congress and accepted by Mr. Bush.
 
Record Debt and Deficit
 Military spending has declined in each of the last two years. But the Federal budget deficit and the Federal debt, which reflects the accumulated total of all Federal borrowing, are at record levels, in large part because of record spending in the Reagan-Bush years.
The debt represents a relentless burden on the nation; there is no way to reduce it unless the Government runs a surplus. And interest on the debt now eats up nearly 15 percent of all Federal spending. Those facts place clear constraints on any President's ability to promote new domestic spending initiatives.
To be sure, in his budget request to Congress in January, Mr. Bush proposed ending 222 domestic programs. But the estimated saving, $1 billion in 1993, would be relatively small in the context of a $1.5 trillion budget.
At the same time, Mr. Bush boasts of making "substantial increases" in Federal spending for Head Start, the immunization of children, prenatal care and child nutrition programs. But liberals in Congress and at advocacy groups like the Children's Defense Fund say he has not gone far enough to meet the nation's needs, in Head Start or other programs.
Even when Administration officials are deeply involved in negotiating a compromise with Congress on a major domestic issue, like Federal aid to cities or Federal subsidies for child care, Mr. Bush and his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, rarely try to take credit. Aides to Mr. Bush find his reticence frustrating and puzzling.
Dr. Wilensky, the deputy assistant to the President, observed that "the White House did not aggressively take credit for achieving an urban-aid package" in June, even though it closely followed White House specifications. The $1.1 billion measure provides loans and grants to Los Angeles and Chicago and includes summer job money for scores of cities.
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research and advocacy group, said the President "missed an opportunity to make striking improvements in urban policy after the riots in Los Angeles." Mr. Bush voiced compassion when he visited Los Angeles after the riots this spring, saying: "We are embarrassed by interracial violence and prejudice. We are ashamed." But then he opposed Congressional efforts to provide more than the $1.1 billion agreed to in the compromise.
Mr. Greenstein asked: "Has George Bush pursued kinder, gentler policies than President Reagan? The answer is yes. But that doesn't say much. You are damning with faint praise. Reagan's policies exacerbated serious social problems. Bush has made some modest improvements, but his course is mainly one of drift."
 
Policy and Personnel
Politics Divorced From Social Issues
 In every Administration, domestic social policy is set at the top. Lyndon B. Johnson and Ronald Reagan spoke with such deep conviction that their appointees and Congress knew what they wanted. Mr. Bush's message has often been uncertain or contradictory. But in some important areas, his policies have clearly been more moderate than those of Mr. Reagan.
Mr. Bush's Social Security Commissioner, Gwendolyn S. King, continually talks of the need for fairness and compassion in ruling on claims for Social Security. Her tone is totally different from that of John A. Svahn, the Reagan Administration's first Social Security Commissioner, who led a campaign to curb the cost of Social Security retirement and disability benefits.
And John R. Dunne, the Assistant Attorney General for civil rights in the Bush Administration, has sided with minority groups in civil rights litigation much more often than his predecessor, William Bradford Reynolds, who frequently sided with whites accused of discrimination.
Likewise, as Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for the last three years, Catherine A. Bertini went out of her way to help people who depend on food stamps, the school-lunch program and the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC.
"Catherine Bertini's door was always open to us," said Edward M. Cooney, deputy director of the Food Research and Action Center, an advocacy group for low-income families. "She supported modest increases in the WIC program, and she was always sympathetic to our concerns."
 
'Not Always in Sync'
 But, he said, "the Administration has opposed legislative initiatives to deal with childhood hunger" in a larger, systematic way. "It refused to provide the additional $3.5 billion that is necessary to address the problem over the next five years," he added.
One reason for this discrepancy is that the Bush Administration has had trouble blending politics with social policy. In this election year, for example, the Administration's experts on social programs have generally been excluded from discussions of political strategy. And the President's political strategists rarely attend the detailed discussions of social programs.
"Politics and policy are not always in sync," said a White House aide who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The things come out of the end of two different tubes."
Bush appointees have not cooperated to concoct an ambitious, coherent social policy. When John H. Sununu served as White House chief of staff, he and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, rebuffed social-policy initiatives proposed by other Administration officials, on the ground that they would be too costly.
Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has voiced far more concern for the plight of poor people than his predecessor, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. But until the riots in Los Angeles, Mr. Kemp was often a voice in the wilderness, crying for the White House to pay more attention to the problems of poor people in the nation's cities.
 
Civil Rights
Uneven Record Pleases No One
 On civil rights, as on environmental issues, Mr. Bush's record is filled with contradictions that suggest that he has conflicting impulses.
In 1990, Mr. Bush worked closely with Congress to secure approval of a landmark law that prohibits discrimination against people with physical or mental disabilities. And the civil rights division of the Justice Department, under Mr. Dunne, has vigorously enforced the Voting Rights Act, blocking many state and local redistricting plans on the ground that they discriminate against people who are black or Hispanic.
The Bush Administration also successfully challenged gerrymandering that excluded Hispanic people from the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors, one of the most powerful local governing bodies in the country.
The Justice Department's support for voting rights may prove to be good politics for the Administration. Republicans have often found themselves in an alliance of convenience with black and Hispanic groups, trying to pack minority populations into urban electoral districts. Republicans assumed they would then have a greater chance of victory in nearby suburban districts because whites would account for a larger proportion of the voters in those districts.
 
A Fractured Record
 Civil rights advocates say there has also been more vigorous enforcement of housing laws in the last three years. "There has been a significant improvement in enforcement of the Federal Fair Housing Act," said John P. Relman of the Washington Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law. "The Justice Department is bringing more cases than ever before. It's more aggressive in seeking large judgments against people who discriminate in the rental or sale of housing."
But Mr. Bush will probably not be remembered for those cases so much as for his veto of the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which sought to protect workers against job discrimination by effectively overruling six Supreme Court decisions. Mr. Bush complained that the bill would force employers to adopt quotas for hiring and promoting members of minority groups.
After a bitter fight with civil rights groups and Democratic members of Congress, Mr. Bush signed a revised version of the bill in November 1991, amid indications that Congress might have had the votes to override a veto. But even as he signed it, he was embroiled in a new furor. The White House counsel, C. Boyden Gray, tried to interpret the law so as to end affirmative action programs that the Federal Government had conducted for decades. At the last minute, Mr. Bush cast aside a statement drafted for him by Mr. Gray and declared his support for affirmative action.
The signing ceremony, normally a time for reconciliation, further strained relations between Mr. Bush and civil rights groups. So now, when asked for an appraisal, Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, says, "President Bush's overall record on issues of race and sex discrimination has been terrible."
 
Health Care
A Stalled Plan And No Money
 The search for a national health-care policy illustrates Mr. Bush's difficulty in grappling with a complex social problem. He recognized the problem, and he ordered a study. But he has had trouble putting together a policy. In his speeches, he emphasized the risks of doing too much rather than the need to do anything at all.
More than 35 million Americans have no health insurance, the largest number in at least 15 years. At the same time, health-care costs are rising twice as fast as the Consumer Price Index. In his State of the Union Message in January 1990, Mr. Bush announced that his Domestic Policy Council would study the issue and recommend steps to bring "the staggering costs of health care under control."
Mr. Bush expressed no sense of urgency until a liberal Democrat, Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania, won election to the Senate in November 1991. Mr. Wofford's demand for national health insurance was a centerpiece of his campaign. His victory quickened Congressional interest in the issue and put a spotlight on the Bush Administration's lack of action.
 
No Sense of Urgency
 Three days after that election, Mr. Bush, in Rome for a NATO meeting, said he wanted to present a comprehensive health plan to the American people before the 1992 Presidential election. But, faced with protests from Congressional Republicans, he eliminated an important feature of his plan: a new tax on health insurance benefits that affluent people get from their employers.
Mr. Bush's proposal, unveiled in February, calls for a variety of tax credits and deductions to help people buy private health insurance. He said his plan would guarantee access to insurance for all poor families. But he did not say how he would pay for it. Nor did he say how he would control the soaring costs of health care.
He was much clearer about what he opposed. He said Congress must not adopt a national health insurance program like the one in Canada, and he insisted that the Federal Government must not compel employers to buy insurance for workers.
President Bush's budget in January said there was an urgent "need for comprehensive health reform." But his proposal is languishing on Capitol Hill.
"The President has not made a sustained effort to sell his program to Congress," said John C. Rother, legislative director of the American Association of Retired Persons. "There has been little activity by the President or the Administration beyond sporadic attempts to bash health-care proposals by Congressional Democrats."
 
 
 
ARTICLES IN THE SERIES
 The series began June 25 with an interview with President Bush and an article assessing his record as leader. Other articles evaluated the President's record on issues including foreign affairs, the economy, education, the environment, judicial appointments and American policy toward Iraq. The most recent article, on his anti-drug efforts, appeared July 28.

HEADLINE: Suit Asserts Right of Homeless to Sleep in Park

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RENO, Aug. 1

 BODY:
A lawsuit has been filed in Federal District Court here asserting that city ordinances against loitering and sleeping in public places discriminate against the homeless.
The suit was filed Tuesday by Washoe Legal Services on behalf of Leopoldo Benavidez Jr., who is described as a homeless man arrested for sleeping in a city park. It charges that the police enforce the laws only against people who look as if they are homeless. 
 The suit seeks certification as a class action on behalf of other homeless people. It is similar to a suit filed on behalf of three homeless people in Miami in 1988; that case has not yet been resolved.
"The issue is one of fundamental fairness," said a lawyer with the Washoe County legal group, Terri Keyser-Cooper. "Everyone has to sleep. We are in effect banishing these people."
According to the lawsuit, many homeless people are mentally or physically disabled and are either unemployed or working at jobs that pay meager wages.
"They are sick, hungry and vulnerable to the elements," the lawsuit said. "Plaintiffs are arrested and jailed for performing the necessary bodily function of sleeping. If they have no place to sleep and they must sleep somewhere, they cannot be arrested for such conduct if no other alternative exists."
A deputy city attorney, Stephen Volek, said the Police Department had never "taken the position that it's appropriate to go in and bother people who appear to be homeless."
 
Disputing a Theory
 But he disputed Ms. Keyser-Cooper's reading of law. "Her theory," he said, "is that there is some legal or constitutional obligation to provide shelter to the homeless and that unless the city finds a way to make them available, it is obligated to make the parks available as a place to sleep. That just isn't the law."
Mr. Benavidez, the 41-year-old plaintiff, was arrested July 2 and charged with violating an ordinance against sleeping in a city park. He was booked into the Washoe County Detention Center and was released on July 10 after pleading guilty.
The lawsuit said that Mr. Benavidez had 4 cents in his pocket when arrested and that he pleaded guilty because he had been told by jailers and other inmates that he would not be assigned a public defender and might serve more jail time if he contested the charge.
Violation of the ordinance is a misdemeanor carrying maximum punishment of a six-month jail term and a $1,000 fine.

HEADLINE: One Suspect's Experience: Property Forfeiture Is Worth $174,000

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOMERVILLE, N.J.

 BODY:
Although the price of real estate in central New Jersey took a beating in the nationwide recession, little compares with the plunge in price on two vacant lots after the Somerset County Prosecutor's office confiscated them in a drug case two years ago.
The land, in the rolling hills of neighboring Hunterdon County, was bought for $174,000 in 1988 by James Giuffre, a Somerset builder and insurance agent. 
 After Mr. Giuffre was arrested two years later in his home with with a half-ounce of cocaine, he agreed to a deal the Prosecutor's detectives proposed in which he would forfeit the lots instead of his house.
Within 26 hours of Mr. Giuffre's arrest, deeds conveying the property to Somerset County were filed at Hunterdon County Courthouse in Flemington. Months later, the same lots were sold to a lone bidder at a public sale for a total of $20,000, and later wound up in the hands of acquaintances of the chief of detectives for the County Prosecutor. The sale of the lots and a lawsuit Mr. Giuffre has filed to get them back or be compensated for their loss have raised questions about the way the Prosecutor's office administers assets taken in drug cases.
The Prosecutor, Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., reasoned that the difference in the $174,000 price Mr. Giuffre paid for the two lots in 1988 and the $20,000 sale price two years later was that Mr. Giuffre had made a bad investment: he had paid too much at the top of the real-estate boom for property with poor prospects for development.
"There's no way, even if you wanted to, that a public sale with sealed bids could be fixed," he said in an interview. "We've got brains, you know. There's no way in the world anyone in this shop was going to submarine his career over a deal like this."
But Mr. Giuffre contends in his suit in Federal court in Trenton that the Prosecutor and his assistants conspired to strip him of the property and that he was pressured into signing the deeds over to the county without a lawyer being present.
The public sale of the forfeited land did not take place until December 1990. Both lots are in the hills above Flemington, where homes in the $300,000 range are not unusual.
 
Prosecutor 'Expressed Satisfaction'
 "It looks like in hindsight we gave it away, but it belonged to the Prosecutor's office and he expressed satisfaction with the price," said Michael Camerino, then the deputy county counsel, who was in charge of the sale. "If the county was selling surplus property we would have gone through a detailed process, like put our engineering staffs on it or hire an independent appraiser. The only information I could base the sale on came from the Prosecutor's office."
Mr. Camerino said he was shown an appraisal by the Prosecutor's office that indicated one lot was next to a junkyard and the other had serious drainage problems. He said he was also told that septic permits for both lots would expire shortly after the sale and that new state standards made their renewal problematic. No minimum bid was set.
The man who did the appraisal is John Graham, a Hunterdon County real-estate broker. He said he "took a look" at the property a few days after Mr. Giuffre's arrest. "It was not a formal appraisal by any means," Mr. Graham said in a telephone interview. "All I did was eyeball the two pieces and give an opinion." He said he would not pay more than $20,000 for one lot and $25,000 for the second.
He said he did not research any county or Raritan Township documents to back up his snap judgments. Had he checked, he would have learned that the property had passed soil tests and that septic tank permits on both lots were good until Dec. 31, 1994.
"If anything," said James A. Gallos, senior sanitarian for the County Health Department, "passing soil tests on developable land like this is like gold."
 
'Junkyard' Is a Farm
 Craig Proctor, a licensed appraiser in Flemington, said: "It's hard for me to believe three-acre lots in that area went for $10,000. They should have sold for 10 times that." The county tax assessment rolls, a few months after they went for $20,000, listed their combined market value at $147,700.
Mr. Graham also acknowledged last week that the "auto junkyard" he cited in his appraisal was in fact a farm with four or five unused cars one-quarter of a mile away.
When the sale was conducted in the Somerset County courthouse on Dec. 10, 1990, three people were present: Mr. Bissell, Mr. Camerino and Juanita DeWit. Ms. DeWit was awarded the two lots for $10,000 each.
At the time, Ms. DeWit was an employee of a local building firm, Merit Developers Inc., whose president was John Hromoho. In January 1992, after Ms. DeWit married Mr. Hromoho, one of the lots was sold to a Somerset County jail officer, Kirk Hamrah, and his wife, for $10,000.
On the second lot, Mrs. Hromoho obtained a $150,000 mortgage from the Somerset Trust Company on the authority of its lawyer, Thomas C. Miller. Mr. Miller also serves as Somerset County Counsel and is a longtime associate of Mr. Bissell, who before becoming the Prosecutor in 1982, represented Somerset Trust as a lawyer.
In April, Mrs. Hromoho deeded this lot for $1 to her husband's company, and the property, with a new house built on it, was sold for $221,000 in the spring.
Mr. Thornburg, the chief detective, expressed indignation when interviewed about his relationship to the two men who eventually ended up with the lots, John Hromoho and Kirk Hamrah. He said he barely knew them.
Yet Mr. Thornburg and Mr. Hamrah grew up in Dunellen, a small community just over the county line in Middlesex County, and they still live near Dunellen, as does Mr. Hromoho. Mr. Hromoho was an assistant football coach for the Dunellen High School in the years when Mr. Thornburg's younger brother Ron was the star running back, just as Mr. Thornburg himself had been a few years earlier. Kirk Hamrah and his brothers had played for the same team.
Mr. Thornburg said that he was living in Hunterdon County when Mr. Hromoho coached the team, and that he did not attend his younger brother's games. Ron Thornburg also is a detective on his brother's squad.
The Prosecutor, Mr. Bissell, said he doesn't know the Hromohos, and Mr. Hromoho declined to discuss the case.
