HEADLINE: Small Orchestras Facing Unharmonious Slow Passages

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The Hartford Symphony has not played a note in more than a year, and the fall season may be canceled this week if musicians reject a contract that would drastically reduce their earnings.
Although the dispute has been particularly bitter, the troubles in Hartford are but one expression of the financial difficulties affecting orchestras in medium-sized communities throughout the Northeast. 
 While big orchestras like the New York Philharmonic or the Boston Symphony are weathering the recession thanks to large endowments and a more solid audience base, symphonies with smaller budgets, less fund-raising prowess and more modest concert schedules have been reeling. They have suffered from the combined effects of reduced public and private financing, the difficulty of attracting new, younger audiences and the high costs of marketing and fund-raising.
Musicians playing for such orchestras have seen their pay drop by 19 percent between 1986 and 1991, while the income of performers with major orchestras has gone up 6.2 percent, according to a study released in June by the American Symphony Orchestra League.
Not only have musicians' pay and concert schedules been trimmed, but administrators have been dismissed, fewer soloists have been hired, and programs have been modified to include more popular works and exclude ones requiring large numbers of musicians.
"Corporate and government support has been way down in the last two or three years, we have an accumulated deficit of $750,000 and this is not a temporary situation," said Paul Reuter, the executive director of the Hartford Symphony. "We asked for concessions from our core musicians because that's the only way we can survive. There's a lot of trouble in our business."
The orchestra league study warned that "unless changes are made in the way orchestras do business, the future of the orchestra industry is in serious jeopardy." The report said that American orchestras' expenses ballooned from $87.5 million in 1971 to $698.9 million in 1991, and their aggregate deficit rose from $2.8 million to $23.2 million during the period.
Although orchestras throughout the country, including ones in Phoenix and Columbus, Ohio, are suffering, the Northeast has had more than its share of problems.
"Orchestras' income, by and large, comes from local sources," said Catherine French, the president of the American Symphony Orchestra League, "so when you have high unemployment, bank failures and you're losing your corporate base, which is especially true of the Northeast, it's bound to hurt." Hartford has been particularly hard hit and musicians are bitter.
 
37 Percent Cut
 "Management called for a 37 percent cut, which on average would have meant going from about $15,000 a year to $10,000," said Emery Tapley, a French horn player, referring to the year-old offer made to the Hartford Symphony's 21 principal musicians. Because of the impasse, he added, the musicians "have been scratching a living as best they can, some taking odd jobs or teaching, and some leaving Hartford altogether."
Hartford is far from alone.
This spring, the Syracuse Symphony abruptly suspended its season when it ran out of cash to pay its musicians. In New Haven, musicians swallowed a pay cut and a reduction in paid rehearsals to keep the city's 98-year-old symphony playing. The Long Island Philharmonic, which played 13 concerts last year, has pared its budget by about 30 percent in the last two years and is cutting its 1992-93 season to nine concerts. Orchestras in Trenton and Buffalo are also struggling.
"We're looking at every possible area of savings, but orchestras have always been operating on shoestrings," said Ernest Rose, the executive director of the Syracuse Symphony, which is cutting its budget from $5.2 million last year to $3.3 million. "We're trying to put together a season with fundamentally no staff and no resources."
In many ways, the Syracuse orchestra's experience is emblematic of the crisis brewing at orchestras outside major cities.
During the 1980's, like many orchestras, the Syracuse Symphony grew rapidly, bolstered by a boom in corporate giving to the arts and an expansion in government aid. By 1990, one-third of the symphony's budget came from a patchwork of public agencies that included the New York State Council on the Arts, the National Endowment for the Arts, Onondaga County and the City of Syracuse.
With New York State's budget troubles, however, support from the Arts Council was cut 60 percent, and another state appropriation was delayed, forcing the orchestra to miss its March payroll and shut down. The union for the 67 full-time and 14 part-time musicians, the American Federation of Musicians, filed a $1.2 million grievance for wages due since March 3, but capitulated in July, accepting a 20 percent pay cut.
"If they had pressed us," Mr. Rose said, "we would have gone bankrupt."
A shutdown was averted at the New Haven Symphony last fall when musicians accepted a cut in their number of guaranteed paid performances, from 104 to 58, and their pay per performance was reduced from $65 to $62. The cuts were prompted by a 30 percent reduction in aid from the Connecticut Commission on the Arts and the fact that several corporations and banks that had provided $80,000 a year as symphony sponsors cut their support in half, becoming "joint sponsors," said Catherine Weiskel, the symphony's general manager.
Even an established regional orchestra like the New Jersey Symphony, which plays about 120 concerts at six locations throughout the state, has seen a string of six-figure deficits, as its government aid has gone from $2.2 million in 1989 to $1.3 million this year, said Helen Paxton, the symphony's director of marketing.
While cutting pay and concerts have been the most obvious results of the financial straits, there have been others.
"Practically anything Impressionistic, like Debussy and Ravel, that needs a really big orchestra is not within our budget at the moment," said John Peter Holly, the executive director of the Greater Trenton Symphony Orchestra.
"We're careful now in how we program works," added Barry Shapiro, acting chairman of the Long Island Philharmonic, whose budget has been cut from $1.7 million in 1990 to $1.2 million this fall.
The recession has also hurt attendance for many orchestras, but what is especially worrisome is the dearth of concertgoers under age 40.
"Since there's been little music education in the schools, we're finding a generation that has not developed an appreciation for classical music," said Mr. Rose of the Syracuse Symphony.
 
Ticket Prices Up Slightly
 For most of these orchestras, ticket prices have continued to inch up, with relatively little effect on attendance, orchestra managers say.
To increase attendance, the Greater Trenton Symphony is concentrating on "warhorse programs" with broad appeal, like Beethoven's Fifth Symphony or the "William Tell Overture," Mr. Holly said. "Tickets sell on the basis of name recognition. We can't engage name conductors and soloists, who would be too expensive, so we have name works."
"Some musicians have criticized us for going to mainstream popular programming, but we used to play to nearly empty halls and now we're nearly full," he added. "Right now, we don't have the luxury to afford more artistically adventuresome programming."

HEADLINE: The Scourging of Africa

 BODY:
Take pity on the untimely sorrows of Africa. At a moment of undreamed-of political gains -- apartheid crumbling, wars ending and tyrannies tottering -- much of Africa is now beset by the worst drought in this century.
The rains never came in January. Crop yields fell by 70 percent in normally bountiful South Africa and Zimbabwe. And as sure as August heat, hunger or death threaten a third of the 100 million people living in affected countries of southern and eastern Africa. 
 The world has just begun to respond. United Nations agencies, having forecast the drought, did better than expected by obtaining $850 million in promised aid from 30 governments. With improvised shuffling, U.S. aid agencies have come up with $220 million in emergency food for the stricken. With energy and a modicum of luck, millions of lives can be salvaged and real catastrophe averted.
But who will mend the barren fields of Africa? Emergency relief, however essential, risks encouraging dependency and corruption; it is no substitute for sustained development programs.
Drought has become chronic in Africa, and there is little that Africans can do to change the weather patterns. But the depredations of nature are made worse by human failures. Africans lack drought-resistant seeds, deep wells and catchment dams. Price controls beggar farmers. Foreign lenders pressure impoverished nations to export surplus food stocks to earn hard currency.
The poignant truth is that the world responds to images of shrunken flesh, but that eyes glaze over when long-term amelioration is proposed. Americans give understandable priority to economic distress at home, and other foreign crises compete with the drought for attention. Such is Africa's untimely luck.
Even so, resignation in the face of such suffering is morally unthinkable. The Administration and Congress need to assure timely arrival and effective distribution of emergency supplies. There is surely a case for urging the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to ease programs that give priority to cash exports. And with an eye to next year, it makes sense to increase rather than trim disaster aid funding in 1993, as the Administration now proposes.
So argue voluntary agencies now marshaling support for Africa. They are well ahead of an indifferent public, but the tide is beginning to turn. Somalia, whose people are victimized by both drought and a mindless clan war, is finally getting attention. And the Security Council has approved Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's move to use U.N. forces to airlift food to the interior.
The world is not helpless, nor are Americans wholly indifferent. All that is missing is leadership.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Redefining National Security

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
We all know that the world has undergone a revolution. Equally evident, U.S. foreign policy has hardly adapted. But no one has added up the new facts, or clearly demonstrated the gap between the new realities and American responses or pointed to eminently doable ways of bridging that gap and restoring American strength and leadership -- until now.
The job was done by a bipartisan commission of government veterans headed by Winston Lord, former U.S. Ambassador to China and State Department planning chief. The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace (of which I am a trustee) sponsored the enterprise. 
 The commission report is an anthology of hard facts and good sense. It lays out where the U.S. and others must spend more money to avoid disasters. It also shows how to pay the new bills.
Based on the new realities, the commission recommends these spending priorities:
Population. The crowded earth already peopled by about 5.5 billion will groan under about 8.5 billion by 2025. This growth will overwhelm governments, resources and the environment. The cures are economic growth and education. But the Reagan and Bush Administrations have not helped. They stopped contributions to family planning efforts abroad because of false fears about promoting abortion.
Refugees. The international homeless total reached 18 million in 1991, and grows faster each year. The main causes are war and poverty. Costs are staggering: $7 billion yearly just for those seeking political asylum.
Peacekeeping and Peacemaking. The flood of refugees will grow and so will threats to peace unless collective security is strengthened, and quickly. U.N. forces now stand guard in a dozen places at an annual cost approaching $3 billion. That figure will have to be at least doubled and a standing U.N. force established to prevent what could become rampant anarchy.
Economic Development. Aid to and trade with poor nations are matters of self-interest to rich ones. U.S. trade with developing nations has been increasing faster than with any other group of nations and already is 35 percent of all U.S. exports. Trade as a percentage of U.S. gross national product has doubled to 25 percent since 1970. Making the poor richer is the best way to prevent refugees and create new exports and wealth for Americans.
The Environment. The tab for making good environmental practices affordable for poor countries (and for wealthy ones as well) will be in the billions yearly. But the costs of doing little to control greenhouse warming gases and deforestation would be unimaginably higher. And dealing with environmental problems will create jobs and growth.
Also with attention to hard facts, here is how the commission proposes to raise the necessary money -- and plenty more to cover domestic priorities and budget-deficit reduction:
Promoting Economic Growth Through Freer Trade. This is the surest and cheapest means to pump up economies. For the U.S., every additional $1 billion in exports produces 20,000 jobs. The leaders of the industrial world have become so mesmerized by economic gimmicks and so mired in domestic politics that they have failed for years to press ahead on the freer-trade front.
Cutting Military Expenditures. Worldwide spending for arms and armed forces reached $1.2 trillion in 1988, and if promises are kept, will decline to about $800 billion by 1996. The commission wants to bring this down by an additional $200 billion, which seems reasonable given the decline of transnational threats. For the U.S. alone, this could generate savings of $90 billion annually after five years.
Raising Energy Taxes. U.S. energy efficiency is about half that of Western Europe and Japan. Inefficiency here adds to the trade deficit and undermines competitiveness and security. Higher prices are central to efficiency, and U.S. gas taxes are one-eighth Western Europe's and one-fourth Japan's. The commission calls for increases of up to $1 per gallon, over time and with help for the needy.
This package of proposals profoundly redefines U.S. national security -- away from military concerns and toward a new agenda. And yet it is manageable and affordable. It does not call for a political or governmental revolution, only for leadership.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: What Other Countries Think of the U.S. Elections: Latin America;
With Perot Out of the Race, Fascination Slips Away

BYLINE: By Tim Golden

 BODY:
For decades, as surely as immigrants and drugs flowed northward from Latin America to the United States, concerns about the possibility of political upheaval moved in the other direction. But that has changed this year.
As Ross Perot shot up in the polls, Latin American technocrats shuddered, and a million satellite dishes swiveled to CNN. But beleaguered Latin populists wondered if they hadn't found a soulmate, and compared him to Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori, South America's out-of-nowhere man. When Mr. Perot criticized the idea of free trade with Mexico, the Mexican stock exchange fell almost instantly; when he dropped out, the market leapt a joyous 5 percent. 
 In Argentina, where President Carlos Saul Menem has jettisoned formal non-alignment and third world leadership to get as close as he can to President Bush, Government officials fret that they could lose the November election, too. Chileans, Costa Ricans and Colombians -- their own hopes of closer trade and economic ties perhaps in the balance -- have watched the American campaign like a strange, distant play full of vague clues to their economic fate.
But monopolar as the world may have grown, some Latin leaders haven't had much time to watch. When heads of state gathered in Madrid 10 days ago to discuss Iberian-American issues, Cesar Gaviria of Colombia stayed home to deal with an escaped drug lord. The Venezuelan Senate denied its embattled President, Carlos Andres Perez, permission to travel, and Mr. Fujimori was busy with a wave of guerrilla attacks.

HEADLINE: 'Free Trade' Means No Jobs and High Prices

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Breakthrough on Mexican Trade" (editorial, July 17) wrongly congratulates President Bush on the impending "free trade pact" with Mexico, and criticizes "the protectionist demagogy of organized labor and Congressional opponents." You pooh-pooh their "frightening stories" about the export of jobs to Mexico. The facts make truly frightening stories. My sources are official documents from the Mexican Investment Board and such United States publications as Business Week for last March 16 -- hardly the voice of labor! 
 The Mexican board reported that United States companies have opened more than 2,000 assembly and manufacturing facilities that provide nearly half a million jobs. In 1990 these plants, called "macquiladoras," generated $3.6 billion in value-added foreign exchange earnings. They pay $1 an hour to Mexican workers in government-controlled unions (Business Week). You say, "Their economy is too small to pose a serious threat." How about China, where even cheaper prison labor is used? The Mexican report adds: "Large multinational companies are also helping their original suppliers to relocate near their macquiladora plants."
Business Week reported that "Last year, Mexico topped one million vehicles" and adds that "the auto makers are loath to discuss their Mexican strategies." It quotes a Big Three executive as saying "We'd put up a lot more plants in Mexico, if it weren't for the U.A.W." And you speak of "labor demagogy"? It quotes the head of Ford Motor de Mexico as saying that if the North American free trade agreement that you praise is adopted, "we could be making three million units a year here, or more."
I hope you are right that "the jury is still out" on Gov. Bill Clinton, and that he takes these and other readily available facts into account when he acts to bring back American jobs. If he wants to prove himself an agent of change, he will distance himself from Mr. Bush and Detroit on this issue, and come out forcefully against the so-called "free trade" pact, which is helping destroy our industrial base by exporting jobs in every industry.
The "free trade" slogan is a fraud: intended to help balance imports and exports, it is the primary cause of the United States trade deficit and of 10 million unemployed, since its main beneficiaries are the profit-hungry multinational corporations, recklessly cutting costs -- but not prices. The public loses both ways: no jobs and high prices.
 
ARNOLD J. OLENICK
Cambridge, Mass., July 17, 1992
 
The writer is a financial and management consultant.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 308 words

HEADLINE: 'Free Trade' Means No Jobs and High Prices;
Let's Be Serious

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The imminent completion of a free trade agreement with Mexico should provide the stimulus for a serious discussion of the direction for economic growth in our country. To term questions about that agreement "protectionist demagogy" in your July 17 editorial demeans all of us who are involved, including Congress. 
 The assumption that free trade and its presumed economic efficiencies will lead to better societies in two countries that are at vastly different stages of development and with fundamental differences in their institutions is naive at best.
A July 21 front-page article, the first in your series "A New North America," looks at the impact of such trade agreements on the glass industry. You note that the only way a West Virginia company could remain competitive with Mexican companies was to lower its wages 25 percent and eliminate worker's health insurance and vacation pay! This is the start of a deflationary economic cycle, of lower prices, yes, but also an impoverished work force unable to buy, even at lower prices.
Our Government is creating an enormous incentive to substitute investment in low-level wages and lax environmental demands south of the border for investments in productivity and greater efficiency in the United States. Our competitiveness in the world will be greatly diminished.
Without specific job protections, labor rights and environmental, health and safety guarantees as an integral part of this agreement the result will be a race to the lowest common denominator of wages and social conditions, not the highest.
The labor movement is not opposed to trade with Mexico. What we seek is a framework for managing this economic integration in a humane, responsible way.
 
JACK SHEINKMAN
President, Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union
New York, July 27, 1992

HEADLINE: 'Free Trade' Means No Jobs and High Prices;
Major New Market

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Breakthrough on Mexican Trade" (editorial, July 17) is a very timely reminder of the powerful impact a successful North American free trade agreement could have on the United States economy. Reducing trade barriers with Mexico, as the United States has done with Canada, offers exceptional opportunities to increase United States exports to Mexico, the fastest-growing economy on the continent. I must take strong exception, however, to your characterization of the United States auto industry as one that will lose jobs if the United States enters into a free trade agreement with Mexico. 
 Because of restrictions imposed by Mexico, exports of United States-built cars and trucks to that country have been strictly limited.
If these restrictions are lifted in a free trade agreement with Mexico, producers in this country will for the first time be able to sell a full range of automobiles and trucks produced in the United States to complement the more limited number of models the companies produce there for the local market. This means new orders for United States plants, increased and more secure jobs for our workers and the opening of a major new market for United States automotive products.
 
STEPHEN J. COLLINS
Director, Economic and Intl. Affairs, Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association of the United States
Washington, July 23, 1992

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 365 words

HEADLINE: Yes, America Needs an Oil Industry

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Shrinking of the American Oil Industry" (July 19) describes how American oil companies are shifting more of their investments in operations overseas and asks the question: "Does the United States really need much of a domestic oil industry anyway?" The question is not answered directly, but the impression is given that the United States does not because oil can be found more cheaply abroad. Thus the movement of oil industry investment, technology and jobs from the United States to overseas is presented merely as a matter of free trade. 
 This argument is fundamentally wrong. The test is not whether oil can be found or produced more cheaply abroad, but whether we can develop new oil reserves in the United States at less cost than the price at which foreign nations are willing to sell their oil to us. Where that test is met, investment occurs domestically, and Americans are made better off.
Then why are American oil companies spending more and more of their exploration and production funds abroad? Because they have no choice but to seek opportunities in foreign lands. The best prospects at home for finding billions of barrels of oil and trillions of cubic feet of natural gas have been put off limits for shortsighted political reasons. Congress has virtually closed the Atlantic and Pacific coasts and the eastern Gulf of Mexico to new offshore development, and even has refused to debate opening the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. The most attractive geologic targets at home are being blocked off because of domestic political decisions to lock up American resources.
American companies in testimony before Congress repeatedly have asserted their eagerness to bid for Federal oil and natural gas leases in parts of the United States now off limits. They believe they could produce those resources at competitive prices. A policy shift in the United States toward utilizing our own economic petroleum resources could slow American job losses, production declines and government revenue losses.
 
CHARLES J. DiBONA
Washington, July 23
 
Mr. DiBona is president of the American Petroleum Institute.

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 16; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 3101 words

HEADLINE: Special Report;
Living on the Edge

BYLINE: By Mary B. W. Tabor

 BODY:
RELIABLE statistics on the extent of the school dropout problem are as scarce as they are suspect. Until this year, the 50 states have reported their dropout rates to Washington in almost as many different ways. Few school systems keep track of students who drop out after eighth grade, just before high school, when educators suspect many students are lost. And evaluations of dropout prevention programs -- a backdoor method for gauging the extent of the problem -- have been practically nonexistent.
But even without numbers, an ever-mounting pile of reports, estimates and anecdotes tell us this much: The problem is bad. 
 More children entered American schools in the past decade than ever before. But the number who never make it to their high school graduation -- almost 1 in 3 according to some estimates -- is alarmingly high. And the category of who is "at risk" of dropping out comprises an increasingly diverse population, including a large number of minority students, especially blacks and Hispanics; students from low-income households; pregnant teen-agers; students who abuse alcohol or drugs, and alienated middle-class youngsters who "drop out" intellectually under pressure to succeed.
The situation, educators and policy makers say, has grown to crisis proportions, becoming an issue of national economic concern. "If we are going to continue being competitive in global markets, we have to address these education issues," said Alicia Coro, director of school improvement programs for the Federal Department of Education. "There are certainly issues of national security as well. The people who graduate now will be our work force for the next 30 or 40 years."
So pressing is the problem that President Bush has set a graduation rate he wants American schools to achieve and a target date to achieve it. By the year 2000, he announced earlier this year, American schools should have a 90 percent graduation rate -- a goal the nation's governors have also endorsed.
Partly in response to such prodding, educators have stepped up their efforts to figure out which dropout prevention programs work, which don't, with which groups of students, and why. They say that the most successful programs do the following:
* Provide early intervention, such as intensive language training, for young students.
* Adapt to fit individual students' needs.
* Involve adults, from families or from local, community-based organizations.
* Make students feel like part of a community.
* Are comprehensive, incorporating home visits as well as classroom work.
* Link school lessons to the working world.
* Set out clear educational goals that are appealing and reasonable, holding students accountable for their performance and also using a short-term penalty and reward system.
* Conduct regular evaluations and send the results to a central office and to the schools.
"Improving the dropout rate does not involve a great and mysterious strategy, but two fundamental principles -- early intervention and providing a climate in which young people feel they genuinely belong," said Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, in Princeton, N.J.
Fully understanding the dropout problem, however, begins with defining who a dropout is; one who enters ninth grade and leaves before graduation? What about the student who drops out for a few months, even a year, and then returns to a different school?
In the United States, with its 83,000 public schools spread across 16,000 school districts, there has been no consensus on the subject -- until now. Last fall, the Federal Government and the 50 states agreed on a definition of a dropout and agreed to use it in future counts. Officially, dropouts are those students who were in grades 7 to 12 the previous year who are not enrolled in school now and who did not graduate. Exceptions are made for students out of school because of illness or temporary suspension.
 
How States Will Count Their Dropouts
 States will also be asked to measure the proportion of their populations that are not high school graduates and are not enrolled in school at a specified time, as well as what happens to a single group of students over a given period. Federal education officials, meanwhile, are demanding that evaluation plans be built into grant applications for federally financed dropout prevention programs, the better to determine which students are in the programs and how they fare.
As of November 1993, when the new national statistics will be available, the numbers may still be inexact but they will be uniform.
Currently, what few numbers there are, combined with anecdotal evidence, suggest that students who drop out are not always the ones one would expect. The usually dismal dropout rates for black students, for example, have improved over the last two decades. But the problem with Hispanic students, who often come from low-income households with poor English-language skills, is proving less tractable: they leave school at twice the rate of their non-Hispanic classmates.
Characteristics known to push children off the edge and out of school, such as pregnancy, drug or alcohol use, low family income or failing grades, do not account for all dropouts. Other pathologies, such as low self-esteem and a sense of alienation, or the school environment, are recognized as manifestations of basic problems that, in combination, threaten all youngsters. For example, a student with a history of poor grades -- the result of trouble at home, perhaps -- develops low self-esteem. He or she joins a gang, tangles with the law, leaves school and never makes it back.
Makisha Bailey's web of difficulties centered on family problems. Ms. Bailey, 17 years old, lives in Boston's Roxbury neighborhood. An average student who says she loves school, she has dropped out twice because she was pregnant. Her mother, a recovering alcoholic, now watches her children during the day. But Makisha, who lives with friends, is not back in school.
Chris Miller's problems sprang more from his high school environment. A member of a prototypical, solid-middle-class family of four in Greenville, S.C., Chris, now 20, said disruptions were so frequent in class that "I got to the point I didn't care." Refused permission to transfer, he dropped out while retaking courses after he failed 11th grade. He works locally as a hotel waiter.
So many targets require a veritable armory of weapons. "I'm not saying we know how to solve the problem," said Russell W. Rumberger, an associate professor of education at the University of California at Santa Barbara. "But we now have a better idea of how complex that problem is and the need to have more varied strategies to address it."
Those strategies are either long-term, such as early intervention, or short-term, such as remedial classes; one-shot efforts targeting a group with a specific program, like pregnancy programs, or full-scale attacks that usually involve overhauling a school system.
Encouraged by the success of initiatives like Head Start for preschoolers, most education experts agree that early childhood education is the best long-term preventive strategy. An estimated 35 percent of all children start school ill prepared for education, especially in the area of language development. Many elementary schools are creating multi-year programs that will help toddlers acquire and develop language skills.
 
Focusing on Short-Term Remedies
 For children already in school and lacking learning skills, teachers are focusing on short-term remedies: trying to keep classes small, for example, to give needy students more attention; providing students with mentors, flexible class schedules and prenatal child care, as well as job placement programs.
Desperate for answers, some schools have gone for gimmicks, like pizza parties and health classes to keep students in school. Others have joined with their states, such as West Virginia, in driver's license revocation programs -- no high school diploma, no driver's license -- to keep students in school. And for certain youngsters in certain settings, these programs seem to work.
But in large urban or desolate rural areas, where dropout rates are higher, they often don't. As a result, educators have begun to look toward more holistic programs, ones that focus on changing the structure inside the school and developing social connections outside it.
The most popular of these are schools-within-schools, settings in which students belong to communities, sometimes organized as "houses" or "concentrations." In a "science and technology house," for example, students would have regular contact with a defined group of classmates who share an interest in science. In these programs their teachers know who they are, what classes they are in and when they have missed school.
Another restructuring plan involves school "clusters" -- high schools with specific feeder elementary and middle schools -- that give students academic and social continuity throughout their school careers.
These and other models for reform are being pushed by the Federal Government, which is allocating more money for dropout prevention projects. Under the nation's School Dropout Demonstration Assistance Program, authorized by Congress in 1988, 65 four-year grants were awarded last year, financed with about $34 million. For fiscal year 1992, the pot is $40 million and the department anticipates adding about 20 new projects.
In New York City, a dropout prevention plan called Project Achieve was recently instituted in 32 public high schools. Participants, such as Prospect Heights High School in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, turn to local, community-based organizations for help with tutoring, mentoring and home visits to students having academic or social problems. In Philadelphia, the Partnership Academies program relies on businesses for volunteer mentors and job training. That program is being replicated throughout California.
 
U.S. Seeking Programs for Hispanics
 The Federal Department of Education is also asking for programs geared to the needs of Hispanic students, the group evidencing the highest dropout rates nationwide. One such program, the Valued Youth Partnership, began in Texas in 1984 and has since expanded to five school systems in predominantly Hispanic areas of Texas, California, Florida and New York. The program targets at-risk middle school students, whom it trains to tutor elementary school students and who in turn improve their own reading, writing and language skills. The object is to boost the potential dropouts' sense of achievement and involvement in school.
Educators have also begun trying to pool resources through national dropout networks. Clemson University's National Dropout Prevention Center, for example, tries to keep track of prevention programs and help school districts find ones that suit their needs.
Few programs, however, deal with students who have already dropped out. Traditional schools, organized along age and grade levels, do not readily accommodate a student who has been out of school for a year or so. And even the best programs, according to teachers and dropout counselors, are believed to bring only about 30 to 40 percent of dropouts back to school. How many of the ones who re-enter actually graduate, no one knows for sure.
But hundreds, possibly many thousands of dropouts, educators say, want to try. A young mother, for example, recently pushed her baby stroller onto a subway train in Brooklyn, sat down and sighed. She had become pregnant at 15, she said, and had enrolled in a special program for pregnant and unwed mothers in Manhattan. Once her baby was born, however, she began having problems at home and was forced to give up her place in the program. Now, she said, she is on welfare and looking for a job to pay for an apartment.
"I want to go back to school," she said. "But I don't know when. It all happens so fast."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 5; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: JULY 26 - AUG. 1;
It Didn't Only Seem Worse

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Call it the incredible shrinking economy. For months, Government statisticians said that the recession that began in the second half of 1990 had lasted two quarters and that output had fallen 1.6 percent during that period.
 But, presto, on Thursday a Government report announced that the recession had actually lasted three quarters, not two. 
Not only that, the report said, but output had declined 2.2 percent during the period.
 The report, which revised statistics based on more complete data, said the recession had begun in the third quarter of 1990 and run through the first quarter of 1991. And the report said the economy did not grow by two-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, as originally estimated, but instead shrank by 1.6 percent on an annualized basis during that quarter.
 Also on Thursday, the government announced more unhappy tidings: Growth in this year's second quarter was a puny 1.4 percent, half the rate in the first quarter.
 All this was not good news for the White House in a campaign year. Gov. Bill Clinton jumped on the unencouraging statistics, saying growth under President Bush was "even more anemic" than at first thought.
 The Bush Administration has long argued that the recession was not really so deep and that one reason growth was so slow in 1991 is that economies do not bounce out of mild recessions the way they do from deep ones. The Administration will no longer be able to use that argument. Trying to put a favorable spin on the news, Administration officials noted that the economy has grown, although weakly, for five consecutive quarters. They predicted that low interest rates and an export boom would push growth to a respectable 3 percent in the second half.

LENGTH: 1832 words

HEADLINE: Bridging the Cultural Gap in Chappaqua

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: CHAPPAQUA

 BODY:
"IT'S not like I miss the bullets," said Tarolyn Molina, a 15-year-old from the Bronx who is a first-year student in the Chappaqua Summer Scholarship Program. "But I mean, I got used to it. At home, my mother would say, 'Didn't you hear the shots last night?' and I'd say, 'No, I slept through it.' But now, where I'm staying, it's like there are 800 little birds chirping outside my window. And I'm like -- Hey, what's that noise?" she said.
Tarolyn is one of 16 visiting students experiencing the relative peace as well as the entirely new culture of the suburbs while she takes courses at Horace Greeley High School. 
 The Chappaqua Summer Scholarship Program is primarily an academic program that brings students who have already shown scholastic promise at their own high schools in the south Bronx to summer school in Chappaqua.
The program began in 1968 as the brainchild of a group of community leaders here who were then meeting regularly at the Quaker Meetinghouse, trying to come up with different ideas to bridge the gap between the turbulent and less affluent parts of New York City and its quieter, more well-to-do suburbs.
A quarter of a century later, many of the programs the group developed have long since been abandoned, but the scholarship program -- which began as a modest proposal -- has survived and flourished.
Students are recommended for the program by their guidance counselors and then interviewed and chosen by the program's directors. The students, who begin the scholarship program after the eighth grade, attend it for three consecutive summers while living with a series of volunteer host families. The students are in school from 8 A.M. to 1 P.M. on weekdays, taking two academic courses and one elective. The program also offers college counseling to seniors.
 
Exposure to Cultural Life
 But while the scholarship program maintains its academic focus, it also seeks to expose its students to the cultural and social aspects of life in the suburbs. Students are required to sign a contract guaranteeing their participation in activities like swimming and tennis as well as their attendance on field trips to places like I.B.M.'s T. J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights and the Katonah Museum.
The Chappaqua Summer Scholarship Program is financed entirely by private donations. It pays for summer school tuition, books, train fare, minibus fare and doctors' bills for the students during their stay in Chappaqua. While the program is financially solvent, it has had trouble attracting host families. This year had more families volunteered as hosts, the program could have handled more than the 16 students selected, said Linda Peterson, co-chairwoman of the program.
"People have the concept that these kids from the city are very cosmopolitan, but they are wrong," said Larry Breen, vice principal of Horace Greeley and one of the founders of the program. "Many of these children have never even been to Manhattan or seen the Statue of Liberty. When we conceived the program, we wanted to take Chappaqua's most unique resource -- our school district -- and share it. But my attitude is also that if communities like Chappaqua exist then these children have a right to know it and a right to know that these people live like they do," he said.
One of the primary new exposures each student gets is living with three different Chappaqua families for two weeks each during the summer. And while many of the students reported that they had little difficulty adjusting to the academic demands of the scholarship program, they all reported culture shock at life in the country.
 
Adjusting to a Slow Pace
 At a recent lunch break in Horace Greeley's cafeteria, students traded notes on their reactions to life in Chappaqua. One of the first things they had to get used to was the slow pace -- students here meander down uncrowded halls with a full 10 minutes between classes. Another adjustment was to unfamiliar sounds -- both the sense of quiet and the sudden, unexpected clamor of suburban wildlife.
Tarolyn's experience of sleeping through gunfire reflects the violent crime in her Bronx neighborhood, which is a constant reality for virtually all the students in the program. Tarolyn noted with some surprise that the day before she had gone out Rollerblading and nothing had happened -- no one came after her and no one had stolen her skates. Some of the students have given Chappaqua the nickname Peaceland. Ebony Jenkins, 16, expressed amazement that people in Chappaqua did not lock their cars or houses.
"These people leave their front door open," she said. "If you do that in the Bronx you see a hole where your house used to be. If you do that with your car, your car is gone," she said.
Several years ago, participants in the program were surprised at the outpouring of community grief when a Horace Greeley student was killed in a car accident overseas.
"They were amazed at how the whole community mourned over this one boy because every week these kids have people they know killed," Mrs. Peterson said. "There's not a kid in this program who hadn't been a victim of violence of some sort -- gunshots coming through their apartment window, or friends being killed or being mugged or stabbed."
 
Two Different Personalities
 Students in the program return to their own homes in the Bronx for the weekend during the school session and the transition is not an easy one on several levels.
One girl referred to her "Bronx personality" and her "Chappaqua personality." Sometimes it is simply a matter of adjusting their slang. Steve Negron, 16, who is in his third year in the program heard Chappaqua teen-agers refer to a girl as a heifer. He had no idea what they were talking about. (They meant she looked like a cow.) Later, he tried out the expression in the Bronx and was met with blank stares.
But the real transition involves the readjustment to the dangers of life in the south Bronx.
"You have to be alert," said Kwame Gyasi, 15, who has been mugged twice. "You remember, well, now we're in the Bronx, we have to act like we're in the Bronx. Sometimes you get caught in between. Up here you can relax. Over there you have to watch out all the time," he said.
 
Strong Family Ties
 At the same time, they miss their own families. Janice Cleland, a member of the scholarship program's board, said that almost all the kids in the program have strong family ties. "The reason that these kids are making it so far is that they have somebody who is backing them and encouraging them. It may be a mom or dad, an aunt or an uncle, but these parents are very strict and these kids have someone who is protecting them," she said.
Critics argue that the program can be a cruel tease. Students are exposed to the wealth of northern Westchester and one of the state's top public schools for six weeks and then sent home to a dangerous and deprived reality. Proponents counter that those who participate are motivated students, most of whom will be going on to college, and that their early exposure to a middle-class life and good schooling can ease their transition by removing some barriers of the unknown.
"This is an urban-suburban program as well as an academic program," Mr. Breen said. "It was not meant to be a black-white program, and it's certainly not a fresh-air program. But it is based on the understanding that college is still very much a white and middle-class world," he said.
Kenny Padilla, who completed the program in 1986, said it not only gave him his first sense of independence but also helped give him the courage to apply to Brown University, from which he recently graduated with bachelor's degrees in economics and in public policy and American institutions. Mr. Padilla, who will attend Rutgers Law School this fall, said the scholarship program introduced him to a world outside his own.
"It really opened my eyes to what was beyond the Bronx," he said. "Just the fact that I was able to go away to Chappaqua was like a first step for me. If I had gone to Brown without going to C.S.S.P. the culture shock would have been a lot worse. It was a lot smoother than if I went through 18 years in the Bronx, which for me was predominantly Puerto Rican, and then went off to Brown," he said.
 
'One More Thing in Your Favor'
 And while tennis and swimming lessons may seem elitist or petty to program critics, the students argue that such exposure will serve them later.
"Before I came up here I didn't know how to swim, play tennis, bowl or keyboard on a computer," Steve Negron said. "Maybe someday I'll be in a business situation and they will want to close the deal with a tennis game. If you don't know how to play, maybe it's no big deal. But if you do, it's one more thing in your favor," he said.
According to the directors of the scholarship program, two students -- neither of whom had ever picked up a tennis racket before coming to Chappaqua -- went to college on tennis scholarships.
Those critical of the program also argue that it is a sort of noblesse oblige project, allowing Chappaqua residents to feel good while ultimately making the students resentful of their parents and their own financial situations. This year's students reacted to that theory with surprise and some amusement.
"That is so ignorant," Tarolyn said. "Why would I resent my mom? My mom works really hard. In my own family, we're all at different levels. A lot of us don't consider money the top value. I'm happy with what I have and my family," she said.
"It's all in the way you see it," Ebony said. "I don't think they bring us up here to make us feel bad. They bring us up here to show us something new. Sure, I see the great big houses in Chappaqua, and I think maybe someday I'd like to live like this. But it's not like we feel bad leaving here and going home. The Bronx is our home. Truthfully, I feel better coming home than leaving home," she said.
 
Cultural Exposure Works Both Ways
 Most of the students said that if they were not in the program they would probably spend the summer watching television or doing nothing. Tarolyn said that she would not be permitted to go downstairs (or out of her apartment building) because her mother was working all day and there was no one to watch her.
Almost all of the Chappaqua families that participate are quick to point out that the advantages of cultural exposure work both ways. Susan and Robert Wolff have been hosts for six years and feel that the program benefits their own three young children as much if not more than the teen-agers who stay at their home.
"Everything that these kids have are things we want to instill in our own children," Mrs. Wolff said. "They have an interest in education, in taking risks, in new experiences, along with a strong sense of family and commitment. These kids are good influences. They have the kind of values I want to instill in my own children."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
No More Blank Checks for Regulators

BYLINE: By ROBERT W. HAHN; Robert W. Hahn is a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute and an adjunct research fellow at Harvard's Kennedy School.

 BODY:
EARLY this year, President Bush saw a Federal regulatory system spiraling out of control and instituted a 90-day moratorium on new Federal regulations, which was later extended for four months. The moratorium, which will expire on Aug. 27, should be renewed.
The moratorium calls for a review of existing regulations and requires that any new regulations be evaluated for benefits and costs. It encourages the use of market-based mechanisms to achieve regulatory objectives. 
 Oddly enough, the President's actions have been received skeptically by the media, which have confused regulatory reform with deregulation.
Most Americans would be surprised to know that regulatory agencies often fashion regulations without regard to their cost. In many instances, Congress actually forbids cost consideration by regulators. The result is a regulatory burden on the economy now estimated at $400 billion a year.
New regulations tend to cost more while delivering less. For example, I estimate that the costs of the 1990 Clean Air Act exceed the benefits by about $16 billion annually. Such regulation is a hidden tax that reduces our competitiveness.
Most Americans would probably not be surprised to learn that regulators are using their rule-making power to micromanage the behavior of businesses and individuals while expanding their own power base. The number of Federal bureaucrats in charge of implementing regulations has nearly doubled since 1970, from 70,000 to 125,000.
Renewing the President's moratorium will slow our accelerated rate of regulatory growth. In the area of the environment, the directives mean that we may no longer have to confront the either-or dilemma presented by inefficient command-and-control regulation, which specify exactly how problems must be solved. Instead we could discover a very attractive "win-win" solution: a cleaner environment and a competitive economic system, without undue government intrusion.
Sensible regulation should balance concern for the environment, health and safety with concern for an economy that can provide jobs, a high standard of living and the resources to attack pressing domestic problems like crime, drug abuse and inner-city blight. These issues are more important to the health and welfare of the people than squeezing the last virtually undetectable part per billion of an offending substance from the air.
Renewing the President's reform program represents an important first step in moving the regulatory train back on track. But Congress needs to become an active partner, not an adversary, if the bureaucracy is to be tamed. Congress should require that regulatory costs and benefits be tallied up alongside budgetary expenditures -- not such an unreasonable request when the current costs average more than $3,000 per household and the benefits are often minuscule.
Congress could take a giant step forward by requiring a serious benefit-cost test for major regulations, making regulations that lowered our standard of living the exception rather than the rule. A 1982 bill containing this provision unanimously passed the Senate but stalled in the House. Just last month, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, introduced a bill that requires benefit-cost analysis and limits the regulatory burden that government imposes on the public. It is a step forward and it should be passed.
The American public is demanding empowerment this election year. Constructive regulatory reform requires greater awareness of how regulation adversely affects the average American. If the public understood that Congress, business lobbyists, so-called "public" interest groups and bureaucracy were the driving forces behind needless regulation, then Congress would be more receptive to regulatory reform efforts. The President's responsibility is to sensitize the public to these issues. The people's responsibility is to direct Congress to clean up the regulatory mess.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Norwich Planning to Market Its Old Mills

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AFTER a year-long study, Norwich will soon start to market more than 2 million square feet of space in 12 largely vacant mill complexes around the city.
The city has $10,000 from the Connecticut Historic Commission, and is itself putting up $10,000 to promote reuse of the mills. City Planning Director Kathy B. Warzecha said she expects to seek bids soon for a marketing campaign beginning next spring. 
 "Other towns have done something similar, but usually with one or two mills," said Ms. Warzecha. "This is much more comprehensive."
The project followed a reuse study by Renee Kahn, executive director of the Historic Neighborhood Preservation Program, based in Stamford. She recommended turning Norwich into a "living museum" of the Industrial Revolution, much as nearby Mystic is a museum of maritime history.
"One of the nice things about Norwich having fallen on rough times is that it's left the city like a time capsule," Mrs. Kahn said. "It has a downtown, and it has mills, that look like someone walked away from them 50 years ago."
Elena L. Kalman, a Stamford architect who worked on the study, concedes that there are hurdles to overcome in such a project. But in the end, she said, developers will have buildings more unusual than anything they could afford to build.
The ornate brick and stonework, decorative wrought iron rails and fences, hand-hewn beams, and other aspects make the buildings attractive to a variety of users, said Ms. Kalman. "Those mills, even the most unimportant of them, have some very interesting spaces," Ms. Kalman said. "They're not simple and meaningless."
The mills have already begun to sell themselves. Brian H. Burchman, owner of Central Sports, is moving his sports-vehicle dealership from a new strip mall building on West Main Street to 15,000 square feet in the 717,480-square-foot turn-of-the-century Ponemah Mills.
Mr. Burchman said that the site, with quick access to Interstate 395, rail lines behind the building on the Shetucket River, is both convenient and attractive.
"The facility is just perfect for any type of business," he said. "If Norwich has a boom, that's going to be the area that booms."
United States Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Bozrah, has proposed a Federal heritage corridor in eastern Connecticut. He said the restoration of the mills could be thes cornerstone of the project, which would preserve through purchase or preservation convenant natural resources, historic sites and other regional attractions.
Most of the mills sprang up on the banks of the Thames, Yantic and Shetucket Rivers. Neighborhoods grew up around them, eventually linking most of the city.
The buildings date mostly from the last half of the 19th century, when Norwich was changing from a shipping port to a mill city. Mrs. Kahn said Norwich must change again.
"Norwich has to re-invent itself, just as it did in the late 1800's," said Mrs. Kahn. "It has to find a new focus."
The complexes range in size from the two-building, 18,570- square-foot Yantic Falls Mills on Yantic Street, to the largest complex in Norwich, the 10-building Ponemah Mills on Route 97.
"Ponemah is the most architecturally interesting," said Mrs. Kahn. "It's like a medieval castle or a Loire chateau, in that it towers over everything around it, and represents the power of the nobility."
Her report recommends a hotel-conference center as the anchor for Ponemah, with restaurants, health club, light manufacturing, retail and offices in other spaces.
She proposed similar mixed-uses for the larger complexes, and limited use for smaller ones, such as housing for the elderly in the 43,740-square-foot Turner Stanton Mill on Clinton Avenue.
Planners say the city has a ready labor force, given that military cuts have affected so many southeastern Connecticut industries. It has easy access to deep water, rail, and Interstate 395.
BUT there are problems. Ms. Kalman said there is little parking for most of the buildings, and some physical limitations: in one building, some of the ceilings are 6 feet, 4 inches high. Many have been vacant and deteriorating for decades and coordinating the multiple ownerships could prove difficult.
Ms. Kalman said there could also be lead paint, asbestos insulation, PCB's, or other hazards in some of the old mills.
The city's report has an entire section on the financial incentives of restoration. For example, most of the buildings are on the National Register of Historic Places and qualify for Federal tax credits.
"No one incentive is going to encourage anyone," Mrs. Kahn said. "But if you put together three or four or five, the bottom line comes out better than new construction."
Some of the mills are already being put back to use, with rents in the $2 to $4 per square foot range. Dale Plummer started his Quinnehticut Woolen Company in the Ponemah complex two years ago. He has eight employees using old-fashioned equipment to turn out specialty woolen yarns.
He said he supports the mill proposals in general, adding that details will have to be worked out by city planners, and people who live around the mills.
"It's kind of up to the community to say, 'This is how we want it,' " Mr. Plummer said. "I want it to go forward. Ponemah is one of the country's premier mill buildings."
Stuart B. Greenfield, a local attorney and co-owner of 230,000 square feet in Ponemah, said he has signed a contract with one retailer for 20,000 square feet, and is negotiating with another for 50,000 square feet.
"There is a lot of interest in bringing the mills back to life, and creating a renaissance in Norwich," Mr. Greenfield said. "The key is going to be flexibility."
Mr. Greenfield said so far the city planning office has expedited his permits and referred potential tenants, and state agencies have been accommodating to his plans.
"Previously, the city and state have been more of a hindrance," Mr. Greenfield said. "It's a real pleasure to see everyone finally working together to create jobs and improve the quality of life in these neighborhoods."
Ms. Warzecha said there is broad-based support for the reuse of the mills, including from the people of the mill neighborhoods.
"The reuse of these mills could make their property values go up, and their taxes go down," she said. "We'll have viable businesses instead of vacant, deteriorated buildings."

LENGTH: 1522 words

HEADLINE: Luncheon Clubs: A Tradition Fades

BYLINE: By TINA TRASTER-POLAK

 BODY:
GONE are the days when men gathered in smoke-filled libraries to scan the newspapers a half-hour before lunch. Gone are the days when power brokers washed down three-course midday meals with too many martinis. And gone are Newark's private luncheon clubs.
In late March, the last remaining and oldest of the luncheon clubs -- the 116-year-old Essex Club at 52 Park Place -- closed its doors. The nearby 744 Club on Broad Street closed last year, and the Downtown Club folded a few years earlier. 
 "Any time there is a downturn in the economy, clubs go under," said Richard G. Schoon, president of the Metro Newark Chamber of Commerce. "After the 1987 Wall Street crash, a number of clubs closed their doors, and many are struggling to survive."
Today, clubs like the Essex Club, with its deep red carpets, oak-paneled rooms and portraits of board members dating to the late 19th century, stand empty. But the demise of traditional men's clubs (some of which later admitted women) may give birth to a new genre.
In October, a new luncheon club will open on the 22d floor at One Newark Center in the Gateway office complex. Many Essex Club members say the new club, with its marble and chrome, will lack the warmth and charm of their old haunt. But it will be Newark's only private dining room.
 
Many Reasons for Decline
 Older clubs are dying for many reasons. Executives who once languished over long meals are more apt to grab sandwiches at their desks. Also, financial belt-tightening has scrapped many corporate perks like club memberships.
In recent years, the Essex Club relied on nearly $35,000 a year in rent for hospitality suites leased to local corporations like Mutual Benefit Life Insurance, Midlantic National Bank, First Fidelity Bank and the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. Only Public Service had been planning to renew its lease for 1993.
Added to a change of business mores is a healthier approach to eating and drinking. Cholesterol and calorie counters do not in good conscience consume a big sirloin steak for lunch, and alcohol consumption has dramatically dropped. Members of the Essex Club recall a time when the club sold its own brand of alcohol.
"The infamous three-hour martini lunch has gone the way of the dodo bird," said Ted Lippencott, a Newark lawyer and the club's most recent board president.
Clubs began having difficulties in the late 1960's -- for example, the longstanding Newark Athletic Club on Fulton Street closed in 1965. The demise of the Essex Club began in the late 1970's, when many of the major banks, legal firms and accounting companies fled the city for corporate parks in the suburbs. In the 1960's, club membership exceeded 1,000; in 1992, there are just 249 members.
"I, like others, feel extremely guilty that I didn't use it," said Roger Clapp, a Newark lawyer. If more members had used the club, he said, "it would still be alive."
 
'A Touch of Civility'
 Mr. Clapp, who called the club "a touch of civility in downtown Newark," recalled how Thomas Del Virginia, the 66-year-old doorman and general caretaker, greeted him by name after Mr. Clapp had been absent from the club for 20 years.
Other members say the closing of the Essex Club has created a huge void in terms of corporate entertainment. The club, they say, was the place to dine with an important guest. Members say there was not a recent governor who did not lunch there.
"The Essex Club stood for a lot; it stood for New Jersey," said Samuel C. Miller, a former member, who was also director of the Newark Museum. "There was never a decision made in New Jersey that was not first discussed in the Essex Club."
Today, business pacts are more likely negotiated over a phone or through a fax machine. But Mr. Miller says the pendulum swings every 15 years.
"For now, in Newark, the luncheon club is dead," he said. "In 15 to 20 years, the private club will be all the rage again."
 
Situated on Top Floor
 The Bellemead Development Corporation aims to lead the revival of clubs with its $2.5 million Newark Club. Situated on the top floor of One Newark Center, it was designed to feel like the Rainbow Room in Manhattan. The building also houses the Seton Hall Law School and numerous law firms.
Jim Servidea, vice president of marketing at Bellemead, said the Newark Club, which itself will operate at a loss, had been created to attract tenants. "If the market for office space was strong, we probably wouldn't create a club that has to be subsidized," he said. "But the Newark Club adds value. It offers a bigger package."
Bellemead runs the 60-year-old Roseland Eagle Rock Club in a corporate park in Roseland. Henry Sgrosso, executive director of both clubs, said, "If we just counted on lunch, which is about 30 percent of our business, we'd be out of business." The Eagle Rock Club is used for weddings, bar mitzvahs and Christmas parties.
The Newark Club will be a world apart from the older clubs like the Essex Club, which was established in 1876 and was considered the grandfather of social clubs in Newark.
Originally, the club was situated at 44 Park Place, where the Quality Inn/ Treet Hotel now stands. Club members bought the five-story Georgian-style town house facing Military Park in 1927. Built a century earlier, the club's building is listed in the National Register of Historic Places.
George William McCarter, a former member and Newark lawyer, said the Essex Club was "built like a man's club." The austere rooms with large fireplaces and grand silver-plated chandeliers gave the club an air of gentility.
 
Ballroom and Squash Courts
 The two most frequently used rooms were the first-floor Grill Room, where buffets were served, and the second-floor ballroom, where formal lunches and special events were held. The building also had two squash courts and numerous bedrooms, which were once lived in year round by elder members.
The Essex Club and others of its era were known to be elitist men's clubs. Although the club's rules did not exclude anyone from membership, the club did not admit women until 1975 or blacks until 1978.
Mourning the club's demise, Mr. Miller said, "To let the club die in such a way says something about the city."
What it says is that the city's vitality and power base have shifted from Broad Street, once home to prestigious law firms and large department stores, to the Gateway complex, civic leaders say.
Over the last six years, said Joseph Freiser, project development officer at the Newark Economic Development Corporation, more than $6 billion in office construction has revitalized the Gateway complex. Buildings like Gateway One and Two, A.T.& T., the N. J. Transit headquarters and the Newark Legal and Communications Center are almost fully leased. The $200 million New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts, which will be built on the site of the old Military Hotel, is slated to open in 1995.
Former members of the Essex Club, many of whose companies have moved to the Gateway, admit that the six- or seven-block walk to their club had become something of an effort. They say they have become accustomed to walking through linked steel-and-glass towers to find a salad or a sandwich for lunch.
Mr. Lippencott, whose law concern is in the N. J. Transit building, said that since the Essex Club's demise he has been experimenting with many of the Brazilian restaurants on Ferry Street in the Ironbound section. "I was glad I paid for feijoada before I knew what was in it," he said, referring to the stew that contains pig snout, jowls, black beans and rice. But now that he has learned about these ethnic specialties, he has begun taking clients to Brasilia, a plain restaurant that serves hearty fare. "It creates opportunity for local restaurateurs," he said.
While some of those who once patronized the clubs have ventured onto Newark's streets for lunch, many more stay locked up in the self-enclosed and self-sufficient worlds that office towers create.
Elizabeth Hull, a political science professor at Rutgers University, likens the throngs of workers in the sleek new office buildings to trailers that plug into local resources temporarily and then move on.
"People come and spend whole days within these complexes," she said. "There is little spillover into the community at large. There is no contact with the city. They don't even walk on the streets."
Like Newark, many urban centers contain abandoned areas once considered the grandest and most exclusive. Small town houses or older buildings that once housed the private clubs cannot compete with mammoth office complexes that offer their own restaurants.
Those who have been in Newark since the 1960's have watched the city transform from a riot-torn town to a rejuvenated business center. But they are painfully aware that the revitalization does not include old and revered institutions like the private eating clubs.
"Cities used to measure their values by keeping old establishments alive," said Clement Price, a Rutgers University history professory. "Tradition has been broken."

HEADLINE: Which Side Are You On?

BYLINE: By Nick Salvatore; Nick Salvatore, who teaches history at Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations, is writing a biography of Amos Webber, a 19th-century unskilled black worker.

 BODY:

"THE RIVER RAN RED"
Homestead 1892.
Edited by David P. Demarest Jr.
and Fannia Weingartner.
Illustrated. 232 pp. Pittsburgh:
University of Pittsburgh Press.
Cloth, $39.95.
Paper, $19.95.
 
THE BATTLE FOR HOMESTEAD, 1880-1892
Politics, Culture, and Steel.
By Paul Krause.
Illustrated. 548 pp. Pittsburgh:
University of Pittsburgh Press.
Cloth, $39.95.
Paper, $19.95.  
 ONE hundred years ago, workers at the Carnegie Steel Works in Homestead, Pa., six miles upstream from Pittsburgh on the Monongahela River, engaged in an epic battle with their employer. More than 3,800 workers, skilled and unskilled, native- and foreign-born, resisted the company's effort to reduce their wages. As the workers prepared to strike, management surprised them. Under the leadership of the chairman of the steel works, Henry Clay Frick (Andrew Carnegie, the owner, was conveniently in Scotland), the company locked out its employees, prepared to hire replacement workers and brought in two boatloads of Pinkerton security guards to protect the plant and the new workers.
As the Pinkerton boats approached the Carnegie pier on the morning of July 6, working men and women, some of them armed, gathered; and when the Pinkertons attempted to come ashore, a daylong battle ensued that resulted in numerous deaths on both sides. Outnumbered, the Pinkertons surrendered and were marched through a gantlet formed by the infuriated crowd, where they were pummeled and beaten. It was this image -- of angry, armed steelworkers joined by their irate, embattled women -- that garnered the press's attention and defined Homestead for much of the nation. This image also justified the use of the state militia to end the violence and, not incidentally, labor's resistance as well. The strike, which lasted five months, proved devastating for labor: the wage reductions held, many strikers were blacklisted, and the industry remained largely nonunion until the coming of the C.I.O.
The Homestead strike, along with other major confrontations in the railroad and mining industries at about the same time, raised serious questions about the meaning and future of American democracy. Could a democratic tradition that reverberated with the rhetoric of Jeffersonian individualism prove viable in an economy of emerging bureaucratic national corporations, mass production and increasingly routine work patterns? Would government, at both the state and Federal level, so align itself with corporate interests as to cede to them a major role in economic and political life?
In "The River Ran Red," David P. Demarest Jr., who teaches English at Carnegie-Mellon University, wants his readers to "be there" in order to answer those and other questions for themselves. His volume is a compilation of documents, taken primarily from the nation's press and from Congressional hearings, that detail the Homestead dispute. It also contains an arresting selection of graphics illustrating the conflict. The inclusion of private material, such as letters and diary selections, might have strengthened the book; yet these more public documents, collected here for the first time, nonetheless tell an important part of the story. The accompanying remarks by the contributing commentators, while occasionally given to florid prose, provide a useful, if necessarily limited, historical context.
In "The Battle for Homestead," Paul Krause, an assistant professor of history at the University of British Columbia, interprets the larger issues. Mr. Krause explores "the politics, culture and morality of steelmaking" in the late 19th-century United States and places the specific events of 1892 within a larger context. He therefore devotes a rather small proportion of his book to the actual conflict; rather, he sees Homestead as one part of the growth of a modern steel industry, its work force and a regional political system in the post-Civil War decades. Informative discussions about industrial development, the details of iron and steel production and aspects of political life follow. But Mr. Krause intends more than a mere narrative.
Central to his analysis is the belief that "labor republicanism" motivated the majority of Homestead workers. Rooted in a "classical republican tradition" that was formed by Machiavelli, British thinkers of the 18th century and American revolutionaries, this labor republicanism, in Mr. Krause's view, staunchly opposed capitalism, stressed cooperative rather than acquisitive principles and focused on the common good. Capitalism, specifically a capitalism dedicated to technological innovation, was its opponent.
In the hands of steelmakers such as Carnegie, the author states, technology undermined the traditional skills of craft workers, extracted greater profits by reducing labor costs and enthroned a "morality of improvement" that sought "to organize work, and indeed all public and private life, toward the achievement of maximum productivity and profit." In contrast, the belief in a communitarian labor republicanism distinguished these Homestead workers from capitalists and liberal labor reformers alike.
The problems with this analysis are manifold. While the debate over labor republicanism is now three decades old (having been initiated in the 1960's with the work of Herbert Gutman and David Montgomery), Mr. Krause reflects few of this discussion's intricacies. His almost Manichaean impulses lead him into simplistic divisions that cloud the more complex history. Steelmakers were not the only Americans enamored of scientific efficiency and material progress. These beliefs permeated the culture, influencing workers, railroad engineers and iron puddlers, as well as emerging middle-class professionals. Explaining this dominant cultural force as driven only by profits is reductionist.
Nor is Mr. Krause's rendering of labor republicanism reliable. He does not recognize that many 19th-century workers defended capitalism and democracy simultaneously; he ignores the individualist themes in the very tradition he extols as solely cooperative, and he fails to develop the empirical evidence for such a tradition beyond a small group of labor editors and activists. His treatment of the increasingly important unskilled immigrant work force in Homestead offers no sustained discussion of the meaning of their ethnic perspectives -- religious, fraternal and familial -- for labor republicanism.
Mr. Krause's understanding of labor reform politics and the working class is rather innocent. He invokes emotive language when noting the political failure of labor republicanism, but avoids dealing with the fact that the overwhelming majority of workers in the region consistently supported one or the other of the two major political parties. Against this reality his claim for an autonomous republic of labor lacks credibility. And his naivete is at times debilitating, as when he argues that a working-class candidate's refusal to identify himself as a socialist in an 1882 campaign "publicly signaled a momentous narrowing of American political discourse and possibilities." The outlook for socialism in a society whose individualist republican tradition gloried in its own revolutionary birth was always far less sanguine than Mr. Krause allows.
The important questions Mr. Krause raises concerning technology, democracy, economic development and the place of working people in the 19th-century United States remain more satisfactorily analyzed in Anthony F. C. Wallace's study of a Pennsylvania coal community, "St. Clair" (1987). Ultimately "The Battle for Homestead" disappoints because the author's beliefs too often substitute for the myriad voices of the historical actors he does not fully understand.
