HEADLINE: LONG DELAY LIKELY IN REBUILDING PLAN FOR TIMES SQUARE

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Conceding that the moment has come and gone for the vast redevelopment of Times Square, state and city officials are close to postponing indefinitely the four giant office towers that were supposed to lead 42d Street to a new day but ended up victims of a devastated market.
Rather than hold the Times Square Center project to the current timetable, which would probably force construction of the first skyscraper to begin next year, officials are asking the developers to revitalize for retail and entertainment use the four sites where the towers were to rise. 
 The Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty acquired the development rights to the parcels from the state in exchange for guarantees that included agreement that construction would follow a precise schedule.
 
Governor Outlines Elements
 "It's obvious now that real estate is overdeveloped for the time being," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said in a telephone interview yesterday, "and, therefore, it doesn't make sense to go forward immediately with the building of the office towers. There's no market for them. To hold these people to the contract is to ask them to commit an act of economic self-mutilation."
He said economic-development officials had, in effect, told the developers: "We'll allow you to wait for the market to get better. In return, we'd like you to accelerate the cleanup."
Most tenants have already been removed from the sites, along Broadway and Seventh Avenue between 41st and 43d Streets. Many of the existing buildings could be pressed into service again, although others might have to be razed.
Under the proposed overhaul of the plan, the developers would be able to proceed with the office towers when the market has improved. But that could be 3 to 10 years distant, if not more.
What they would get out of the deal, if they agreed to it, would be protection of the $180 million investment they have already made in condemnation awards to property owners whose land has been taken by the state, in addition to tens of millions of dollars in development costs. They would keep their claim on the sites and avoid a potential default.
"We want the buildings, but we don't want them empty," said Vincent Tese, chairman and chief executive officer of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. "A default doesn't do us any good."
Times Square Center, as conceived, was the engine that was supposed to drive the rejuvenation of 42d Street. It was to have more than four million square feet of offices, equal to the floor area of four Chrysler Buildings. The problem is that since the deal was approved by the city's Board of Estimate in 1984, vacancy rates have soared in Manhattan, fueled by a construction boom followed by a recession.
State and city officials have been negotiating with the developers for several months and are apparently near agreement, although not all of the issues are resolved, including how much the developers would be required to invest in the revitalization project. However, Mr. Cuomo said that in general "there is no intention to relieve the developers of any obligation."
City officials, citing the confidentiality of negotiations in progress, declined to discuss the matter.
As part of the overhaul, the developers would not have to pay in advance for rebuilding the Times Square subway station, an amount that had been set at $91 million. At the outset, that would be left to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, with reimbursement to come eventually from the rental income of the office towers.
The developers, who are leasing the sites from the state, would continue to pay condemnation awards, which could cost them at least $60 million more than what they have already invested.
The developers would also contribute $18 million for the renovation of two historic playhouses: the Liberty Theater, 234 West 42d Street, and another house, probably the Victory Theater, 207 West 42d Street.
Efforts to "clean up" 42d Street, which is both a thriving commercial strip and a potent symbol of blight and crime, go back many years. The current plan includes Times Square Center, the renovation of nearby theaters and the construction of a wholesale trade mart and hotel on Eighth Avenue.
In 1982, Park Tower, headed by George Klein, and Prudential were designated as developers of the office towers. Their architects were Philip Johnson and John Burgee.
The largest building, on the site between 42d and 43d Streets where the Toffenetti's and Nathan's Famous restaurants operated for many years, was to have 56 stories and 1.5 million square feet of space.
Park Tower and Prudential were required to begin building one tower within a year of receiving the first sites from New York State in "vacant possession," that is, without tenants. This deadline would probably have been reached in September 1993. They would have had to complete the structure no later than September 1995, by which time they would also have had to start a second building.
 
Delay Was Sought
 About six months ago, Mr. Tese said, the developers approached officials in the hope of renegotiating.
"We told them we were amenable," he said, "except there were certain things that we wanted that were important to us and that ought to be important to them. We think we got spectacular results from a bad situation."
Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, a subsidiary of the state development agency, said, "The quid pro quo for not having to build is that you have to bring 42d Street back to life."
That is to be done according to a plan that would be devised over the next six months by architectural and retail consultants.
Under this new plan, for example, the Nathan's Famous building might be leased again, as might storefronts in the Longacre Building next door and in the Rialto Theater. Facades would be refurbished and new signs would be be added above them.
Tenants might include restaurants, jazz and supper clubs, snack bars, tourist-information offices, souvenir shops, music and book stores, newsstands and theaters where multimedia "spectaculars," geared to tourists might be presented.


GRAPHIC: FEBRUARY 1981 -- State and city officials announce the 42d Street redevelopment project, to include four office towers on Broadway and Seventh Avenue, the renovation of historic theaters and construction of a wholesale trade mart and a hotel on Eighth Avenue.

AUGUST 1986 -- The law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, which was to have been a large tenant at Times Square Center, withdraws from the project.
JUNE 1988 -- Leases and development agreements are signed between the city and state and the development team.
JULY 1988 -- The state begins the condemnation process, which is slowed considerably by some 50 lawsuits.
APRIL 1989 -- Chemical Bank, which was expected to be a prime tenant at Times Square Center, withdraws from the project.
AUGUST 1989 -- The design by Mr. Johnson and Mr. Burgee is revised to make each of the towers different.
NOVEMBER 1991 -- Reports surface that the developers are seeking a delay, but state officials insist the project will not have to be slowed.
JULY 1992 -- The state reports that 230 of the 267 tenants have been relocated from the project area. (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: On the Mexican Market, Doubt Replaces Demand

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 2

 BODY:
When values in the Mexico City stock market plunged in June on false rumors that telephone workers would sell their stake in the monopoly Telefonos de Mexico, company officials tried to tell investors that it had all been a big misunderstanding. But the stock continued to drop.
When the Mexican exchange tumbled again in early July as the cement giant Cementos Mexicanos S.A. took over a Spanish company without warning or much explanation, business executives here acknowledged that there was a lesson in the failure to communicate. But two weeks later, the Mexican company bought another Spanish cement maker, investors complained again, and the stock fell once more. 
 After three years in which foreign investors helped fuel spectacular growth in Mexico City's stock market, the Bolsa de Valores, their lust for Mexican equities has begun giving way to doubt and even some disaffection. Since June, the market has dropped nearly 20 percent.
Analysts attribute the sudden shift to disparate forces: a glut of new Mexican equities that has finally outstripped the demand; a retrenchment of big international investors as other foreign markets turned down; sluggishness in the Mexican economy; and the failure of Canadian, American and Mexican officials to conclude their negotiations for a North American free-trade agreement after more than a year.
Yet the Bolsa's latest problems have also exposed a clash of culture in the lucrative relationship between big Mexican companies and their new foreign shareholders.
For American retail investors whose Mexican stocks may be their first investments abroad, the country's politics are never quite as clear as its economic policies. Even to more experienced buyers, Mexican accounting procedures can look like quantum physics. And although reporting on Mexican companies has increased geometrically, openness is hardly a Mexican corporate trademark.
In the world of secretive, family-owned enterprise from which many of the Bolsa favorites have come, the term "investor relations" has often meant that the investors are also relations.
"In general, Mexican companies have not been accustomed to having their actions questioned by investors or seeing such strong reactions in the price," said Pablo Riveroll, research director at the Mexico City office of Baring Securities. "Most of these companies have been very closely held."
 
Correcting a Correction
 Blips in market values after the reporting of better-than-expected second-quarter earnings for companies including the telephone company, known as Telmex, and some optimism about the trade agreement were as close as the market has come to a rebound since its June drop. But some analysts described this as a correction of the earlier correction: with values down to around 11 times projected 1992 earnings, many buyers are long-term investors taking advantage of prices they do not expect to last.
A conclusion to the trade negotiation, expected within weeks, would be a boon, although such news might have to be balanced against Democratic Party challenges to the agreement and slower Mexican economic growth. Barring any big developments, many brokers and analysts predict the Bolsa will continue to move sideways for months.
It will also apparently have some time to digest. When the market ran into trouble, companies were lining up behind the country's biggest financial house, Banacci S.A., to place billions of dollars in stock. Now, brokers and Government officials say, the market is expected to make them wait at least until the fall.
In all, Mexican companies sold $4.8 billion of new stock last year. By the middle of this June, when the market tumbled, they had placed another $4.3 billion -- the equivalent of about 10 percent of the Bolsa's actively traded shares, or float. With roughly $12 billion in new bank equities sold over the same period, the issues amounted to 6.7 percent of Mexico's gross domestic product.
 
A Flood of Foreign Funds
 The flood of new money explains much of the market's new volatility. Three years ago, the Bolsa was familiar to few non-Mexican investors and was played almost solely by those with a refined taste for risk. But from $4.25 billion at the beginning of 1991, foreign money in the Bolsa leaped to $27.2 billion in May, and now accounts for about one-fifth of the market's capitalization and more than half its float.
Today, while the total capitalization is still only about $130 billion and almost one-third of that is in Telmex, the Bolsa is the eighth-largest exchange in the world. Suddenly, its investors range from huge European pension funds to skittish Midwestern retirees.
"In the past four months, a lot of very unsophisticated investors -- people who invest on the basis of headlines -- have put money into Mexico," said Jorge O. Mariscal, manager of Latin American equity research at Goldman, Sachs.
As more foreigners have rushed into the market, Mexican companies have allayed their concerns about insider trading and loose regulation. Company analysis has increased, and many firms that have been questioned in the past have done better at showing their finances and strategies to be sound.
But communication problems persist.
 
'The Culture Here Is Very Closed'
 While "el roadshow" has become part of Mexican business lexicon, for instance, skeptical foreign investors have sometimes turned such presentations into "bloodbaths," said Jacques Levy, executive vice president of Mexico's most successful brokerage, Banamex/Accival.
"It is a cultural problem," he added. "The culture here is very closed. People don't take your telephone calls. They don't speak well in public, even in Spanish."
The rumor that Telmex workers were moving en masse to sell their 4.4 percent stake in the company illustrated the confusion. A few hours after the stock began to plunge in New York, Telmex sent the head of the Bolsa, Manuel Robleda, onto the floor to read a letter from the president of the telephone workers' union, denying plans to sell. When that did not work, company executives tried a hastily arranged video teleconference with some investors in New York. But the stock fell again the next day, leading several analysts to conclude that the problem ran deeper.
For all the talk of learning experiences, though, the Telmex dust had barely settled when Cementos Mexicanos, known as Cemex, found itself in similar trouble. When Cemex began buying up big chunks of Compania Valenciana de Cementos Portland S.A., Cemex officials were unavailable to answer questions. Even after one newspaper report overstated the cost of the deal by $500 million, the company gave only a spotty explanation of its plans.
The market shuddered at the thought of a favorite Mexican company reaching too far afield, and Cemex's stock dropped 10 percent in a day. Only then did the company turn to public relations consultants and begin issuing statements to try to clarify the deal.
Pulled by Cemex, the market fell 3.9 percent that week.
 
'Meltdown Scenario'
 In the wake of the market's recent troubles, some analysts have found a prophet in President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's discreet chief of staff, Jose Cordoba Montoya. In a speech to the annual Bolsa convention weeks earlier, Mr. Cordoba had warned against weak-handed investors and excessive new issues.
But the Salinas Administration's hand has generally not been so cautionary. A sell-off by the Telmex union would have represented a placement of some $800 million in new stock just weeks after the Government had sold 500 million of its own shares on Mexican and foreign markets. And when Banacci presented its first global share offering with hopes of raising as much as $1.4 billion, the Finance Minister, Pedro Aspe Armella, was on hand at the New York roadshow in an unusual show of official support. (As the market fell, the banking and brokerage firm at first halved its offering from 220 million shares and then canceled it altogether.)
Many brokers and economists believe the Salinas Administration has also made the market jittery by overselling the benefits of a free-trade pact.
"They have created a lot of expectations in the investment community that if it goes through it's a great thing and if it does not it's a horrible thing," Mr. Mariscal said. "On the basis of fundamentals, it may matter very little."
In the longer term, the flow of capital out of Mexico has refocused attention on what one broker in Mexico called "the meltdown scenario."
With the current account deficit at $11.9 billion last year, imports rising more quickly than the Government had hoped, and two-thirds of the $13 billion of foreign capital inflows last year going into portfolio investments, many economists have worried that money could move out of the economy much faster than imports could be stemmed. One Government economist called the estimated $1 billion to $2 billion that fled Mexico "the first real warning that we cannot rely only on speculative inflows."
Some economists were reassured by the momentary dearth of buyers for Telmex and other stocks, concluding there were limits to how fast money can flow out of the country. Emilio Icaza, director of research at the brokerage G.B.M., noted that the danger of money flowing out of Mexico through the stock market has also receded because so much trading in Mexican stocks is now done abroad and in dollars.
But in the coming years, Mexico's economic stability will depend on the more complicated transition from speculative money to greater savings and direct investment.
In that shift, a regional free-trade agreement is expected to be critical. After a trade accord is signed, Government officials say they will promulgate rules to encourage foreign investment, complementing changes that are already being made in mining, fishing and agriculture. The Government also established a new pension-fund system to encourage domestic savings.
"What Salinas is doing is correct," said Jonathan E. Heath, chief economist at Macro Asesoria Economica, a Mexico City consulting firm. "The question is: Will it be enough?"

HEADLINE: Japan Buys Too Few Chips, U.S. Finds

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The United States has concluded that Japan's efforts to open its semiconductor chip market to American exports are inadequate so far, but will not impose immediate sanctions, American officials said over the weekend.
In an agreement reached a year ago, the Japanese Government supported the American industry's goal of having foreign companies account for 20 percent of all chip sales in Japan by the end of 1992. The agreement, however, specified no penalties if the target was not met. 
 The foreign share, almost all of it American, has hovered between 14 and 15 percent for the last year. The lack of increase prompted the Office of the United States Trade Representative to announce on May 27 that it would review progress in the agreement by Aug. 1.
The review is now virtually complete and is scheduled for release this week, probably on Monday. The final report is critical of Japan but does not call for the United States to retaliate against Japanese exports, American officials said.
Japan blames weak economic growth for the stagnation in the foreign share of the chip market, saying the weakness has made electronics companies reluctant to do business with new suppliers. But that is a new argument, complained Daryl G. Hatano, the director of international trade and government affairs at the Semiconductor Industry Association, an American group.
Mr. Hatano said in an interview today that until recently the Japanese electronics industry had been blaming a quickly growing market for the low market share of foreign chip makers. Japanese officials used to contend that with the market in their country growing 10 percent a year American companies would have to increase their sales in Japan by 20 or 30 percent to increase market share, Mr. Hatano said.
According to the industry association, which is based in San Jose, Calif., Japan bought 47 percent of the $54.6 billion worth of semiconductors produced worldwide last year. Japanese companies accounted for 86 percent of the sales there, while American semiconductor companies had 12 percent of the Japanese market and companies from other countries had 2 percent.
In the United States market, meanwhile, American companies had a 70 percent share, Japanese semiconductor companies had 20 percent and other companies had 10 percent, according to the industry association.
Japanese officials have also sought in recent months to change the calculations to include all semiconductor shipments to Japan by the International Business Machines Corporation. Until recently, I.B.M. shipped chips to Japan only for inclusion in computers that it builds there. The agreement excludes wholly owned subsidiaries that do assembly work with imported chips, but does include subsidiaries that function as trading companies.
I.B.M.'s subsidiary has now begun selling chips to other manufacturers in Asia, including Hyundai in Korea, but in small quantities. American officials say these chips can be included in the foreign-market-share calculation, but are too small to matter and do not mean that I.B.M.'s operation in Japan now qualifies as a trading company.
By contrast, if all of I.B.M.'s shipments were included, the foreign market share would rise by up to two percentage points.

Japan Opposes U.S. Bill
 TOKYO, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Tokyo will appeal to the Gevena secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade if "protectionist" American legislation raising tariffs on mini-vans and sport utility vehicles becomes law, Japanese newspapers reported today.
The House of Representatives passed a bill on Friday that would reclassify some mini-vans and utility vehicles as trucks, subjecting them to a tenfold increase in import duties. The bill now goes to the Senate.
"This is clearly in violation of GATT," Asahi Shimbun quoted Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry as saying, referring to the world body that governs free trade. The report noted that because European cars were effectively excluded, the legislation was clearly aimed at Japan.
The bill includes two exemptions that could exclude European mini-vans, like those made by Volkswagen, that have been imported since 1963 and vehicles with sales of less than 10,000 a year, like Britain's Range Rover.
The Bush Administration opposes the mini-van reclassification on the grounds that it would raise costs to consumers, could be seen as a violation of GATT and could result in retaliation against American exports. On Thursday, President Bush threatened to veto the bill.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
After Riots, A Paradise Lost for Advertisers

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Three months after riots rocked Los Angeles, Southern California advertisers are slowly coming to grips with the psychic damage to consumers. Many ad agency executives are trying to soft-pedal the city's uneasiness. A few are trying to exploit it. And some, by coincidence, are soothing frayed nerves with campaigns planned well in advance of the riots.
Images of Los Angeles seen throughout the United States and the world are also due for revision. For example, the Los Angeles Convention and Visitors Bureau will roll out a $25 million to $30 million marketing campaign next year to help the city's recession-wracked tourist industry, which has been depressed even more by recent earthquakes as well as the deadly racial disorders and their aftermath. 
 But for now, the immediate target of post-riot advertising is local consumers.
 
'Tomorrow Will Be Better'
 Some campaigns conceived months before the riots erupted, like Pacific Bell's "Perfection" television spots by Foote, Cone & Belding, attracted considerable attention in their wake. A series of images of Californians improving themselves, "Perfection" is interlaced with eerily comforting lines like: "To the outside world, we appear lucky just to survive" and "It's just another day in California. Tomorrow will be better."
The campaign was scheduled to start production around April 29, the day the riots began, when Pacific Bell's advertising director, Allen Olivio, conferred with Foote, Cone.
"Given increased sensitivity," he said, "we wanted to make sure we weren't going to be insulting with the idea of continuous improvement and the notion of achievable perfection." After a few days, Mr. Olivio decided that Los Angeles was beginning to regain its balance and production went ahead unchanged.
Many Los Angeles advertising executives consider product advertising to be an inappropriate venue for responding to social unrest -- nothwithstanding the sportswear maker Benetton's billboard of a burning car, which was taken down in Los Angeles after the riots.
Some advertising executives said ads like the Benetton billboard could easily be misunderstood. "The possibility of messages being misperceived as insulting or offensive is great," said Jo Muse, chairman of Muse Cordero Chen in Los Angeles, which specializes in advertising to black, Asian and Hispanic consumers. "Even advertising that tries to accomplish social good, that is altruistic, will sometimes be misunderstood in the area of advertising."
On the other hand, Mendelsohn/ Zien Advertising chose to create a campaign for Wok Fast, a food-delivery company, that dealt directly, and flippantly, with the tensions in Los Angeles. In late June, a billboard was put up in West Los Angeles with a picture of Daryl F. Gates, the Los Angeles Police Chief who had to be pressured into retiring after the riots. The caption on the billboard read: "When you can't leave the office. Or won't. Great Chinese food delivered."
Initially, the agency's president, Richard Zien, figured that the publicity for the chain would outweigh the risk of legal action by the former chief. But by mid-July, Mr. Gates had threatened to sue. So, Mr. Zien said, "we agreed to take it down because our mission was accomplished."
In contrast, a few Los Angeles ad agencies are proposing campaigns to connect consumers with Rebuild L.A., a local business organization that was formed after the riots. Farada Fotouhi, president of Fotouhi Alonso, said she was urging clients to tell consumers that a percentage of their purchases would go toward product donations to Rebuild L.A.
"If a company positions itself as socially active, that encourages consumers, particularly those who want to help, to buy from that company," she said, adding that several clients are considering her proposal.
Beyond the West Coast, consumers are likely to see an alteration of the classic fun-in-the-sun image of Los Angeles, which now no longer seems to fit the city.
"In the past, not just Los Angeles but California had this mystique to it that a lot of advertisers drew upon," said Bob Wolf, chief executive of North America for Chiat/Day/Mojo in Los Angeles. "We've done one that tried to capture it -- a California Cooler campaign with the 60's thing, making coolers on the beach. But I think advertisers will be wary of using that currency again."
 
'Finding a Comfortable Area'
 Advertising executives are gradually trying to create new positive images for Los Angeles. "They're finding a comfortable area where they can mirror those interests in the American lexicon without making people mad," Mr. Muse said. "For instance, a lot has been said about the new street-wear designers -- I could see an ad with two young black guys having a clothing company."
Still, while local advertising executives are sensitive to the recent shocks dealt consumers, some believe that the recession remains a much more important factor in advertising. "Price and value will continue to dominate," predicted Phil Joanou, chairman and chief executive of Dailey & Associates.
As for rebuilding confidence in Los Angeles, he said, "What is required more than advertising is some political leadership."
For Howie Cohen, chairman and creative director of Cohen/Johnson in Los Angeles, price-and-value ads are themselves socially redeeming. "They work," he said. "They move stuff. Those able to lift their heads above the debris will be those who are able to help the suffering. I'm not unique in saying I care and I feel, but I also know I need to keep business going for those who depend on me."

HEADLINE: Job-Ad Index Eased in June

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
An index of help-wanted advertising edged lower in June, the Conference Board said yesterday, indicating that wary employers had held back on hiring.
The seasonally adjusted index fell to 92 in June, one point below May's revised level of 93, the business research group said in its monthly report. The June 1991 figure was 96. 
 "We're at a standstill: while labor-market indicators are not declining, they are showing very few signs of improvement," said a Conference Board economist, Ken Goldstein.
 The unemployment rate reached an eight-year high of 7.8 percent in June. July's jobless rate is to be reported on Friday, and economists expect only slight improvement.
The rise in the May and June unemployment rates hurt consumer confidence, but the real labor market problem is "the lack of any substantial and sustained improvement," Mr. Goldstein said.
Advertising volume rose in four regions and declined in five, the report said. The New England region's 8.4 percent gain was the largest. Steepest declines were registered by the West North Central region, down 10 percent, and the West South Central area, off 8.6 percent.
 The board monitors help-wanted advertising volume in 51 leading newspapers across the country.

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief's Dispute With Council Boils Over

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 30

 BODY:
The peacemakers who run the United Nations are fighting again.
Not since the days of Dag Hammarskjold, the Secretary General from Sweden, who locked horns three decades ago with the Soviet delegation over policy on the Congo, have the Security Council's permanent members been confronted with a Secretary General so determined to shape the international organization. 
 The French press has called the dispute "la petite guerre" because the diplomats here have been, at moments, so undiplomatic.
 
The Limits of Diplomacy
 "You have to be a diplomat at certain times and at certain times you have not to be a diplomat," said Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the former Egyptian Foreign Ministry official who took over as Secretary General from Javier Perez de Cuellar in January.
"Certain facts have to be said," he insisted.
The dispute, which had been building all year, broke into the open in mid-July. The Council and the Secretary General had pointed differences over how to stop the killing in fractured Yugoslavia and how to save millions of starving people in Somalia, where civil war has led to famine. Mr. Boutros-Ghali challenged the Security Council's decision to expand the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Yugoslavia if this was to occur at the expense of urgently needed peacekeeping and relief operations in black Africa.
Both sides compromised, but the dispute has festered and at times has erupted into a collision of cultures between the Secretary General, who feels compelled to speak for the less powerful nations of the third world, and the Western powers that dominate the Security Council.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali, the sixth man to hold the top peacemaking job and the first from an Arab country, Egypt, and from the African continent, sees the dispute as a clash between the "colonial" powers of Europe and the desperate and often neglected developing world.
 
Discord in Crucial Period
 The episode is producing an unusual degree of disharmony at a time when the United Nations is more heavily engaged around the world than at any other time in its 47-year history. It has caused bitter and personal recriminations, aborted a sensitive United Nations dialogue with Libya last week and injected a level of discord that could further disrupt and delay critical Security Council decisions, a number of United Nations officials and diplomats said.
The United Nations has major operations in Cambodia, Iraq, the Western Sahara and now in what was Yugoslavia. It is also involved in longstanding operations in Cyprus and Lebanon and is undertaking new efforts in Somalia and South Africa.
All of these have deepened the financial crisis brought on by the $2 billion in arrears from donor nations, including $800 million that the United States has not paid.
One Western diplomat has described the Secretary General's recent actions as "petulant," "inflexible" and "disingenuous." Others have faulted him for being prickly, "arrogant" and "aloof."
Mr. Boutros-Ghali was no less blunt, pointing out that the Security Council had for the most part acceded to his views on Yugoslavia and Somalia. He bristled at the criticism he has received recently in the British press and wondered aloud in an interview on Thursday if it was "maybe because I'm a wog," using the 19th-century British pejorative for colonial subjects.
His characterizations stunned United Nations officials, who avoid even the hint of ethnic epithet. Sir Brian Urquhart, the longtime United Nations Under Secretary who is now at the Ford Foundation, could only gasp on hearing Mr. Boutros-Ghali's reference to the possible "wog" factor: "My my . . . dear me. . . ."
 
A Longing for Yesteryear
 A French diplomat lamented that in the days of Mr. Perez de Cuellar the Secretary General was "more consensual" and "when the Council wanted something, the Secretary General was at their disposal." Indeed, many missions have been surprised by what some view as Mr. Boutros-Ghali's imperious and mercurial style.
The Secretary General often goes over the heads of delegates to deal directly with their Foreign Ministry bosses. Adding to an image of aloofness, he seldom shows up for informal meetings of the Security Council because, he said, of the crushing workload that has been placed on the Secretariat to streamline the organization and run proliferating peacekeeping operations.
The Secretary General, the French diplomat added, "has his own personality and we cannot expect him to act and to react as his predecessor." But, he concluded, "if this kind of relationship continues, I don't think it is favorable for anyone."
The stress of Mr. Boutros-Ghali's first seven months was apparent in the interview. The normally relaxed and witty 69-year-old Egyptian scholar, most famous for having been at the side of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt when he flew to Jerusalem in 1977, fidgeted with a bundle of pencils in front of him as he sat at the felt-covered conference table in the cavernous Secretary General's suite on the 38th floor of what Mr. Boutros-Ghali calls "this house."
 
Some Blunt Talk
 In assailing his critics, he lapsed at times from the high language of pin stripes to seething denunciations. On several occasions he ordered a reporter to turn off a tape recorder so he could answer more bluntly. Pointing to the machine, he snapped, "Please stop it," before responding to what he said was "another lie."
Speaking in English in which Arabic and French accents blended, he acknowledged that, at times, his behavior had been less than diplomatic, but he said that was not the problem.
"The problem is, one, the ego of certain members of the Security Council are accustomed to being treated in a certain way. Secondly, because maybe I don't spend enough time with them, certainly this is the second reason. But the simple explanation is high policy -- the policy of the states."
He further explained, saying: "When a country is in difficulty with its public opinion concerning what to do in Yugoslavia, or when there are other problems, they are a monster. They will not hesitate to find the body to accuse him of all the sins."
Asked if he meant that too many countries were hoisting their problems and frustrations onto the United Nations, he said, "Certainly, to the Secretary General, to the U.N." He suggested that a combination of what he termed "Europecentrism" and the inability of third world nations to address their economic and social ills was the greatest obstacle to building an effective United Nations program for the future.
 
'So Many Problems'
 "The real problem of the next 10 years will be mainly in the countries of the third world," he said, "and the problems of the third world is not only the military confrontations, but the problem of refugees, hunger, drought. So many problems."
But he added: "If we continue to get involved in Yugoslavia, this will be at the expense of the other activity of the house. At a certain time, we must say, 'Stop.' "
With the perennial shortage of cash, Mr. Boutros-Ghali warned in May that "our plate is full," and that any new peacekeeping responsibilities would have to come at the expense of other urgently needed relief and peacekeeping efforts.
Then, on July 17, the Security Council, with Mr. Boutros-Ghali absent, accepted a cease-fire accord for Yugoslavia hammered out by Lord Carrington of Britain and a European Community team of negotiators in London. The accord, which failed to stop the fighting, would have placed a significant burden on the United Nations by sending its forces into the combat zone to locate and collect the dueling artillery batteries in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
When Mr. Boutros-Ghali learned of the Security Council's action, he objected, arguing that collecting the guns would take three months and 1,100 men. He also feared that such actions would draw United Nations forces into a what he termed "a new Vietnam" that would strain United Nations resources at a time when they were needed elsewhere, particularly in Somalia, where a quarter of the population of 4.5 million to 6 million is facing death from famine this summer.
"I believe it is my duty to put the minimum pressure on the Europeans to say, 'Try to do something,' " he said. When the French military Chief of Staff told him that French and other European military forces could complete the artillery survey in Yugoslavia in three days, Mr. Boutros-Ghali seized on this assertion to put more pressure on the European powers to take part in bringing peace to their own region.
The United Nations Charter, Mr. Boutros-Ghali has become fond of saying, states that "the regional organizations" like the European Community and the Western European Union "are at the service of the United Nations, not that the United Nations is at the service of the regional organizations."
Sir Brian said he thought the Secretary General was right to be upset over how the London accord was handled. "You cannot suddenly tell a guy who is responsible for a peacekeeping operation that you are going to add an enormous burden to a group that is hopelessly overstressed," he said.
 
'Under Great Pressure'
 At the same time, Sir Brian added that he thought it "very odd" for the Secretary General to "widen the issue" by accusing the Council of being Eurocentric.
"I think he is under great pressure," he said, adding, "The European efforts to deal with Yugoslavia have been hopeless and it may be useful for them to blame the U.N. if nothing is happening."
There was more than a hint of scorn in Mr. Boutros-Ghali's voice over Lord Carrington's refusal to go to Sarajevo to try to wring a lasting cease-fire accord out of the warring factions. He contrasted the talks held at a safe distance in London with the willingness of Cyrus R. Vance, the former American Secretary of State, to conduct negotiations where the fighting was taking place.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali said that when Lord Carrington's accord collapsed, the Europeans "just threw the ball" to the United Nations
 
'Backstabbing' Politics
 One United Nations diplomat, defending the Secretary General, sneered at the "backstabbing" politics of the Security Council and wondered why the Europeans could not take on some of the military burden.
"Of course they are worried about their boys being killed, so they would rather have Fijians do it for them," the diplomat said, referring to the Fijian contingent among United Nations peacekeeping forces.
By all accounts, in pouncing on Lord Carrington's handiwork Mr. Boutros-Ghali not only angered the former British Foreign Minister, but also embarrassed Sir David Hannay, the British representative at the United Nations, who had pushed the London accord through the Security Council in the Secretary General's absence.
Western diplomats point out that the Mr. Boutros-Ghali had two representatives in the chamber when the Council acted and must therefore share the blame for the failure of coordination and communication.
Western officials also said that despite the eloquence of Mr. Boutros-Ghali on behalf of Somali famine victims, he had been slow to recognize that the staff member he put in charge of the negotiations was not up to the task and only belatedly removed him.
Despite the problems, the Secretary General predicted that his "controversy" with the Security Council would pass.
"This is quite exaggerated," he said of the dispute, "and I will say it is healthy."
He admonished a reporter at the end of the interview not to "provoke" or strain his relationship with the Security Council further because, he said, "it is my job to be provocative."

HEADLINE: SPARKILL JOURNAL;
Black Church Links Suburbs and New York City

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

DATELINE: SPARKILL, N.Y.

 BODY:
IN an old stone church here, a small congregation is setting out to show the world that the walls separating blacks in suburbia from those in the city can come tumbling down.
The parishioners of the St. Charles African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church used to anguish over youths caught up in street violence. They lamented the lack of role models. Then they would retreat into their comfortable homes in this Rockland County community, where the pond is laced with duckweed and everyone turns out for potluck dinners and the annual Shad Fest on the church grounds. 
 It took the riots in Los Angeles and later the disturbances in Washington Heights, they say, to shake up their congregation, composed mainly of middle-class professionals, educators and retirees. The 130 church members stopped talking about what they thought needed to be done and moved into action.
Every weekday morning now, a dark-blue church van rumbles across the George Washington Bridge into the heart of Harlem to pick up homeless children housed in a shelter run by the Abyssinian Baptist Church. Their destination: a day-camp program called "Reach Out Suburbia."
"It just gives them another perch from which to think about their world," said Clarence Branch Jr., the chairman of the St. Charles trustee board and a high school science teacher. On a recent afternoon, he led some young charges across a rushing creek on a nature study.
"There's an obvious need for people of different backgrounds, races, ethnic and economic groups to get to know each other better," said Mr. Branch. "We're walled off in these communities and this isolation prevents people from seeing that we can get along."
Church officials hope their program will serve as a model for other black churches and organizations in suburban communities. It is long overdue in the view of the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church. "They are doing something that very few black families in the suburban communities are willing to do," Mr. Butts said. "It's a marvelous gesture on the part of the people of Rockland County. It gives youngsters another perspective of how African Americans live."
As part of the program, the children are welcomed into the homes of church members like Albert and Jacqueline Holland, who recently had a swimming-pool party for the children at their cooperative complex.
Mr. Holland, a lawyer who grew up as a teen-ager in Harlem, said he had always wanted to give back something to the community where he once lived. "This shows what the other side is doing and gives them something to aim for," he said.
Corey Walcott, a wiry boy of 12, said movies and television had taught him that only whites seem to have the nice things in life. He said his perception is changing every day with his trips to Rockland County. "When you see people like us who've got something like this, it makes you feel good," he said. "When I grow up, I want to have the same thing."
Frances Pierson, 77 years old, who is described as the church matriarch, said she hoped the experience would teach the children more about a sense of community than about material success. "Everybody belongs to everybody," she said. "That is what we want to impart. We hope what they see and hear will have a positive influence over their thoughts and maybe change some attitudes."
The program accommodates 20 children who are 12 years old or under. Parishioners said they intended to keep track of the youths into adulthood as the program continues to grow. For now, church officials say, the program is fueled on church money and faith, but in fact there is more because this is a savvy church flock.
Some of the most influential leaders in the city were sought out to insure the modest proposal takes hold. The program got the blessing of Mr. Butts, whose church is a flagship institution in Harlem and whose endorsement may later lead to corporate financing.
Mayor David N. Dinkins also wished the church well.
The program also has won acceptance from parents like Lashe Walcott, who watched from the sidewalk in Harlem as the church van picked up her two children, ages 12 and 9.
The 28-year-old mother said she could not imagine what Rockland County was like, but she was relieved that her children were heading out of a neighborhood where some people called them "bums."
"If you let them stay out here, they'll eventually think the streets are what it's all about," she said. "Maybe that's what they might want for their kids when they get older, to live in the suburbs."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Risks and Hopes of Salzburg's New Face

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALZBURG, Austria, July 31

 BODY:
It is no accident that during his first week as artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, Gerard A. Mortier programmed two works about Roman emperors and the exercise of power: Mozart's opera "La Clemenza di Tito" and Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar." The first showed the pains of power, the second its nearly insurmountable dangers. Mr. Mortier will have reason to get to know both; there are more than enough people in town who seem to be showing that lean and hungry look.
But Mr. Mortier is too acutely aware of the importance of signs and portents in artistic governance to ignore the risks. The Salzburg Festival has always dealt in symbols of authority, from the way its founders in the 1920's used a series of musical and dramatic morality tales -- "Everyman," "Faust" and "Don Giovanni" -- to emphasize the spiritual ground of Austrian and German art, to the way the festival concert halls use the ancient rock cliff that towers over the town as foundation and backdrop. Mr. Mortier just has a different set of symbols. His first season, to run until the end of August, is a declaration of independence from the previous regime, which lasted 30 years under the firm control of Herbert von Karajan. Mr. Mortier has moved quickly and decisively. For some, that is the problem. 
 It is estimated, for example, that 20 percent of the old guard supporters have dropped out. There are hotels in town that have gone out of their way to discourage ticket purchases. It is also possible to find a vacant hotel room and, on occasion, even buy a ticket to a festival event, outlandish for Salzburg. And there is some muted caution among record companies: Mr. Mortier has said that Salzburg opera productions will no longer be coordinated with the release of recordings. He has even suggested that there might be a better way for the companies to spend the estimated $10 million they allot for publicity and posters and press conferences at the festival. There have also been unprecedented withdrawals by major stars: Riccardo Muti and Marilyn Horne over artistic disagreements, Jessye Norman because she is canceling her European tour.
The stakes are enormous. This festival is the world's largest, and Karajan ran it like a fief: the native son exercising his divine right. Because of his influence, record companies came to this town where Mozart was born, paying stores to display their posters, stroking their artists. An extraordinary network with Karajan at its center spread through the music world from Salzburg; it included major managers in New York (Ronald Wilford) and Paris (Michael Glotz), close relations with video and electronics companies (Telemondial and Sony) and recording companies (Deutsche Grammophon and EMI), contractual arrangements with two of the most distinguished orchestras in the world (the Berlin and Vienna Philharmonics), the ability to draw stars and a wealthy audience and have them each bask in the glow of the other.
In 1990, the Austrian Government estimated that the festival brought 2.2 billion schillings, or $220 million, into the national economy; $70 million was spent directly by visitors to Salzburg. The private jets and high-priced tickets, the lines of stargazers in front of the Festspielhaus, the opera productions that had their premieres in conjunction with new recordings by the same casts: all that was due to Karajan's influence. When Wilhelm Furtwangler died in 1954, the choice of his successor as conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic was so obvious that Karajan was sent a telegram by a supporter: "The King is dead. Long live the King." When Karajan died in 1989, Mr. Wilford, the president of Columbia Artists Management, himself no minor player in what Karajan once called "the game of the powerful," said that now the proper proclamation would be "God save the Republic."
As with Shakespeare's Caesar, the ruler had no heir. At a news conference on Thursday, a spokesman for the Vienna Philharmonic, Werner Resel, noted the end of an era of Kultifiguren -- cult figures -- who dominated music; who of Karajan's stature, with his business sense and artistic appeal, could run the festival? Something had to change. There had even been increasing unhappiness with Karajan's reign, complaints about cliquishness and stolidity. In fact, the search for a successor began a year before Karajan's death.
Enter Mr. Mortier. According to Hans Landesmann, appointed by the Government to head a search committee for a new artistic director, Mr. Mortier, the director of the Theatre Royal de la Monnaie in Belgium, was chosen because he "represented the most obvious change," the greatest contrast with Karajan. Beginning with a career in public relations, then working with the Flanders Festival and as administrative assistant to the conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi in Frankfurt and Hamburg, Mr. Mortier's reputation rests on a decade of work in Brussels. In opera, he emphasized production, design and dramatic direction. He admired such contemporary composers as Pierre Boulez and proselytized for neglected repertory, selling out 35 performances of "Lulu" and "Wozzeck" and drawing attention to the operas of Janacek.
Mr. Mortier arrived in Salzburg to interview for the festival position just after Karajan's death and took office in September 1991 in a completely revised administrative structure; an attempt, again, to alter the character of the festival. It is now run by three directors: a local Salzburger, Heinrich Wiesmuller, as president; Mr. Landesmann as financial officer and programmer of the concert series, and Mr. Mortier with the title of intendant. All have six-year contracts and theoretically share responsibility; they are answerable to a board that includes four government officials from the city, state and national governments, and one local representative of the Salzburg tourist board.
Mr. Mortier, 48 years old, has no illusions about the difficulties of the tasks before him. Not only is he an outsider in a town loyal to insiders, he is also unraveling traditions that many local people, ranging from hotel owners to high-society types, have found effective. But he takes pains to acknowledge the achievements of Karajan, praising him, not burying him: "I was a great fan of the festival during the 60's," he said, "a great lover of Karajan. But in the 80's he didn't care as much." The festival became increasingly commercialized, the local audiences less involved.
His plans are ambitious. As he said in an interview, he wants to move the festival away from its origins: "When the Salzburg Festival began, there was only Bayreuth. Now there are hundreds of musical festivals. Salzburg must distinguish itself."
Mr. Mortier would keep Mozart -- that disenchanted Salzburger -- at the festival's heart but would move Shakespeare into Goethe's place. He wants the festival to be a celebration of European culture and, with the inclusion of the United States, of Western culture. This year France has a major presence with Messiaen and Debussy. Next year there will be an Italian accent with Verdi's "Falstaff" and "Giovanna d'Arco," with Monteverdi's "Orfeo" (conducted by Rene Jacobs) and "Poppea" (led by Nikolaus Harnoncourt), along with presentations of works by Luigi Nono. There is also a look toward Eastern Europe, with Janacek this year and Bartok and Ligeti next.
This cosmopolitan perspective is also meant to treat the 20th century as part of the mainstream European tradition. Mr. Mortier will have composers in residence, like Mr. Boulez this year. In opera, Mr. Mortier plans more Janacek, a "Rake's Progress" (possibly directed by Peter Sellars), "Lulu," "Pelleas" and "Moses und Aron." He has talked, too, about giving operas that have had recent premieres their second major productions.
This is radically different from the traditional Salzburg festival, though in drama, Mr. Mortier plans to return to the festival's early interests, when the German director Max Reinhardt had a central role in its founding and planning. Last year plays accounted for 12,000 tickets out of the 200,000 available for all festival events; this year they amount to 25,000; next year the number will more than double to 58,000. Mr. Mortier hired the German director Peter Stein as manager of theater productions.
The biggest challenge will be marketing the festival: new -- and wealthy -- audiences will have to be found. "My most difficult season," Mr. Mortier said, "will be the next one." He has begun the changes by establishing one-week subscriptions to events, with 2,400 sold this season; people under 25 can subscribe at half price thanks to donations by corporate sponsors. Contemporary music is often being marketed in separate categories at different prices. The problem is that ticket sales in 1990 provided about 46 percent of the festival's $48.2 million of income; prices range up to $360. And the audience that is able and eager to pay those sums may be looking for something quite different from what Mr. Mortier is planning.
The president of Deutsche Grammophon, Andreas Holschneider, sees a fundamental shift in the festival's emphasis: "It is now more on the message than on the star." This is bound to affect the recording business in Salzburg. Deutsche Grammophon, as the first company to open an office at the festival, 25 years ago, is not overly concerned; stars will, of course, still be required. But ultimately, Mr. Holschneider noted, "all companies will have to think over whether their presence and exposure in Salzburg is really in the line of the new festival."
The audiences are also thinking things over. Count Johannes Walderdorff, who was a close friend of Karajan (he was one of the few people at the private funeral) and oversees the Salzburg social scene as proprietor of the Goldener Hirsch Hotel, is optimistic but guarded. Some of his clientele have balked, others are intrigued. In response to demand from new donors to the festival, for example, an additional performance of "Salome" was added for the end of August.
At performances I attended this week, audience response was committed and justly enthusiastic. The baritone Dmitri Khvorostovsky gave a virile, nuanced recital of Russian song. Mr. Dohnanyi conducted the Cleveland Orchestra in a witty performance of Weill's "Sieben Todsunden" (with Anja Silja as soloist). And many performances of Mr. Stein's "Julius Caeser" ended with standing ovations.
In the meantime, there is a lot of breath-holding in town. Mr. Mortier must walk a fine line, finding a role for the festival without allowing it to become a center for another variety of esthetic fashion; courting new audiences without losing the old; altering the tradition without losing its weight. Mr. Mortier, during a conversation, pointed to the logo of the festival, a Greek mask behind a draped flag and an image of the town's famous Hohensalzburg fortress. "It is a little Fascistic, no?" he asked. "But it can be changed later. Everything a little bit at a time." Mr. Mortier, who must answer to both higher and lower powers, is not about to underestimate the power of symbols. He must find a way, in the midst of his artistic transformations, to render unto Caesar what is Caesar's.

HEADLINE: Let's Contain the Supercollider

 BODY:
The superconducting supercollider, an enormous and costly instrument for probing the structure of matter, poses a stark issue for the Senate today:
Should the nation, faced with recession and budget deficits, continue to build an $8-billion machine to explore scientific questions that are of great intellectual interest but may have little practical payoff? Or should it write off the $1 billion spent so far and terminate the project? 
 The House voted in June to cancel the project as unaffordable. But President Bush traveled to the construction site in voter-rich Texas last week to declare support for "one of the greatest scientific projects in the entire world." The Senate is expected to approve further funding today, setting the scene for a showdown with the House over whose view will prevail.
On the merits, the mammoth machine is worth building -- provided it can be financed without robbing a host of other vital scientific projects.
The supercollider will be a huge underground instrument, 54 miles in circumference. It will accelerate two beams of protons in opposite directions around a giant ring lined with magnets. When the protons smash together, they will release showers of debris from which scientists hope to divine a deeper understanding of the fundamental forces and particles that shape the universe.
Unlike the controversial space station, which is primarily an engineering feat, the supercollider is at the cutting edge of research in two important fields. It is a key to further advance in high-energy physics, which seeks to find the most elementary particles and forces from which everything else is made. And its findings will shed light on events at the very creation of the universe, the domain of cosmology.
Even critics don't quibble that the supercollider will perform good science. But its relative importance remains in dispute. Some critics note that a large accelerator now being built in Europe may answer some of the same questions. Others contend that less costly small-scale physics is even more important because it involves more scientists and students, and it studies phenomena that are relevant to the every-day world.
Proponents have greatly exaggerated their case. They suggest, plausibly, that the machine might revolutionize our understanding of force and matter. But they neglect to mention that it may prove a dud, finding little of interest. And they predict spinoff benefits for industry and medicine without acknowledging that $8 billion invested more broadly in science might yield even greater benefits.
Proponents have repeatedly low-balled their cost estimates, only to revise them upward. And they insist that foreign nations will foot part of the bill, with little to show for their optimism.
In the past, this page has opposed the collider for fear its escalating costs would divert funds from more fruitful research. But with care and determination, it now looks possible to do both. Project managers seem finally to have stabilized their costs and surmounted the most worrisome technological hurdle -- the huge superconducting magnets.
The collider should be completed because it will perform pioneering research in a field long dominated by the U.S. but where Europe is taking the lead. It would be a shame for a great nation to shrink from this intellectual adventure.
The project should be canceled only if it threatens to damage other fields of science, thus doing more harm than good.
Congress could assure the happier outcome by continuing the collider while setting firm limits to the total budget for high energy physics in future years. That way the new machine could be financed largely by shrinking or closing its obsolescent predecessors. Resources would not need to be drained from other vital research.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Yesterday's Man

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
The men were taken from the village at gunpoint and forced into freight cars. As many as 180 were jammed, standing, into boxcars measuring 39 by 6 feet. They were kept that way for three days, without water or food, as the train moved slowly across the countryside.
Nazis transporting Jews in 1942? No, Serbs transporting Muslim Bosnians in 1992: one glimpse of the worst racial and religious bestiality Europe has known since World War II. 
 When Bill Clinton called for meaningful action to stop such Serbian atrocities, the Bush campaign denounced him as "reckless." Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's spokesman, said Governor Clinton was "unaware of the political complications in Yugoslavia."
That Fitzwater phrase reminded me of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain explaining in 1938 why Britons should not care about Nazi designs on Czechoslovakia: It was, Chamberlain said, "a quarrel in a faraway country between people of whom we know nothing."
Neville Chamberlain, his country and the world learned the price of ignoring Hitler's aggression against a faraway country. And similarly, what the Serbs call "ethnic cleansing" in Bosnia and Herzegovina -- the murder and transport of Croats and Muslims -- has the gravest implications for Europe and the world.
The Serbian onslaught is, in fact, the model of the next great challenge to international peace and order. The West, which marshaled its political and military resources to maintain the peace through the cold war, must now confront the problem of ethnic conflict overlapping national boundaries.
President Bush has been a veritable Neville Chamberlain in refusing to face the challenge in Yugoslavia. He has dithered, deferred to a Europe that was looking to him for leadership, refused to call for the international military action that everyone knows is the only way to stop the Serbian aggression.
The excuse for his inaction has been that the Serbian war on the other peoples of what was Yugoslavia has not aroused the American public. But Americans were not greatly exercised about Iraq's occupation of Kuwait either -- until George Bush skillfully used all his powers as President to bring the country into the Persian Gulf war.
But there was oil in Kuwait, the Bush people say, and there is no such American interest in Yugoslavia. No, nothing except the European stability that has been at the heart of our international policy for decades.
Again it is argued that the ethnic situation in what was Yugoslavia is complicated. True. But the essence of what has happened there is simple. Michael T. Kaufman of The New York Times, after traveling in four of the Yugoslav republics, wrote:
"What has been going on is fundamentally a Serbian war of aggression waged largely against civilians. . . . It is guns and ammunition supplied by Belgrade that are killing civilians in areas beyond the borders of Serbia. . . . Serbian forces everywhere have resorted to the same tactic of sustained artillery shelling of cities, towns and villages."
President Bush compared Saddam Hussein to Hitler. I am against such analogies, because they cheapen the Holocaust. But if that one is to be used, it better fits the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, the inventor of "ethnic cleansing."
Governor Clinton's statement on Yugoslavia took up ideas suggested by many international observers. The economic blockade of Serbia should be tightened, he said. The United States should ask the U.N. Security Council to authorize air strikes against those who attack relief convoys, as the Serbs have been doing. American forces should be lent to that operation. And Mr. Milosevic should be charged under international law "with crimes against humanity."
If President Bush had had the courage or the vision to act, the horror in Yugoslavia would have ended long ago. When Serbian gunners began lobbing shells into Dubrovnik a year ago, a few air strikes would have stopped them -- and headed off the tragedy that has followed.
In denouncing Governor Clinton last week for his call to action in Yugoslavia -- action long overdue -- the Bush campaign inadvertently advertised its own candidate's inability to respond to new realities in the world. It showed George Bush for what he is: yesterday's man.

HEADLINE: Senate Resuscitates Big Science Project

 BODY:
The Senate overwhelmingly endorsed spending $550 million next year for the superconducting supercollider, which just weeks ago was rejected by the House as unaffordable. 
 After intense Administration lobbying and a surge of concern over unemployment, it appears that the House will also vote to revive the project. The $8.2 billion, Texas-based proton smasher would generate thousands of jobs and could shed light on the essence of nature.
 Article, page A11.

HEADLINE: Six Theaters to Benefit From Revised Times Square Plan

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Six theaters on 42d Street will be among the biggest beneficiaries and most closely watched symbols of the revised redevelopment plan for Times Square.
Two or possibly three of the theaters -- all of which were taken over by the city and the state during condemnation proceedings in 1990 -- are to be renovated with $18.2 million committed by the developers of the original Times Square Center office project, the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty. That is the largest outlay of money for a single purpose under the new renovation plan. 
 "The theaters will now be the most visible surviving aspect of the redevelopment," said Cora Cahan, president of New 42d Street Inc., the corporation that is charged with overseeing the restoration and management of theaters on the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. "We have even greater responsibility for the future, and we are eager to show that the street can be reclaimed."
The six theaters are the Victory, the Selwyn, the Times Square, the Apollo, the Lyric and the Liberty. The theaters most likely to be renovated are the Liberty, and the Victory. Three other theaters on the block are privately owned: the Harris, the New Amsterdam and the Empire.
 
Tempered Resignation
 News of the theater renovation helped to temper Broadway's resignation yesterday to hearing that development plans had changed once again.
"Of course it's a disappointment," said Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, the city's largest theater owner. "But it appears to be a holding action, and we're pleased by the continuing commitment of the city and the state to the project."
Harvey Sabinson, executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers in Manhattan, said: "We've been supporting the redevelopment of 42d Street for 18 years. It's encouraging that it will keep moving forward. I just hope I'll be able to see that in my lifetime."
Broadway has always had a major stake in the project, hoping that redevelopment would generate new excitement, and new ticket sales, for the declining theater economy.
 
Change in Plans
 Under the original plan, Times Square was to be renovated and the office towers built as part of the $2.5 billion 42d Street Redevelopment Project, a state and city initiative that was to be financed largely with private money. Under the proposed overhaul of the plan, the office towers will not be built until economic conditions improve, from 3 to 10 years in the future.
Many of the existing buildings in the redevelopment sites along Broadway and Seventh Avenue between 41st Street and 43d Streets have had their tenants removed. At least one former tenant affected by the redevelopment plans was angered by the change. "I'm more than a little ticked off that they made me move," said Joe Franklin, the WWOR-TV talk-show host who was displaced by the redevelopment from the Longacre Building at 147 West 42d Street last year.
Ms. Cahan said New 42d Street Inc. will announce in the fall which of the theaters will be renovated, and she hopes that they will be able to house nonprofit theater and arts groups.
"We will aggressively pursue uses for the other theaters," said Ms. Cahan of state-and-city-owned theaters that will not be renovated.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Environmental Debate;
Gore Says Bush Is Hypocritical on Ecology Issues

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Calif., Aug. 3

 BODY:
Giving full voice to an issue that has been muted in the early stages of the Presidential campaign, Senator Al Gore today sharply criticized President Bush for his environmental record, saying he had been hypocritical on those issues.
In stops at a factory in Irvine, Calif., that makes environmentally safe intravenous bags for hospitals and at a plant here that recycles used motor oil, Mr. Gore sought to highlight his own credentials as an environmentalist. 
 Mr. Gore, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, used an appearance at the Evergreen Oil plant to underscore contrasts with Mr. Bush, who visited the same plant in June just after the United Nations Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. The Tennessee Senator said the company was struggling to survive primarily because the Bush Administration had failed to promulgate regulations that would encourage the recycling of oil.
Indeed, Evergreen is a member of the Hazardous Waste Treatment Council, an industry group that is suing the Environmental Protection Agency for its failure to draft regulations that company officials say would lead to more oil recycling. Currently, 90 percent of used motor oil is either burned or dumped in landfills.
 
'The Hypocritical President'
 "The American people trusted George Bush when he said he was going to be the environmental President," Mr. Gore told a crowd of employees and their families. "When George Bush came to Evergreen, he was the hypocritical President."
Today's comments mark the first time Mr. Gore has made detailed criticism of the Administration's environmental record. His nomination was cheered by many environmentalists, who said it would mean that matters like pollution and global warming would receive more attention in the campaign. But until today, Mr. Gore had mainly articulated the broad outlines of the party's message and attacked the Administration's handling of the economy.
Mr. Gore's reluctance to speak on the environment is a marked contrast to criticism in his book, "Earth in the Balance: Ecology and the Human Spirit," of politicians -- including himself -- for not boldly addressing ecological issues.
In the book's introduction he wrote that he had "become very impatient with my own tendency to put a finger to the political winds" when it came to environmental issues.
 
Hitting Back
 Yet, as Mr. Gore steps up his comments on the environment, the Republicans have already begun to hit back, at times using Mr. Gore's book to try to portray him as an environmental extremist.
Last week, after Mr. Gore spoke at a Washington clinic on women's health issues, Republican campaign workers circulated several pages from Mr. Gore's book that dealt with the harvesting of Pacific yew trees, whose bark yields the chemical taxol, which has shown promise as a treatment for ovarian, lung and breast cancers.
Mr. Gore took no position on whether the trees should be harvested, but the message the Republicans intended to convey was that he cared more about trees than cancer victims.
 
Jobs vs. the Environment
 Democrats acknowledge that Mr. Gore must proceed carefully, in the face of Republican charges that environmental proposals will cost jobs. The task for Democrats, these officials say, is to sell environmental protection as a job-creating program.
"We've got to do a clear job of saying that the choice George Bush lays out there of the environment or jobs is an absolutely false one," said Senator Tim Wirth, a Colorado Democrat who is coordinating the campaign's environmental policy.
Mr. Gore's visits to both Evergreen Oil and McGaw Inc. in Irvine were intended to highlight the Democrats' message of creating jobs while saving the environment. McGaw manufactures an intravenous bag for hospitals that contains no polyvinyl chlorides and can therefore be recycled.
Larry Watts, a company vice president, said McGaw had revenues last year of about $300 million, with $200 million of that coming from recyclable intravenous bags.
In his speech to the company's employees, Mr. Gore said: "This demand in the marketplace for new, more environmentally efficient products is a worldwide demand. And if we are going to enjoy the kind of economic advantage in the 90's and in the next century that we want for our kids, we really should be leading this environmental revolution in all industries, the way you're leading it in your industry."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
T.W.A. Holding Sale Talks With Unions and Creditors

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it was negotiating an agreement with many of its unionized employees and its creditors to buy out the troubled airline's chairman, Carl C. Icahn, who would step down.
The deal would provide short-term relief for T.W.A., which entered bankruptcy court protection in January, industry analysts said, but it would leave a once-proud carrier ill positioned to compete. T.W.A. has sold some of its most attractive assets and it has an aging fleet, shortcomings that threaten its long-term health. 
 Mr. Icahn personally stands to lose up to $100 million as a result of his adventure in the skies, said a person involved in the negotiations who declined to be identified. Mr. Icahn recovered his initial $400 million investment when he took the airline private in a leveraged buyout in 1988, but he holds T.W.A. bonds that would become worthless in the deal.
Under the agreement, Mr. Icahn would give up his 90 percent stake in the carrier. The unions representing most of T.W.A.'s 28,000 employees, who now have the other 10 percent, would trade a 15 percent concession in wages, benefits and work rules for an expanded 45 percent equity stake.
T.W.A.'s creditors would forgive two-thirds, or roughly $1 billion, of the company's debt in exchange for debt securities, preferred stock and 55 percent of T.W.A.'s common equity. Together, the lower employee costs and reduced interest expense would save about $400 million a year.
Mr. Icahn's successor is unclear. One person involved in the talks said Alfred D. Kingsley, T.W.A.'s vice chairman, was being discussed as the likely candidate. But another source said he was not interested in the job.
An agreement has been under discussion for two years, according to people involved in the talks. However, a broad change in pricing strategies by the major carriers in April, followed by a bruising fare war, gave new impetus to discussions of wholesale changes at T.W.A., which is losing almost $1 million a day, according to people familiar with its finances.
To be sure, a deal is far from final, and it still requires the approval of certain organizations and agencies, which will probably take months to win. The Air Line Pilots Association said several key issues were unresolved, adding that it wanted assurances that its 2,800 T.W.A. pilots would have jobs should the airline ever be sold.
And the Federal agency that insures T.W.A.'s pension fund, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, said it would oppose any proposal that would break T.W.A. from Mr. Icahn's affiliated companies unless protection was in place to cover the more than $1 billion in unfinanced pension liabilities.
The International Association of Machinists, the largest T.W.A. union, with 15,000 members, said no substantive issues threatened the agreement. "This provides a cushion to deal with the current downturn in the industry and the economy and assures T.W.A.'s viability," said Brian M. Freeman, an investment banker in Roseland, N.J., who represents the union.
He added that other unions had shown willingness to follow the machinists' lead. But the standing of 6,300 management and clerical employees who are not unionized is not clear.
 
An Uphill Climb
 If and when these hurdles are cleared, a reinvigorated T.W.A. with a healthier balance sheet and lower costs could emerge. "But I don't think it puts them in the hunt," said Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst with Morgan Stanley. No airline has ever entered bankruptcy and rejoined the ranks of the financially strongest carriers. "The track record is not good," Mr. Murphy said.
In a fiercely competitive industry, T.W.A.'s fleet is nearly twice the age of American's and Delta's, both at nine years. And T.W.A. is consistently among the performance laggards on score cards that track on-time arrivals, customer complaints, mishandled baggage and passengers "bumped" from flights.
And in its strategy of paring back, T.W.A., is going against a powerful industry trend toward consolidation. Once a dominant carrier with global routes, T.W.A. has sold some of its strongest assets, including landing rights, airport gates and slots in London. To succeed, the airline may require more capital than is readily available, analysts said.
Although it is no longer one of the nation's leading carriers, T.W.A. is still an important presence in many cities, particularly St. Louis. Earlier this year, it also increased the number of flights to Kennedy International Airport.
Some industry analysts speculate that the restructuring may make T.W.A. more appealing to other carriers. USAir, which recently announced a plan to merge with British Airways, had previously expressed interest in acquiring some of T.W.A.'s assets.
Mr. Icahn began his association with T.W.A. in 1986. He took control of the airline, which was once owned by Howard Hughes, after most of its unions sided with him and granted wage concessions to fight off Frank Lorenzo, the Texas Air chairman. But the employees were soon feuding with Mr. Icahn, who sought further wage concessions.
If the buyout deal is approved by the bankruptcy court, Mr. Icahn would become a passive investor.
Since taking the airline private, Mr. Icahn has fancied himself a maverick who bucked industry wisdom. In recent months, he has tangled with Robert L. Crandall, American's chairman, and became the unofficial spokesman for troubled carriers.
He has contended that American's fare-simplification strategy put into effect in early April was an attempt to drive weaker airlines out of business. Although the debate elevated Mr. Icahn to a more prominent industry role, he is said to have grown weary of the business.
The proposed agreement calls for Mr. Icahn to invest $150 million to $200 million to help the airline operate until the plan is approved by the bankruptcy court. That money would be safe, because it would be secured by the airline's assets, although Mr. Icahn's other businesses may ultimately be held responsible for the pension fund obligations.
