HEADLINE: Senate Approves More Financing For Supercollider Project in Texas

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Rejecting arguments that the superconducting supercollider is a luxury the country cannot afford, the Senate today overwhelmingly approved spending $550 million next year for the Texas-based proton smasher.
The $8.2 billion supercollider was put in peril six weeks ago when the House voted to stop its financing. But with concerns over the budget deficit now overshadowed by worry over unemployment and slow economic growth, a House-Senate conference committee is likely to follow the Senate's lead and resuscitate financing for the project. 
 The Senate vote followed weeks of intense Administration lobbying in favor of the project, including a visit by President Bush last week to the project site in Waxahachie, Tex., about 20 miles south of Dallas. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Mr. Bush's Democratic opponent, also supports the project.
Most Senators agreed that it would be worthwhile and exciting to investigate the essence of nature, as the supercollider is intended to do by smashing subatomic particles within a 54-mile tunnel to simulate conditions that existed just after the creation of the universe. But the debate over financing the project centered on priorities, with opponents contending that it would expand the budget deficit and crowd out other research spending.
 
Seeing 'Marginal Payback'
 Senator Dale L. Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat who is the principal opponent of the project, said that "in a perfect world" he would like to see the supercollider built. But in difficult times, he added, "it adds to the deficit with very marginal payback."
Those favoring the supercollidercontended that behind the project was the same impulse that drove the nation to go to the moon and explore the stars and that such ambitions ultimately created jobs and technologies to export. In addition, more than 7,000 jobs are tied to the project in Texas, and it promises to provide several hundred million dollars in Federal money to states.
The Senate rejected the amendment to the Energy-Water Development Appropriations bill proposing to shelve the supercollider by a vote of 62 to 32. Today's result was widely expected, and support for pressing ahead, though with $100 million less than Mr. Bush proposed, came from both parties, with 31 Democrats joining 31 Republicans in endorsing the project. The Senate later approved the entire bill.
Ultimately, several wavering Senators were persuaded by the argument that the supercollider would provide several potential spinoff benefits for medical diagnosis, computers and super-fast trains. The Senate action underlined a developing consensus in Congress that the way to control spending is not to cut science projects but to curb the escalating costs of entitlement programs like Medicaid.
"There is no question that our economic future is being harmed by a declining international competitiveness due in part to insufficient investment in basic scientific research," said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, whose state has pledged to contribute $1 billion to the project.
 
Support From Project States
 Mr. Bentsen was joined by his Republican counterpart from Texas, Senator Phil Gramm, as well as by Senator J. Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democratic who is chairman of the Energy Committee, in leading the forces for the supercollider. Many of the giant magnets that propel the protons towards their high-speed collisions are assembled in Hammond, La.
The Government has spread out contracts and research grants connected with the project to universities and private companies in 45 states, in large part to shore up political support; New York, for instance, would receive $44 million in contracts. The base for Congressional backing has come from the dozen or so states that have received the most lucrative contracts.
Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, said today before the vote that he opposed the project because of cost overruns, predicting that the estimated $8.2 billion price tag would eventually reach $12 billion.
"Allowing the supercollider to continue to suck up billions of research dollars that might otherwise have gone to countless smaller-scale projects may be the greatest threat of all to our leadership role in basic scientific research," Mr. Sasser contended. Since 1987, Congress has approved $1 billion for the proton smasher, which is supposed to be completed in 1999.
But Senator Johnston asked: "Are we going to just let this country sink slowly like the sun in the west and say we can't compete anymore, we have no scientific curiosity, we have no scientific competitiveness? We're going to let this budget deficit fueled by entitlements just overwhelm us?"

HEADLINE: New Outlays For Buildings Fell in June

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Construction activity in June posted its worst decline in 13 months, the Commerce Department said today, in large part because of a sharp drop in spending for government projects.
The value of new construction put in place fell 1.5 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $416.9 billion. 
 It was the first decrease since December and the largest since May 1991, when construction activity fell 1.8 percent. The decline followed a slight gain in May. That gain, originally reported as two-tenths of 1 percent, was revised downward to one-tenth of 1 percent.
In June, a 1.1 percent increase in residential construction was not enough to offset a big 5.7 percent drop in government construction and a nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in private, nonresidential projects.
Analysts cautioned against reading too much into the drop in government construction. Activity there swings widely from month to month but, over all, it has been one of the strongest construction sectors during the two-year economic slump.
"Is the latest drop simply month-to-month volatility or are governments starting to be constrained by budget problems?" asked David Berson, an economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. "There may be some budget constraint, but at this point I think it's mostly month-to-month volatility."
 
Government Spending Falls
 Government spending fell to an annual rate of $113.4 billion. The other public buildings category, which includes administrative offices, jails and courthouses, declined 12.2 percent. Highway spending dropped 6.5 percent and spending for school buildings fell 5.8 percent.
Lower interest rates have helped stimulate residential construction, but have not helped the commercial market, particularly for office buildings.
The third consecutive decline occurred in June in nonresidential construction activity. It fell to an annual rate of $84.9 billion. Industrial spending was off 4.3 percent and offices fell 2.4 percent. Other commercial projects, including shopping centers, rose 2.2 percent.
"The nonresidential sector has been in long-term decline and it continues to weaken," said Mark Zandi, an economist for Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. "I would expect declines at least through the end of this year and probably well into 1993. We still have vacancy rates near record highs for office, industrial and retail space."
Spending for residential projects totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $180.7 billion. Single-family home building was up 1.3 percent, while apartment spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Analysts were surprised by the June decline. Still, spending for the month was 5.7 percent higher than a year earlier. Spending during the first half of 1992 was 4.7 percent higher than spending during the first six months of 1991.

HEADLINE: Stocks Edge Up Again in a Quiet Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market closed slightly higher yesterday in a quiet session as many investors took a breather to digest last week's sharp gains.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials edged up 1.62 points, to 3,395.40. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners about 5 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume eased to 164.5 million shares from 180.6 million in the previous session. 
 There was little news to move the markets. Prices traded in a narrow range and volume was light, but the Dow still rose for the fifth consecutive session.
 
'Nothing to Cause Volatility'
 Stocks showed little reaction to mixed reports on the economy. The Commerce Department said construction spending fell 1.5 percent in June. But a poll of the nation's purchasing executives showed the manufacturing sector continued to grow in July, posting its sixth consecutive advance.
"The reports weren't too strong and they weren't too weak," said Jon Groveman, president of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. "There was nothing to cause volatility."
Some investors were staying away ahead of important economic readings scheduled for this week, including June's index of leading economic indicators today and July's employment figures on Friday.
Yesterday's gains were broad. The Nasdaq composite index gained 1.53, to 582.36. The Big Board's composite index rose 0.51, to 233.66, while the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.02, to 390.87.
Chase Manhattan led the Big Board's most actives, easing 1/8, to 24 7/8. Among other actively traded issues, Philip Morris rose 5/8, to 80 1/2, and Wellcome was unchanged at 15 1/4.
Merck rose 1, to 52 7/8, after several analysts said the company's prostate drug, Proscar, will become a billion-dollar product by the end of the decade.
McDonald's fell 1 1/8, to 42 3/4, after an analyst cut the intermediate-term rating to "above average" from "buy."
Monsanto fell 1 1/2, to 53 1/2, after an analyst lowered its rating to "sell," citing the Food and Drug Administration's approval of Ivax's generic version of a Monsanto drug. Ivax, traded on the Amex, rose 4 5/8 to 28 7/8.
Marvel Entertainment fell 2 7/8, to 31 1/2, after Barron's reported that an analyst was urging investors to sell the stock.

HEADLINE: Times Square's Future May Be Found Back at Its Roots

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
For more than a decade, city and state officials sought to reinvent Times Square as a major office district, in the hope of bringing new vitality to the crossroads.
This week, they acknowledged publicly that there was little chance of luring a major commercial tenant to the neighborhood until the next century. Even Prudential Securities, a subsidiary of one of the partners in the Times Square development team, would not move to 42d Street. 
 Today, officials believe, Times Square would profit most from its reincarnation as a jumbled, energetic patchwork of small buildings topped by big signs and filled with stores, restaurants, theaters, amusements and nightspots -- in other words, fitting a description that might have been written 50 years ago.
"What we're doing is playing to the natural potential of the area," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
"What our market study has found is that there is a tremendous unexploited potential for tourism here," she said, "a market which has always been underserved in this area."
 
A Deal With Developers
 The revitalization project would be financed in large measure by the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty, the development team that was supposed to build the four enormous office towers known as Times Square Center, along Broadway and Seventh Avenue between 41st and 43d streets.
On Sunday, officials said they were prepared to release the developers from a construction timetable and allow those towers to be built as the market dictated.
Further details of the tentative deal came to light yesterday. The chairman of Park Tower, George Klein, said the developers were "very hopeful that we'll soon have an agreement." Brian J. Strum, a Prudential executive, said the city had devised a "workable strategy."
Carl Weisbrod, the president of the city Economic Development Corporation, said the developers would make a "substantial investment in retail uses" along 42d Street, paying for the renovation of existing buildings and, perhaps, new construction.
All told, the developers would contribute more than $30 million to the renovation of the project site, Ms. Robertson said.
This would include their earlier commitment to an $18.2 million renovation of two theaters on 42d Street and a $2.6 million renovation of the "streetscape," including lighting and sidewalks, plus a loan to the state, which would undertake its own renovation of several parcels on the south side of 42d Street.
Mr. Weisbrod said the rent paid by the developers for the sites, which they lease from the state, would be "significantly increased."
For their part, the developers would keep their claim to four sites that might one day support a project with more than four million square feet of office space. They would also protect an investment they have already made: $180 million in condemnation awards that they have paid to owners whose property was taken by the state, at least $60 million they have yet to pay and tens of millions of dollars in development costs.
One of the last efforts to resuscitate Times Square Center came last winter, when officials tried to persuade Prudential that its search for a tenant need go no further than its own corporate family, because Prudential Securities, a wholly owned subsidiary with some 5,000 employees in Manhattan, was looking for new space.
"Unfortunately, it does not appear as if Times Square works for Prudential Securities," Mr. Weisbrod said. "However, we are engaged in constructive discussions with Prudential Securities to keep them in the city."
Mr. Weisbrod insisted that rejuvenating existing buildings and bringing tenants back to spaces that were only recently emptied was not a return to square one.
"Square one was where there were six to eight crimes a day reported on the block," he said. "Square one was where the street cost 10 times more to clean than any other single block in Manhattan. Square one was where we hadn't seen anything positive on the block in a half-century.
"Whatever happens, we're not going to see a return to that," he said.
In broad concept, the proposed interim arrangement -- in which tourist and entertainment uses would be stressed -- echoes proposals made in recent years by two staunch critics of Times Square Center.
In 1989, Douglas Durst, whose family briefly controlled the leases to eight theaters on 42d Street, proposed an increase in stores on the street and an upgrading of the existing movie theaters. In 1991, State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, called for the abandonment of the office towers "in favor of a tourist-oriented entertainment center."
Asked about the parallels, Ms. Robertson said yesterday: "You know what? Every good idea has its time. The fact of the matter is that this is a good idea, even if we're not necessarily the authors of it."
The new plan is to be developed in consultation with Garrick-Aug Associates, a retail leasing concern.
The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, said the "decision to refurbish and upgrade existing buildings in the area as a means of revitalizing Times Square is a good one." But she added that officials "should use this postponement as an opportunity to reconsider the entire premise of the Times Square redevelopment plan."
Mr. Leichter went further, calling outright for an end to the Times Square Center project. "Forty-second Street today is much worse than it has ever been," he said, "with its closed-up shops only increasing its dangerous character."

HEADLINE: Building-Permit Extension

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
An effort to create jobs by extending construction permits and zoning approvals that expired during the recession was approved for a third time by the New Jersey Assembly today and sent to Gov. Jim Florio. HEADLINE: Business and Health;
States Weighing Cost-Control Ideas

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
DISMAYED by climbing Medicaid budgets and the growing numbers of Americans without health insurance, several states are considering bold new efforts to hold down health-care costs. Many states have concluded that they cannnot afford to expand access to health care unless costs can be brought under control at the same time.
Vermont and Minnesota have already decided to set targets for overall medical spending. Colorado and Vermont have authorized studies of systems that would funnel all health-care payments through a single agency to a limited number of competing insurers. California is looking at a similar approach. Iowa is studying a combination of both spending targets and regulated competition. 
 Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado said in a telephone interview that his state wanted to establish minimum health coverage that would emphasize "preventive care to reduce costs rather than spending it all on heroic medicine," which labors to keep desperately ill people alive.
Minnesota wants to limit the spread of costly new medical technologies.
Health-policy experts hope the states can serve as laboratories for an eventual national program to deal with the problems of cost and access. "Not that any state by itself is likely to fix the problems," said W. David Helms, president of the Alpha Center, a nonprofit health policy group in Washington, "but we can learn from these state experiments." Mr. Helms is also a national program director for the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, which plans to spend $25.5 million to promote state health-financing experiments.
The foundation announced yesterday that it was giving one-third of the money to health-policy planners in a dozen states: Arkansas, Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Minnesota, New Mexico, New York, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, Vermont and Washington. Experts from the Rand Corporation, the Urban Institute and the National Governors' Association will help the 12 states study the legal and economic implications of the experiments.
Chris Petersen, a senior counsel with the Health Insurance Association of America, an insurers' trade group, said the association supports experimentation at the state level. But he said the group opposed the single-payer concept, which would eliminate a traditional insurance company business. Other state programs that use a number of competing insurers should be tested in the marketplace, without state subsidies, he said, because the subsidies could not last forever.
Nancy Barrand, a Robert Wood Johnson project officer, said the states might eventually need permission from Congress and Federal Medicare and Medicaid officials to proceed with experiments. Some may require special exemptions from the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, which restricts state jurisdiction over health insurance.
Gov. David Walters of Oklahoma said he hoped to get waivers from Medicaid and a Federal tax exemption for a state plan to establish deferred individual and family health accounts resembling I.R.A. savings accounts. The state would use interest on the accounts to pay for broadened access to health care, he added.
The Bush Administration has held up a request by Oregon for a Medicaid waiver that would permit the state to set priorities in paying for medical care. Ms. Barrand said the new state programs would seek support in Washington by showing that they could "actually achieve broader access and better control over costs." The foundation will finance research so states that propose to require all insurers to charge standardized rates, for example, could predict which employers would pay more and which would pay less.
New York plans to use its Johnson grant to work on a statewide clearinghouse to process all health claims. It will also look at new rate-setting strategy for paying physicians and at ways to improve access to health care. Ronald Rouse, acting planning director with the state's health department, said that a uniform system for paying doctors could curb the "micromanagement of physician decision making," which many doctors hate. All of the New York projects need legislative approval.
Stephen H. Long, an economist in Washington with Rand, the policy center based in Santa Monica, Calif., said 35 states with widely varying characteristics had applied for the Robert Wood Johnson grants. They ranged from Minnesota, where only about 7 percent are uninsured, to New Mexico, where more than 25 percent do not have coverage. The national average is about 15 percent.
He added that some experts worry that generous health-care programs will attract people from neighboring states where benefits are sparse. He added that insurers might decide to pull out of states that sharply restrict their business. Mr. Long said the chances for success would be best in states like Minnesota where the economy is strong and the number of uninsured is relatively small.

HEADLINE: Trade Talks Bog Down Over Dispute on Apparel

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Negotiators made slow progress today on the final details of a planned North American free-trade agreement, largely because of an obscure dispute involving Canada's apparel industry, people close to the talks said today.
The trade ministers of the three countries plan to continue the talks on Tuesday, and possibly through the week. But a foreign official said that Trade Minister Michael H. Wilson of Canada and Commerce Secretary Jaime Serra Puche of Mexico might go home if a deal was not reached on Tuesday, and return on Friday for more negotiations. 
 Deputies would continue talking in the meantime, and several people close to the talks said that they expected a comprehensive agreement to be struck this week.
The disagreement over apparel is not considered a deal breaker, and is tiny compared with the multibillion-dollar issues already decided. But it has tied up a lot of the top negotiators' time for several days. This has meant that other touchy issues, like trade in automobiles, have not been settled as quickly as expected.
 
Politically Important Trade
 The apparel dispute is important because it involves a politically important industry in all three countries and because it has become a target for critics who charge that the agreement discriminates against companies outside North America.
The Canadian apparel industry accuses the United States of pursuing a back-door strategy to restrict Canadian exports while encouraging American exports to Canada. The industry employs 120,000 Canadians, three-fifths of them in Quebec, which is the home province of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and the key to his hopes of winning re-election next year.
"It puts the Canadian Government in a a very difficult position; it puts the Canadian industry that might very well be supporting an agreement in a very difficult position," said Jack Kivenko, the president of the Ottawa-based Canadian Apparel Manufacturers Institute.
But American officials contend that the agreement would represent the most far-reaching dismantling of trade barriers ever tried by the United States in this highly protected industry. They point out that the accord would gradually eliminate restrictions on imports from Mexico, a low-wage country, without imposing any new restrictions on countries outside North America and imposing a very small restriction on Canada.
The lingering differences between the United States and Canada are abstruse even by international trade standards.
The dispute begins with the 1988 U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement. That accord called for eliminating, over 10 years, each country's apparel tariffs, many of which are close to 25 percent. To prevent China and other countries from benefiting by shipping products intended for Canada through the United States, or vice versa, the tariff reductions applied only to clothing made in the United States or Canada from fabric also made in either country.
Because Quebec clothing producers rely heavily on imported fabric, they were given an exemption from this requirement for up to 40 million square meters worth of clothing each year.
The North American Free Trade Agreement will add a third requirement, concerning yarn, for garments to qualify for lower tariffs. Garments will have to be made in North America from fabric made in North America, and the fabric will also have to be made from yarn produced in North America.
The practical effect of the extra requirement may be limited because the economics of fabric production force most North American fabric factories to spin their own yarn. But a handful of factories do import yarn, and a few Quebec companies buy fabric from them.
The United States has offered to increase the limit set in 1988 to account for these extra garments with imported yarn. But Canada wants a much larger increase because Quebec producers contend that the original limit was too small.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
After the Fade to Black, The End Isn't Hollywood

BYLINE: By George Judson

DATELINE: SEYMOUR, Conn.

 BODY:
THE people who make movies can always count on happy endings: they just write one into the script. In "Other People's Money," starring Danny DeVito, a financier persuades stockholders to liquidate an aging wire and cable company; at the last minute, employees step forward to buy the company and run it themselves.
Happy endings are harder to come by in the Naugatuck Valley, which bled tens of thousands of factory jobs in the 1970's and 80's as one brass mill after another shut down. But in 1985, employees of Bridgeport Brass in Seymour did save their jobs by buying their mill. 
 When the crew for "Other People's Money" came here in 1990 to film scenes at the 104-year-old factory, now called the Seymour Specialty Wire Company, Warner Brothers's payment for using the plant helped it pay off one of the last notes from the buyout.
Cut to last Friday, when the gates of the idled plant opened so its remaining employees could come in and clean out their lockers. Then to the next day, when, officials say, someone set fire to the laboratory building. Then to the sign on the guard shack that says the property is being prepared for liquidation.
Seymour Specialty closed on June 29 for its annual maintenance shutdown and has not reopened. Out of money, it is in the hands of a creditor, the Foothill Group Inc., that is owed $1.7 million.
The management is looking for a buyer, but one way or another, a lot of people are going to lose money. The state is owed more than $1 million in loans, the town of Seymour is owed $400,000 in property taxes and utilities haven't been paid.
The employees -- Seymour Specialty's owners -- have sacrificed all along. As their contribution to the buyout, they took a 10 percent pay cut and gave up 40 of 250 jobs. But more concessions were needed, and more layoffs were ordered. At the end, as few as 70 people were working in a mill where 800 had worked in Bridgeport Brass's heyday.
"One of the things always said was, 'We're doing this to save ourselves, we'd rather have a job that makes a little bit less than be on the street collecting unemployment,' " said Michael Kearney, the president of Local 1827, United Auto Workers, in 1985, and still a company director. "I think some people regret that, because look where they are now."
Across the United States, 11 million people work for companies owned under Employee Stock Ownership Plans, or ESOP's. Seymour Specialty's buyout was held up as a model of white-collar and blue-collar cooperation; 100 percent of its employees took part in its ESOP.
ESOP's can be an effective way to recapitalize a company. In Seymour, at least at first, employee ownership also appeared to bolster production, said the Rev. Kevin Bean, who assisted the company as staff director of the Naugatuck Valley Project, a coalition of religious, business, labor and community organizations.
But, Mr. Bean said, "An ESOP doesn't protect you from the harsh realities of larger economic forces, especially recessionary forces. It's not a magical force field to protect a company."
In "Other People's Money," Danny DeVito, as the financier Larry the Liquidator, explained why old wireworks don't survive: "Fiber optics. New technologies. Obsolescence."
The Valley's brassworks are almost gone, in part, because brass is no longer a universal material. Another movie, "The Graduate," predicted their fate 25 years ago in one famous word: "Plastics."
Mr. Bean and others acknowledge the shrinking brass market, while pointing out that Seymour had a firm hold of a niche, producing alloys for the automobile industry and other users. It has customers waiting for its furnaces to fire up again.
But employee ownership, workers learned, doesn't transform a decades-old factory into a state-of-the-art factory. It doesn't install new equipment. It doesn't provide skilled workers to replace the experienced hands who know the old machinery but retire.
"A lot of old-time bosses retired," said Tom Klimovich, another former union president. "They didn't have their knowledge written on paper, they had it between their ears. When they left, it went with them."
Nor does an ESOP eliminate the need for management, or make it smarter, as employees learned when they elected a majority of hourly workers to the board of directors.
"I learned a lot through the buyout," said Mr. Klimovich, who is a director, "but I'm not going to tell you I was a genius at business. You hire people to do that. And you hope they're doing the job right."
An ESOP doesn't prevent losing orders in a recession, or a furnace melting down, or mistakes in the front office or on the shop floor. This one, very likely, will have no Hollywood ending. Its success, Mr. Bean said, is that it kept the furnaces burning in Seymour seven years longer than they would have otherwise.
"We got seven years out of it," Mr. Klimovich agreed. "That's the way I look at it. We got seven years."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS
Taubman Centers, a Mall Empire, to Go Public;
Big Developer To Shed Debt In Stock Sale

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
A. Alfred Taubman's shopping mall empire plans to sell shares to the public, hoping to raise between $335 million and $389 million from investors who would get a 22 percent stake in a group of 19 large shopping malls from California to Connecticut, the company announced yesterday. The move would effectively free Mr. Taubman of hundreds of millions of dollars of personal debt.
The company said the offering and the accompanying restructuring would enable it to slash debt and expand. It said it planned to enlarge some large regional shopping centers and might buy or build others. 
 Mr. Taubman, the 67-year-old real estate developer who controls Sotheby's Holdings as well as the Woodward & Lothrop department store chain based in Washington, would end up owning less of his shopping center empire than the public will own. The plan is to ask the public to pay more than 50 times last year's earnings for a stake in the company.
 
Other Offerings Halted
 The success of the deal will hinge on the willingness of investors to pay such a high multiple. In recent weeks, a number of large equity offerings have been withdrawn, and others have been cut back, because of investor resistance. But the fact that the filing comes after those setbacks indicates that the underwriters, led by Morgan Stanley & Company, are optimistic that buyers can be found.
Mr. Taubman and his family are not taking money out of the deal directly, but a loan of about $450 million to the Taubmans from his empire will, in effect, be forgiven. And Mr. Taubman will be in a position that could enable him to take out large additional sums within a few years.
The offering of shares in Taubman Centers Inc. would provide a windfall for pension funds at General Motors and American Telephone and Telegraph. Those funds would get all the cash, after expenses, from the offering and still own 52 percent of the shopping center empire. That ownership stems from a $610 million loan made in 1985, which the pension funds are now converting into a controlling stake in the empire, a right they were given when they made the loan.
If the offering of 26.8 million shares goes as planned, with shares selling at $13.50 each, the midpoint of the $12.50 to $14.50 range cited in the prospectus, the pension funds would end up with $327 million in cash and equity interests worth $874 million.
 
 
Old Loan Would Be Forgiven
 Mr. Taubman would own a stake worth about $326 million, although he has pledged that holding to banks in return for $80 million in loans.
In 1985, when the pension fund loan was made, Mr. Taubman and his associates effectively pocketed the cash by borrowing $600 million from the shopping center empire, with three- quarters of that going to the Taubman family. As part of the restructuring that accompanies the offering, they will essentially end up owing that money to themselves, effectively canceling the loans.
The Taubman properties range in size from the 1.9-million-square-foot Woodfield Mall in Schaumburg, Ill., near Chicago, to the 714,000-square-foot Meadowood Mall in Reno. In all, the malls have 21.3 million square feet of space.
Taubman Centers said that it would initially pay dividends at a rate of 22 cents a quarter, although it cautioned that there was no guarantee that the rate would remain level. At that rate, the shares would yield 6.1 to 7 percent, depending on where they sell within the expected range. On a pro-forma basis, Taubman Centers reported profits of 24 cents a share last year, indicating that the shares are to be offered at a range of 52 to 60 times trailing earnings.
 
A Glimpse of Mall Economics
 The offering prospectus, filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, provided the first look at the economics of such a large shopping center developer. And it showed that while the stores that sell in shopping centers have run into problems in recent years, the problems have so far not severely damaged the Taubman centers, notwithstanding the bankruptcies of several anchor stores.
Under the normal operating procedures of those centers, the tenants pay not only rent but almost all of the operating expenses as well. And rents have steadily climbed, in large part because leases signed years ago contained escalation clauses.
But there were signs that the recession began to pinch the centers' operations. New leases signed in 1991 called for lower rents than similar new leases signed in 1990, although still well above the levels of expiring leases they replaced. In an interview, Bernard Winograd, the company's chief financial officer, said he expected that "in a cyclical recovery" the figures in new leases would rise again.
In the meantime, however, it is clear that tenants of the shopping centers have been squeezed even as the centers' profits have risen in recent years. At 15 Taubman shopping centers that were in operation before 1987, sales by the tenants peaked in 1989 and declined slightly in 1990 and 1991. But because of escalation clauses and new leases, the centers saw their revenues rise.
In 1989, the 15 centers had revenues of $317.4 million, or 16 percent of the $1.99 billion in sales by tenants of the shopping centers. By 1991, the centers' revenues of $350.9 million amounted to 18 percent of the underlying sales of $1.95 billion.
On a long-term basis, it may be difficult for stores to continue paying ever-larger percentages of their sales for rents, and that could put a damper on revenue increases as leases come up for renewal.
Over all, Taubman reported that 87.2 percent of its space was leased on March 31, down from 90.5 percent at the end of the year. It said that this was a normal seasonal dip and noted that the figure was higher than a year earlier.
If the deal is completed, Taubman Centers Inc. will become a real estate investment trust, required under tax laws to pay out 95 percent of its income to holders. Its sole asset would be a 32.5 percent stake in a related company, Taubman Realty Group Limited Partnership, which will actually own the Taubman stakes in the shopping centers, which range from 100 percent to as little as 25 percent. Those ownership percentages are likely to rise, however, as minority partners cash out by trading their stakes for shares in Taubman Realty and eventually for shares in Taubman Centers.
Under complicated arrangements, the pension funds at General Motors and A.T.&T., as well as other holders including Mr. Taubman, can effectively ask the company to sell new shares to redeem their interests. For that reason, it is possible that in the next several years, beginning as early as mid-1993, there will be many more shares of Taubman Centers available for trading, perhaps depressing the price.
Of the 19 centers included in the deal, 8 have seen one or more anchor tenants file for bankruptcy in recent years, for a total of 15 stores. But only one mall, the Mall at Short Hills in New Jersey, actually lost anchors. Both B. Altman and Bonwit Teller closed, but the mall has announced plans to expand and add three new anchors: Nordstrom, Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed While Gold Drops Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday against most currencies as traders waited for more definitive economic and political news to take shape later in the week.
Gold prices dropped sharply. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold was quoted at $352.60, off $4.80 from late Friday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $353, off $4.50. 
 Currency traders said the dollar's behavior reflected a reluctance to make any aggressive moves amid a lack of information to trade on.
"People would like to have more news to make up their mind," said Peter Wild, first vice president and treasurer of the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer & Company.
Traders are not sure what the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, will do when it meets on Thursday, Mr. Wild said, and many refrained from any speculative activity. Last month, the German central bank raised interest rates to a 61-year high, jolting the financial markets.
The July unemployment figures in the United States are scheduled to be reported Friday, and many traders are awaiting that news. A higher number could signal a further drop in interest rates in the United States, which would hurt the dollar.
Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.25 yen, down 0.05 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.25 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 127.20 yen, from 127.15 on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9245, from $1.9205 late Friday. Later in New York the pound fell to $1.9240, from $1.9270 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4750 German marks, up from 1.4745; 1.3165 Swiss francs, up from 1.3155; 4.9800 French francs, unchanged; 1,114.00 Italian lire, down from 1,114.75, and 1.18395 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18425.

HEADLINE: GlenFed Loss at $26 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GLENDALE, Calif., Aug. 3

 BODY:
GlenFed Inc. said today that it lost $26 million in its fourth quarter and $120.9 million for the fiscal year as real estate problems continued, though the losses were narrower than in the periods a year earlier.
GlenFed, the parent of Glendale Federal Bank, reported the losses late Friday and restated its third-quarter loss to $146.6 million from $106.7 million. 
 GlenFed said that as a result of continued weakness in the economy and deterioration in California real estate markets, it had significantly increased its provisions for loan losses and real estate write-downs.
It recorded a $78.7 million provision for loan losses in the quarter. It also set aside $12.4 million for losses related to foreclosed real estate holdings.
Nonperforming assets and restructured loans totaled $827.1 million on June 30, 1992, compared with $712.1 million on June 30, 1991, and $930.4 million on March 31, 1992.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: ON BASEBALL;
When Game Isn't Fun, Astros Owner Knows It's Time to Get Out

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
Despite all the talk about George Steinbrenner since he ousted himself from baseball two years ago today, nothing memorable has been said about him, certainly nothing that compares with the comments made about the Yankees' owner more than a dozen years ago.
"The two of them deserve each other," Billy Martin uttered July 23, 1978, referring to his boss and his star player, Reggie Jackson. "One's a born liar, the other's convicted." 
 Then there was this view, expressed May 14, 1979: "There's nothing more limited than a limited partner in the Yankees."
John McMullen made that remark, and he knew whereof he spoke. He had been a limited partner of Steinbrenner for several years. When he offered his observation, he was on his way in as majority owner of the Houston Astros. Thirteen years later, with Steinbrenner on his way back to active duty with the Yankees, McMullen is on his way out as the Astros' owner.
"I'm not selling it for the money," said McMullen shortly after the sale was announced on July 24.
He has sold the team, effective after the season, because after 13 years, he no longer was having fun in Houston; too many people there wouldn't let him.
It was not enough that the New Jersey resident rescued the Astros from the Ford Motor Credit Company, keeping the team in Houston instead of having someone else move it elsewhere.
Members of that city's news media never forgave him for firing the team's president and general manager, Tal Smith, in 1980. Everything McMullen has done since that 1980 act, including the Astros' declining fortunes since they won a division title in 1986, has been viewed through eyes that focused with intense dislike and resentment on the man who sacked their good buddy.
Perhaps McMullen's tenure in Houston would have run more smoothly had he publicly explained Smith's dismissal at the time, but despite the urging of associates he thought it was an internal matter and no one else's business.
Under Ford Motor Credit ownership, Smith ran the Astros operation unimpeded. When McMullen came in, Smith lost the control he had. He reacted, in McMullen's view, by being insubordinate and disloyal, behaving rudely toward Jacqueline McMullen, the owner's wife, among other things, and not talking to Robert Harter, whom McMullen named president of the Houston Sports Association.
The clincher came when a top-level official of a Houston newspaper told McMullen that Smith was leaking derogatory stories about him to the newspaper. After confirming the information, McMullen acted.
As recently as this summer, Houston newspaper columnists were still citing the Smith firing as one of McMullen's dastardly acts. Ironically, the dirty deed with Smith always is coupled, as punishable offenses, with the owner's failure to re-sign Nolan Ryan when he was a free agent after the 1988 season. McMullen indeed blundered in not keeping Ryan, but if he had listened to Smith in 1979, he never would have signed the ageless marvel initially.
Smith opposed McMullen's decision to make Ryan baseball's first $1 million-a-year player. Smith did not believe in paying such salaries, and he was a firm believer in developing players in the minor league system rather than signing expensive free agents.
In recent years, McMullen has followed that pattern, but now he is criticized for creating a losing team by maintaining a low payroll. The critics ignore the fact that the Astros are ahead of the Los Angeles Dodgers, whose payroll is more than three times that of Houston's.
Ignored is the corps of good young players the Astros have and the excitement the team creates when it sweeps a three-game series from the first-place Cincinnati, takes two of three games from first-place Pittsburgh and opens a monstrous road trip by beating first-place Atlanta twice.
They ignore the $8 million the Astros are spending on their player development system, one of the biggest expenditures among major league clubs. They ignore McMullen's laudable record of hiring members of minorities, like Bob Watson, his assistant general manager, forgetting that the owner tried to hire Joe Morgan, the Hall of Famer, as his manager or general manager well before anyone talked about the need for such appointments.
The critics also have had a field day with the team's four-week road trip, necessitated by McMullen's decision to allow the Republicans to hold their convention at the Astrodome (rent-free, no less).
But not everyone is a critic.
"I'm glad what they did," Tom Pagnozzi, the St. Louis Cardinals catcher, remarked recently. "A lot of economies are suffering, and that owner was willing to say, 'I'll take my club out on the road and help this economy.' Look at the multimillions the convention is going to pump into that economy."
McMullen has had his faults as an owner -- name one who hasn't? -- but unlike some owners, he is not two-faced, saying one thing publicly and acting the opposite way privately. And he certainly is not what some people in Houston paint him to be, but they nevertheless have succeeded in painting him out of the picture.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign;
Bush: Change and Principle . . .

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
Television Script (President Bush speaking): "Everyone wants change. America must change. But change must be guided by principle, and there are three basic principles that must lead our quest for change.
"First, we must control wasteful Government spending. That's absolutely essential for the kind of change the American people want. 
 "And second, we must strengthen the American family. The decline of the American family is hurting the soul of America, and we've got to change that.
"Third, we're a nation of laws. We must increase respect for the law. We must pass strong legislation to help the fight against crime and to back up our police officers and law enforcement officers out on the street.
"These are the kind of changes that America needs, and I'm convinced I can bring about that change."
Producer: November Company, New York.
On the screen: Opens with these words in black letters on a white screen: "Change must be guideed by principle." The Presidential seal is in a corner of the screen. The words dissolve into an earnest looking President Bush, in extreme close up, gazing into the camera. At the end are the words, "President Bush."
Scorecard: The advertisement sounds as if it was produced for a longshot challenger, not an incumbent President. But for this ad, Bush media consultants thought it more effective to seize on the anti-Washington mood than to emphasize the President's accomplishments. While the ad does not attack Gov. Bill Clinton, it seeks to neutralize the Democrat's portrayal of himself as the outsider. The ad also emphasizes themes that are always popular with core Republican voters -- controlling wasteful spending and being tougher on crime -- and makes a pass at one that the Bush campaign has begun emphasizing -- family values.
 
. . . And the Deficit
 Television Script (President Bush speaking): "To get our economy moving faster we have to reduce the huge Federal deficit by cutting spending. The only way to do that with certainty is to pass the Balanced Budget Amendment. And earlier this summer we came nine votes short of getting the two-thirds majority needed to pass it. I'm going to fight to get those nine votes from a new Congress next year and pass the Balanced Budget Amendment."
Producer: November Company, New York.
On the screen: Begins with black letters filling a white screen: "We must reduce the huge Federal deficit." The letters dissolve into an extreme close up of President Bush, speaking directly to the camera. It ends with words on a plain background, "President Bush."
Accuracy: The facts about the budget vote in Congress are correct, but the 30-second commercial does not give the full story. Mr. Bush has never offered a balanced budget to Congress in his years in office, and both proponents and opponents of the amendment agree that the legislation by itself would not balance the budget.
Scorecard: Mr. Bush's Democratic challenger, Bill Clinton repeatedly says that he balanced every budget as Governor of Arkansas (which he is required to do by state law), and this advertisement seeks to neutralize the Federal budget deficit as an issue. Mr. Clinton also likes to remind voters that the national debt has soared in the 12 years Republicans have been in the White House. In this ad, Mr. Bush seeks to blame Congress for that.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ENDICOTT JOHNSON TO SELL UNIT TO NORCROSS FOOTWEAR

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Endicott Johnson Corporation will sell off its Ranger Rubber Footwear division to a Kentucky company, leaving more than 300 employees without jobs, the company said. Terms of the sale to Norcross Footwear of Louisville were not disclosed. An Endicott Johnson executive vice president, Peter Duff, said the sale included equipment, inventory and the Ranger trademark. 
 Endicott Johnson's rubber footwear manufacturing operations in Johnson City, N.Y., will be shut on Oct. 3, he said. The waterproof boots manufactured under the Ranger trademark are made primarily for firefighters and for industrial use. Endicott Johnson is based in Endicott, N.Y.

HEADLINE: This China Bill Is on Target

 BODY:
This year there doesn't have to be a Washington stalemate on whether to renew China's trading privileges despite its human rights abuses. Congressional human rights champions have come up with a much improved bill. It threatens targeted trade sanctions should Beijing fail to improve its record of repression, trade abuses and reckless weapons exports.
The House has given overwhelming bipartisan approval to the bill, sponsored by Representative Nancy Pelosi of California. Senator George Mitchell, the majority leader, is now trying to assemble a veto-proof Senate majority as well. 
 The Pelosi bill would extend Beijing's trading privileges until July, as President Bush asks. But requests for further extensions would have to be accompanied by a report showing "significant progress" in getting Beijing to respect human rights in China and Tibet; release political prisoners; stop the export of goods produced by slave labor, and abide by treaties governing the export of missile technology and nuclear materials. Should China not meet these conditions, tariffs would be increased on exports from its state-controlled industries. Private sector exports would continue to enjoy their present privileges.
This page opposed earlier bills which would have removed low tariff privileges from all Chinese exports. Such a sweeping approach would have hurt the entrepreneurial sectors Americans most want to help. But to impose higher duties on government industries if Beijing continues to violate its international commitments would be entirely appropriate.
The Bush Administration, though endorsing the goals of this legislation, promises a veto. Yet Republicans as well as Democrats have good reason to vote for targeted trade sanctions, aimed at the most obnoxious practices of the world's largest Communist dictatorship.
Through his failure to express American outrage over the Tiananmen tragedy, Mr. Bush has eroded a bipartisan consensus on China. The Senate now has a chance to make America a force for democratic change in China once again.

HEADLINE: Notch Babies Threaten Real Babies

 BODY:
This is a sordid tale of two babies. The first is abused and neglected, living in poverty. The second is a "notch" baby, a retiree born between 1917 and 1921 who claims that Congress has cheated on Social Security benefits. Today, notch babies turn viciously on real babies in an unconscionable attempt to get what's unrightfully theirs.
The battleground is the House floor. At stake is a laudable children's initiative that would provide funds for troubled families, foster care and adoption. Standing in the way are supporters of the notch babies, who plan to propose that the children's bill be amended to increase Social Security benefits. But if the notch babies win, real babies lose: The expensive amendments would make eventual passage virtually impossible. 
 Notch babies have no justified gripe. When Congress revised the formula for Social Security benefits in 1972, it botched the arithmetic and overcompensated for inflation. It corrected the error five years later by phasing out the windfall for new retirees. Under the corrected formula, retirees born before 1917 were allowed to keep their excessive benefits. Retirees born between 1917 and 1921, the notch, would receive a declining portion of the benefits; and everyone born after 1921 would receive only normal benefits.
The notch babies cry foul. So they propose a "fix" that will cost an astonishing $300 billion over 30 years. That's an unforgivable giveaway to an undeserving claimant. The notch babies are receiving every dime they deserve and every bit as much as any succeeding generation.
Last month notch baby supporters tried to hold up the urban aid bill until benefits were hiked. Now they threaten to hold poor kids hostage.

HEADLINE: Milosevic Isn't Hitler, But . . .

 BODY:
"Greater Serbia." "Ethnic cleansing." Civilians transported in sealed buses and railway cars. And now, concentration camps. The chilling reports from Bosnia evoke this century's greatest nightmare, Hitler's genocide against Jews, Gypsies and Slavs.
The parallel, mercifully, is not complete. Serbia's leader, Slobodan Milosevic, does not directly threaten the entire European continent. He does not have one of the world's largest economies at his disposal. His aggressive designs are limited to the Balkans. 
 But by standing aside while he implements his version of the Final Solution, the world sets a frightening precedent for a dozen other areas of ethnic tension. It's not too late to send a firmer message -- through diplomatic ultimatums, backed by the threat of armed intervention. Mr. Milosevic recognizes only one language, military force; the rest of the world may soon have to speak it.
Serbian atrocities are one parallel with Nazi Germany. Another is Europe's peace at any price response. At Munich in 1938, Britain and France agreed to a "peace plan" that forced Czechoslovakia to surrender part of its territory, the Sudetenland, to Hitler. Today, the European Community wants Bosnia to agree to a "political solution" that would surrender part of its territory to Bosnian Serb forces loyal to Mr. Milosevic.
Europe brushes aside Bosnia's request for international enforcement of a cease-fire as a precondition to political talks. Instead, Europe treats Serbian commandos as if they had the same legitimacy as Bosnia's elected Government. Like their predecessors at Munich, Europe's negotiators proceed as if Serbia were negotiating in good faith, despite a string of broken promises and violated cease-fires.
Even now, Mr. Milosevic might be convinced to stay his terror squads by a credible threat of force. Although Yugoslavia's rump army is Europe's third largest, and is fighting on favorable terrain, it is no match for the larger, high-tech forces of NATO or the West European Union.
Yet Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, again rules out military action. His Foreign Minister goes further, asserting that no state would even consider using force against Serbian aggression.
Do Europe's leaders think that if Mr. Milosevic gets what he wants in Bosnia, that will be the end of it? There can be little doubt that he will pursue his "ethnic cleansing" campaign in other parts of the former Yugoslavia, like Kosovo or Macedonia. Or that a successful pogrom in Bosnia will inspire demagogues elsewhere in Europe to adopt the same tactics. Bosnia's Croats and Muslims, the Red Cross reports, already respond to Serbian atrocities with their own gross abuse of human rights.
Diplomacy has one last chance. Later this month, an international conference on Bosnia convenes in London. Not just the European Community, but also the U.S., Russia and the U.N. will be represented. They need to demonstrate that they have learned something from the tragic errors that led to the Second World War. Mr. Milosevic is only a minor-league Hitler. The London Conference must not become a minor-league Munich.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is an Economic Realist

BYLINE: By Paul R. Krugman; Paul R. Krugman, author of "The Age of Diminished Expectations," is professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Republican contentions that Gov. Bill Clinton's economic program is based on reckless taxing and spending are predictable. More important are the concerns of moderates that the blueprint is less substantive than it first seemed -- that, unlike Ross Perot's program, it would do little to reduce the Federal deficit.
It is certainly possible to argue that the Clinton program would do little to hasten a reduction in the budget deficit. Still, the program is pretty good and represents a much-needed change of direction in economic policy. 
 Leave aside Mr. Clinton's hope that he can cut $26 billion a year in non-defense spending as well as his claim that he can reduce the deficit by accelerating growth. There is still a sensible core to his program.
He proposes to invest moderate sums -- less than 1 percent of the gross domestic product -- in child care, education, training and infrastructure. To pay for these investments, he proposes tax increases for the affluent, reforms in taxing foreign corporations and spending cuts, primarily on defense.
The taxes and cuts would amount to $53 billion a year, and the new investment spending to $47 billion a year, so there might be some direct deficit reduction. But Mr. Clinton's main emphasis is on financing new investment, not on cutting the deficit.
The defense cuts are well within the range that reasonable experts believe is feasible. The added revenue from taxes on the rich means rolling back less than 25 percent of the tax break given in the 1980's to the 2 percent of families with the highest incomes. Only the extra revenue from foreign corporations looks shaky, but it is surely true that some additional revenue can be captured.
Investment in the nation's infrastructure, neglected for 12 years, is badly needed. So patching the holes in our fraying transportation, communications and sanitation systems means high payoffs. The evidence suggests that, with one-fifth of the nation's children below the poverty line, Head Start and other programs for children are also investments with high economic (not to mention human) payoffs.
But shouldn't everything else be put on hold until the deficit monster has been slain? The budget deficit, estimated at $372 billion for fiscal 1992, is serious, but it is not our only -- even our main -- economic problem.
Economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York recently estimated that the deficits of the 1980's reduced the growth rate of the economy's productive capacity in that decade by about 0.3 percent. This figure, which most economists would agree is in the ball park , is not insignificant. But it represents only a small part of the woes of an economy in which median family income rose 2.8 percent a year from 1947 to 1973 but has been virtually stagnant ever since.
There is no reason to think that eliminating the deficit would end our malaise. If we balanced the budget by 1996, instead of running the deficit the Congressional Budget Office projects, a reasonable estimate is that our long-term growth rate would rise by only about 0.25 percent.
A President with unlimited political power could balance the budget and simultaneously find the resources to spend on urgent investment needs. In the real world, choices must be made. If a President can save $1 billion through feasible cuts in spending or raise $1 billion by taxing high-income families, should that money be used to reduce the deficit or help repair bridges and finance Head Start? Mr. Clinton's answer is that investments should have first priority. He's right.
Ross Perot, with a single-minded focus on the deficit, proposed inflicting far more pain than Mr. Clinton is willing to consider. But that doesn't make the Perot program better. The Clinton investment plan would probably do more for growth than Mr. Perot's frontal assault on the deficit.
By contrast, President Bush has no economic plan at all. His only significant initiative is a proposal to cut capital gains taxes -- which would worsen the deficit, do little to stimulate private investment and do nothing at all to meet our increasingly desperate needs for investment in the infrastructure and in children.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: BROWN'S RESIGNATION;
Brown Abruptly Resigns His Police Post

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Lee P. Brown resigned suddenly as New York City's Police Commissioner yesterday, jolting the nation's largest police force and raising questions about whether his grand scheme of remaking the department by putting more police officers back on the street will be fully achieved.
The resignation was announced at a hastily arranged news conference at City Hall where Mayor David N. Dinkins also said that David W. Scott, the department's highest ranking uniformed officer, would step down. 
 Mr. Brown, who took control of the department two years ago, said he was leaving to spend more time with his ailing wife, Yvonne. Top police officials, who insisted on anonymity, said Mrs. Brown had cancer. Mr. Brown refused to discuss her condition.
 
Said Little of Wife's Illness
 Mr. Dinkins said that he had known of Mrs. Brown's health problems for several months. But several close aides to Mr. Brown, who described the Commissioner as an intensely private man, said that he had never discussed his wife's illness before Sunday night, when he told them of his plans to leave.
In some recent public appearances, Mr. Brown had expressed a determination to stay in New York and put the police back on the streets where they can win the trust of communities under siege from lawless elements.
While he had long been a national advocate of this approach, he said it was crucial at a time when tension between residents and the police had fueled the recent riots in Los Angeles and posed danger in other cities.
Mayor Dinkins said that Commissioner Brown informed him last Tuesday that he planned to step down because of his wife's condition, but the Mayor said that he kept the news to himself until he had time to act on it.
 
Effective Sept. 1
 Mr. Brown submitted his resignation, effective Sept. 1, to Mr. Dinkins on Sunday night at a private dinner at Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's official residence. The Mayor appointed Mr. Brown's chief deputy, Raymond Kelly, a 29-year veteran of the force, to be acting commissioner.
Mr. Brown's resignation comes at a difficult time for the Dinkins administration: In recent months it has been at odds with the Police Department following charges of police corruption and excessive force in the racial unrest in Washington Heights. Last month, Mayor Dinkins announced his support for an all-civilian complaint review board, while Mr. Brown has adamantly supported keeping the board mixed with police and civilians.
Such public disagreements led to speculation around City Hall that Mr. Brown had been pressured to leave or that he was angry with the administration's handling of the review-board issue and had decided to leave.
At the news conference, Mr. Brown rejected such notions, saying: "My priorities are quite clear. My family comes first." The Commissioner said that he planned to return to Houston, where he served as police commissioner before coming to New York in 1990 and where he will teach criminal justice at Texas Southern University.
Mr. Brown said he would move to Houston because he had two daughters attending college there and the family would be closer while his wife receives medical treatment. When pressed for details about his wife's health at a meeting with reporters at Police Headquarters he said: "I have already said all I intend to say about my wife. She is a private person."
Because his wife's condition had worsened in recent months, Mr. Brown said, he had been speaking with several universities about a teaching position.
Mayor Dinkins said that he understood and supported the Commissioner's decision to leave the force to devote more time to his family and that he would be sorely missed. "It's a very sad moment," Mr. Dinkins said. "I did not try to talk him out of it. It was not negotiable. It would challenge our relationship if I tried to talk him out of it."
Mr. Brown was the architect of the administration's plan to increase public safety by remaking the police force. That vision included increasing the number of officers on foot patrol and encouraging them to form community ties and enlist the help of residents in solving crimes, a concept known as community policing.
The Mayor praised Mr. Brown's short tenure as Police Commissioner, saying that he had laid the foundation for achieving that vision with more officers patrolling the streets and a significant decline in crime, despite a national trend upward.
 
Efforts Praised
 Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a private police watchdog group, called Mr. Brown a "champion of public safety" and said that community policing would probably have never come to New York City without the Commissioner's drive and talents. "I'm really sorry to see him go because he really has made a difference in a very short time," he said.
Phil Caruso, head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said that he was saddened by Mr. Brown's departure because the Commissioner had shown himself to be an expert manager who really understood the conditions that police officers face and who had worked to improve them. "He's been a man of his word, and we liked him," Mr. Caruso said.
Mr. Brown's plan for putting police officers back on the streets is far from complete. So far, every precinct has divided its area into geographic beats and the number of "community patrol officers" who are assigned to watch over those areas has been increased to 40, from 10. But only one precinct -- the 72d in Sunset Park, Brooklyn -- has switched its entire force to that model. And the entire department is still being trained in new techniques aimed at seeking innovative solutions to crime rather than responding to emergencies.
"Community policing has yet to go into high gear," Mr. Reppetto said.
 
Search Panel to Be Appointed
 Mr. Dinkins said that he would soon appoint a search committee to begin evaluating candidates to succeed Mr. Brown, and is likely to face tremendous pressure from his core constituents to choose a Hispanic or black commissioner. The corruption inquiry will also put pressure on the Mayor to choose an outsider.
But yesterday the Mayor said that the search would not be limited to black candidates, and that he was looking for "the most qualified person for Police Commissioner."
Mr. Dinkins said that Acting Commissioner Kelly, who is white and a veteran of the force, would not be excluded from consideration.
Chief Scott, who has been on the force for 30 years, said he would retire because of poor health. He refused to elaborate but several police officials said that they were aware that he had been having health problems for some time.
 The Housing Commissioner's correct name is Felice L. Michetti, and she remains in the post.
The correct name of Ms. Hernandez-Pinero's predecessor is Laura D. Blackburne; she is thus former chairwoman of the Housing Authority, not former Housing Commissioner.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS
Taubman Centers, a Mall Empire, to Go Public;
Still Dealing And Living In 80's Style

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
Contrary to the talk from the Hamptons' links to London's auction rooms, A. Alfred Taubman is not going bust, at least if his extravagant life style is any indicator. At a time when developers are struggling to survive, the 67-year-old shopping center and real estate magnate is acting as if the 80's never ended.
He is still collecting art, still playing host to parties at his homes in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.; Manhattan; Southampton; London and Palm Beach, still playing golf and attending game-hunting parties and still globetrotting in his private jet. He has money in the bank, $130 million to be exact -- the proceeds from the sale of part of his stake in Sotheby's, the auction house he bought nine years ago. He remains chairman and still owns $170 million worth of Sotheby's stock. 
 Now, Mr. Taubman is even looking to expand his billion-dollar empire by building more shopping centers or buying existing ones, despite the distressed retail climate. He is also going public with his company, he said, to make it easier to finance expansion.
 
Planning for Expansion
 "Years ago there were plenty of funds available from banks, but banks are overextended these days," Mr. Taubman said in an interview earlier this summer. "By issuing a public offering we are giving people an opportunity to become investors in a profitable and successful business."
And in a revamping connected to the public offering, Mr. Taubman and his family are effectively being forgiven $450 million in personal loans.
Whether he is discussing Monets or malls, Mr. Taubman is a gifted salesman. With a Midwestern twang and the gusto of a used-car salesman, he seems to think anything is believable -- even that the recession has not affected his business.
Real estate executives, fearful of Mr. Taubman's power, would talk about him only on condition of anonymity. What they are saying is that his decision to take the shopping centers public has been in the works for years but that now he is being forced to raise money to cover some losses. The setbacks, they say, have come both from real estate investments like 712 Fifth Avenue, the landmark office building between 55th and 56th Streets that also houses Henri Bendel, and his retailing investment in Woodward & Lothrop, the Washington-based department store chain.
The office building is 50 percent vacant. Woodward, which he bought for $162 million in 1984 and for which he has guaranteed more than $300 million in loans, reported a $43.6 million loss last year, company officials say.
Nevertheless, the 6-foot-3-inch developer still thinks big and talks big. "I'm not liquidating assets; I'm repositioning them," he said, sitting in his office at 712 Fifth Avenue behind an oversized conference table custom-designed by Michael Graves, the Princeton, N.J., architect. (The space next door he rented to his old friend John Gutfreund, who resigned as chairman of Salomon Brothers after that firm's Treasury market scandal last summer).
"I'm looking at my business long term," Mr. Taubman said.
Since he started his business 42 years ago, Mr. Taubman has been given credit for the evolution of plain suburban shopping centers, once referred to as "strip centers," into architecturally designed, multi-storied structures that his colleagues say are an art form in their own right. His are the most extravagant and elite -- and some of the priciest for tenants. They are filled with such high-end retailers as Bottega Veneta and Ralph Lauren, Saks Fifth Avenue and Yves Saint Laurent.
But it has not been so easy to fill his two real estate holdings in Manhattan -- 712 Fifth Avenue and the 34-story, 515-foot-tall granite and glass building at 1325 Avenue of the Americas, developed in collaboration with Edward J. Minskoff Equities.
"I paid $12 million a year and a half ago and am a limited partner," Mr. Taubman said of 1325 Avenue of the Americas, at 54th Street. "That's my total responsibility."
The other building, 712 Fifth Avenue, is a rockier tale. Housed in the old Rizzoli building, it was originally a team effort between the Taubman Company and Salomon Equities. But when Salomon Equities went bankrupt two years ago, the Taubman Company became the project's managing partner. Of the office space, Mr. Taubman says that so far it is about 50 percent leased, which he acknowledges is a blow. "But it's certainly not making a change in my life style," he said.
 
A Shift in Retailing
 Little, it seems, does make a dent in his life. Many retailers say the developer is throwing away money on what appears to be a losing proposition in Woodward & Lothrop. Nordstrom, Macy and other national retailers have moved in on and conquered its traditional turf in Washington and Philadelphia. Some investors are asking how Woodward can make it when Garfinckel's, Washington's high-end local department store, was forced out of business by this crowd.
Mr. Taubman is moving the company in a new direction, to fill a gap in what he perceives the public needs and wants -- high-end home stores. His new free-standing stores are not meant to compete with Ikea or Conran's, but to appeal to a more affluent shopper. So far he has opened two Woodward & Lothrop Home Stores in shopping centers in the Washington area, and he reports they are performing well. But the company can provide no figures to back up the claim.
 
People 'Thought I Was Crazy'
 "We realize we have to lose money for a while, but we've made the important initial investment," Mr. Taubman said. "People may think it's a crazy investment, but people thought I was crazy when I bought Sotheby's."
 Indeed, in Sotheby's he managed to make a profit from the time he bought the company in 1983, marrying his lifelong passion for art with his skill as a retailer and developer. Mr. Taubman's flair for retailing helped transform Sotheby's from a sleepy auctioneer frequented mostly by dealers to a one-stop shopping center that offers a broader mix of customers everything from financing to appraisals, repairs and sales.
In the 80's, the formula worked; speculators loved being seen bidding in public. Now, however, Sotheby's, along with the rest of the auction business, is suffering from a sluggish economy. When the company released its end-of-season figures last week, it reported sales of $1.14 billion, a decline of 15.5 percent from last season.
Sotheby's is also watching a gradual erosion of its market share and stock price. Seven years ago, the auction house had 60 percent of the market, while archrival Christie's had 40 percent. Now, Sotheby's reports it has 52 percent.
Still, Mr. Taubman insists his decision to sell a bulk of the company's shares had little to do with the economy or his own personal finances. "The company has a great name and a great future," he said. "I still have control of it, and I still feel I can be important to Sotheby's."
"But I'm 67 years old," he added. "It's time to start planning for the future." For this week at least, Mr. Taubman is in Europe, joining his wife, Judy, who was in Paris attending the fall couture shows.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 5, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the real estate developer A. Alfred Taubman misstated the name of a former co-owner of a building at 712 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan in some editions. It is Solomon Equities. The article also described the company's financial condition incorrectly. It has never declared bankruptcy.
