HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Quiet Bond Market Awaits Data

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market's focus turned yesterday toward Friday's unemployment report for July and the auction of around $36 billion of Treasury notes and bonds next week.
The uncertainty before both events, combined with some mixed economic data, made for a quiet day in the market as a lot of investors stayed on the sidelines. But yesterday was notable as Salomon Brothers returned as a full-time player in the bond market for the first time since its Treasury auction scandal was disclosed a year ago this Sunday. 
 The firm's suspensions were lifted effective yesterday by the Federal Reserve and by the Treasury. Salomon, which was suspended by the Treasury last Aug. 18, can now bid for its customers in Treasury auctions again. For almost the last year, it could bid only for its own account.
On June 1, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York suspended Salomon from trading government securities with the Fed. These are transactions that the central bank does with its primary dealers to control the growth rate of the nation's money supply.
 
A Mood for a Market
 The unemployment report on Friday may establish a mood for a market that has been through several emotional swings lately and is now waiting to see if the direction will change again. The report could determine if the recent rally in the long bond will continue and push interest rates through their January lows toward levels not seen since 1986.
The tone set Friday will also be important for the three quarterly Treasury auctions next week. A stall in the rally may lessen the appetite for the notes and bonds to be sold, depriving the Government of some small savings on its interest bill. The details of the auctions will be announced Wednesday.
It was the surprisingly gloomy June report, which pushed the unemployment report up to 7.8 percent, that set off the rally in the market, which surged for most of July until it ran out of steam at the end of last week.
As of now, the consensus seems to be that there will be no big surprises, with the level of nonfarm jobs expected to rise about as much as the 117,000 decline in June.
To some, like John Costas, managing director of government trading and sales at the First Boston Corporation, an unemployment report of this kind would "reverse the weakness of last month but not show any real strength." And this, he said, would mean that yield on the 30-year bond, which was at 7.44 percent in late trading yesterday, compared with 7.45 percent on Friday, would continue to decline after the quarterly Treasury auctions next week. And he said the yield would break through the January low of 7.38 percent.
But Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., thinks that the employment data will be stronger, in fact, about twice the consensus, with nonfarm payroll jobs rising about 200,000. One of his reasons for this forecast is technical, not economic. The jobs survey was taken much later in the month in July than in June, which means that there is more time for the usual stream of summer hirees to be counted.
For him, this stronger number would mean that the rally of July would be over, at least for the rest of the summer.
"If these kinds of numbers came out, I think you would see the market stalling out here," he said. "But I don't think you would see any significant rise in interest rates."
 
Home-Mortgage Refinancings
 The fact that interest rates would not rise significantly is the important factor. If this is the case -- even with stronger employment data than the consensus forecast -- then the window of opportunity for refinancing home mortgages will stay open much longer than it did in January, when long-term yields hit their recent low.
In January, that window was open for only about two weeks because the bond market reacted negatively to signals, which later proved faulty, that a healthy economic recovery was getting under way.
The market for mortgage-backed securities has been hit hard in the last two to three weeks because the refinancings mean that people holding the securities may be paid much sooner than expected. This leaves them with cash that will probably have to be invested at lower interest rates and faces others with losses because many of the mortgage securities were selling at premiums to their face or par value. But the prepayment is at the par value.
In the bond market yesterday, Treasury securities were buffeted early in the day by the report of the National Association of Purchasing Management, which said that its index of economic activity rose to 54.2 percent in July from 52.8 percent in June.
The increase was difficult to interpret. It was up but a little less than some forecasters had expected. Its employment component seemed to signal continued slow growth. Its inflation index was up a little. Bonds and notes fell, then rose, and ended little changed for the day. By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 106 18/32, up 1/8 point to yield 7.44 percent, compared with 7.45 percent on Friday.
The five- and seven-year Treasury notes, which had fallen sharply at the end of last week, were basically unchanged for the day.
In the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the three-month bill was sold at an average discount rate of 3.20 percent, up from 3.18 percent last week. The average discount rate on the six-month bill was 3.30 percent, up from 3.27 percent a week ago. This is the second consecutive week that the discount rates have risen. The rates had fallen 43 basis points, from 3.59 to 3.16, for the three-month bill, and 42 basis points, from 3.66 to 3.24, for the six-month bill, after the Federal Reserve cut its discount rate July 2.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bill:

HEADLINE: How Escobar, a Rare Jailbird, Lined His Nest

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENVIGADO, Colombia, July 31

 BODY:
The image of Pablo Escobar lounging on his prison water bed while coordinating shipments of tons of cocaine to the United States on his cellular telephone is not quite accurate, say lawyers who visited the trafficker in his hillside jail here.
First of all, Colombia's wealthiest citizen had to make do with a foam mattress until his water bed was installed last year. Second, until he received his cellular phone he had only the rustic services of the 50 carrier pigeons in his personal prison aviary. 
 Finally, the lawyers say, the 42-year-old Mr. Escobar was not one to work in bed, and presided over his business meetings at the head of a proper boardroom table. He also enjoyed the use of an office equipped with a computer linked by modem to a national computer network.
What about charges that Mr. Escobar continued trafficking until he escaped from the jail on July 22?
"It was important to have him physically detained, but no one really thought he would stop trafficking," said Juan Guillermo Sepulveda, a lawyer from nearby Medellin who, as local state prosecutor, helped negotiate Mr. Escobar's surrender June 19, 1991.
In the wake of Mr. Escobar's escape, formerly tight-lipped officials are coming forward with a flood of new information confirming long-held suspicions that the fenced-off complex overlooking this suburb was not the trafficker's jail but his fortress, a cage that he was able to gild to his liking and from which it appears he could have escaped whenever he wanted.
But there was little reason for Mr. Escobar to want to leave, not until the Government began a crackdown last month to reassert control over the prison. With the state paying his security bill, Mr. Escobar quickly developed the comforts of home in his prison compound.
For exercise, there was a soccer field and a personal gymnasium. He spruced up his personal living quarters with rugs, walk-in closets, a video cassette player, a stereo system, a bar, a refrigerator, a 60-inch color television and a whirlpool bath. The living quarters included a reception area with a wood-burning fireplace. The police also discovered large quantities of pornographic magazines and videos.
"Pablo Escobar's rooms looked like a wealthy bachelor's pad," an official in the state prosecutor's office told the newspaper El Tiempo on Friday. "It seems to have been designed by an interior decorator. The colors of the rugs, curtains and bedspreads match perfectly."
[Two weeks after Mr. Escobar and nine of his cohorts escaped, police officials are increasingly pessimistic that the nationwide manhunt will have any success. On Aug. 4, the authorities announced that overflights of Medellin by United States military spy planes had ended. "It's very difficult to predict the outcome," Fernando Brito, director of Colombia's intelligence police, said in an interview in Bogota. "Escobar is a very wily man and he has very great economic power. We are confronting the world's most powerful criminal."]
Short of domestic servants in luxurious prison, Mr. Escobar impressed several of his guards to serve as bartenders and waiters during his parties, photographs confiscated at the prisons indicate.
The police also found a large selection of women's underwear, leading them to conclude that the prisoners received frequent visits from prostitutes. But one photograph taken at a prison party shows a male trafficker dressed up in women's clothing.
"The whole spectacle is disgusting," Colombia's Attorney General, Gustavo de Greiff, said after inspecting the prison and reviewing a series of party photographs. "It is absolutely incredible that no one rang the alarm bell, that no one said anything."
The authorities suspect that a food truck with a false bottom may have smuggled in the contraband items seized from lockers after Mr. Escobar's escape: computers, pistols, tear-gas masks, radiotelephones, a cellular phone and bundles of United States currency.
But not all of Mr. Escobar's comforts were obtained illicitly. Correspondence between officials and lawyers for Mr. Escobar in the period leading up to his surrender to the authorities shows the lawyers won guarantees of Mr. Escobar's freedom to choose his guards and to design his jail, nicknamed The Cathedral.
Inside the jail, 17 members of the 28-man guard service were picked by Mr. Escobar's allies in the municipal government of Envigado, his power base for two decades. Dressed in civilian clothes, these 17 guards patrolled the jail's innermost security ring, a report issued on Thursday by Colombia's National Association of Prison Guards said.
Their shift from prison guard to bodyguard became apparent during the army's recent early-morning assault to reassert control over Mr. Escobar and his 14 fellow inmates. While guards from the federal service offered no resistance, seven of the Envigado guards fought back, and one was wounded.
"Look at the prison guards like a presidential guard," Jose Salomon Lozano, one of Mr. Escobar's lawyers, suggested in an interview in Medellin. "They have to respond for the life of the President. They cannot allow an attack from the outside. Enemies can appear disguised as soldiers."
The army assault was prompted in part by Mr. Escobar's refusal to allow security changes at The Cathedral. According to a Government report made public last week, an engineering company inspected the jail last October and pronounced it "very vulnerable" to escape.
In January, Fernando Carrillo Florez, then Colombia's Justice Minister, maintained that the prison "does not fulfill the minimum requirements for a high-security jail." He recommended a $4 million construction plan, including fencing off prisoners' free access to the eight-acre prison grounds and fortifying perimeters with concertina wire, land mines and electronic sensors.
But work progressed slowly. On June 8, it stopped entirely after "two prisoners demanded that the contractors suspend work," the Government report said. Unhappy with the changes, Mr. Escobar summoned a crew of Envigado city workers, who started to tear down an offending stretch of electrified fence. Army officers ordered that the fence be put back up.
"As soon as work resumed, 10 prisoners intimidated and beat the construction foremen and, with death threats, demanded suspension of work," the log reported for June 12. "Work was suspended."
To back up their threats, several prisoners photographed the construction workers and said they would be killed if they were ever seen again in Envigado.
Suspicious that Mr. Escobar might have ordered the construction of an escape tunnel, Colombia's Defense Minister, Rafael Pardo, ordered the air force to take infrared photographs of the prison grounds, a technique that allows detection of tunnels.
On June 27, an air force plane made a successful photo run, eluding fire from a prison antiaircraft battery. The photographs did not reveal tunneling activity.
 
Bombing of Prison Feared
 The antiaircraft battery had been installed in response to Mr. Escobar's fear that his numerous enemies -- drug rivals, relatives of murder victims, or the United States Government -- would try to bomb the prison.
Indeed, on March 9 the police in El Salvador announced the arrest of nine people who allegedly had shipped three 500-pound bombs to Cali, Colombia. Arrested members of the Salvadoran Air Force said Cali's cocaine cartel intended to use the bombs to obliterate their Medellin rivals in prison here.
On Mr. Escobar's orders, construction workers dug a rudimentary bomb shelter. Civil aviation authorities closed the airspace over the prison and guards had standing orders to douse the lights if a plane entered the area at night. The traffickers also controlled the prison's electrical system, an advantage they may have put to use when they escaped in the early hours of July 22 during a mysterious three-minute blackout.
Many people here believe that the Mr. Escobar had slipped out of jail on several previous occasions.
"Since September, my in-laws have been saying that Escobar has been seen around town," an American woman living in Envigado said. "I guess he was tired of being locked up and went out for joy rides."
 
His Daughter's Message
 Mr. Sepulveda, the lawyer, recalled that during a jail visit last year the trafficker told him, "Here I have what I like -- books, soccer and my family."
During his 13-month jail stay, Mr. Escobar refused to permit the police to take identity photographs. The only known photographs of Mr. Escobar taken inside the jail, published this week in Semana magazine, show a heavy-set family man with a mustache surrounded by his wife, Victoria Eugenia Henao, his 15-year-old son, Juan Pablo, and his 4-year-old daughter, Manuela, who held a pet white rabbit.
"Daddy, I love you, and I send you Colombia's biggest kiss," Manuela chirped in a radio message the day her father fled the jail.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Weakness in a G.O.P. Citadel Threatens Bush in California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Aug. 4

 BODY:
The sunny, deeply conservative political terrain of Orange County has served as the staging ground of Nixonism and the Reagan Revolution. Now it may prove the Waterloo of the Republican heir of those two Presidents, George Bush.
A deep disaffection over President Bush, from both his right and left, is spreading through this traditional bastion of Republican strength. The Republican leadership has been shaken by recent polls showing the President trailing the Democratic nominee, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas -- and this in a county where Mr. Bush whipped Gov. Michael S. Dukakis four years ago by a 69-to-31-percent margin.
 
A Change of Heart
 The disaffected include Patricia Cox, a longtime resident active in social and charitable affairs who says she has voted Republican since she went for Thomas E. Dewey in his losing race against Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1944. But as she peered out over Upper Newport Bay from the shady lawn of her large home she declared herself a Clinton backer. 
 "I can't believe Bush's stand on choice and fetal-tissue research," Mrs. Cox, 70 years old, said with dismay.
The change of heart may have come more from events in her life than from anything politicians have done. George Bush, after all, had the same stance against abortion and tissue experiments four years ago. But since then, Mrs. Cox's battle against cancer and the illnesses of several relatives have altered her perspective on issues that are both medical and personal.
A few miles from Mrs. Cox's home, in the sleek business parks of Irvine, Roger W. Johnson, a former Bush contributor who is chairman of the board of the Western Digital Corporation, a maker of computer parts, is preparing to forsake Republican roots that go back to the Eisenhower and Goldwater days, but for a different reason: the slumping economy. "He's made an art form out of doing nothing," Mr. Johnson said of the President. "They don't know what's going on in the country. We cannot compete internationally; the schools are in shambles; people cannot get health care."
The President's backers insist his stock will rise after the Republican National Convention, which begins in two weeks in Houston, and when wavering Republicans here confront the awful prospect of actually voting Democratic. But they nevertheless fear that Mr. Bush will not carry Orange County by a large enough margin to offset the normally heavy Democratic pluralities in the Los Angeles and San Francisco areas. At stake are California's 54 electoral votes.
"The President's in very serious difficulty," said Allan E. Hoffenblum, a Republican political consultant in Los Angeles. "If he's in trouble in Orange County, he's in trouble, period. Bush will carry Orange County, but the question is, will he get just 52 percent? Any time a Republican gets less than 60 percent in Orange County, he loses the state."
No Republican since 1880 has won the Presidency without carrying California.
 
Sensing the Urgency
 Evidently sensing the urgency, the President has visited California five times this year, most recently Thursday. He came to Orange County, spoke at the Anaheim plant of a robotics maker and tried to appeal to concern for military preparedness.
For now, the news is mostly bad for the President:
*A poll by The Orange County Register on July 16-17, just after the Democratic National Convention, found Governor Clinton leading the President in the county, 42 to 35 percent, with former backers of Ross Perot going for Mr. Clinton by nearly two to one. The poll of 403 registered voters had a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.
A Field Poll taken July 22-27 gave Mr. Clinton what the poll called a "phenomenal" 62-to-28 percent lead over Mr. Bush statewide, the largest lead ever for a Presidential candidate in the 45-year history of the poll. The poll of 1,192 adults had a margin of error of three percentage points.
*An editorial in the libertarian Orange County Register Sunday called on President Bush to quit the race, saying he has "shown too much of a willingness to work in tandem with Congressional Democrats."
*A poll July 25-27 by Fairbank, Maullin & Associates, a Democratic survey firm in Santa Monica, put the Clinton lead at 52 to 26 percent in California. The poll of 800 voters had a margin of error of four percentage points.
All of this comes against a backdrop of a county of 2.4 million people which, while still 79 percent white and 55 percent Republican by registration, has long outgrown its caricature image of wealthy right-wing zealots battling Communism, taxation and big government. Moreover, its economy, heavily dependent on Government aerospace and military contracts, has suffered in the recession.
"This translates into more people who were living a blissful, middle-class life who are now unemployed or threatened by unemployment," said Richard Maullin of the survey firm. "And as it continues to urbanize, the county becomes more complex. It has a growing minority population, and substantial numbers of Democrats. It just doesn't fit the conservative stereotype as much as it used to."
In all this, President Bush has appeared to many residents to be remote and detached from California's problems. And the Republican ranks are increasingly influenced by business-oriented young people who are put off by the Bush-Quayle attempts to appeal to the religious right, abortion foes and "family" values.
"You have a lot of young, under 35, swing Republicans," said Mr. Hoffenblum, the Republican consultant. "They're conservative on economic issues, but not on social and environmental ones. They were originally part of the Democratic base that the Republicans picked up during the 80's. They're uncomfortable with the religious right." Mr. Hoffenblum might have added that these are the very people Mr. Clinton is wooing.
David L. Scott is one of these people. He moved to Orange County from Texas almost three years ago and quickly became involved in Republican politics, giving $500 a year to the local party and serving on the board of directors of the Silver Circle, a fund-raising group. But Mr. Scott, 30-year-old director of government relations for a computer software company, is now leaning toward Mr. Clinton.
"I look at Bush and see a nice guy who is going in circles," said Mr. Scott. He said he recently wrote the Republican Party complaining that it should avoid getting involved in "endorsing social viewpoints," like the abortion issue.
 
The Abortion Issue
 Indeed, the abortion issue appears to have been a major factor for Republican women in the county, where the polls show there is strong backing for a woman's right to choose, as there is in California generally. Last Thursday, Anita M. Mangels of Laguna Beach, who says she has never voted Democratic, led a demonstration against President Bush at his Anaheim visit.
"First and foremost, I am pro-choice," said Ms. Mangels, laid off from her job with a real estate developer. She said she felt betrayed by President Bush when he agreed to raise taxes.
Greg Haskin, executive director of the Orange County Republican Party, said he was confident that Mr. Bush's support would solidify once memories of the Democratic convention faded and the President began his campaign in earnest. He disputed suggestions that the abortion issue was crucial.
"We've had eight years of pro-life Ronald Reagan and four years of pro-life George Bush," he said. "The economy is the important factor."
For some time, California Republican leaders have been warning the White House. "Clinton is receiving a massive Republican crossover, which is very unusual in a county where Republican loyalty is so high," said Tony Quinn, a Republican strategist in Sacramento. "What you're seeing is the Bush Administration's general neglect of California's economic interests.
But Mark Baldassare, a poll-taker and longtime student of Orange County politics who teaches urban planning at the University of California at Irvine, warns against writing off Mr. Bush. "There is so much pent-up frustration right now, so many people looking for a way out of the economic malaise," he said. "But if Bush can come up with a plan to make people regain confidence, he'll get the voters back."
Still, Larry Thomas, a longtime Orange County public relations adviser to the national Republican Party, said many in the local party had been urging the White House to reassure Californians, to demonstrate that "what they are seeing is not the absolute demise of one of the great states in the nation but a painful restructuring, that there is some hope."

Companies
Phar-Mor said top executives had embezzled company funds and reported $350 million in nonexistent profits for the high-flying discount drug chain. Phar-Mor said that Michael I. Monus, 43, a company co-founder and executive in the Colorado Rockies baseball expansion team, who was dismissed as president last week, had also "diverted company funds for his own use." [Page D1.]
Delta Air Lines discounted its tourist fares to Europe and Israel for the fall and winter. Continental matched the discounts of 25 to 35 percent, while United and American said they would be competitive. Northwest is studying the matter. [D1.] 
 Emerson Electric and Monsanto announced a $1.28 billion deal for Emerson to buy Fisher Controls International from Monsanto. Analysts praised the move. The two companies will be the biggest makers of certain industrial process measuring equipment and control valves. [D3.]

Ross Cosmetics appointed Richard P. Rifenburgh as chairman, succeeding Eugene Derry, who retired as chairman and president of the distributor of imitation designer-label perfumes. [D4.]

Canada, Mexico and the U.S. raced toward an agreement on a North American free trade accord, trying to fashion a single broad compromise on a short list of small but politically touchy differences, including trade in cars, energy and textiles. [D1.]
The U.S. contends Japan has not been doing enough to keep its pledge to buy more foreign semiconductors. [D5.]
 
The Economy
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 3.9 percent in late July, but sales for the month stayed close to the gradual rate of recovery that began in the spring. Some dealers, auto executives and analysts called the results sluggish; others contended that they were not bad in light of recent weak economic indicators. [D5.]
The index of leading indicators dropped 0.2 percent in June. It was the first decline in six months for the forecasting measure, but analysts said it did not signify renewed recesssion. [D5.]
 
Markets
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 11.08 points, closing at 3,384.32 and snapping a five-session string of gains, but advancing issues led declines 856 to 832 in the broader market. [D6.]

Wheat futures prices fell for the 10th straight day. A Government report indicated that the crop would be plentiful, and export demand seems weak. [D14.] The dollar rose slightly in slow dealings; gold prices barely moved. [D14.]

Honda is catering to car buffs' love of the open air in its new Civic del Sol. Designed with a Cray supercomputer, the two-seat roadster has a removable roof panel that stores in the trunk. [D4.]
For bicyclists who do not like shifting gears, the Dugil Automatic Derailleur uses centrifugal force to shift speeds. [D4.]

HEADLINE: 3 Countries Move Closer to Free-Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Canada, Mexico and the United States made steady progress today toward agreement on a North American free-trade accord, pushing to fashion a single broad compromise on a short list of small but politically touchy differences.
The final step is likely to come this week, possibly as soon as Wednesday morning but more likely on Thursday or Friday, people involved in the negotiations said. Differences on all of the remaining sticking points in the negotiations, including the contentious issues of trade in automobiles, energy and textiles, were narrowing. 
 A few smaller issues also remained, including how quickly tariffs would be reduced on products like beer and glass.
President Bush is eager to announce the agreement personally, and will not be in Washington until Thursday night, people involved in the negotiations said. So the final touches may not be put on the pact until then, with a series of news conferences taking place on Friday.
As an agreement grew near, the Administration and its allies among Congressional Republicans began gearing up their effort to sell the anticipated pact to lawmakers.
Seeking to garner Democratic votes, two senior Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee endorsed late Monday a resolution calling for the free-trade pact not to hurt American health, safety or environmental standards.
Kathleen A. Lydon, the chief spokeswoman for Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said that the resolution, sponsored by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, did not contradict the agreement. The House is scheduled to consider the nonbinding resolution on Thursday.
"They're going to try to hug us to death," said a Democratic Congressional aide.
The talks were expected to continue until Wednesday morning.
During 13 months of talks covering everything from truck routes to avocado diseases, trade officials from the three countries have frequently said each sector of the economy would be handled separately.
But now the principle of matching concessions within industries is fraying as the negotiators assemble their final list of differences and try to resolve them in one final deal.
Gradual progress was made on some issues, like textiles and oil shipments, this morning. Mexico gave a partial guarantee to the United States that it would continue supplying oil during international crises. Negotiators also neared agreement on a requirement that cars have slightly more than 60 percent of their value produced in North America to qualify for duty-free treatment.
But most of the remaining disagreements, notably involving trade in automobiles and rules for resolving commercial disputes, are down to a few sticking points where compromises involving several industries may be made.
In the auto dispute, American negotiators are close to paying for a recent concession benefiting American workers with a concession to Mexico that would hurt the same workers, rather than with, say, a concession that would hurt American farmers or aircraft industry workers.
Mexico agreed 10 days ago in Mexico City to abolish over 10 years its complicated system for restricting car imports, a move that should help American auto makers and their employees. People with detailed information on the negotiations said today that in exchange, the United States might quickly exempt Mexico from the current 25 percent tariff on imported pickup trucks. Mexico currently produces few trucks, but reducing the tariff would make truck production much more attractive.
A report of the tentative American concession first appeared in The Journal of Commerce today.
Car and truck imports are a sensitive political issue, particularly in an election year. Last week, the House passed a broad bill on tariffs that would reclassify mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles as light trucks instead of as cars, subjecting them to the 25 percent duty.
Representative Sander M. Levin, the Michigan Democrat who sponsored the vehicle section of the House bill, was leery of the American concession. He said in an interview that detailed studies should be done before the lawmakers considered the agreement.
"Nobody has analyzed it, and before it's submitted it needs to be analyzed," Mr. Levin said.
Steven M. Beckman, the international economist for the United Automobile Workers, said the union opposed any exceptions from the stiff tariff on light trucks. The Bush Administration has insisted that the accord being negotiated must eventually eliminate all tariffs on trade within the continent.
But people involved in the negotiations defended a reduction in truck tariffs, saying its effect would be limited. New Japanese and European assembly plants in Mexico would not qualify for the exemption, and American companies would find it too expensive to close their existing factories in the United States and replace them with factories in Mexico, they said.

HEADLINE: IRAQ FOOD IMPORTS ARE SAID TO DROP

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Iraq's imports of basic foods like rice, sugar, cooking oil and tea have fallen sharply in recent weeks, say Government officials here and private traders in the Jordanian capital who traditionally handle most of that country's import needs.
Iraqi merchants have virtually ceased placing new orders here for some weeks now, their Jordanian counterparts say, apparently because of the disruption caused by a more than 50 percent fall in the value of the Iraqi dinar last month and after Baghdad executed some 40 merchants it had accused of profiteering. 
 This sudden devaluation of the dinar, which pushed the Iraqi currency down from about 14 dinars to the dollar to 22 or 24, and the disruption it caused may represent a first success for a reported plan by the Central Intelligence Agency in Saudi Arabia to destabilize President Saddam Hussein's Government by flooding Iraq with forged dinar notes in order to create hyperinflation.
 
A Sharp Drop in Imports
 The total flow of Iraqi imports through the Jordanian Red Sea port of Aqaba -- most of which consists of staple foods -- has dropped sharply from a 1992 peak of 550,000 tons in May to 160,000 tons in June and only 80,000 tons in July, the Jordanian Finance Minister, Basel Jardaneh, said in an interview.
With private Iraqi merchants no longer ordering, most of this food is now being imported by the Baghdad Government, which provides Iraqis with a basic monthly food ration at very low prices.
Mr. Jardaneh said he could not explain the fall, but he speculated it might either mean Iraq has sufficient stocks to last for a while or that it is running low on dollars to pay for new supplies.
While Iraq traditionally imports flour and processed foods from neighboring Turkey, Syria and Iran, the port of Aqaba is the cheapest entry point for rice, sugar, cooking oil and tea, which come by ship from the Far East.
Jordan's Finance Minister insisted the Government is strictly enforcing United Nations sanctions against Iraq by allowing it to import only food and medicine and certain other supplies approved on humanitarian grounds by the Security Council.
He said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had appeared satisfied with Jordan's enforcement procedures after being briefed on the situation when he visited Amman on July 21.
In June, after an American intelligence estimate that 30 percent of the goods crossing from Jordan into Iraq violated sanctions, the United States Director of Central Intelligence, Robert Gates, visited Amman in an unsuccessful effort to persuade King Hussein to install United Nations monitors on the border to check what was being exported to Iraq.
But the visit led to a sharp tightening of Jordanian controls, diplomats here say, which appear to have eliminated many sanctions violations.
 
Truck Traffic Drops
 Foreign journalists who visited the main Jordan-Iraq border crossing at El Ruweished on Monday were told by the customs director, Aziz Bsoul, that the number of trucks going into Jordan has fallen from about 400 a day in June to 200 a day in July and was only 42 on Sunday and 30 the day before.
The United States, Britain and France, which have stationed warships outside Aqaba to enforce the sanctions, have also stepped up searches of cargo vessels using the port to look for banned Iraqi imports or exports.
Diplomats here say the number of trucks crossing into Iraq from Turkey has also fallen drastically in recent weeks. But the situation on Iraq's borders with Syria and Iran is unclear.
Jordanian traders here report that Iraqi merchants who traditionally order staple foods as well as detergents, razor blades and other items through them have disappeared from the market over the last few weeks.
The immediate cause was the sudden fall in the Iraqi dinar's value on the free currency market here last month.
Many Iraqi importers suffered big losses as a result of this devaluation, which made it hard for them to re-sell merchandise at prices that covered their dollar costs.
But the final straw came when the Iraqi authorities, facing mounting public anger at rising food prices brought about by the devaluation, arrested some 500 merchants on charges of speculation and profiteering and then executed 42 of them in an effort to force prices lower.
The effect, Jordanian merchants say, was to bring private imports of basic foods to a virtual standstill, with Iraqi traders frightened they would face imprisonment or death unless they sold their goods at a loss.

HEADLINE: Israel Threads the Maze Toward U.S. Loan Pact

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Here is Israel's economic Catch-22 as its pursuit of billions of dollars in United States loan guarantees moves into high gear this week:
To get the aid, as well as to assert its spending priorities, the new Government has canceled plans for 12,000 publicly financed apartments, nearly half of them for Jewish settlers in the occupied territories. 
 But by putting the brakes on future construction, the Israelis have undercut a booming sector of their economy, one that accounts for more than half of the 6 percent growth projected for the gross national product this year.
In other words, in part to obtain American help intended ultimately to make the economy run faster, Israel has taken measures that will probably cause it to limp a bit for a while.
"The next two years will be difficult," Finance Minister Avraham Shohat acknowledged, telling a parliamentary committee a few days ago that deep slices in the country's 11.6 percent unemployment rate are not likely until 1994. But the situation will then improve considerably, he promised.
 
A Political Conundrum
 For Americans and other interested foreigners, the loan guarantees tend to be seen as a political question: How badly do the Israelis want this help in absorbing some 400,000 immigrants who have arrived over the last three years, most of them from the former Soviet Union? Do they want it badly enough to stop building settlements in the occupied territories, as the Bush Administration would like?
The answer from the previous Likud-led Government was no. In turn, the Administration told the Israelis to forget about the guarantees, which do not involve actual loans but rather a United States pledge to back up Israel when it enters international markets to borrow $10 billion over the next five years.
Now the new Labor-led Government of Prime Minister of Yitzhak Rabin says it will greatly scale back future settlement-building. The Americans smile at this and suggest that some form of loan guarantees will be approved, although important details are still unsettled and may not be resolved before Mr. Rabin journeys to Kennebunkport, Me., next week for two days of meetings and appreciative pats on the back from President Bush.
These political considerations aside, the loan guarantees have become something of a grail for Israeli economic planners. For starters, $2 billion in loans were included in the 1992 budget that has been huffing along without them since last January. Looking ahead, Israel's economic establishment views the guarantees as the seal of approval it needs for favorable terms on the loans.
"The guarantees have become a symbol of the prospects for the Israeli economy," said Jacob Frenkel, governor of the Bank of Israel. "Whether legitimately or not, they have become part of the economic reality. They are the key to creating the environment for turning around the recent slowdown in immigration and the entire mood of investment."
Mr. Frenkel left for Washington today with a new plan for economic change that the Israelis hope will satisfy Washington's concern about the Israeli budget, which is almost as important as its interest in curtailing settlement. While Israeli officials insist that they are not about to accept economic dictates from the United States, they acknowledge that they can hardly ignore American wishes.
Last week Mr. Frenkel warned the Rabin Cabinet that "a disaster" lay ahead if it used the borrowed money to cover budget deficits, instead of financing investments to create jobs for Russian Jews and thus make it easier to repay the loans.
On this score, leaders of the new Government insist there is no need to worry. Their goal, Mr. Shohat, the Finance Minister, said in an interview, is to reduce the inefficient, centralized economic planning that runs deep here, to sell off state-owned companies, to encourage exports and to liberalize financial markets.
Moreover, the minister said, anyone who worries that Labor will inevitably fall back on its familiar ways, born of an Eastern European socialism that even Eastern Europe has abandoned, has it "totally upside down."
"We want to attract investors and create jobs," he said. "We are going to put a lot of money in infrastructure, in communications, in research and development. The 1993 budget will reflect this shift in priorities."
Nonetheless, there are those who worry, especially free-trade advocates like Alvin Rabushka, an American economist who has closely studied (and criticized) Israeli economic ways. Mr. Rabushka is not convinced that this Government, any more than its predecessor, will use the money it hopes to borrow to strengthen the economy. This is a country hooked on subsidies, he asserts, including the $3 billion in economic and military aid it receives from the United States each year.
"It's the only country left in the world that's saying that if we increase the debt of every citizen, we will somehow revitalize the economy," he said.
Other critics question whether Israel now really needs to borrow $10 billion, for that figure was premised on having a million immigrants arrive from former Soviet territory over five years.
With unemployment among these newcomers running to nearly 40 percent and the sense of danger they felt in the old Soviet Union now abated, Russians more and more are choosing to stay in Russia. Immigration has been greatly reduced, to about 32,000 people in the first half of the year -- a high figure by historical standards but one-third of the number forecast.
Despite this reduction, Mr. Frenkel, the bank governor, argues that $10 billion is still needed. As for skeptics, he says the question is whether one can have faith that the Government will "use the money correctly."
"My judgment is that conditions exist for that," he said.

HEADLINE: Agreeing to Raise Taxes, Officials Get Out of Jail

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: JACKSON, Ky., Aug. 4

 BODY:
Three Breathitt County officials agreed to raise taxes to balance the budget for the county in Kentucky's Appalachian region, but only after spending four days in jail.
The officials, who are magistrates on the county's governing Fiscal Court, were jailed on Friday for failing to comply with a court order to meet a requirement of the State Constitution to adopt a balanced budget by July 1. In seven successive budget proposals, they refused to adopt a 1 percent payroll tax that state officials said was essential to avoid a $400,000 deficit. 
 Judge James King of the Circuit Court held the three officials in contempt on July 24 and began fining each $200 a day until they adopted a budget acceptable to the state.
On Monday, they grudgingly agreed to support the 1 percent tax that they had said residents of the depressed area about 80 miles southeast of Lexington could not afford. They were freed from jail today to vote on the budget.
The Magistrates, Hubert Hollon, Hershel Manns and Arch Turner received a standing ovation from about 150 spectators as they entered the county courtroom today shortly before noon for the Fiscal Court meeting to vote on the tax.
In a strange reversal, Cecil Clair, who as Judge Executive of the Fiscal Court is the county's highest elected official, and Magistrate Helen Combs, who have consistently voted for the tax, voted against the budget proposed today. They said they disagreed with several items in it.
But the other three county officials prevailed, passing the budget and insuring their freedeom.
A separate ordinance enacting the payroll tax was unanimously approved but must be approved twice more by the Fiscal Court before it becomes official. The county's lawyer, Mike Stidham, said he hoped the tax would take effect by Sept. 1.
The just-freed officials were not happy about trading their votes for freedom. "I think the state has forced us into a position to vote against our consciences," Mr. Hollon had said.
 
Most Services Closed
 When the board missed a July 1 for adopting a balanced budget, the courts closed and garbage collection and most other services in the eastern Kentucky county of 18,000 people were shut down.
Because the county's jail was also closed, the three had to be held in a neighboring county's jail.
After about 60 supporters showed up at the jail on Monday, the three decided that staying in jail was not the solution.
"They realize our only avenue is to vote against our wishes to get out of jail," Mr. Turner said of the supporters.
Breathitt County, in the state's Appalachian coal region, has been hard hit by a mining slump and a sharp drop in its share of the state's coal severance tax. Unemployment was 11.4 percent in May, the most recent figure available.
Despite hard times, some residents said they were willing to pay the tax to keep the magistrates out of jail.
Yvonne Maggard, whose husband is a state legislator, organized the group that visited them in jail. She said that she did not want a tax increase but that being jailed was too high a price for the magistrates to pay.

HEADLINE: Campus Journal;
Teaching Ex-Communists Capitalism

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif., July 31

 BODY:
Until this summer, Mihaly Kopanyi had only one textbook about capitalism for his business school students in Budapest, a recent Hungarian translation of Paul Heyne's "The Economic Way of Thinking."
Now Mr. Kopanyi has a treasure trove of materials -- case studies, professorial bon mots and jottings from dormitory bull sessions -- to take home to the Budapest University of Economic Sciences when he resumes teaching after seven weeks at the Stanford Business School. 
 Mr. Kopanyi is one of eight Eastern and Central European professors who this year, for the first time, are part of the Stanford Executive Program, joining more than 160 senior-level international executives on this sun-baked campus for a summer of instruction in marketing, finance and organizational behavior.
As academics, the eight are better versed in the ins and outs of capitalism than their pupils at home -- undergraduates and graduate students, but most importantly executives who must be re-educated after a lifetime operating not-for-profit businesses.
"We have to change the mentality of our managers," said Marcel Duhaneanu of the Academy of Economic Studies in Bucharest, Romania. "We have to teach them to take risks and to see this activity of making money as important and honorable."
Serguei Vasilievich Sarkissov, who runs the executive training program at the International Business School in Moscow, clucked at how formidable the task is. "Our managers are so ignorant," he said. "They come and ask, 'What means marketing?' "
Before the fall of Communism, these were the Young Turks on their campuses, teaching about stock markets that neither they nor their students had ever seen and trying to explain competitive pricing in a world where central planners decided how much everything cost.
"I was expected to teach Marxist theory, but I considered it quite obsolete," said Lena Minkova Roussenova of the Univeristy of National and World Economy in Sofia, Bulgaria.
In addition to the subject matter at Stanford, the visiting teachers are also studying the pedagogic techniques of American professors, who are more inclined to jocular give-and-take than the stern lecture-and-listen style that predominates in Europe.
The Stanford program is part of a rare cooperative venture of five premier business schools. Along with Harvard, M.I.T., Northwestern and the University of Pennsylvania, Stanford has waived the $25,200 tuition, room and board and paid the travel expenses of the young faculty members because "training the trainers" is the most efficient way to widely disseminate American expertise to the emerging free market economies.
The 100 or so Central and Eastern European professors here, divided among the five campuses, are enrolled this year in general management programs. At Stanford, the professors live in a dormitory alongside excutives from Merrill Lynch, Bank Suez and Liz Claiborne, to name a few of the companies represented.
They attend morning lectures by such professors as Ezra Solomon. They gather in study groups in the afternoon to dissect case studies, like how the Otis elevator company set about modernization. And they take field trips to local businesses like Nordstrom's department store.
After the general management program, the professors will return to their own campuses, pledged to conduct field research and write case studies about companies that are in the process of privatization.
The last stage of the program is scheduled for next summer, when the professors return to pursue a specialized area of study, say, organization behavior at Harvard or managerial accounting at Stanford.
At Stanford, joint ventures with Central and Eastern European nations have been all the rage since the beginning of perestroika. The Hoover Institute, for example, has conducted seminars for young diplomats from these countries for two years.
The professors in this summer's program have been quick studies in capitalism. Take Mr. Duhaneanu, who spent his four-day semester break in Hawaii, fulfilling a lifetime dream by taking a trip that he felt compelled to defend as a wise economic decision.
"In Rumania we have the Black Sea," he said. "So this was a very interesting case study for me in industrial tourism."

HEADLINE: Governors Find School Improvements Hard to Sell

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 4

 BODY:
Education improvements and the extra money they often require have never been an easy sell to the public. But the task has become much tougher.
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, who is campaigning for a $300 million tax increase for education in the face of stiff opposition, knows that. So does Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, where a proposition calling for changes in schools and $385 million in new taxes to initiate them was defeated by voters last November. So do governors in Oklahoma and Nebraska, where citizen-led initiatives on the ballot the last two years tried to rescind education legislation. 
 "There is skepticism and cynicism among the public," said David Hornbeck, an education consultant who spoke on these issues at the National Governors' Association annual meeting, which ended today. "People aren't sure whether the reforms will work, and many believe they have 'already given at the office.' "
As an indication of the grim mood among voters, the National Governors' Association for the first time at its annual conference offered a seminar to governors' staff representatives on how to market education reform to the public. Many governors said states hadn't been explicit enough in defining for voters what the potential changes mean.
 
A Hurdle Underestimated
 Voter skepticism is a bigger hurdle than many educators and politicians had believed, several governors and education policy experts said. Among others are the sluggish economy and budget deficits in many states, and demands to see results.
Also undermining state education efforts, they added, is the fact that only 25 percent of American families have children in school. Many people believe they don't have much stake in education.
Part of the problem, too, is that legislation to effect change has become more sophisticated. Most states have moved away from first passing required academic improvements and then tackling financing legislation, either to increase spending for education or to equalize spending between between rich schools and poor ones. Now education legislation tends to combine both.
"Over all, states are doing a very poor job of selling," Mr. Romer said during an interview at the conference. "Change and higher taxes are always difficult."
Missouri offers a case study in how difficult it is to sell change. Last fall, state officials believed they had assembled a solid ballot initiative, with improvements like smaller classes and school-based management; they had backed those improvements with about $385 million in new taxes.
The measure was rejected by voters, despite vigorous and vocal support from Governor Ashcroft, a fiscal conservative. "There are many lessons to be learned," said Richard McClure, the Governor's chief of staff.
Mr. McClure said state officials should combine the proposed improvements with measures that hold schools accountable. Voters are more likely to support the legislation if they know there are consequences for schools that do not perform well.
Some states have started to adapt to the tougher climate by being more aggressive in publicity.
In Colorado, for instance, Governor Romer faces a groundswell of opposition to a ballot initiative that he has proposed. The initiative, on the ballot this November, proposes to increase the state sales tax to 4 cents from 3 cents on every dollar; the Governor asserts that if the initiative fails, public education spending will have to be cut by 12 percent in the 1993-1994 school year. Mr. Romer is campaigning on the breakfast circuit, flying the width and breadth of the state and eating breakfast three times a day to line up support for his tax increase.
"It's not fun saying, 'I'm your Governor and I'm going to raise your taxes,' " Mr. Romer said. "I get a lot of hostile audiences."
Among the hostile gatherings are a good number involving senior citizens, who, the Governor said, ask why they should support education improvements. He says he responds by telling the retirees that schoolchildren are future workers who will pay the retirees' Social Security benefits.
Although some statewide polls show the inititive has more support than opposition, Governor Romer expects a fight. "I'm telling my staff to take no prisoners. You're either with us or against us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, who is campaigning for a $300 million tax increase for education in the face of stiff opposition. "It's not fun saying, 'I'm your Governor and I'm going to raise your taxes,' " he said. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Chicago, a Model Farm School

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Jason Zeigler's summer school assignments include breeding fish, learning to groom a dog and raising vegetables in a small garden set in one of the fields surrounding his high school.
Jason, who is 15 years old and lives on Chicago's South Side, had not spent much time around animals, much less in a vegetable garden, until he started high school two years ago. 
 "In my neighborhood, some people have flowers or they have plants inside their house, but if you talk about growing vegetables, they think you're going to work on a farm," he said.
Jason is working on a farm, of sorts. He is a student at the Chicago High School for Agricultural Sciences, a public school set on the last farm in the city of Chicago.
Although a farmer is paid to plow and harvest the fields, the 55-acre farm in the city's southwest corner is an outdoor classroom, where students assist the farmer and care for their own gardens. Inside the brick school building are regular classrooms, as well as a 300-gallon fish tank, a half dozen rabbit pens, a floral design shop and two greenhouses.
 
Study of Food and Fiber
 "It's not just sticking plants in the ground," said Jason, who hopes to become an environmental engineer for a national park.
The school's curriculum is designed to prepare public school students for such disparate jobs as marine biologist, nutritionist, food quality inspector, customs agent, commodities trader or "anything to do with food and fiber," said the principal, Barbara Valerious.
When it started in 1985, the high school was only the second of its kind in the country, the first being Philadelphia's Biddle Saul School for Agriculture. Last year, Kansas City, Mo., started a similar program, and San Jose, Calif., plans to open a high school devoted to agricultural and environmental sciences this fall.
With the United States Department of Agriculture estimating that 50,000 agriculture-related jobs will open up each year in the 1990's, most of them off the farms, Chicago's agricultural high school is attracting a lot of attention. Officials from school districts in Phoenix and Atlanta have visited the school in the last year, seeking to model programs on Chicago's curriculum.
"It is quite an amazing school," said Diana Pihos, a spokeswoman for the Agriculture Department. "There is such a huge need out there for people to work in these areas that there are going to have to be more schools like it."
Students at the agricultural high school take college preparatory courses like English, mathematics and foreign languages, as well as classes in animal sciences, horticulture and agriculture technology. Their school day is slightly longer than the average public school's, and they graduate with 31 credits, as against the 21 required for graduation in Illinois.
About 70 percent of the school's graduates have gone on to four-year colleges. The school's graduation rate is 89 percent, as against about 50 percent for all Chicago public schools.
Almost half the students in the 90-member graduating class this spring was awarded a total of $1.4 million in college scholarships from about 15 universities, including Princeton and the United States Military Academy at West Point.
For Jeremy Bartel, who is 15 and intends to be a geologist, it was not the scholarships, or even the job opportunities, that lured him to the schoo; it was the chance to be around plants and animals.
 
Calming Nature of Plants
 "Plants are very calming," he said. "When I have a big test, sometimes I just go into the greenhouse and stand there and watch the plants grow."
Teen-agers from throughout Chicago can apply to the school; students in the neighborhood get in automatically, and those from outside the neighborhood are chosen by lottery. Hispanic youths make up 14 percent of the 450-member student body, whites 18 percent and blacks 68 percent, Ms. Valerious said.
This summer, the most popular summer school class is one that operates a fresh produce stand. The class buys vegetables from the farmer growing the crops and sells them to the public. Students manage the business transactions and can earn wages if the stand makes a profit.
Last year, a team of Chicago students came in 20th in the nation in the horticulture competition sponsored by the FFA, formerly the Future Farmers of America, in which students rated several samples of a plant. "Just like other high schools have a football team," said Marcia Watman, who teaches agriculture techniques. "It's the same thing with us, only we have a horticulture team."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the Chicago High School for Agricultural Sciences, Cathie Henkins and Jason Zeigler, students, observed a talipia for their aquaculture class. The curriculum is designed to prepare students for fields with "anything to do with food and fiber," said the principal, Barbara Valerious. (Barry Jarvinen for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Teachers Ask Mediator To Aid in Contract Talks

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Trying to accelerate contract talks that have been stalled for almost a year, Sandra Feldman, the president of the New York City teachers' union, formally declared yesterday that the negotiations were at an impasse and asked a state mediator to step in.
The unexpected action, announced at a crowded news conference at the United Federation of Teachers headquarters in Manhattan, will produce an effort by the State Public Employment Relations Board to settle the dispute. If that fails, then a fact-finder will determine whether any money exists to pay for a raise for the teachers. 
 Ms. Feldman's move comes after more than 10 months in which the city's 66,000 teachers have been working without a contract. It is aimed at putting pressure on Mayor David N. Dinkins and the Board of Education to offer more substantial wage proposals, something Ms. Feldman contends her antagonists at the negotiating table have not done.
 
Report Can Be Rejected
 Unlike a binding arbitration ruling, a fact finder's report can be rejected by any party to a negotiation, but those findings would carry considerable weight in the public debate and might force some concessions.
Ms. Feldman, caught between a restless membership and a Mayor whose candidacy she helped launch, tiptoed around reporters' questions about whether she would call a strike when schools reopen on Sept. 9. But she made several veiled warnings.
"We want to do everything possible to avoid a serious confrontation with the city, but I can't rule anything out," she said. "For teachers to go into a second school year without a contract is unprecedented."
The union last struck the schools in 1975, in a five-day walkout that disrupted the lives of hundreds of thousands of children and their parents. Under the state's Taylor Law, it is illegal for public school teachers to strike.
James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, said the board had "bargained in good faith" but any calls for pay raises should be put at the door of City Hall, which controls the budget.
Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said, "Fundamentally we've had enormous difficulty finding ways to fund a settlement that would be even remotely acceptable to her."
Ms. Feldman said she welcomed proposals put forward by Mr. Fernandez on Friday that would create incentives for experienced teachers to work in the city's most troubled schools. But she said she wanted to dispel any impressions that Mr. Fernandez might have created that the contract talks were anywhere near completion.
In fact, she said, there has been absolutely no movement in negotiations since the contract expired on Oct. 1. The city has insisted that any money for a modest raise would have to be squeezed out through concessions in other parts of the teacher contract, from areas like sabbaticals.
Ms. Feldman would not say how large a pay raise she wants, although she indicated that she is seeking parity with surrounding suburbs, where the top pay ranges from $3,000 to $16,000 more than that of senior New York City teachers. Salaries for New York City teachers range from $26,375 for beginners to $52,750 for those with 20 years of service, a master's degree and 30 additional graduate credits.
One official familiar with the negotiations said the teachers have asked for a raise of at least 10 percent -- about $5,000 a year at the top salary scale -- that would give them parity with some suburbs. Such a raise would cost roughly $400 million.
The city, the official said, is considering only inflation-linked raises of roughly 3 percent that would have to be financed through concessions in work rules.

HEADLINE: After Long Battle, Cuomo's Jobs Plan Faces Hurdles

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Although the state Legislature has passed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's $800 million bond plan to create jobs and improve the state's infrastructure, debate over the proposal is far from over. Two of the biggest hurdles remain: deciding how the money should be spent and persuading voters to approve the plan in the November election.
The passage of the bond act was a big victory for Mr. Cuomo, who had made it the centerpiece of his economic development program this legislative session and who had feared just a month ago that the measure was dead. Its passage last week prompted the Governor to call the session, which has ended for the summer, "extraordinary." Mr. Cuomo signed the bill on Monday, so the proposal will be put on the ballot in November. 
 As the state continues to reel under the weight of the recession, Governor Cuomo hopes the bond act will prime the economy and create jobs by putting people to work to upgrade roads, water mains and other improvements, and then by attracting businesses to the newly improved areas. State officials say the plan will bring in about 25,000 new construction jobs right away and hundreds of thousands of other jobs in the ensuing years.
But while most politicians would normally be delighted at the prospect of having economic development projects to take home to their constituents, some conservatives fear political repercussions from supporting anything that could lead to more state debt in the current political climate.
 
Conservative Opposition
 "In these tough fiscal times, some politicians are unwilling to go along with spending of any kind," Brian D. Backstrom, vice president for research at Change-NY, a conservative group that opposes the bond act, said recently.
The chairman of the state's Conservative Party, Michael R. Long, has called the proposal to pay for infrastructure improvements with money borrowed through bond sales a "disastrous economic plan" that would cause state taxes to rise.
"Once again, away from public scrutiny, the backroom politicians have reached agreement on an economic package that will increase the economic misery of New Yorkers," he said. "If this bond act is approved it will fuel higher taxes in the near future, taxes that will lead to more private-sector jobs fleeing New York."
Some supporters of the bond act have expressed concern over whether voters will approve it. The last large bond proposal, a $2 billion initiative intended to set aside money for the environment, was rejected by voters in 1990.
This time, officials say, they hope to raise voters' consciousness about the bond act through speeches and public appearances, although they are barred by law from advertising or specifically asking voters to support it.
"What's better than putting people to work?" Governor Cuomo asked at a recent news conference. He added that the bond act would do more than employ people just for the sake of employing them.
"This is not just basket weaving," he said. "This is hundreds of thousands of jobs. You find another way to put people to work right now, when we need it worse than we have at any time since the Great Depression."
Even before the voters decide the fate of the proposal, politicians in Albany will be scrambling over how to divide the money.
Under Mr. Cuomo's plan, $600 million would go to the state's 62 counties and the five boroughs of New York City, based on population, with a $2 million minimum per county or borough; $100 million would be divided regionally, and $100 million would be used for statewide infrastructure.
The money will go to decidedly unglamorous projects, like sewer hookups and water lines, that would help persuade companies to move in, said Mary Ann Crotty, the Governor's director of policy management. Localities would submit proposals to a legislative task force, which would allocate the money based on criteria outlined in the legislation. The bulk of the money should be spoken for by October. If the bond act passes on Nov. 3, she said, the projects could begin next spring.
 
Renovation and Development
 The money could be used to renovate aging industrial parks or develop idle state land or to reopen closed factories. It could not be used as a loan or grant to an individual company, unless it can be proved that the public would benefit from the company's moving into the area.
New York City's share of the money would come to about $239 million, money it needs because of reductions in its own capital budget in the last couple of years. Projects that might be financed with the money include improvement of the Harlem River railyard for a flower wholesale market; infrastructure for an industrial park in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and refurbishment of Pier 11 on the East River in Manhattan for commercial and tourist use, said a spokesman for the state Department of Economic Development.
"This is a good deal for the city," said John Bozzella, the city's lobbyist in Albany. "No matter how big your capital budget is, you don't thumb your nose at $239 million."

HEADLINE: July Vehicle Sales Off a Bit After Slump Late in Month

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 3.9 percent in late July, but sales for the entire month stayed close to the gradual rate of recovery that began in the spring, according to statistics released today.
In late July, 397,546 domestically built vehicles were sold, based on the daily selling rate. Cars were down 5.1 percent, to 248,053; light trucks were off 2 percent, to 149,493. There were 10 selling days in the latest period, compared with 9 last year; percentage changes are based on the daily selling rate. 
 For the month, auto makers sold 1,107,064 vehicles, which included all cars and light trucks, domestic and imports, a 1.5 percent drop from July 1991. Sales of cars dropped 4.2 percent, to 705,087; sales of light trucks, which include mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, rose 3.5 percent, to 401,977.
 
Tracking the Pace of Sales
 Sales of domestically built cars were running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.7 million for the period from July 21 to 31, up from a rate of 6 million in the middle of the month but the same rate as in late July of last year. For the entire month, the rate was 6.5 million.
Dealers, auto executives and financial analysts were split in their assessments. Some said that sales were sluggish; others contended that they were not bad in light of weak economic indicators like unemployment, consumer confidence and personal income.
The weakness in late-July car sales suggested that a "pay back" effect was at work. Rental car companies ordered more aggressively than usual in June, fearing they might not have enough cars to cope with heavy summer travel, fed by the surge in airline bookings that resulted from deeply discounted air fares. Those earlier car sales reduced the orders placed in late July.
"We're in a holding pattern," said Jack Kirnan, an auto analyst for Salomon Brothers in New York. "Consumers are waiting to see whether we're slipping into recession or just having a painfully weak recovery." But Mr. Kirnan counted himself among those who thought sales were "pretty good."
 
View From the Dealerships
 Rick Ellis, who owns a Ford dealership in Malone, N.Y., said, "We had a good May and June, but July was hell."
John Koerner, general sales manager of Healy Chevrolet-Geo-Oldsmobile in Beacon, N.Y., said July sales were up from a year ago but were softer than in any other month this year.
The General Motors Corporation, the top auto maker, had a 6.1 percent decline in sales of all vehicles for the month, to 407,384, reflecting an 11.6 percent drop in car sales. Light-truck sales rose 5.7 percent. Saturn and GMC Truck were the only sales divisions to register positive comparisons with last July. Consequently, G.M. has slightly trimmed its third-quarter production plans.
The Ford Motor Company, ranked No. 2, posted a 5.4 percent increase in vehicle sales for the month, to 284,506, thanks to a 3.8 percent increase in car sales and a 7.8 increase in light trucks.
The Chrysler Corporation posted a 7.2 percent increase in vehicle sales, to 131,810, with a 6.8 percent rise in light trucks and a 7.8 percent increase in cars.
The Honda Motor Company's car sales rose less than 1 percent, to 67,084. Honda's Accord model was the top-selling car for the month, leading the No. 2 Ford Taurus.
 
Mixed Performances
 The Toyota Motor Corporation's vehicle sales were off 6.4 percent, to 97,119, for the month; car sales were off 8.2 percent, sport utility vehicles were off 15.1 percent and mini-vans were off 30.6 percent, but sales of pickups rose 11.8 percent
The Nissan Motor Company had a 30.3 percent sales drop in cars and light trucks for the month, to 45,287. The Mazda Motor Corporation's sales fell 1.9 percent, to 29,758, but the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation increased sales 12 percent, to 18,559. Mitsubishi said a lease program on its Diamante sedans spurred sales to nearly 5,000 for the month.
Detroit's Big Three gained market share against foreign auto makers, continuing a trend that began early in the year. The Big Three's share of the car market increased to 64.7 percent for the month from 64.1 percent in July of last year; the Japanese auto makers also increased their car share slightly, to 27.6 percent, from 26.9 percent last year. All other importers, mostly European, dropped to 7.7 percent of the market, from 8.9 percent last year. Volkswagen, Mercedes, Porsche, Hyundai and Saab posted declines; Audi, BMW and Volvo had gains.

HEADLINE: Thruway Authority Is Given New Powers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 4

 BODY:
The New York State Thruway Authority will start economic development projects along the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and take over the state Barge Canal system, under legislation signed today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
As a start, the measure authorizes the Thruway Authority to help finance development projects along waterfronts in Buffalo and Syracuse, as well as a new interchange near Stewart International Airport in Orange County. 
 "This legislation allows the Thruway Authority to become a catalyst for economic development along the Thruway corridor and our canal system," Governor Cuomo said.
State officials said the measure would not require higher tolls on the Thruway, the nation's longest toll road.
However, the legislation makes it even less likely that the Thruway's tolls will disappear when the road's construction bonds are paid off in 1996. A special state task force, citing the fact that one-third of Thruway tolls are paid by non-New Yorkers, has recommended preserving the tolls.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Salaries Increase In Public Relations

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
The median salary for public relations practitioners has risen 6.5 percent, to $46,556, from $43,718 last year, according to the seventh annual salary survey by The Public Relations Journal, which is published by the Public Relations Society of America in New York. 
 The publication said the results of the survey indicated that the industry was emerging from a recession after two years of layoffs and few pay increases; the median salary rose only 1.2 percent in 1991 from the previous year. The survey also showed that a "salary gender gap," a disparity between men's and women's pay, had widened: the men's median salary of $57,766 was 47 percent higher than the women's median of $39,207.

HEADLINE: Yields Fall at Slower Pace For Bank Funds and C.D.'s

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Nearly a month after the last cut in the Federal discount rate and cuts in the prime lending rates by most leading banks, yields of bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit have continued to slip, but the decline in the week that ended today was less pronounced than in previous weeks.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, a bank-interest-rate publication, says that bank rates have tumbled 40 basis points since the cut and that he thinks a new bottom may be in sight. But, he says, the Federal Reserve may yet take another hard look at the economy and see if another easing is in order. "The odds are even money on another rate cut," Mr. Heady said. "It could happen this month or in September.". 
 Rates at the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills rose on Monday, marking the third time they have risen in as many weeks. Many interest rate watchers consider the auction a fairly good indicator of what many banks may pay out to depositors in the weeks ahead.
 
 
3-Month Bill Up 2 Points
 The average rate on a three-month bill at auction was 3.20 percent, up 2 basis points from the previous auction, while the six-month bill rose 3 basis points, to 3.30 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"A close look at commercial banks in New York show that two-thirds are pricing their three- and six-month certificates to yield under 3 percent," Mr. Heady said. "Banks do not appear to be squeamish about chopping yields as depositors flee to higher-paying investments elsewhere."
In the latest week, New York area banks -- both commercial and savings institutions -- reduced the average money market account and six-month certificate of deposit by 2 basis points, to 3.06 percent and 3.31 percent, respectively. The average three-month certificate was cut 4 basis points, to 3.09 percent.
Commercial banks left money market accounts and three-month certificates unchanged this week at 2.86 percent and 2.91 percent, respectively and reduced six-month certificates by a basis point, to 3.07 percent.
 
 
Biggest Adjustments
 Savings banks cut both money market accounts and six-month C.D. yields by 4 basis points, to 3.25 percent and 3.54 percent, respectively. The three-month certificate was cut by 7 basis points, to 3.29 percent.
The largest yield adjustments in the New York area were at the Dime Savings Bank, which lowered its money market account 15 basis points, to 3.25 percent, and at First Nationwide, which dropped its three-month C.D. 50 basis points, to 2.85 percent, and its six-month C.D. 13 basis points, to 3.15 percent.
By comparison, the yields at 20 large banks outside the New York market were down slightly, with an average bank money market account off a basis point, to 2.96 percent, and a six-month certificate down 2 basis points, to 3.20 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Manages Slight Gain In Listless Domestic Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose slightly yesterday against other leading currencies in slow domestic dealings that reflected a dearth of economic news to trade on.
Gold prices barely budged in New York after falling overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, bullion rose 10 cents an ounce, to $352.70. A late bid at the Republic National Bank at $353.00 an ounce was unchanged from Monday. 
 "It was a real yawner," Jay Wertheimer, senior foreign currency trader for the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia, said about dollar trading. "The markets were very thin, very dead."
Traders are waiting for the unemployment figures due to be released Friday. The data will be the Government's first significant report on how the economy fared in July. "Up until then, we don't expect much to go on," Mr. Wertheimer said.
A Commerce Department report that showed the Government's economic forecasting gauge fell in June for the first time in six months had no effect on foreign exchange dealings, traders said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.20 yen, down 0.05 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.25 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York the dollar fetched 127.25 yen, up from 127.20 on Monday.
The British pound fell in London to $1.9230, from $1.9245 late Monday. In New York, the pound cost $1.9195, cheaper than its $1.9240 exchange value Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4770 German marks, up from 1.4750; 1.3245 Swiss francs, up from 1.3170; 4.9900 French francs, up from 4.9800; 1,116.00 Italian lire, up from 1,114.00, and 1.18485 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18395.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, were: 1.4745 German marks, down from 1.4770; 1.3205 Swiss francs, up from 1.3185; 4.9815 French francs, down from 4.9850; 1.6625 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6655; 1,114.50 Italian lire, down from 1,115.00; 1.1851 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1840.
