HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Post First Drop in 6 Months

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell in June for the first time in six months, the Commerce Department said today.
Analysts had expected the slight decrease in the index of leading indicators and said it was not a sign of renewed recession, but a symptom of the weak and erratic growth that has bedeviled the economy since the middle of last year. 
 The drop of two-tenths of 1 percent in the leading indicators, which are intended to predict economic activity six to nine months in advance, was the first decline since the index fell one-tenth of 1 percent in December. The June drop was the steepest decline since January 1991.
The drop followed gains of six-tenths of 1 percent in May and three-tenths of 1 percent in both April and March.
The report suggests that the economy is in "for more of the same -- a lackluster, limpid, lethargic performance that goes on month after month," said Robert Dederick, an economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
That is bad news for President Bush and other incumbents who would prefer that voters on Election Day feel good about the economy, or at least optimistic that difficult times will soon be over.
The July figure in the most politically potent set of election year statistics -- the unemployment rate -- is scheduled for release on Friday. Despite five consecutive quarters of weak economic growth that economists say constitute a recovery, the unemployment rate has continued to rise.
 
Making Predictions
 Many analysts say that unemployment, after hitting an eight-year high of 7.8 percent in June, will register a slight decline for July, but few believe the rate will dip below 7 percent by the end of the year.
"I think we'll see some improvement," said Paul Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. "But I think the improvement will be perceived as late in the day."
In June's leading indicators, 6 of the index's 11 components contributed to its decline. One was unchanged and four were positive.
The negative indicators, in order of magnitude, were a drop in the inflation-adjusted supply of money in the economy; a decrease in the average factory employee's workweek from 41.3 hours to 41.1 hours; an increase in new claims for unemployment insurance from an average of 415,000 a week in May to 429,000 in June; a decline in stock prices as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; a decrease in building permits and a drop in consumer confidence as measured by the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center.
 
A Ragged Recovery
 The positive indicators were a gain in new orders and contracts for business equipment and buildings; a rise in new orders to factories for consumer goods; a slowdown in business delivery times, which indicates increased demand, and an increase in the price of various raw materials.
The backlog of unfilled orders at factories was virtually unchanged and did not push the overall index in either direction.
The various changes left the index in June at 149.6 percent of its 1982 base of 100, down from 149.9 in May.
Economists say the June decline probably will be followed by a rise in July. But they say the sawtooth pattern reflects structural problems constraining the kind of robust growth that has typically followed postwar recessions. The problems include the decline in military spending that has followed the end of the cold war, the plunge in commercial real estate values, the weak condition of many banks and, most important, an overhang of consumer, business and government debt.
The drop in the leading index prompted the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Democrat from Michigan, to call for "a significant increase in the money supply by the Federal Reserve."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
ALL is not well in the wine world. The wine market in the United States declined last year for the seventh year in a row. Domestic wine shipments were down 1.5 percent, to 147.4 million cases while imports fell 8.7 percent to 25.8 million cases.
The persistent economic recession, a widespread and growing concern about alcohol abuse, heightened public indignation over drunken driving and the consequent stiffer penalties, plus steeper Federal excise taxes all combined in 1991 to deliver yet another blow to the already troubled industry. 
 Total shipments were 173.2 million cases, down from the 1984 peak, 220.2 million cases. The figures are from Impact, a trade publication that has tracked the wine industry's performance for many years.
Impact tracks cases shipped rather than cases produced because producers may hold wine anywhere from weeks to several years for aging. What's more, the wine production calendar rarely coincides with the producer's fiscal calendar.
The one bright spot in an otherwise somber picture was California varietal wines, which were up 7.4 percent, to 47.7 million cases. Varietal wines are better-quality wines that bear the name of the principal grape variety from which they are made. A bottle of wine made mostly from the cabernet sauvignon grape is a varietal. A bottle of California burgundy, usually made from a number of cheaper grapes, is known as a generic, or jug, wine. The jug wines, which were the keystone of the California wine market for generations, are slowly dying out. Shipments of California generics fell 8.7 percent last year, to 58.7 million cases, Impact reported.
The encouraging performance by the higher-priced varietals lends substance to a slogan the industry uses to cheer itself up: people, the wine makers say, are drinking less but better.
Indeed, dozens of smaller wineries, particularly in California, continue to see great demand for their products, allocating their often quite expensive wines to favored customers. There are still a few wineries where fans wait for a place on the waiting list.
Which is little solace for larger, less elitist producers whose customer bases have been shrinking like grapes after a late spring frost.
California, where everything seems to be going wrong at the moment, has been hit especially hard. Ordinarily, Californians drink more wine than anyone else in the country. They are still ahead of the rest of the United States; they drank 42 million cases last year. Even so, their overall consumption fell 5.2 percent.
Table wine, the reds and whites we drink with dinner, accounted for 76.8 percent of the United States market last year, up a tenth of a percentage point over 1990. Sparkling wine made up 8.6 percent, also up a tenth of a point. Actual shipments of sparkling wine dropped 1.7 percent, to 15 million cases, but the drop was mostly in imported wines; American sparkling wines actually did better in 1991 than in 1990: shipments were up 3.5 percent, to 11.2 million cases.
Lest you mistakenly attribute this small bright spot to some post-80's let-'em-eat-cake attitude, be aware that most of the performers were low-enders like Tott's and Eden Roc brands, both owned by Gallo, and Canandaigua's Cook's, which, Impact says, shipped 26.5 percent more cases in 1991 than in 1990.
Domaine Chandon, best known of the top-of-the-line domestic sparkling wines, was off 9 percent, to about 350,000 cases, but the real losers were the imports. All French Champagne shipments were off 12.5 percent, with Moet & Chandon, the Domaine's European cousin, down almost 10 percent.
The rest of the market, about 15 percent of it, is made up of dessert wines, which include port, sherry and inexpensive flavored wines like Canandaigua's Wild Irish Rose; special natural wines like bottled sangria and the so-called apple wines; vermouth, and imported speciality wines. Only the special natural category showed any improvement, possibly, Impact speculates, because some big producers are making them -- they are inexpensive to concoct -- in lieu of more expensive table wines.
In the imported category, popular-priced Italian table wines were the biggest losers. Over all, shipments from Italy, the United States' largest foreign supplier, were down 12.1 percent. But individual brands suffered much more. Banfi Vintner's Reunite Classics were down 21.2 percent, and Austin-Nichols' Canei line was off 33.6 percent. Even the redoubtable Georges Duboeuf, the prominent Beaujolais shipper, posted an 11 percent drop, from 545,000 cases to 485,000, according to Impact.
Shipments from France, the second most important wine exporter after Italy, were off just under 5 percent. The Italians sent 8.1 million cases of table wines, down from 9.3 million in 1990; the French sent 5.8 million cases, down from 6.1 million. A case, by the way, contains 12 750-milliliter bottles.
As they cast about for something good to say about 1991, most wine makers and marketers clutch at the Nov. 17 broadcast of the CBS program "60 Minutes," in which French and American medical researchers suggested that France's lower incidence of heart disease might be explained by the fact that the French drink more wine than Americans do. The program suggested that the moderate consumption of wine, preferably red, could cut the risk of heart disease. The program's contentions have been criticized by some nutrition experts.
According to Impact, data from Infoscan Resources, a company that monitors supermarket sales, showed that supermarket sales of red wine rose 44 percent from late December 1991 through early January 1992. One industry leader, Art Ciocca, president of the Wine Group, told Impact that the broadcast was "an absolute watershed event for the wine industry."
 
TASTINGS
Ruffino Aziano Rosso, 1989; about $8.
 Ruffino is one of the best-known names in Italian wines. With the proliferation of newer types of wines and smaller, trendier producers, the old house of Ruffino, which has been owned by the Folonari family since 1913, is mentioned less frequently. This is a mistake. Ruffino wines, beginning with their top-of-the-line Riserva Ducale, are invariably excellent. Aziano is a Chianti Classico made from the grapes of a single vineyard called the Villa Zano, a wine property with records dating back to the 10th century. The grape mix is usually about 80 percent sangioveto grosso, with 10 percent canaiolo and other red grapes, 4 percent white grapes, and a varying amount of governo, the concentrated must of dried grapes. In other words a Chianti made mostly but not entirely in the old style. The 1989 is a rich, full-flavored wine that will hold nicely for another five years but is ready to drink now.

HEADLINE: How European Films Have Treated Blacks Through the Years

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
"Eurobeat: Blacks in European Cinema," a series at Lincoln Center at the Walter Reade Theater that explores the presence of black characters in European films from the 1920's to the present, opens today with the only surviving fragment of Josephine Baker's first feature and a movie starring Paul Robeson in one of the few nonstereotyped roles of his acting career.
The series, which runs through Aug. 20, is presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. It includes the New York premiere on Friday of "No Fear, No Die," by the French director Claire Denis, whose first feature was the acclaimed "Chocolat" in 1988. 
 The series includes titles -- some familiar, others obscure -- from France, Switzerland, Spain, Britain, Italy and the Soviet Union. On the opening bill, Baker appears in a 25-minute chunk of "Siren of the Tropics," a semiautobiographical silent film made in France in 1927. Directed by Henri Etievant and Mario Nalpas, "Siren" is about a woman from a Caribbean plantation who, as a dancer, becomes the toast of France. In the other opening feature, Robeson appears with his wife, Eslanda, in "Borderline," a silent film made in Switzerland in 1928 by the director Kenneth MacPherson. The film looks at racial tensions that develop in a Swiss mountain resort when a black couple arrives.
Also on today's program is Montxo Armendariz's "Letters from Alou," made in Spain in 1990, which examines the harsh life and hopeful outlook of a poor Senegalese immigrant as he travels through Spain looking for work.
 
Dignity and Complexity
 As was true in Hollywood, black actors in early European films were often no more than background characters. Yet taken together, the 18 films in the series show that European film makers often portrayed blacks and race relations with more dignity and complexity than their American counterparts did. Roberto Rossellini's 1946 "Paisa," for example, is a passionate drama about the wartime relationship between an Italian boy and one of his liberators, a black American soldier. And the Yiddish-language Soviet film "The Return of Nathan Becker," made in 1932 by Boris Shpis and Rokhl M. Milman, involves a young Jew returning to his Byelorussian village from America and taking with him a black friend, whom he assures, "You, too, are going home."
Richard Pena, the program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, theorizes that Europeans were better able to look at blacks as individuals than as representatives of a group because Europe did not begin experiencing large-scale immigration from Africa and the West Indies until after World War II.
"In certain ways, rightly or wrongly, Europeans have been able to approach black characters without as much of the history and baggage that American film makers have had," Mr. Pena said. "That's not to say that Britain, Spain and Portugal were not involved in the slave trade, but in many ways it was distant from them; it was happening somewhere else."
Mr. Pena also cited Hollywood's fear of offending moviegoers in the South. "The United States industry was meant to be a national industry," he said. "European film production was done on a much more individual basis and there has been more of a tradition of intellectual and socially oriented cinema."
Ms. Denis's "No Fear, No Die," made in 1990, is about two alienated black immigrants in France -- one from Benin in West Africa and the other from the French West Indies -- who become involved in supplying birds for cockfights.
 
Who Is French?
 "We have in France immigrants from Africa or North Africa and they are not French," Ms. Denis, who is to attend the premiere, said in a telephone interview from Martinique. "If you consider the African situation, they might be very poor immigrants with a lot of hard times. They still have in their mind that they have their own country, that they are related to another civilization."
In contrast, she added, immigrants from Martinique and Guadeloupe are French. "They have a French passport," she said. "But some white people don't want to know that people with black faces can be French. The people from Guadeloupe and Martinique become much more isolated and much more offended by the way they are treated than a person from Africa. They feel it is even more unfair because, after all, they belong to France as much as any white person."
Eight films in the series are from Britain. Of those, "The Proud Valley," Pen Tennyson's 1940 drama about unemployed Welsh coal miners who are helped by a black stoker is said to be the film of which Robeson was proudest. In the 1959 thriller "Sapphire," by Basil Dearden, the investigation of a woman's murder reveals that she was racially mixed, pregnant and passing for white. Stephen Dwoskin's "Ballet Black," in 1986, is a documentary about Les Ballets Negres, the first black ballet company in Europe.
In the magical-realist film "Ama," made in 1990 by Kwesi Owusu and Kwate Nee-Owoo, the young daughter of African parents becomes the medium for an ancestral prophesy, discovered on a computer floppy disk in the English countryside. In an interview from London, Mr. Owusu, who was born in Ghana, said the film was an attempt to "reconcile my place within the Western world in relationship to my own background."
Here is a list of the films in the series and when they are playing:

HEADLINE: BARCELONA: BOXING;
Help Wanted? Call Havana

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 4

 BODY:
One of the first things you notice about Ireland's Olympic boxing team is Nicolas Hernandez Cruz.
He doesn't look Irish, and his name certainly doesn't imply that he is. 
 But Hernandez, Ireland's 34-year-old Olympic boxing coach, will tell you that since he moved to Dublin from Havana in 1988, he has adopted Ireland, from its songs to its brogue.
"I'm not Irish, but I feel like being Irish when I am here with the boxers," Hernandez said with an unmistakable Irish lilt. "I get some odd looks, mostly because of my color. They say, 'Is that the black Paddy?'
"I feel at home, really. I have all the music. I know the songs. The only difference between Dublin and Havana is the weather. Nice people, friendly people."
Hernandez is among the growing contingent of Cuban coaches who are working with teams from other countries. Once forced to import coaches and specialists from East Germany and the Soviet Union, Cuba has become a major exporter of sports advisers. Nine countries in these Olympics, including Ireland, have Cuban boxing coaches and several other nations have hired Cuban coaches in volleyball, weight lifting, track and field and other sports.
"Sports has been like an embassy for Cuba," said Raul Villanueva, the vice president of Cuba's National Institute of Sports and Physical Education. "We have a great relationship in sports with the United States. Politics has been a barrier in other areas between us, but never in sports."
As part of the latest evolution of its highly refined sports system, pride in its coaches has served as a positive link to counter Cuba's negative economic news.
In addition to Hernandez, there are Cuban boxing coaches on the Olympic teams of China, India, Mexico, Pakistan, Spain, Tanzania, Thailand and Uganda.
And Cuba's coaching presence here goes beyond boxing. Mario Figueroa is Venezuela's wrestling coach; Gilberto Herrera Delgado is the men's volleyball coach for Spain; Carlos Cruz Delgado is Mexico's track and field coach, and Jose Cortina Martinez coaches Italy's baseball team.
Spain had never even entered a team in the volleyball competition until this year, but under the direction of Herrera, for 15 years the coach of the Cuban national team, it has reached the quarterfinals.
In addition to the political benefits, there is also a significant financial component to Cuba's export of coaches. Each Cuban coach sent abroad signs a contract for a one or two years. Half of the money received from the hiring nation goes to the coach and the other half goes back to the Cuban sports system, to help Cuba's teams to travel, train and live a privileged life style.
The amount of money received varies, depending on the country, the sport and the level of competition involved. For example, Herrera receives more because he is a national team coach for Spain, whereas many of the other Cubans abroad work in younger divisions.
Hernandez is not a typical product of Cuba's boxing system, because he didn't begin in the sport until he was 18. But by 1981, he was rated the second-best light heavyweight in Cuba. He missed the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles because of a Soviet-led boycott, and he missed a shot at the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul because Cuba boycotted those Games in solidarity with North Korea.
He graduated from the University of Sports Culture in 1983, and began to work as a coach that same year, even as he continued to fight. Three years later, he returned to the university as a professor of sport and physical culture, and he still has that post.
 
Foreign Coaches Gone
 Cruz remembers that when he began boxing in the 1970's, there were 42 foreign coaches in Cuba. As Cuba participates in its first Olympics in 12 years, there is only one foreign coach in its contingent, in archery.
In Montreal in 1976, at the last Summer Olympics unaffected by boycotts because of East-West tensions, Cuban boxers won three gold medals, three silvers and two bronzes. In competition here at the 1992 Games, Cuban boxers have dominated thus far, winning 34 bouts and losing only three through today. In addition, the baseball team was undefeated after tonight's 6-1 victory over the United States.
Cuba has recently taken significant steps to upgrade in several other sports, and the results here have been promising. Among the medals the Cubans have so far won in Barcelona are ones in fencing, judo, Greco-Roman wrestling, weight lifting and track and field.
For Cuban officials, however, the most significant sign of the country's continuing advancement in sports is the fact that coaches like Hernandez have become valuable international commodities.
There are 150 Cuban coaches working throughout the world in a variety of sports and the Cuban coaches may be in even greater demand after the Olympics.
"Even here at the boxing competition, other countries have approached us and asked us to send them some of our coaches," Villanueva said. "The fact that our coaches are being requested is a source of pride and prestige for the country. It shows the high level of sports we have achieved."
Ireland won five Olympic medals in the 1950's, but the country's last Olympic boxing medal was a flyweight bronze at Moscow in 1980. The country's sports officials hope the presence of Hernandez will lead to more medals and international success, but Hernandez said that it won't be easy. Two Irish fighters have reached the semifinal round, bantamweight Wayne McCullough and welterwight Michael Carruth.
"There is a big difference between boxing in Ireland and Cuba," said Hernandez, who while growing up participated in basketball before he turned to boxing. "The main difference is that the Irish are part-time boxers, the Cubans are full-time boxers. They train every day without worrying about losing their jobs or how to find a job.
"Unemployment is a big problem in Ireland. How can you get the money to bring back to your family? Some of the amateurs trying to make a living out of boxing -- some of them work very hard, work in the day three times a week and train. But training after being tired, how can you produce?"
 
10 Months Since His Last Visit
 For Hernandez, the most difficult part about living in Ireland has been being away from his wife and their daughter. "This time it has been 10 months away from home," he said, referring to his second stint in Dublin. "I have a daughter 4 years who I haven't seen since last October."
At least the Olympics have provided Hernandez with an opportunity to see Cuban friends he hasn't seen in a long time. "All of the coaches get together each night at the Olympic Village," he said. "We play cards, tell stories, jokes."
 
Heart Is With Irish Now
 But Hernandez said his heart is now with his Irish boxers.
"I want my boxer to win," he said. "I've been sweating and training with them. How can I say that I want the other boxer to win?"
Where is his heart when Ireland is not fighting?
"When I am not with the Irish, I just enjoy boxing," Hernandez said. "My motto is, 'Let the best man win.' I put my hands together for that one that deserves to win. It doesn't matter where he comes from.
"We are all human beings. We all are working very hard to win."

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Utility Bonds From San Antonio

 BODY:
Taking advantage of low interest rates, San Antonio tentatively priced a $690.4 million refunding issue yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The Municipal Electric and Gas System refunding bonds were priced to yield a maximum of 6.073 percent for a bond due in 2013, with other term bonds yielding about 6.067 percent for an issue due in 2017, 6 percent in 2009 and 5.85 percent for a noncallable bond due in 2007. 
 For shorter-maturity serial bonds, yields ranged from 2.75 percent in 1993 to 4.6 percent in 1997, 5.4 percent in 2002 and 5.7 percent in 2005.
Underwriters said they had a confirmed rating of Aa-1 by Moody's and expected an AA rating from both Standard & Poor's and Fitch.

HEADLINE: Dangerous Stalling on Russian Aid

 BODY:
The U.S. wants to propel Russia toward democracy, markets and disarmament. But you'd never guess that by watching the House toy with the Administration's bill to assist the former Soviet republics. Proposed in April, the House bill -- whose Senate version passed in early July -- has remained bottled up in committee.
The Russian economy is collapsing, and opposition is mounting to President Boris Yeltsin's pro-market reforms. Yet the House dallies. If it delays much longer, there might be no reform Government left to help. 
 Western aid alone can't turn the Russian economy around. But it can cushion the shock of the transition to markets, help Mr. Yeltsin overcome domestic opposition and keep reforms marching forward. Russia's immediate need is $5 or $10 billion to import food, medicine and factory raw materials at a time when centralized controls have been dismantled but market controls haven't arisen to take their place.
The Administration's bill would make a modest start. It would help to promote markets, dismantle defense installations and facilitate the exchange of technical assistance. The money would be provided only if Russia keeps democratic and economic progress alive.
The centerpiece of the bill would authorize a $12 billion increase in the U.S. contribution to the International Monetary Fund. Because the money is considered a deposit at the fund, not an expenditure, it wouldn't trigger tax hikes or spending cuts. The U.S. deposit, along with similar contributions by other fund members, would be used to support various I.M.F. aid programs -- including those it hopes to negotiate with Mr. Yeltsin.
For now, the I.M.F. is key. The West has promised the Russians a $24 billion aid package; a chunk would come from the fund. And the I.M.F. would have to approve Russia's economic plan before the aid package would be released.
Agreement has proved dismayingly elusive. Some, but not all, of the problem is unnecessary rigidity on the part of the I.M.F. The fund's task has been made fiendishly difficult by divisions within the Russian Government. By reinforcing the reform faction, Congressional action would make durable and believable commitments to monetary and fiscal austerity easier to strike.
Western aid would allow the Russians to pay their bills without printing mountains of new rubles. That way Mr. Yeltsin can clamp down on inflation without clamping down on the economy. And that might buy him some breathing space to launch his ambitious plans to privatize state-owned enterprises and open the economy to foreign trade and investment.
The danger is that, without sizable help from abroad, the pain of market reform will prove backbreaking, impelling politicians to retreat to centralized controls. There's no excuse for the House to flirt with that disastrous possibility.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 520 words

HEADLINE: The Sleaze Factor

 BODY:
Mary Matalin's snarling press release attacking Gov. Bill Clinton -- it referred, among other things, to "bimbo eruptions" plaguing the Clinton campaign -- is said to have embarrassed President Bush. As well it should. Ms. Matalin's broadside defied Mr. Bush's admonition to his staff to avoid personal invective. And it deflected public attention from his effort to start talking aggressively about issues.
Despite Mr. Bush's disavowal of Ms. Matalin's comments, issued through an aide, questions linger. Was Ms. Matalin engaging in the political tactic known as "surrogate sleaze" -- carrying out an authorized attack for which Mr. Bush could later deny responsibility? After all, Ms. Matalin, as deputy campaign manager, is no small potato in the Bush re-election effort and is presumably in regular consultation with the White House. 
 Even if Ms. Matalin was flying solo, she may have done so in the confident expectation that her charges would be secretly welcomed. There's one other possibility: that Mr. Bush meant what he said the first time and that Ms. Matalin never got the message. In that case the Bush campaign is more frazzled, incompetent and confused than even its worst critics suspected.
Granted, Presidential races are not tea parties. They are usually rough and often harsh. It is the rare candidate who can promote his own vision without ridiculing his opponent's. Al Gore calls Mr. Bush a "hypocrite" on the environment. Mr. Bush says Mr. Clinton's health care program shows "all the compassion of the K.G.B." Even Ms. Matalin's charge that Mr. Clinton's campaign is "lower than a snake's belly" fits comfortably into the less-than-noble tradition of American political discourse.
The question is where to draw the line. Negative campaigns are disheartening enough; campaigns that employ personal invective are more so. Mr. Bush seemed to realize as much when, in early July, he repudiated a TV commercial (independently produced by a Republican loyalist) about Mr. Clinton's relationship with Gennifer Flowers. Mr. Bush said the ad was "the kind of sleaze that diminishes the political process."
That was not only the right thing to say. It was also politically shrewd. Voters are growing resistant to sleaze, and with the economy faltering they are far more interested in what both candidates intend to do about national problems than they are in anyone's personal life.
That point appears to have escaped Ms. Matalin. In an interview with The New York Times a few days before her press release, she said Bill Clinton's big problem was simply that he's "evasive and slick. We've never said to the press that he's a philandering, pot-smoking draft dodger."
"The way you just did?" she was asked. "The way I just did," she conceded.
Voters care about a candidate's character, about integrity and truthfulness, just as they care about the issues. In the end they tend to rely on the public record and their private instincts. Raw innuendo adds little to public enlightenment and discredits its author. Mr. Bush has now made that point twice. Beware if he has to make it again.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Smoking And Politics

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
It is both quite simple and somehow difficult to write about cigarette smoking. The simple part is this: Smoking kills. Cigarettes are, as Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, once said, "the only legal product that when used as intended cause death." It is lung cancer, not breast cancer, that is now the number one cancer killer of American women. "Smoking is associated with more death and illness than drugs, alcohol, automobile accidents and AIDS combined."
That last is from the memoirs of C. Everett Koop, who as Surgeon General did more to promote a smoke-free America than anyone. 
 This is the difficult part: Why do we allow the sale of a product that has no beneficial effects and many fatal ones? Why do we allow cigarette advertising to be a tissue of lies? Why do we tolerate an industry that attracts and addicts consumers when young, many too young to legally purchase the product?
I can't recall hearing a President inveigh publicly against smoking. While President Bush talks of the "behavior" that must be modified if AIDS is to be conquered, I don't recall hearing him decry the "behavior" that causes emphysema.
Jimmy Carter, in a speech earlier this year, spoke of his intimate interest in the problem. "My father, my mother, both sisters and my brother all died of cancer," he said. "And all smoked cigarettes." On television not long ago Al Gore had to fight to maintain his composure as he talked of watching his sister, Nancy, die of lung cancer.
Neighbors of the Gores have said that the family stopped growing tobacco on their farm after Nancy's death. But the Clinton-Gore campaign will benefit from contributions of more than $680,000 given to Democratic Party committees by various tobacco interests. Republicans have received more than $1.2 million in such contributions, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, in Washington D.C.
(In his memoirs Dr. Koop describes heavyhanded efforts by elected officials friendly to the tobacco industry to persuade him to ditch his crusade. "Everywhere there were reminders about the cozy relationship between tobacco and politics," Dr. Koop writes. "At Republican fund-raiser dinners each table offered free cigarettes, complete with the President's profile embossed in gold.")
The tobacco companies have been enormous beneficiaries of the American system. Our emphasis on personal responsibility means that even activists oppose outright prohibition. The tension between human services and the economy means that we have both a Health and Human Services smoking office, budgeted last year at around $8 million, and a Department of Agriculture tobacco program with a budget of nearly five times that for support services like crop insurance subsidies and research and development.
One in four Americans smokes. Many started as teen-agers, anxious to show how grown-up they were. Then they couldn't stop, even after they saw the dark spot on the X-ray. One way to prevent tobacco addiction is to fight it as zealously in schools and in advertising as we do drugs. There must be some lung cancer patients willing to show kids how glamorous and grown-up radiation can be.
The biggest change in recent years, people will say, is that everyone knows now that cigarettes cause cancer. But only 10 years ago the chairman of R. J. Reynolds was still saying that "no causal link between smoking and disease has been established." Today the official line from the Tobacco Institute is: "We recognize the risks associated with smoking; at the same time there is virtual universal awareness by the public of those risks."
But there isn't universal awareness of how tenacious cigarette addiction can be. And there is little awareness among kids of how mortality can come knocking at your door. Will we ever have a President who speaks fiercely to this issue? Or a First Lady who looks at how many brands are targeted to women, and at how many women die, and takes up the fight as her personal cause?
That would be politically difficult, given the enormous power of the tobacco lobby. But to balance the difficult, there is the simple truth: Cigarettes contribute to the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people every year. One of them may be someone you love. And if you hold a person's hand and watch her die, it seems to me that your only choice afterward is to go after the killer.

HEADLINE: What America Owes the Ex-Soviet Union

BYLINE: By James A. Baker 3d; James A. Baker 3d is Secretary of State.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Twice before in this century, America was summoned to international leadership. After World War I, we ignored the summons, and we and the world paid dearly. After World War II, wiser from experience with depression and dictatorship, we heeded the call to leadership and created the democratic coalition that won the cold war. Today, America is summoned again, this time to secure a democratic peace with Russia, Ukraine and the other new independent states of the former Soviet Union.
As President Bush said, "Democrats in the Kremlin can assure our security in a way nuclear missiles never could." The House of Representatives, by passing the Freedom Support Act, can help those democrats -- and help America, too. 
 Just seven weeks ago, in his address to a joint session of Congress, Boris Yeltsin spoke as Russia's first freely elected President, boldly committed to democracy and free enterprise. He spoke as a full partner in the search for security, eager to join President Bush in the most far-reaching nuclear arms reductions in history. And he spoke as a friend, prepared to end secrecy and throw open secret files that can help shed light on the fate of M.I.A.'s and P.O.W.'s.
The Freedom Support Act, announced April 1 by President Bush, is a crucial step in building a democratic peace. The act comprehensively addresses the military, political and economic problems of Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Armenia and the other new states.
The act will support arms control, nonproliferation and nuclear safety. It will expand our democratization programs and encourage free markets. It will make it easier for U.S. companies to invest in and trade with the new independent states. That's good for American businesses and could create thousands of jobs for American workers. Indeed, helping develop vast new markets in the states of the former Soviet Union will create great possibilities for America's economy.
* The act is not a foreign aid give-away. President Yeltsin and other reformers are attempting to build modern, free-market economies on the ruins of Communism. Their task is extraordinarily difficult and complicated by political turmoil and deep economic hardship. Our help is no handout. The reformers must make the hard decisions and do the hard work. Our help cannot guarantee they will succeed -- but should Congress fail to act, their task will be all the more difficult. All who want to see this brave experiment prevail must help them succeed, for their sake and for ours.
* The act is America's share -- and a fair one -- in a coalition effort. The problems of the former Soviet Union are too huge for any one country to tackle. In a policy I call collective engagement, we have joined forces with other major industrial democracies, the International Monetary Fund and World Bank.
* Above all, the act is an investment in America's security, now and in the future. There are two peace dividends. The first is financial and important. The second is human -- the freedom from fear we wish for all Americans -- and it is vital. If Russian and other reformers fail, if democracy collapses and authoritarianism returns, both dividends will slip through our fingers and we will all lose. Defense budgets would rise again and the fear of confrontation we knew during 40 years of cold war would be certain to return.
* The Senate has passed the Freedom Support Act. The House of Representatives should not hesitate, because history certainly will not. Events are moving quickly in the former Soviet Union, and we must keep step to help shape them. It will take statesmanship to pass the act -- and pass it quickly. Statesmanship is the ability to distinguish between a reason and an excuse.
There could be plenty of excuses for the House to reject the act or to cripple it with "killer amendments": the Federal budget is tight, times at home are lean, this is an election year. But there is a simple, compelling reason why the act should pass: It will help insure our security for decades to come.
Statesmen of the 1940's -- from national leaders like Harry S. Truman and Senator Arthur Vandenberg to freshman Congressmen like John F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon -- understood the difference between reasons and excuses. They answered their generations' summons to international leadership.
Today, it will require similar statesmanship, from Democrats and Republicans alike, to answer our call to leadership and secure a democratic peace for future generations of Americans.

HEADLINE: Reducing Casualties in the Abortion Battle

BYLINE: By Mario M. Cuomo; Mario M. Cuomo is Governor of New York.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
The struggle over when and whether abortion should remain a legal choice for American women seems likely to rage on for years, and while people of good will struggle over their polarized views, what should be a vital common ground may continue to be neglected.
Whatever else the abortion adversaries believe, most of them would also agree that there are entirely too many abortions in this country. Of the six million pregnancies in the United States every year, more than half are unplanned; more than a quarter -- 1.5 million -- end in abortion. That's a rate higher than for any other industrialized Western nation. 
 It's here that we may find some real hope of accomplishing what most people agree is a desirable goal -- reducing the rate of abortion by helping women avoid the circumstances that press them to make such a difficult choice. It's an idea that could join people rather than tear them apart. Here are some general principles I would suggest as a starting point for such a constructive discourse.
First, we should try to teach young men and women their responsibility in creating and caring for human life. At the very least, young people should hear from us that they are not deficient because they choose to abstain from sexual relations until another and better time.
Today, speaking up for abstention may sound old-fashioned and naive, but if we don't, we run the risk of saying -- with our silence -- that we condone the alternative message of the popular culture, that sexual activity is a necessary way to validate one's maturity.
At the same time, however, we must recognize that not all young people will follow the path of restraint -- even with our best efforts -- so every young American who is sexually active but not yet prepared for the responsibilities of parenthood should have access to complete, intelligent information and counsel on the possible consequences of sexual activity and on the uses of contraception. Now more than ever, responsible sex education is an appropriate part of the public school curriculum.
Some of us believe the use of contraceptives is wrong. Those who do have a right to live by that belief. That is one of the great beauties of this democracy: No one can be required to have an abortion or to use contraception. But for the sake of those who believe that contraception is a better alternative than an unwanted pregnancy that ends in abortion, we should invest in better, simpler, safer contraceptive technology.
Beyond abstinence, education and contraception, there is another partial solution that deserves our attention: adoption. Some women would choose not to end a pregnancy if they could be relieved of some or all of the emotional, physical, financial and social commitments of rearing a child -- commitments they judge themselves incapable of undertaking for a lifetime.
We need to re-examine the adoption alternative, not as a panacea for abortion but as one of the many ways we can create real choices for people. There are literally thousands of couples eager to adopt. We should remove undue obstacles to adoption where they exist, making the process as easy as possible, consistent with prudence.
Finally, for those women who might consider an abortion because of economic extremity, we must make sure that carrying a child to term is a realistic choice. Specifically, we must make the health care needed to have and raise a healthy child as available as the care needed to receive an abortion. That's the New York policy; it should be America's.
Everyone, I hope, would agree that life beyond the womb deserves more consideration, but in this regard our work has barely begun. We are a long way from creating a society where the concern for new life doesn't end at the moment of birth; where an infant isn't helped into a world that doesn't care if a baby is fed properly, housed decently, educated adequately; where the blind or disabled child isn't condemned to exist rather than empowered to live.
Unless we change the terms of the debate, the question of abortion rights will lock our nation in combat indefinitely. To allow the current differences on this subject to postpone humane and constructive action to reduce the need for abortion and improve the lot of our children would be foolish.
As we have done for a decade in New York State, we must resolve as a nation to pursue every avenue that helps bring down the rate of unintended pregnancy and, therefore, the number of abortions. Wouldn't it be useful if both Governor Clinton and President Bush could join in such a discussion?

HEADLINE: Enticed by Tax Breaks, Prudential Will Stay in New York

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Having declined to take space in the Times Square Center office complex planned by its parent company, Prudential Securities Inc. has nonetheless decided to stay in New York City, keeping its headquarters and about 5,000 jobs in lower Manhattan.
The Prudential brokerage firm is to receive tax incentives and energy savings worth at least $106.2 million over 20 years. In return, it is to sign 20-year leases for a total of 1.5 million square feet of space at One Seaport Plaza, where it now has its headquarters, and One New York Plaza. 
 By keeping Prudential in New York, the city will realize more than $830 million in tax revenue over 20 years, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday as he announced the deal with Howard A. (Woody) Knight, an executive vice president of Prudential Securities.
The Mayor described the deal as the "second-largest lease transaction in the history of the city," exceeded only by Merrill Lynch's commitment to 3.9 million square feet at the World Financial Center in 1984.
"Let there be no mistake -- and Woody, you can back me up on this -- P.S.I. was out the door," Mr. Dinkins said. "They had launched an intensive two-year search for more affordable space. But we are fighters. And this is a win for all of us."
Deputy Mayor Barry F. Sullivan said there was no direct link between the decision by Prudential Securities to stay in New York and a recent decision by city and state officials to relieve the Prudential Insurance Company of America of its obligation to follow a construction timetable at Times Square Center, of which it is a developer.
But Mr. Sullivan added, "I have to tell you that the good will from one negotiation washed over to the other, and vice versa." Under the tentative Times Square agreement, the developers would invest about $30 million in renovations along 42d Street.
Although it has not been completed, the Times Square deal has already been criticized by State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, for needlessly consuming millions of dollars in public money for acquisition of the site.
And the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, who has frequently questioned the city's incentive policies, said yesterday of the Prudential Securities deal that "any financial package this size requires an examination of its costs and benefits." But she said she was "delighted that Prudential Securities remains a part of the New York community."
 
Deemed Inappropriate
 Among "literally hundreds" of alternatives Prudential Securities was considering for its operations, Mr. Knight said, was Times Square Center, a four-tower office project on Broadway and Seventh Avenue.
But Mr. Knight said that in February, Prudential executives "concluded it would not be appropriate" for the firm to move to 42d Street.
Even if Times Square Center had been ready when Prudential's leases began expiring in 1994, Mr. Knight said, "we would have been one of the very first people in a project that had a long time from start to finish."
What that would have meant, said Rodger G. Parker, a senior vice president at Prudential Securities, was that the area "would be in a state of flux probably for five years."
 
Search Led to Other Cities
 Instead, Prudential will lease one million square feet in One New York Plaza, at Water and Broad Streets, a 50-story building owned by the Chase Manhattan Bank, and renew its lease for 500,000 square feet in One Seaport Plaza, at Water and Fulton Streets, a 34-story building owned by the Resnick family. It will vacate space in six other buildings downtown.
The search for new space took the company to Houston, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Jersey City, as well as Times Square, Mr. Parker said.
But Mr. Knight said state and city officials were able to "level the playing field" through the incentives.
The package includes these items:
*An estimated $48.4 million in energy savings through the use of power generated by the James A. FitzPatrick Nuclear Power Plant.
*An estimated $41.1 million in tax revenue that the city will forgo in sales taxes on construction materials and major equipment like computers and telecommunications systems, real estate taxes, commercial rent taxes and mortgage-recording taxes.
*An estimated $16.7 million in tax revenue that the state will forgo in sales and mortgage-recording taxes.
The package does not include the tax benefits that Chase Manhattan might receive, under the city's new Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program, for the renovation of the Prudential space.

HEADLINE: A Compromise on Radio Station Ownership

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission took the middle road today on radio ownership, bowing to opposition from Congress and the radio industry itself.
The agency raised the number of radio stations that a single company may control, to 18 AM and 18 FM stations from the current 12 each, but it retreated from the new rules that it issued earlier this year that would have allowed a company to own 30 AM stations and 30 FM stations. 
 Critics had said the higher limits could have led to a few broadcasters dominating the nation's airwaves.
The F.C.C. also ruled that radio companies could buy noncontrolling stakes in an additional 3 AM and 3 FM stations beyond the 18, if the new stations were owned by members of minority groups. After two years, the limit on controlling interests will be 20 AM and 20 FM outlets, plus the 3 additional, noncontrolling stakes.
 
Help for Three Companies
 The new rules will take effect when published in the Federal Register, probably within a month or so.
Three companies are nearing the old ownership limits and presumably could take advantage of the new rules soon: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. of New York, with interests in 11 AM and 10 FM stations nationwide; the Willis Broadcasting Corporation of Richmond, with interests in 13 AM and 13 FM stations, and Ragan Henry of Philadelphia, with interests in 9 AM and 12 FM stations. Willis and Ragan Henry are minority-owned.
The companies could not be immediately reached for comment.
Since 1940, the F.C.C. has limited the number of stations that a single owner can control. But in the 1980's, it licensed more than 2,000 new radio stations at a time when competition from MTV and other cable-television music programs reduced radio's share of advertising dollars. Today, more than half the industry's 11,000 stations are unprofitable, and scores of stations are closing. Concerns owned by members of minority groups were hit especially hard.
Earlier this year, the commission proposed to loosen the ownership limits so that financially stronger companies could rescue the weaker ones and thus promote diverse voices in radio programming.
But even the radio industry, especially smaller stations, felt the commission had gone too far, especially in adopting rules that allowed broadcasters to buy as many as 6 radio stations in the largest markets. Some radio broadcasters also feared that reaction in Congress would be so adverse that lawmakers would pass legislation freezing the ownership limit at 12 AM and 12 FM.
Alfred C. Sikes, F.C.C. chairman, favored the proposal to raise the limits, which commission staff members had drafted, but had difficulty winning support on the five-member panel. Commissioners Andrew C. Barrett, Ervin S. Duggan and James H. Quello opposed the more sweeping F.C.C. staff proposal but favored some change. Only Sherrie P. Marshall sided with Mr. Sikes.
The National Association of Broadcasters, the radio industry trade group, said in a news release yesterday, "The commission has answered the radio industry's distress signals with rules that will clearly help keep the industry afloat and on course."
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and a leader of the opposition to the F.C.C. rules, said in a statement, "The commission has wisely decided to moderate its excessive decision of last March." He added that the new rules would improve the industry's economic well-being while avoiding "the risk of excessive concentration."
 
An Angry Letter
 In an angry letter to Mr. Sikes, dated May 27, Representative Dingell implied that the agency had acted hastily and had seemed to ignore evidence that high limits would lead to an alarmingly low number of broadcasters owning most of America's radio stations. He complained of an "apparent lack of analytical support" for the 30-30 limits.
The commission then produced an analysis, explaining an earlier worst-case scenario, under which 166 broadcast companies could end up owning all of America's radio stations, down from 5,200 nationwide.
"We heard that after Congressman Dingell asked for the analysis, people over at the F.C.C. were up all weekend preparing one," said Dennis Fitzgibbons, Mr. Dingell's press secretary. William H. Johnson, deputy chief of the bureau that prepared the economic analysis, disputed the contention that the commission lacked an analysis but acknowledged that "some of the work was done before the Congressman's letter and some of it was done after."
 
'Pioneer's Preference' Rejected
 In other actions, the commission denied a much-sought-after "pioneer's preference" to five companies seeking to establish a satellite telephone system that would allow customers to place cellular telephone calls from anywhere on Earth, even the remotest regions.
A pioneer's preference would give a company numerous regulatory advantages and the use of the critical parts of the electromagnetic spectrum that are under Government supervision and are necessary for providing the phone service.
Five companies are seeking to establish satellite phone service, including Motorola Inc., whose Iridium project is the most ambitious. Motorola and financial backers that it has not yet lined up plan to spend more than $3 billion to launch a constellation of 77 satellites.
The commission's staff concluded and the commission agreed that no company's plan was so innovative as to qualify for the preference.
The commission also agreed with a staff proposal that paved the way for shifting part of the electromagnetic spectrum now used by oil companies, electrical utilities and ambulance services to new concerns offering what are known as personal communications services.

HEADLINE: Brown Says Community Policing Will Endure

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Imperturbable, guarded, at times wistful, and above all jovially confident, Lee P. Brown took stock yesterday of the New York City Police Department that he will be leaving at month's end and pronounced himself satisfied that the new wave of local-based policing he sponsored would outlive his abrupt departure.
He said the executive staff he put in place -- including his interim successor, First Deputy Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly -- combined with new systems set in place and the strong commitment of Mayor David N. Dinkins to community policing would preserve his legacy, which he called the only option for the department. 
 "It's no longer a program," he said. "This is how we do business."
Yet, he acknowledged, "We don't have a manual that we're following -- we're doing a lot of this as we're going along."
At City Hall, meanwhile, Mayor Dinkins and some of his aides said yesterday that Fritz W. Alexander, the deputy mayor for public safety, hoped to announce by Friday or Monday a committee of four or five police experts from outside the department to screen candidates for the commissioner's job. Mr. Dinkins said he would not give the panel a deadline although he wanted them to move "as quickly as they can."
In his first long interview after his surprise announcement on Monday that he would quit to spend time with his ill wife, Mr. Brown, a 54-year-old police professional and criminologist, said he had "a lot of regrets" at not being able to see his program through to fruition in 1996, when the number of officers will peak at about 31,000, up from about 28,000 now.
"I'll have to watch from afar," he said, calling his two and a half years at the helm of the nation's largest police department "the apex of my career" -- where else, he asked, was there to go after that?
In fact, it will be back to Houston, where he served as Police Chief from 1982 to 1990 and where, starting Sept. 1, he said, he will begin teaching at Texas Southern University while his wife, Yvonne, receives medical treatment. Citing her privacy, he declined to say anything about her illness or condition, but associates have said she has cancer. The couple have twin daughters attending Texas Southern, as well as two other grown children in the Chicago area. Mr. Brown said he had sold his house in Houston and would have to start house hunting all over again.
 
Points to Make
 Sitting at times bolt upright and at other times fidgeting in a wing chair in his top-floor office overlooking Chinatown, Mr. Brown, in a gray houndstooth suit, crisp white shirt and navy polka-dot tie, made the following points, among others:
*While speaking warmly of Mr. Kelly, he declined to say whether he favored Mr. Kelly as his permanent replacement. But he said "race shouldn't be a factor" in the appointment. Some of the suggested candidates for the job are black, as is Commissioner Brown. Mr. Kelly, as are several of the others, is white. Mr. Brown said that he stood ready to assist in the selection, but he had not been approached.
*He said that while he had been "sidetracked by crises" like a police drug-corruption scandal and disturbances in Washington Heights triggered by perceived police brutality, he saw none of the crises as symptoms of serious failures by himself or the department.
*Although he and Mayor Dinkins did not always see eye to eye, he said, "I'm not mad at the Mayor." As for rivalries with budget officials and others at City Hall, he said he had always clashed with those who would cut his funds or try to run his department.
*The abrupt resignation by Chief of Department David W. Scott, the department's highest uniformed officer, was unrelated, Mr. Brown said, to his own resignation. Mr. Brown said he was told by Chief Scott of his plans to retire for health reasons before Chief Scott could have know of Mr. Browns own plans.
The Commissioner, renowned for his equanimity and relentlessly upbeat predictions, said community policing had been too firmly rooted to be jeopardized although, he said, in every crisis, "There are those who would clamor to go back to the old ways."
He warned that if the economy seriously worsened and crime soared "quite likely there would be a demand to go back to traditional policing." But he voiced confidence that the collaboration of the police and neighborhood residents and citizens' groups, working together to identify and solve problems, would withstand challenges.
Even in the event of Los Angeles-type riots, he said, "It would still be better to have a cop firmly fixed in the community on a permanent basis than a SWAT team waiting to put out disorders."
His tone turned plaintive as he spoke of not being able to see his plans mature. "I would prefer to have been here," he said quietly.
 
Hiring Up, Crime Down
 Although foot patrol strength has grown from 750 officers in August 1990 to some 3,000 now, the full complement of 5,000 will not be reached until the hiring plan is completed in 1996, he said. The original plan to hire 1,626 more civilian employees to free police officers assigned to desk jobs has been sharply scaled back because of the fiscal crisis, a matter of some disappointment, Mr. Brown said.
But he attributed at least a share of recent dips in reported crimes to community policing. Reported crimes have been down over the corresponding month of the year before for 20 of the last 21 months. In the first four months of this year there has been a 6.7 percent drop from the four months in the same period a year ago.
He said that in the case of a Brooklyn officer, Michael Dowd, accused of running a cocaine ring with other officers, there was "blame all over the place" -- not just in the Police Department but also in the former special prosecutor's office and District Attorney's offices.
Checking the records, Mr. Brown said, he found some police scandal in each of the last 20 years.
He also defended his absence during the recent outbreak of rioting in Washington Heights after a police officer fatally shot a suspected drug dealer. He said that while visiting his mother in Fresno, Calif., he remained in close touch with his office.
He said resignation was straightforward: "I've been married 34 years," he said haltingly. "My wife has been the person who has followed me all over the place in terms of my career. And at a time when she's in need, I'm going to make sure I'm there for her. That's the bottom line."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
There They Go Again: Clinton and Gore Climb Back on Bus for a 3-Day Trip

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Iowa, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Having their act together, Bill Clinton and Al Gore are taking it on the road again.
No Presidential ticket has ever put together anything like the political stage show of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, which is so mutually supportive that it sometimes resembles an old vaudeville act -- "Absolutely, Mr. Clinton. Positively, Mr. Gore" -- as each man relentlessly complements and compliments the other. 
 And few pieces of political theater have ever had such initial success as did Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore in their tryouts, when they found cheering crowds and glowing press throughout a six-day bus trip from Manhattan to St. Louis.
In search of more of the same, Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gore, their wives, the Gores' oldest daughter, 40 or so staff members and 150 journalists returned to their buses and the highways of the Middle West today in a three-day trip that will take the entourage from St. Louis (picking up where the first trip ended) north through border towns and small cities in Illinois, Missouri, Wisconsin and Minnesota.
 
Rehearsed Spontaneity
 The bus tour started out with the Clintons and the Gores exhibiting somewhat self-conscious displays of high spirits as they posed for the cameras at Lambert Field, the St. Louis airport. Mrs. Clinton, who started out the day wearing a button reading "Hillary Clinton: One Smart Cookie," and Mrs. Gore whispered and giggled and hugged each other.
Mrs. Clinton sounded a bit like a cruise ship recreation director as she exhorted the crowd at the airport. "Are you ready? Are you ready? This is going to be fun," she said, adding, "We're going to start singing 'Happy Trails.' "
Their first day out, the Democrats found very much what they were looking for. After an appearance before a smaller-than-expected crowd in East St. Louis, Ill., to begin the trip, the buses left the Interstate system and proceeded north through a series of small Mississippi River towns and cities in a sort of "Blue Highways" political journey.
As the entourage of 15 vehicles moved along blacktop lanes through cornfields and river flatlands, crowds of flag- and sign-waving people began to be seen at gas stations, intersections and country stores. Four times in the space of 100 miles, the crowds were large enough to bring the procession to a halt and send the candidates, shirtsleeved and beaming, out to shake hands and say hello to the hundreds of people stretched along rope lines.
The tone of the people who came out to see the candidates was notable for its infectious enthusiasm, with people pushing and yelling in their rush to get the attention and, if possible, the touch of the candidates. In Wayland, Mo., Mayor Bill Moss was among the more than 500 people who gathered in the late afternoon. Mr. Clinton, greeting him, asked what the population of the town was.
"Whole bunch bigger now," Mr. Moss said. (Officially, it is 391.)
It was clear that Democratic officials along the way had worked hard, using radio announcements and telephone networks, to bring out the crowds. For several days before this trip, Clinton tacticians have been busily playing down the size of the crowds they expected to see.
In fact, the Democrats had taken efforts to build the most self-consciously dramatic crowd of the day, a group of more than a thousand people gathered at a gas station and parking lot off a state highway in Bowling Green, Mo. The size of the crowd forced the bus entourage to what was billed as a "spontaneous" stop.
"There was quite a lot of phone calls," said Helen Pratt of Franklin, Mo. "I got called by Brenda Wells, the sheriff's wife, who is the vice president of the Women's Democrat League around here, and I gathered up a whole bunch of people and brought them down."
 
City by the River
 The day culminated here in Burlington, a manufacturing and farming city of 27,000 on the banks of the Mississippi River, where Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, evidently exultant, took the stage before a crowd of some 10,000 people, many of whom had been waiting for hours to see them.
Mr. Clinton quickly went into a new and especially pointed attack on President Bush for his handling of the recession, drawing on a quote from the President published in a news report today. "My opponent is quoted as saying the recession is over," Mr. Clinton said. "You just don't know it. That's what they've been telling you all along. Things are great. You're just too dumb to see it."
In Hannibal, Mo., Samuel Clemens's hometown by the Mississippi, the crowds were large enough to be more than respectable, and seemed nearly as enthusiastic as those that greeted the Democrats on their first trip together.
They used the friendly settings to continue their escalating attacks on President Bush. In the deeply impoverished city of East St. Louis, where the bus caravan first stopped, both candidates offered a sharply heightened and more pointed criticism of Mr. Bush for his handling of the civil war in the former Yugoslav republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, suggesting that he was, in not taking more forceful action, ignoring a genocidal situation that they implicitly compared to the Holocaust.
In the small, green city of Hannibal where Clemens grew up, and where half the shops and restaurants in town exploit the writer's pen name, the Arkansas Governor invoked the shade of Mark Twain in a sort of literary-politico jab at Mr. Bush. "Mark Twain once said petrified opinions and old ideas never did anything to break a chain or free a human soul," he said. "That's what we have in Washington: petrified ideas."
"Their whole idea is that it could be worse," Mr. Clinton said. "Our whole idea is that it could be better."

HEADLINE: In Budgetless California, a Sense of Business as Usual

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 5

 BODY:
On California's 36th day without a state budget, negotiations here are moving sluggishly, lawmakers are cranky, Gov. Pete Wilson's face is etched with strain and state workers are scrambling to cash the i.o.u.'s they are getting instead of paychecks.
Today the Bank of America, the state's largest bank, stopped offering cash to its customers in exchange for the i.o.u.'s and several other banks are expected to follow suit at week's end. 
 But despite the $10.7 billion budget gap, the ballooning interest costs on the i.o.u.'s, the precipitous drop in California's credit rating and the steadily deteriorating economy, what is most striking here in this scorching state capital is the sense of business as usual.
Legislative committees continue to debate bills about mobile-home loans and the reporting requirements for dialysis centers. Tourists, many of them Californians, continue to troop through the Capitol rotunda and relax on the leafy grounds.
Lobbyists continue to buttonhole lawmakers and aides at the water coolers. And government officials continue to lament the fact that the state, unlike the Federal Government, lacks the statutory authority to furlough workers or close monuments in order to generate a sense of urgency about the failure to agree on a budget for the fiscal year that began July 1.
 
An Old, Familiar Tune
 "All the experts were expecting that people would take to the street in righteous anger," said Dan Schnur, Governor Wilson's director of communications. "But people have built up a lot of resistance. They've been inoculated by years of budget shortfalls. They've heard this all before."
Indeed, California has often failed to finish its budget by July 1 in years past. But this year is different, because there is no reserve fund to cover the temporary lapse.
Governor Wilson and the four legislative leaders met this afternoon in what is still known here as the Ronald Reagan Cabinet Room. Similar meetings have taken place since Friday.
While the Bank of America's refusal to accept any more i.o.u.'s inconvenienced state workers who patronize it, they will not be left in straitened circumstances, as employees at the huge bank were quick to tell them. Other banks and credit unions, primarily First Interstate, the No. 3 bank in the state, and Credit One, the credit union that serves three-fourths of the state workers in the area, still accept the warrants. In fact, they are saying so in their advertising, hoping to lure new customers.
By all accounts the only people so far who are truly suffering from the stalemate are the vendors who do business with the state, providing goods and services at prisons, hospitals and other institutions. While a law requires that state employees be paid, at least with i.o.u.'s, and a court order for the time being guarantees health and welfare payments, there is no law covering vendors; they are receiving no money or scrip for now.
 
Hardships for Vendors
 Scattered news reports in recent days have told of hardships for vendors, like a meat company in the Yosemite area that cut back employees' weekly hours to 24 from 40, or a cold-storage company in Orange County that laid off 4 of its 25 workers and is considering taking out a high-interest loan to meet its payroll. These small-business owners are far from the Capitol and are unable, as the state workers would be, to clamor in the corridors or even go on strike.
It was the prospect of Bank of America's joining 20-odd smaller banks in refusing to accept the i.o.u.'s for state workers, as well as a poll late last month that showed approval ratings plummeting for both the Governor and the Legislature, that brought Mr. Wilson and the four legislative leaders back to the bargaining table on Friday for the first time in many weeks.
 
Some Tentative Agreements
 For a few days those negotiations looked promising, with tentative agreements struck among the leaders about how to reduce spending for higher education, health and welfare, and corrections.
But the heavy lifting remains. The sticky question of financing for public schools and community colleges has been put off, to be tackled only after everything else is settled. And on Tuesday the leaders confronted what is thought to be the second-highest hurdle to agreement: how to slash funds to already cash-poor counties, which by law are the providers of last resort of health and welfare benefits to the poor.
Governor Wilson, a Republican, wants to give counties authority to spend shrinking resources as they wish, even if it means eliminating required welfare payments to single, childless people. Many Democrats fear that lifting these mandates will mean that rural counties can, in effect, put the poor on buses to San Francisco or Los Angeles and leave the urban counties stuck with the bill.
Mr. Wilson talked tough about Democratic intransigence after Tuesday's bargaining session. "This is a zero sum game," Mr. Wilson said at a news conference. "I really don't think that has sunk in."
Meanwhile, rank-and-file lawmakers were grousing about a tortuous process that has already cost them their July vacations, tarnished their reputations with constituents and left them feeling like bit players in a drama that is being played out without them.
Last week there was a brief outcry for the leaders to step aside and let the foot soldiers take over the budget-writing process. A resolution was offered suggesting that the Governor be chained to the podium until a budget was passed. And the speeches that any member is permitted to make at the close of each session grew more numerous and more cranky each day.
"There is a very high level of frustration and disappointment, frankly, that the process isn't working," said Senator Marian Bergeson, a Republican from Newport Beach.
Assemblyman Robert Campbell, a Richmond Democrat, crossed party lines to agree. "There are so many other issues," he said, citing the continuing drought, the declining quality of elementary education and fee schedules at the state universities. "And we can't do anything else because we're spending all our energy on the budget."
There were also isolated examples of public unhappiness -- no groundswell, to be sure, but stirrings. A carpenter at work in the old Senator Hotel, now an office building, said he had heard on a radio talk program that the i.o.u.'s had already cost the state more than $2.6 million in interest, which he did not like one bit. A cafeteria worker in the elevator at the Capitol muttered unprintable epithets about the Governor.
And the Capitol bureau of The San Francisco Chronicle received a handful of phone calls from angry citizens, including one urging the newspaper to publish the phone numbers of lawmakers to make it easier to complain.
But, as with most crises, there were winners here as well as losers. The city-owned parking garage used by lawmakers and their staff members was bustling at a time when it is usually half empty. And business was brisk last month at Frank Fats restaurant, a Capitol institution famous for its banana cream pie and its high-powered clientele.
Prognosticators were busy, too. In the course of one day here earlier this week, David Roberti, the president pro tem of the State Senate, changed his prediction that the budget would be complete by Aug. 15, just before the Republican National Convention opens in Houston, and said that Sept. 1 was a safer bet.
And Sherry Bebitch Jeffee, a political analyst at the Claremont Graduate School, said she had been wandering the corridors of the Capitol and had "heard everything from Labor Day to Nov. 1."
