HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Jabs at Rival's Morals, Saying Values Are Besieged

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: RENO, Aug. 5

 BODY:
President Bush today put religion and morality at the heart of his effort to undermine public trust in Gov. Bill Clinton, suggesting that the Democratic nominee lacks the moral fiber to be President.
Accompanied by John Cardinal O'Connor, Mr. Bush appeared before a wildly applauding, flag-waving crowd at a Knights of Columbus meeting in New York City to present himself as the nation's "moral compass" at a time when he said its "fundamental values" were under siege. 
 Making a two-day, cross-country campaign swing to New York, Nevada and Colorado, Mr. Bush displayed as much confidence and animation as he has shown in the weeks since his poll numbers plummeted after the Democratic National Convention.
Leaving New York, he eagerly clambered aboard a lime-green firetruck to ride back to Air Force One at John F. Kennedy Airport while his aides beamed their approval. "I think he looked a little more studly than Dukakis in the tank," said Torie Clarke, the campaign press secretary, in a reference to one of the 1988 Democratic nominee's most embarrassing campaign gaffes.
 
'Set the Record Straight'
 By the time Mr. Bush arrived in Reno to address a gathering of the Disabled American Veterans, he was talking about his Democratic rival with a directness unusual for a politician who usually refers to his opponents as "they."
"The Clinton-Gore ticket has two more weeks of leave and then after the convention we're going to go after them," Mr. Bush told supporters at the airport here, the first time he has referred to the Democrats by name in a public setting. "We're going to take it to the people. We're going to set the record straight."
Addressing the veterans, Mr. Bush suggested that Mr. Clinton was too untried in foreign affairs to be entrusted with the country's security. "The foreign playing field is so competitive that I'm not sure we should trust our team to a rookie quarterback," he said.
In New York, Mr. Bush staked out tough stands against abortion and for organized prayer in schools as he portrayed the Arkansas Governor as an opportunistic politician who would let 13-year-old girls obtain abortions without their parents' consent.
"Today I make the same appeal to you that I make to every voter," said Mr. Bush, who received two standing ovations from the Knights, a Catholic service organization, at the Marriott Marquis hotel on Times Square. "Look beneath the rhetoric. Take a look at the ideas to determine who has the courage to stand up for the changes that are morally right for America."
Using one of the homespun lines crafted for him by his new speech writer, Steven Provost, Mr. Bush offered a calculated sound bite that not only presented Mr. Clinton as less morally worthy but also echoed Republican charges that Mr. Clinton was "slick."
"If you're looking to restore America's moral fiber, why buy a synthetic when you can get real cotton?" the President said.
 
Strategy for Victory
 Mr. Bush's speech reflected the extent to which his strategists are calculating that to win in November the President must alarm voters about his Democratic opponent by painting Mr. Clinton as too liberal on issues like welfare, abortion and religion. This year, as in past campaigns, the Republicans are making a strong appeal for Catholic voters, an important bloc in the Northeast and the Midwest.
White House officials said early on that they would try to make morality and family values a centerpiece of the Presidential campaign because of Mr. Clinton's personal problems in the primary season.
On Monday, Mr. Bush was forced to repudiate an effort by his campaign to bring up the issue head-on, and the speech yesterday was clearly intended as a more sophisticated allusion to the reports about Mr. Clinton's private life. It also seemed intended to further Republican efforts to present Mr. Bush and his wife, Barbara, as more fitting and more traditional role models for the nation.
Appearing more relaxed and confident than he has in recent weeks, Mr. Bush also used the occasion to stake out a strong anti-abortion position two weeks before the Republican National Convention, at which the party's right wing will be trying to beat back efforts to moderate its platform plank on the issue.
Introduced to the crowd by Virgil Dechant, Supreme Knight of the organization, as a staunch anti-abortionist, Mr. Bush said, "Seven times I have ignored the polls and acted on what I believe is fundamental principle and vetoed, as Virgil very generously pointed out, abortion legislation."
Bringing the crowd to its feet, Mr. Bush added: "And I promise you again today, no matter the political price, and they tell me in this year it's enormous, I am going to do what is right. I am going to stand on my conscience and let my conscience be my guide when it comes to matters of life.
"In some places, a 13-year-old girl cannot get her ears pierced without parental permission, without bringing her mother and father along. But some believe that the same girl should be able to get an abortion without parental consent. And I think most Americans believe this idea is crazy, and I'm going to fight to see that it doesn't happen."
The President also continued to refine his efforts, which have proved unsuccessful thus far, to present himself as an agent of change even though he has been in public life for decades. "Sure, change is natural," he said. "But maybe a better word for the United States of America is renewal, because the change we need is based on principles that never change."
 
Stressing a Moral Tone
 But Mr. Bush's primary purpose yesterday seemed to be to chip away at public confidence in Mr. Clinton on moral grounds. "Some think it's O.K. to hand out condoms in schools, but oppose amending our Constitution to allow our kids to put their hands together in prayer," Mr. Bush said. "I disagree."
Calling the Presidency "more than managing the economy, more even than being Commander in Chief," Mr. Bush said, "I stake my claim to a simple belief: The President should try to set a moral tone for this nation. And all around us, we see evidence that America's moral compass has gone awry."

HEADLINE: Banks Cite Expense in Refusing State I.O.U.'s

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Bank of America was not the first bank in California to stop accepting the state government's i.o.u.'s, but because of its huge network of 1,435 branches, the decision by the largest bank in the state was a particularly inconvenient to state workers, creditors and local governments.
"To say that banks stopped accepting the i.o.u.'s to put pressure on the political process is an overstatement," said Greg Wilhelm, legislative director at the California State Bankers Association. He pointed out that the expense of handling the i.o.u.'s was a frequent complaint of banks and that some bankers had been stung by newspaper editorials claiming that continued acceptance of them was prolonging the problem. 
 Wells Fargo Bank, the second largest in the state, and Union Bank, the fourth largest, had previously said they would not accept i.o.u.'s dated after July 31.
Mr. Wilhelm said that "most elected officials were probably glad when the banks started to pull the plug."
"The banking industry's willingness to accept the warrants acted as a shock absorber in keeping the pressure off the Legislature to solve the budget problem," he said.
A spokeswoman for the Bank of America, Sharon Tucker, said the bank did not have any special arrangements to help customers who might fall behind in loan payments because they cannot cash the i.o.u.'s. "We tried to accommodate the vast majority of people by accepting the i.o.u.'s after the end of July, when most state workers are paid," she added.
Officials at Bank of America and Wells Fargo noted that accepting the i.o.u.'s, or registered warrants, created an additional expense that was not fully covered by the 5 percent interest rate the state is paying.
 
A Difficult Balance
 Finding the right balance between serving customers and accepting the extra cost of handling the i.o.u.'s has been difficult for many bankers in the state. William M. Ried, president of the Mechanics Bank in Richmond, said that early in the week he had decided to stop accepting the i.o.u.'s but that yesterday he changed his mind.
"I thought about our customers and decided that outweighed the extra costs or the possibility of fraud," Mr. Ried said.
As the state's paper becomes harder to convert into cash, financiers are beginning to look for alternatives to banks.
Gray Davis, the State Controller, said that "the jury is still out as to whether banks can make a little money" because of the interest payments.
To encourage banks to continue cashing the i.o.u.'s for their customers, Mr. Davis said his office is working to develop a secondary market where banks might sell the i.o.u.'s they do not want to hold. Because the 5 percent interest paid by the state is exempt from Federal and state tax and is two or three percentage points higher than other short-term securities, Mr. Davis hopes there are investors willing to accept the uncertain maturity of the notes.
The WesCap Federal Credit Union in Pomona is already providing a similar service for credit unions, by promising to buy i.o.u's that they have cashed for their customers but do not want to hold.
Los Angeles County is serving as a banker of sorts for other local governments that have received i.o.u.'s rather than cash from the state.
Maureen Oster, the development officer in the Los Angeles County Treasurer and Tax Collector's office, said the county's offer to buy state i.o.u.'s from other local governments has attracted more and more telephone calls in recent days. She warned that if other local governments do not find ways to cash the i.o.u.'s, "they might be forced to issue registered warrants themselves."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
WPP Gets a Second Chance As Holders Clear Debt Plan

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
SHAREHOLDERS of WPP Group P.L.C. voted overwhelmingly yesterday at a special meeting in London to approve a plan that extensively restructures its crushing debt.
The approval, by holders of 99.7 percent of the shares voted, offers the agency holding company time to try to ride out the industry's seemingly endless recession. 
 Analysts in Britain and the United States, who have followed WPP's travails as avidly as soap-opera fans await the next installment of their favorite serial, welcomed the vote. They praised aspects of the agreement that the British financial press had characterized as a rescue plan, because it eliminated a well-publicized threat by a syndicate of 28 creditor banks to seize control of WPP and force it into receivership.
"Barring an Armageddon, we shouldn't be here again," David Forster, a media analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities, said in an interview from London. "I'm not saying they're out of the woods, but they have bought themselves a lot of breathing room. It's a major step in the right direction."
Under the restructuring, about $270 million of WPP's debt, which totaled $1.1 billion to $1.5 billion, will be forgiven, and the annual interest payments will be pared about 40 percent. In exchange, the banks, which gained voting control of WPP in November when the company failed to pay them dividends, will assume ownership of 52 percent of WPP, a stake that will be reduced after the issuance of additional shares to 47 to 48 percent.
WPP's debt had threatened to overwhelm the financially hard-pressed parent of advertising agencies like the J. Walter Thompson Company and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and public-relations firms like Hill & Knowlton.
"There won't be any more recourse to the bankers after this," said Lorna Tilbian, a media analyst at S. G. Warburg in London, noting that under the plan, WPP will not begin repaying its debt until 1997. "I think it's steady as she goes from now on."
Still, the analysts cautioned that like a soap-opera heroine who recovers from amnesia only to learn she has an evil twin sister, WPP remains faced with daunting challenges, not the least of which is the damage caused by the intensive coverage of its financial struggles.
"It was not helpful to us at all to have all those headlines about 'financially troubled WPP,' " Burt Manning, Thompson's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview as he prepared to return to New York from the meeting.
"As an operating entity," he added, "Thompson wasn't in question. During all this time, we've gotten new assignments, new billings and we've been profitable.
"But every time a story about the holding company appeared, it would create concern, which I guess is understandable."
Martin Sorrell, chief executive of WPP, said he was pleased by the outcome of the vote, which seemed in doubt until Fidelity Investment Services, WPP's largest shareholder, reluctantly decided late on Friday to support the plan.
WPP's operating companies, he added, "have performed particularly well, given the circumstances they were operating under -- what has been going on in the industry and the particular uncertainty we faced.
"The removal of the uncertainty will enable our companies to be even more successful."
Analysts said the restructuring, which includes providing WPP with $150 million in working capital, seemed predicated on no early or significant upswing in the uncertain British and American ad economies.
"It was put together on a very conservative basis," said Mr. Forster of Kleinwort Benson, "with no assumption of a strong recovery."
In the next few days, concurrent with the restructuring, Gordon Stevens will replace the legendary adman David Ogilvy as WPP's chairman. Mr. Sorrell noted that as regional director of the North American operations of Unilever P.L.C., a giant WPP client, Mr. Stevens had worked with both Thompson and Ogilvy.
Mr. Ogilvy, 81 years old, will become WPP's president emeritus and a consultant. He came out of retirement to become WPP's chairman in 1989, to mollify those anxious about Mr. Sorrell's $865 million hostile takeover of Ogilvy.
It was that acquisition, two years after Thompson's, that pushed WPP to the brink.
"You've got to remember, they bought something they shouldn't have and paid too much for it," said Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at Paine Webber in New York. As a result, he said, even after the restructuring, "there's still not a whole lot of room left for mistakes."
He added, "The situation isn't critical, but it ain't good."
One way to improve WPP's situation would be to sell assets. Analysts said that WPP was continuing to negotiate a possible sale of Scali, McCabe, Sloves in New York, which also has interests in agencies like Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, to the Interpublic Group of Companies.
"They'd been getting silly offers" for assets, Ms. Tilbian of S. G. Warburg said. "Now that suitors see the company is on a safer footing, they might not try to take advantage of the situation."

HEADLINE: Suffolk Raises Sales Tax Half a Cent

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 5

 BODY:
After a final round of flailing, the Suffolk County Legislature agreed today to raise the county sales tax by half a cent to 8.5 percent to close a budget deficit and avert a property-tax increase.
The new rate, which means Suffolk joins neighboring Nassau County in collecting the highest sales tax in the state and among the highest in the nation, will take effect on Sept. 1. It automatically expires on Dec. 31, 1993, unless county officials gain state permission for an extension. The higher rate will produce an estimated $12 million in revenue this year and about $50 million next year. 
 Last year, the county got state permission to increase the sales tax by half a penny. That increase also expires at the end of next year. County officials said that would mean $100 million to $120 million less in revenues for 1994.
Under an aid plan approved for the financially troubled county last month in Albany, half of the revenues from the new sales-tax increase will pay off a budget note the county plans to approve and sell by the fall to close a $36 million deficit in the county's $1.3-billion 1991 budget.
 
Avoids Rise in Property Taxes
 Without borrowing, the county would have been forced to raise property taxes in the 1993 budget to close the deficit.
"The sales tax reduces the amount of money you will need from property taxes," said the Legislature's Presiding Officer, Donald Blydenburgh of Smithtown. "That's what it comes down to."
The revenues will be divided between the county's general fund, where they can be used to close a projected deficit in the 1992 budget of $5 million to $10 million, and the police district that covers the county's five western towns, where the money will provide financing to hire 300 new police officers.
The 10-to-8 vote today gave the increased sales tax the minimum support needed to go into effect. The budget note also needs a minimum of 10 votes to pass.
In the debate preceding the vote, legislators opposed to the increase said that the county should consider deeper program cuts and laying off workers first. They clashed with colleagues who said that the county had done everything it could and that the economic problems were caused by higher expenses mandated by the state and Federal Governments. In the end, a combination of Democrats, Republicans and two Conservative legislators provided the narrow margin of victory.
The vote ended a difficult period for County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, a former State Assemblyman who found himself caught between the conflicting wishes of the State Legislature and the Governor's office on one hand and the County Legislature on the other.
 
One Plan Fails
 The plan Mr. Gaffney, a Republican, offered initially called for sellingup to $90 million in general obligation bonds, but support evaporated after Mr. Gaffney reduced his estimate of the total budget deficit last month to $42 million to $46 million.
Mr. Gaffney then settled on a plan with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and leaders of the State Legislature that would have allowed the county to sell general obligation bonds to close out the deficit for 1991 and also to cover whatever deficit occurred in 1992.
But in an unexpected turn, Republican members of the County Legislature rejected the plan and demanded a revision that substituted the budget note, which must be repaid within one year, for the six-year-general obligation bonds.
Mr. Gaffney told county officials that no changes were possible. But last month, when Governor Cuomo called a special session of the State Legislature for final votes on financial packages for Suffolk and Nassau, Mr. Gaffney raced to Albany to lobby frantically for the changes the county officials wanted.
In a final moment of embarrassment, Republican Assemblymen from Suffolk, Mr. Gaffney's colleagues when he served in the Assembly, declined to vote to authorize the sales tax increase, nearly derailing the plan's approval.
"At the time I felt they were abandoning ship," said Mr. Gaffney. "It was disappointing."
The Suffolk officials must now turn their attention to the 1993 budget, which Mr. Gaffney will announce in mid-September. Mr. Gaffney has warned of a potential $100 million "problem" that lies ahead.

HEADLINE: Negotiators Hope to Finish Free Trade Pact Today

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
American, Canadian and Mexican negotiators hope to complete a North American free trade agreement by late Thursday afternoon or Friday, people involved in the talks said today.
The negotiators finished the broad outlines of the planned agreement on Tuesday evening and labored over many of the remaining details today. 
 On Thursday at 5 P.M., President Bush is scheduled to return from a campaign swing in the West, the same people said, and could use the White House as a politically dramatic setting for the announcement of major accomplishment 10 days before the Republican convention.
But experienced trade hands cautioned that unexpected disputes could still crop up, either in the next two days or even after an accord is struck. Seemingly small details could suddenly turn into important stumbling blocks and push a final deal into next week or beyond.
Early this week, the talks were held up as much as a day by a heated dispute over whether Canada would be able to start shipping to the United States more square meters of clothing made from imported yarn or fabric. That issue is now largely resolved. But differences remain on arbitration panels for bilateral and trilateral commercial disputes and on trade in automobiles, energy, beer, glass and apparel.
American law requires that before the free-trade accord can be submitted to Congress, 40 industry groups must produce detailed evaluations of the pact. A member of one groups said today that the groups had been told that they were likely to receive a final copy of the agreement by Saturday so that they could produce their reports by Aug. 28.
The accord would then be submitted to Congress on Sept. 8, the day after Labor Day and the day that Congress returns from its August recess, the group member said and an American official confirmed.
An Administration official said that Aug. 28 was not a hard and fast deadline but that the groups had been asked to produce their reports as quickly as possible. Several groups whose industries were dealt with early in the negotiations have already prepared draft reports, the official said.
In another sign of an imminent deal, senior American trade officials will spend four hours on Thursday afternoon describing it to a group of chief executives, trade association presidents, and labor and environmental-group leaders.
As the negotiations at the Watergate Hotel dragged through their eighth consecutive day, including four days with Trade Ministers present, tempers were beginning to fray. "It's like the Energizer battery -- it keeps going and going," one tired participant complained of the talks.
Meanwhile, the International Trade Commission, an independent Federal agency that performs nonpartisan analyses of trade policies and rules on trade law cases, embarrassed the Administration today by announcing that the free trade pact would hurt American allies in the Caribbean.
By lowering Customs duties on imports of garments from Mexico, the free trade accord would shift international investment away from Caribbean nations' apparel industries and toward Mexico's, the commission said in a report issued this evening.
The report, which was commissioned by Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, gave new credence to criticisms that the accord will help Mexico at the expense of other poor countries. Economists have long criticized regional agreements that divert trade instead of creating new trade, because this distorts international markets.
The House is scheduled to vote Thursday on a resolution sponsored by Representatives Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader. The resolution calls for the free trade accord to protect jobs and the environment, and is so broadly worded that even the Administration supports it.
Public Citizen, a consumer and environmental group founded by Ralph Nader, distributed fake deeds to the Brooklyn Bridge on Capitol Hill today. "If you believe President Bush's promises on trade, jobs and the environment, he's got a bridge he'd like to sell you," an attached flier said.
All three negotiating teams are haunted by the problems that cropped up after top American and Canadian negotiators shook hands on the 1988 United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement. Senior officials then left aside a variety of legal phrasing issues for their assistants to work out, only to discover that some of these technical issues had commercial implications that made them politically touchy.
The senior officials ended up holding another meeting two months later to sort out these differences.
The 1988 pact also failed to end trade disputes between the countries because of murky language concerning how to resolve disputes and what qualifies as a car made in North America. To minimize such quarrels in the future, all three countries are devising extraordinarily detailed provisions for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Even if the Trade Ministers strike a deal this week, their lawyers will continue to work on the legal language through the end of the month. The point of the extra negotiations is to uncover possible disputes over these issues now.

HEADLINE: More Buses and Trains Planned to Lure Riders

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
As part of a new strategy to turn around the falling ridership on New York City's public transportation system, the Transit Authority is planning to increase the number of subway trains on certain lines and start new bus service beginning in September.
The changes are the first concrete steps in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's initiative, proposed in June, to intensify customer service and improve the transit system's infrastructure. 
 The board of the transportation authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency, is expected to approve the changes at its meeting on Aug. 14. They would be phased in over a year and the hope is that the new strategy will build back ridership, which since 1989 has fallen by 9.6 percent for subways and by 6.8 percent for buses.
"We're committed to aggressively getting new ridership," said the Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman, Peter E. Stangl. "We're going to market it hard and see whether it works."
In April, the transportation authority proposed what it called its "Fare Deal" strategy. Instead of cutting service to narrow a projected budget shortfall of about $300 million by trimming expenses, the authority decided to concentrate on increasing ridership.
"It's an if-you-run-it-they-will-ride-it idea," explained Jared Lebow, a Transit Authority spokesman.
 
'A Complete Turnaround'
 The initiatives, which were announced yesterday by the Transit Authority president, Alan F. Kiepper, would cost $5 million to $6 million for the first year but could easily pay for themselves if they add 6 million fares a year to the 1.6 billion now recorded in the city's public transportation networks, Mr. Kiepper said. Most of the new riders are expected to be tourists and weekend riders and then as the economy improves, people commuting to work.
"What has happened is a complete turnaround," said Joseph Rappaport of the Straphangers Campaign. "It's like they had new brains implanted. For years they had their knife to the subway and bus service. It's incredible and it's fantastic."
Several of the initiatives will go into effect in September and although the M.T.A. board must vote on all changes in fares and new lines, Mr. Stangl stressed, he expected the proposal to pass this month without any problems.
But money to pay for the entire "Fare Deal" strategy awaits city, state and Federal approval. The Transit Authority faces a multimillion-dollar deficit in 1993, Mr. Lebow said.
 
Changes in Trains
 The Transit Authority's September changes focus on specific lines. There will be more and faster service on the N and R lines that connect Queens, Manhattan and Brooklyn, reducing travel time by 7 to 10 minutes. In addition, there will be 27 percent more weekend afternoon service on the Lexington Avenue No. 6 Line.
Beginning in October, there will be a 50 percent increase on the A and D trains on weekends as well as a new A Train Rockaway Park express service, improved platform signs, pocket schedules and better station announcements.
Two new bus lines have already been approved by the transportation authority board and will go into effect in September. The M60 will connect Harlem to La Guardia Airport and the S79 will link Staten Island to Brooklyn. In October, reduced rate bus-to-subway transfers at Jamaica Center in Queens and Stillwell Avenue in Brooklyn will take effect and on Staten Island there will be free express-to-local bus transfers and free transfers from local buses to Staten Island Rapid Transit trains. Beginning in January, there will be new limited bus-stop service on the B41, BX1, Q43 and M7 buses that will stop at one-third fewer places.

HEADLINE: Trenton Budget-Cut Layoffs to Total 2,700

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
New Jersey officials said today that they would lay off nearly 2,700 state workers beginning in October because of $1.1 billion in budget cuts voted by the Legislature.
The number of layoffs was more than twice what the Republicans, who control the Legislature, had predicted would be necessary but only half of what the administration had forecasted. 
 The work force reduction will be the biggest layoff in New Jersey history, said the State Personnel Director, Anthony J. Cimino. That cut and the elimination of 2,850 other jobs through attrition will reduce the state work force to 62,000, he said, 9,000 fewer people than the state employed in January 1990, when Gov. Jim Florio took office.
The cuts range across all 19 state departments but appeared to spare both the Governor's office and the Legislature's staff, at least for the time being.
 
'The Spirit of the Budget'
 Mr. Cimino said that the administration had attempted to abide by the Legislature's admonition to begin the layoffs with well-paid employees and so-called unclassified employees, those without a civil-service classification.
Although the State Attorney General, Robert J. Del Tufo, told department heads last month that they were not obligated to honor the Legislature's dictates about where cuts were to be made, Mr. Cimino said, "we honored the spirit of the budget language."
He said 1,051 of the layoffs affected management employees, of whom 631 have no civil-service classification. They could be laid off immediately, but Mr. Cimino said they would probably "be given at least two weeks' notice." Most of the layoffs will begin on Oct. 2, he said.
But it is by no means certain that those targeted for layoffs will lose their jobs. Any employee with a civil-service classification, including an unknown number of managers, can "bump" a less senior employee in the same or a lower classification. The second person can do the same, taking a third person's job.
The process is complicated and subject to restrictions -- an electrician, for example, could not take a nurse's job, and there is no bumping across departmental lines. The result can be chaotic.
During a round of about 900 layoffs last year, Mr. Cimino said the ratio of employees affected was 3 to 1. That is, for every person laid off three people changed jobs because of bumping.
The immediate response to today's announcement was relatively muted. Jan Pierce, vice president of the district office of the Communications Workers of America, which represents some 38,000 state employees, said the union would "dedicate all of its resources to working with the administation and other unions toward the goal of maintaining state services while minimizing layoffs."
But the Policemen's Benevolent Association, the union representing corrections officers, maintained that it was understaffed by 337 officers because of a hiring freeze and that the Corrections Department has been used as a "political pawn" in a battle between the Democratic Governor and the Republican Legislature.
 
9,000 Fewer Workers
 Local 195 of the New Jersey Public Employees Union, representing about 8,000 state workers, said it intends "to do everything possible to keep these recently announced layoffs from taking place." The union argued that despite the layoffs in middle management "the largest number slated for layoff are those in lower-salaried positions."
The state work force has been reduced by 9,000 people since 1990, despite a $2.8 billion tax increase Mr. Florio pushed through the Legislature that year. The Republicans pared that increase by $608 million two months ago by cutting the sales tax from 7 to 6 percent.
But even with the lion's share of the increase still in place, a stagnant economy and lower revenues made sharp cuts in state jobs and programs unavoidable.
"Twenty-seven hundred jobs is an enormous amount of pain for a penny," Mr. Cimino said today, continuing the administration's criticism of the tax cut in the face of an already serious budget crisis.
The Republicans, who wrested all-but-total control of the Legislature from the Democrats largely on the strength of resentment over the 1990 tax increase, insisted on cutting the sales tax though Mr. Florio and the Democrats warned that it would mean laying off 6,000 to 7,000 state workers.
The Republicans, on the other hand, insisted that the savings could be accomplished while cutting only about 1,400 people, almost all of them middle managers earning more than $50,000 a year.

HEADLINE: William Maxwell McCord, 61, Author and Sociology Professor

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Dr. William Maxwell McCord, an author on social and urban issues and a sociology professor at City College of New York, died on Monday at Yale University Health Services Center in New Haven. He was 61 years old and lived in Guilford, Conn.
His family said yesterday that he had died of injuries sustained in a car crash in Guilford on July 9. 
 Dr. McCord, a native of St. Louis, was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Stanford University and earned a doctorate in social science at Harvard in 1955. That year he began his teaching career as a Harvard instructor in social psychology. He returned to Stanford to join the sociology department in 1958 and gained tenure at the age of 28.
He spent six years teaching at Rice University in Houston and Syracuse University before moving to City College in 1971. He served as sociology department chairman for 10 years, until 1983, and lectured widely overseas at universities from Dublin to Cairo to Singapore.
Dr. McCord was a co-author of books and monographs on delinquency and crime and later ranged over economic development, international politics and urban affairs. His credits grew to 17 books and nearly 100 articles.
Among his works were "The Springtime of Freedom: Evolution of Developing Societies" (Oxford University Press, 1965), "Mississippi: The Long, Hot Summer" (W. W. Norton, 1965), and, more recently, "Paths to Progress" (Norton, 1986), written with his wife, Arline McCord. Researching the Mississippi book, Dr. McCord joined the Freedom Riders in their drive against racial segregation.
In addition to his wife, the former Arline Fujii, Dr. McCord is survived by five sons, Geoffrey, of Durham, N.C., Robert, of Narberth, Pa., Maxwell, of White Plains, and William of Guilford; a daughter, Elinor Mary McCord, also of Guilford; a stepdaughter, Dr. Karen Sakuma of Seattle; two stepsons, Theodore Sakuma of Orangeburg, N.Y., and Michael Sakuma, of Stony Brook, L.I., and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Plans $36 Billion Auction

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury as expected announced yesterday that it would auction $36 billion of Treasury notes and bonds next week, including $10 billion of 30-year bonds. But this decision appeared to surprise some investors in the bond market, who were apparently looking for some unexpected twist.
The consensus forecast for the auction announcement was exactly what the Treasury announced: $15 billion of 3-year notes, $11 billion of 10-year notes and the $10 billion of 30-year bonds. But traders and analysts said there was speculation in the morning as the bond market rose that the size of the entire auction might be cut and that the 30-year bond auction would be reduced or even suspended. 
 The disappointment of far-fetched expectations can have some impact. Just before the announcement in Washington at 2:30 P.M., the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were up 7/8 point on the day in the secondary market for Treasury securities, to yield 7.39 percent, just a few basis points or hundreths of a percentage above its low for the year.
But immediately after the announcement, the price of the long bond began to fall. And it ended the day all but unchanged. In late trading it was offered at 106 27/32 , up 1/32 for the day to yield 7.42 percent, unchanged from Tuesday.
"I don't know what the bond people were smoking," said Jay Goldinger, a bond trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles. "Bond investors got a lot higher on the market than they should have."
 
The Buying of the Long Bond
 Some traders said that the buying of the long bond could have been in part just to hedge in case there was a surprise announcement. This would help to explain why the 7/8-point gain unraveled so fast in the afternoon.
The price of Treasury notes also came off after the announcement. But by the end of the day they had rebounded a little. Traders said that investors who sold the 30-year Treasury bond moved into the shorter maturities -- ranging from 2-year to 10-year notes.
At the end of the day, the 30-year bond to be auctioned next week was trading in the pre-auction, or when-issued, market at a yield of 7.37 percent, five basis points below the current issue.
Lou Crandall, chief economist for R. H. Wrightsom & Associates, said investors were willing to pay a little more for the new bond because once it was issued it would trade with more liquidity than the old issue. But he said as an investor he would stick with the current issue. "If I found out that my pension money was in this one just because it was the new one, I would fire the manager," he said.
The new three-year note appeared to be in less demand. In the when-issued market the three-year note to be auctioned next week was at a yield of 4.83 percent, 14 basis points over the current three-year note. The current note was offered in late trading at 103 1/32 , up 1/8 to yield 4.69 percent, compared with 4.74 percent on Tuesday.
And the 10-year note to be aucitoned next week was trading at a yield of 6.62 percent in the when-issued market, just two basis points over the current 10-year note yield. In late trading the current 10-year note was offered at 106 12/32 , up 5/32 , to yield 6.60 percent compared with 6.62 percent on Tuesday.
The spread on the 10-year note is so close, Mr. Crandall said, because there is such strong demand for it that a real shortage has developed.
On other issues affecting the market, the Treasury said the nation's debt ceiling, which caps the level of Treasury borrowing, should be reached in the first quarter of next year. As it has in the past, the Treasury indicated that it would like Congress to approve a higher debt ceiling before it adjourns this year so a "crisis situation" can be avoided early next year.
Congress and the White House have avoided debt ceiling crises, complete with threats to or actual shutdowns of the Government, for almost two years because the debt ceiling, which is now $4.145 trillion, was raised much more than usual in November 1990.
The Treasury also said it was encouraging both Brazil and Argentina to buy the 30-year zero-coupon bonds they need in the secondary Treasury market. But the Treasury also said it might still sell some of these bonds directly to the two Governments. The two countries need the bonds to provide the guarantees on loan repayment that are at the heart of their recently negotiated debt reduction agreements with their commercial bankers.
The prospect of these two countries buying billions of dollars of 30-year bonds would provide a little support for the bond market and could even help the Treasury get a slightly better price in next week's auciton.
There was economic news that also gave the bond market some support yesterday before the Treasury announcement. This included the Federal Reserve's so-called beige book, which reports on economic activity around the country. In addition, there were comments from the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, that also indicated that the pace of economic growth was still sluggish. For bond traders this means that inflation ought to remain low and interest rates would not be rising, all good news for the bond market.
The beige book said that "economic activity has been uneven" in recent weeks with little strength anywhere. According to the Fed report, growth was especially disappointing in manufacturing and retail sales, with only a few parts of the country reporting any strength.
The report also noted that the recent reductions in interest rates had not had a significant impact on home sales, although a new round of mortgage refinancings is clearly under way.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts a Broad Gain Aided by Pound's Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most currencies, helped in part by weakness in the British pound.
The British pound was weak in relation to the German mark and was not supported by the British central bank or the United States Federal Reserve, said Jack Adkins, a currency analyst with the Refco Group in Chicago. "That seemed to lead all the currencies lower and that benefited the dollar," Mr. Adkins said. 
 Trading among foreign currencies, known as cross trading, can have a spillover effect on the dollar.
Also factored into the mark's activity was the release yesterday of figures showing a continued rise in unemployment in Germany, Mr. Adkins said.
"It's indicative that the German economy is showing signs of slowing down because of extremely tight monetary policy," Mr. Adkins said, noting that the German central bank raised its discount rate last month. The discount is the interest central banks charge commercial banks.
Mr. Adkins said the market remained uncertain about the unemployment figures the United States will release tomorrow. "We are kind of on hold until we see that," he said.
The dollar traded at 127.50 yen in New York, up from Tuesday's late bid of 127.25. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 127.30 Japanese yen from 127.28 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 127.35 yen.
The British pound fell in New York to $1.9075, off from $1.9195 late Tuesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9135, from $1.9230 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.4815 German marks, up from 1.4770; 1.3300 Swiss francs, up from 1.3245; 5.0050 French francs, up from 4.9900; 1,120.00 Italian lire, up from 1,116.00, and 1.18375 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18485.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.4775 German marks, up from 1.4745; 1.3240 Swiss francs, up from 1.3205; 4.9889 French francs, up from 4.9815; 1.6655 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6625; 1,116.75 Italian lire, up from 1,114.50, and 1.1827 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1851.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Mixed Yields Are Shown For Money Market Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds were mixed in the latest week, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report. Analysts said the yield situation appeared to be stabilizing as the funds caught up to the Federal Reserve's lowering of short-term interest rates a month ago.
Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist, does not think the Fed is likely to take further action, unless the unemployment numbers released tomorrow compel it to do so. Otherwise, he said, the monetary officials will hold the line until next month. "The Fed doesn't like to take action so close to its quarterly refunding," Mr. Frank said.
 
Varied Directions
 Yields on tax-exempt money funds posted their first gains in weeks, as investors moved toward the longer end of the market and locked into higher-yielding longer-term securities. Among taxable money market funds, yields were down, but the speed of the decline eased. 
 Both the seven-day compounded and the simple average yield for tax-exempt funds showed gains of 2 basis points, to 2.22 percent and 2.20 percent, respectively. In the last 30 days, the average compounded and simple yields are both down 3 basis points, to 2.18 percent and 2.16 percent, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
IBC/Donoghue's said assets of tax-exempt money funds showed a slow leak as $620 million was withdrawn, leaving total assets at $94.7 billion. Much of the money was taken out by investors looking for higher yields in longer-term municipal bonds, it said.
The average number of days left to maturity of the securities in tax-exempt portfolios rose by a day, to 64. This is quite long, analysts say, and indicates portfolio managers are not fearful that interest rates will suddenly go back up.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-free yield is 3.08 percent, up 11 basis points in the last two weeks, while the equivalent for those investors in the 31 percent tax bracket is 3.21 percent, up 19 basis points in two weeks.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market fund, distributed by Strong/Corneliuson in Milwaukee, gave the best return for the sixth straight week, at 2.99 percent.
Yields on taxable money market funds fell, as assets declined by $6.3 billion, to a total of $496.9 billion. Of that, institutional assets fell $4 billion, to $177.4 billion, with retail funds accounting for the rest of the drop, with assets off $2.3 billion, to $319.5 billion.
The average seven-day compounded yield for taxable money market funds was 3.15 percent, down 4 basis points, while the simple yield fell 3 basis points, to 3.11 percent. Over a 30-day period, the compounded and simple average yields were both down 7 basis points, to 3.23 percent and 3.18 percent, respectively.
 
Extending Maturities
 Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios rose two days, to 64 days, as managers extended maturities in search of higher yields.
The Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, had the best return among general purpose funds, with a yield of 3.98 percent. Over all, funds holding government debt outperformed others: United Service Government Securities Savings, distributed by United Services in El Paso, showed a return of 4.37 percent. The fund's management does, however, absorb some costs, enhancing the yield.
For bank money market accounts, which are the prime competitor of money funds, the average yield was 3.07 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Below $350 an Ounce, But Some Remain Bullish

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices dipped below the psychologically important $350-an-ounce level yesterday. Some analysts, however, said the downturn might be just a blip in a long-term rally.
Gold for August delivery fell $3.50, to $349.20 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. It was the lowest daily settlement since July 14 and a significant setback for the market, which had climbed from less than $340 in mid-May to more than $360 by late July. 
 Silver for September delivery rose 1 cent, to $3.892 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange; October platinum sank $1.40, to $376.30 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The selloff of gold futures was led by commodity funds, said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential Securities.
Gold fell $4.80 an ounce on Monday in reaction to the relatively quiet start of a two-day strike by black workers in South Africa, a leading gold producer. But yesterday's decline was prompted more by technical factors like the market's failure to hold above $360, analysts said.
Still, Ms. Raptopoulos said the fundamental factors behind gold's recent rally -- low interest rates, a weak dollar, falling stock prices and political uncertainty in the United States and elsewhere -- remained in place.
Dinza Mehta, chief bullion dealer with the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, said that prices might have risen too high, too fast, and that this week's downturn was a temporary pause. He predicted gold would again approach or exceed $360.
"Why the market should put on such a severe selloff is a tiny bit puzzling," he said.
Oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange after the International Energy Agency reported that five OPEC nations had raised their production last month to push the organization more than a half-million barrels a day over its self-imposed output ceiling.
Prices were also under pressure as a result of an American Petroleum Institute report on Tuesday that showed United States crude oil stocks rose by 6.3 million barrels last week, a greater increase than traders had expected.
Light sweet crude oil for September delivery fell 17 cents, to $21.18 a barrel; September heating oil dropped 0.44 cent, to 58.63 cents a gallon; September unleaded gasoline fell 0.73 cent, to 58.95 cents a gallon; September natural gas slipped 1 cent, to $1.851 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Trade-Pact Fears Seem Overstated

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
NOW that a North American Free Trade Agreement looks imminent, some Democrats are worried that it will make America's working poor even poorer. The most dire predictions, from the liberal Economic Policy Institute, are that low-wage Mexican workers will steal $1,000 from the paychecks of most American workers each year and rob them of half a million jobs.
Though legitimate, such fears -- which the Canadians also share -- seem overstated. A comprehensive review by the middle-of-the-road Brookings Institution recently found that all but one of 15 studies of the effect of freer trade with Mexico and Canada concluded that pay would get a small increase. The single exception, and the one cited by the Economic Policy Institute, fails to take into account the pay-raising effects of greater competitiveness and bigger market size. 
 Real-world evidence should do even more to soothe anxiety. Trade with Mexico has mushroomed in the last few years but American jobs have been gained, not lost, as a result: 175,000 jobs since 1989, many in manufacturing, by the reckoning of Gary Hufbauer at the Institute for International Economics. That's more, incidentally, than the headline-grabbing job cuts at General Motors, I.B.M. and McDonnell Douglas combined.
The fact is that Mexico, growing again and hungry to modernize, is on the verge of becoming America's second-biggest foreign market. It is expected to replace Japan as the No. 2 export market. Canada will remain the biggest buyer of American products. As Mexicans buy American trucks, computers and other goods, trade with that country has swung from a $2 billion deficit for the United States in 1989 to an estimated $7 billion surplus in 1992.
Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute, argues that American workers are in for a rude awakening when the agreement throws open borders to cheap imports. Then, the young, the less educated and males -- the people whose paychecks have been taking a beating in the recession and for the last decade -- will be forced to compete directly with Mexican factory hands, who earn half as much an hour ($2.17 to be exact) as the worst-paid American.
Some workers will inevitably be hurt, everyone agrees. But others will be helped. And the overall effect will probably be positive, but even the negative effects will almost certainly be modest.
First, most of the working poor are employed by service companies, from fast-food restaurants to hospitals to gas stations, and do not compete directly with foreign workers. Secondly,
United States trade barriers vis-a-vis Mexico and other poor countries are already low. Tariffs on Mexican goods average just 4 percent. Lowering them further cannot conceivably make a sharp difference.
"You're removing a small amount of protection against a small country," said Gene Grossman, an economist at Princeton University. "Americans won't even notice Nafta."
On the other hand, the agreement is likely to have a positive effect on American exports from cars to computers. Mexico does two-thirds of its overseas shopping in the United States. And Mexican tariffs, though sharply lower than a few years ago, are still hovering around 10 percent. Mexico also has strict auto quotas.
Mexico's recent appetite for American capital goods is not likely to fade anytime soon. As Mexico struggles to join the world's newly indsutrialized countries over a decade or two, that nation is likely to keep running trade deficit -- just like the United States before World War I, Japan in the 1950's and Korea in the 1970's.
The most plausible anxiety concerns investment, not trade. The worry is that the agreement will divert investment and jobs from the United States to Mexico as American manufacturers are drawn to magnet of low Mexican wages.
A look at a few basic facts shows that such fears appear to be exaggerated. People forget that Mexico's economy is one-twentieth the size of America's. Even if the United States contributed every penny of foreign direct investment Mexico could absorb, the amount would be only a minute fraction of all the money Americans invest. Mexico now receives a total of $3 billion in investment from all foreign sources, compared with $725 billion that Americans invested at home last year.
"If Mexico's total investment were to go up by 10 percentage points of the Mexican G.D.P., or $30 billion, and it all came from the U.S., our domestic investment would go down by two-tenths of a percent of United States G.D.P.," said Rudiger Dornbusch an economist at M.I.T.
"They would be an instant Korea and we would have a rounding error."
In any case, virtually everyone agrees, much of the new direct investment in Mexico will substitute for American investment now flowing to places like Taiwan, Indonesia and Ireland.
Again, take a look at what's actually happening. To increase its competitiveness, Japan has been exporting labor-intensive manufacturing operations to low-wage Malaysia and elsewhere in the Pacific Rim throughout the 1980's. Germany has been setting up shops and factories in Czechoslovakia, Portugal and southern Italy. Yet, neither of these models of enlightenment has seen the pay of its low-wage workers collapse.
Closer economic ties between the United States and Mexico will help make both economies more competitive without having much effect, one way or the other, on the living standards of America's poorest workers. Rising pay in Mexico should ease immigration pressures, as they are already. And the benefits of investing in Mexico -- as opposed to Czechoslovakia or Malaysia -- is that Mexico is more likely to buy American exports.
Thus, the notion that a more isolated nation -- as opposed to one with productivity-enhancing training, tax cuts or renewed economic growth -- will materially help those American workers who are falling behind seems wrongheaded to say the least.

HEADLINE: Fed Downgrades the Nation's Business Prospects

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve today downgraded its assessment of business prospects around the country, with the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, conceding that the economic recovery is "quite minimal."
In its latest nationwide survey of the economy, the Fed declared that "economic activity has been uneven" in recent weeks with some pockets of strength but many more areas where activity is stagnant or declining. 
 The new Fed survey of its 12 regional banks was in stark contrast to a review just seven weeks ago that had sounded the most optimistic assessment of the economy's prospects since the recession began in July 1990.
 
'Significant Pressures' Noted
 But since that report was issued, the national unemployment rate has shot up to an eight-year high of 7.8 percent and several statistics have flashed warning signals that this year's rebound could be in danger of stalling out, just as a similar recovery did in 1991.
Testifying before Congress today, Mr. Greenspan insisted that the economy was still advancing, but said that "there are definitely very significant pressures which are holding the economy back."
He added, however, that this year's weakness is not as severe as last year's, when the recovery faltered.
"I do wish to make the distinction between an economy that is going down, or an economy that is completely stagnant," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee. "The economy is scarcely moving in a way which we consider adequate, but it is moving forward."
The Fed report, known as the "beige book" for the color of its cover, will be used as the basis of discussion when Fed policy makers meet on Aug. 18 to review interest rate strategies.
The Fed last cut rates on July 2 and many economists believe that a further reduction is in the offing if economic signals do not show signs of strengthening. A key report will be unemployment for July, which will be released on Friday. Many economists believe it will show only a slight dip in the unemployment rate, perhaps down to 7.7 percent.
 
Mortgage Refinancings Spurred
 The central bank has already cut rates 23 times in the last three years, which has driven mortgage rates to their lowest level in nearly two decades.
But the Fed survey said that so far the latest rate reductions have had little impact on home sales although they had spurred another round of mortgage refinancings.
In a separate report today, the National Association of Realtors said that housing sales and prices remained under significant downward pressure in many parts of the country with 21 cities reporting price drops in the spring and 16 states reporting falling sales.
Where the Fed's June report on the economy had found manufacturing showing strength throughout the country, the new report said that growth in factory output varied widely from region to region and from industry to industry.
The Fed's regional banks in Cleveland and Chicago said that manufacturing continued to lead the economic recovery in their regions. But Boston, Philadelphia, Richmond and St. Louis all said that manufacturing employment had failed to show any significant increases in their region.
 
Cutbacks Weaken Economy
 San Francisco complained of continued weakness because of cutbacks in defense and aerospace industries.
Minneapolis and Atlanta complained of depressed sales of big-ticket appliances while auto sales were weak in most districts, with the exception of Atlanta and Dallas.
Cleveland, Richmond, Kansas City, Mo., and Dallas said that lower interest rates were failing to spur home buying, with real estate agents in some parts of the country reporting that worries about job losses were holding down sales.
The Fed said that the farm economy was somewhat better. The Richmond, Chicago, St. Louis and Kansas City districts all said that recent rains had brought relief to drought-stressed crops.

HEADLINE: G.M. Subsidiaries Report Mixed Results for 2d Period

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation's three nonautomotive subsidiaries posted mixed second-quarter financial results today. But their cumulative performance was sharply lower than last year's because of a $749.4 million restructuring charge reported six weeks ago by G.M.'s Hughes Aircraft unit.
G.M. will report overall second-quarter results Thursday. Analysts expect Hughes's one-time write-off to leave the auto maker with a loss of several hundred million dollars in the quarter. 
 Following are the details of the subsidiaries' results:
 
Hughes
 Including the charge, G.M.'s Hughes Electronics subsidiary posted a second-quarter net loss of $615.7 million, compared with earnings of $83.4 million in the period a year earlier. Revenue edged up 2.6 percent, to $2.97 billion from $2.89 billion.
Hughes will use the charge to pay for severance and related expenses in connection with laying off about 9,000, or 15 percent, of Hughes's workers; to discontinue business lines, and to consolidate facilities. G.M. said the Hughes write-off would enable the company to reduce costs by about $700 million annually.
G.M.'s class H stock, which represents a right to receive dividends based on Hughes's earnings, closed today at $25.625, up $1.125 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
G.M.A.C.
 The General Motors Acceptance Corporation earned $286.9 million in the second quarter, 1.2 percent more than the $283.6 million of the period a year earlier. G.M.A.C.'s earning assets eased to $94.7 billion on June 30, from $98.4 billion a year earlier.
Robert T. O'Connell, G.M.A.C. chairman, said lower earnings from financing and mortgage operations reflected lower earning-asset levels and lower interest rates, partly offset by lower borrowing costs and better loss trends. G.M.A.C.'s insurance lines generated $45.5 million in profits, up $17.8 million from last year.
 
E.D.S.
 The Electronic Data Systems Corporation subsidiary posted a 12 percent increase in second-quarter net income, to $157.1 million from $139.8 million. Revenue rose 20 percent, to $2.02 billion from $1.68 billion. On a per-share basis, earnings on G.M. class E stock were 33 cents, compared with 29 cents a year ago. G.M. class E represents a right to receive dividends based on E.D.S.'s earnings. It closed today at $28.125, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
E.D.S. said the highlight of its second quarter was the signing of a 10-year contract to provide systems-management services to Smith's Food and Drug Centers Inc. in Salt Lake City. E.D.S. declined to disclose the contract's value.
Despite the gains of the class E and class H shares, General Motors common slid $1.125 today, to $39.125.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fujitsu Expects Its First Deficit Ever

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 5

 BODY:
In another sign of Japan's deepening economic slump, Fujitsu Ltd., the nation's largest computer company, said today that it would lose money for the first time in its history in first half of this fiscal year.
Company officials and analysts say the loss, expected to be about $80 million, stems from severe pricing pressures in the semiconductor business and sluggishness in the computer business. In addition, analysts say, Fujitsu, which is heavily dependent on large mainframe computers, is facing some of the same pressures as its archrival, the International Business Machines Corporation, which has gone through wrenching pain as computers have become smaller and less expensive. 
 Such problems, which are also hurting other companies, are forcing Japan's once-vaunted high-technology companies to cut investments in product development and factories and in some cases to drop businesses that are no longer profitable.
 
Prospects Do Not Look Good
 "The prospects for recovery are receding," said Peter G. Wolff, vice president for Asian electronics research at Kidder, Peabody & Company in Tokyo. "Probably there are others on the way" to losses, he added.
Indeed, the NEC Corporation, one of Japan's largest semiconductor and computer companies, had a consolidated net loss of 3.4 billion yen in the second half of its last fiscal year, ending in March, because of write-offs. And the Sony Corporation had a loss in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.
A spokesman for Fujitsu said the company expected to lose about 10 billion yen in the sixth-month period ending in September. That loss, equivalent to roughly $80 million, contrasts with a profit of 10.4 billion yen in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenues are expected to be about 1.7 trillion yen, or about $13.4 billion, up slightly from 1.6 trillion yen a year earlier.
The loss will be on a consolidated basis, meaning it includes the results of Fujitsu's subsidiaries here and abroad. The parent company alone is still expected to eke out a tiny profit, a company spokesman said, and the company still expects a profit for the entire year on a consolidated basis.
 
Problems at Overseas Units
 Consolidated results are worse than parent company results because of problems in some foreign subsidiaries, including a British semiconductor factory that is still in the start-up phase, the spokesman said.
Fujitsu has been taking steps to try to improve its results, although Mr. Wolff of Kidder, Peabody said he thought that further measures would be needed.
This week, Fujitsu said it was closing a 260-employee semiconductor assembly plant in San Diego, shifting the work to Malaysia. Earlier this year, the company pulled out of the fax machine business in the United States.
Fujitsu has had big problems in its semiconductor business in large measure because of low prices for dynamic random access memories, the main chip it makes. To cut its costs and enter new markets, Fujitsu agreed last month to team up with Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a Silicon Valley semiconductor company, to build a plant to manufacture a new type of memory chip.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Hanoi Is Blocking Progress on Missing

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The Pentagon said today that Hanoi had begun to put new obstacles in the way of resolving more quickly the cases of American servicemen still unaccounted for from the Vietnam War.
The two countries had just begun to make significant progress on the issue, which is blocking the normalization of relations and the lifting of an American economic embargo. Joint American-Vietnamese teams have been excavating crash sites and conducting interviews in wide areas of Vietnam. 
 "The train is fast coming to a halt," Col. John Cole, chief of the Defense Intelligence Agency's office in Bangkok, told the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs near the end of two days of testimony on the most emotional aspect of the issue, the reports of live sightings. "The Vietnamese are beginning to change the rules."
The Pentagon says it has 110 unresolved, first-hand reports from Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos of sightings of Americans covering nearly 19 years since United States forces were withdrawn from Indochina and Hanoi said all prisoners had been returned. The Defense Department lists 2,266 Americans still unaccounted for in Indochina, although half of them are assumed to have died.
Colonel Cole told the committee that in a meeting a week ago, Hanoi demanded full files from the United States on reports by people who claim to have seen Americans, including information on sources. Vietnam would then decide which cases to investigate.
Senior Defense Intelligence Agency officials testifying before the committee said the United States would not jeopardize sources by complying with the request. Vietnam has also denied that it ever offered free access to prisons in the search for Americans.
In testimony, officials acknowledged that they had not asked for access to a Vietnamese Defense Ministry compound in Hanoi that has been the source of persistent rumors and refugee accounts of an underground prison housing foreigners.
Today, a brief confrontation erupted between the committee and the defense intelligence officials, led by Robert Sheetz, chief of the Pentagon's Special Office for P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs, when it was determined that nine photographs of the Hanoi site, known since French colonial days as the Citadel, had been reversed in printing -- the equivalent of viewing a slide backward in a projector -- before being turned over for exhibition in the hearing room, making sites difficult to identify.
The committee's vice chairman, Senator Bob Smith, a New Hampshire Republican, challenged the intelligence agency to prove that it had not been confusing informers by showing them similarly reversed pictures of the Citadel site. Mr. Sheetz apologized and said there had been no intention to deceive.
 
Might Be Non-Americans
 Reports of sightings, the majority of them later proved to be false, have played a large part in creating accusations of Government conspiracies among groups lobbying for the prisoners of war and those missing in action. Defense intelligence officials reiterated today that they believed that most of the sightings are of Russians or Europeans or Cubans working in Indochina.
But committee members said that as long as Laos and Vietnam barred American teams from areas that have generated some of the more credible reports, the sense of cover-up would grow, despite stepped up efforts by the Defense Department to narrow the list of the missing considerably.
Senator John F. Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the committee, asked today that officials and relatives of the missing consider the plight of Vietnam, where officials cannot be expected to open their most sensitive files and sites to the American military and where the bureaucracy can stall even the most well intended plan.
On the other hand, giving the Vietnamese more time and information on sites to be studied, Senator Kerry said, only increases the chances that lobby groups will find investigations unsatisfactory because they will believe prisoners were quickly moved by Hanoi.

HEADLINE: House Democrats Agree to a Vote on Russian Aid

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
House Democratic leaders agreed today to bring President Bush's plan for aid to Russia and other former Soviet republics to a vote Thursday or Friday after the Administration agreed to consider their appeals for more domestic spending on housing and transportation.
The legislation, whose centerpiece is a $12 billion increase in the United States commitment to the International Monetary Fund, was passed in the Senate in June. Despite a range of opposition over everything from Soviet troops in the Baltic to Moscow's aid to Cuba to domestic issues, the bill is expected to pass in the House with majority support from Republicans and Democrats. 
 The Administartion has said that replenishing global lender's funds was necessary so the agency could help Russia and other former Soviet states. Today the fund approved a $1.04 billion loan to Russia.
Urging the House Rules Committee to clear the bill for floor action today, Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the second-ranking Democrat on the Foreign Affairs Committee, said it was essential to pass it quickly. He called it "by far the most important foreign policy vote that most members will cast in their careers in the Congress."
He said passage could not guarantee the success of reforms sought by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, but it could provide critical help. "Time really is of the essence here," he said. "Yeltsin is on the bubble. He really is on the precipice."
Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of New York, told supporters that he would like to support Mr. Bush, but that he was troubled because he felt his unemployed constituents would oppose helping a former enemy when the Federal Government lacked the money to help them.
Mr. Hamilton said, "This is an issue where leadership can persuade."
He said lawmakers should explain to the voters that without stability in Russia and the other former Soviet republics, defense expenditures would be higher, and that with stability, trade and jobs could increase.
Representative Dante B. Fascell of Florida, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, said the cost of the bill "is not even a blip on the screen" when compared to United States expenditures over the duration of the cold war.
While Republicans insist that a solid majority of their 166 House members will vote for the bill, Democrats have not taken a final count, and collecting all their votes could put a vote off until Friday.
One part of that effort will be to persuade members to vote for the bill without their favored amendments. The other will be to persuade Democrats that the Bush Administration is moving to meet their concerns about domestic needs.
Today Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, and David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip, said they were finally prepared to back the bill because Richard A. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, agreed today to give serious consideration to two domestic demands.
One would provide an expansion of federal loan guarantees for housing and another would provide money to speed up higwhay construction.
Mr. Gephardt said it was "not a conclusive meeting." "I felt we made some progress toward solving a set of employment problems," he said. "We're not asking for a great deal. We've asked for attention."
But both the Democratic leaders said that if no agreement was forthcoming, they would oppose final passage of the bill when it returned from a House-Senate conference after Labor Day.
Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican, criticized the Democrats for having a constantly changing set of domestic demands. But he said it was important to move on the bill now. He said that after the Congress-bashing expected at the Republican National Convention, which begins in 11 days, it would be hard to get bipartisan agreement on such a difficult bill in September.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
TV Images of Bosnia Ignite Passions and Politics

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Once again, Washington finds itself under siege by television news.
After the Persian Gulf war, pictures of battered Kurdish refugees forced the Administration to provide them with a semblance of protection. Now the pressure is on to put an end to the grim scenes from what used to be Yugoslavia: 
 Two small corpses (one a Serbian infant, an ethnic-cleansing bullet having evidently gone astray) after an attack on a busload of children trying to escape the killing ground; mourners scattered by mortar fire at the funeral for the two children, a mother running from her 32-month-old daughter's grave, a grandmother injured; civilians dashing across dangerous streets to do their daily chores, like people seeking sanity in a madhouse; cities destroyed and families who have left everything behind coming up against closed borders.
There have been no pictures yet of what some have charged are detention centers for former Yugoslavs of non-Serbian extraction, but news programs have made up for that by illustrating the reports with the still-painful photographs of prisoners found in Hitler's concentration camps.
The major networks rely on outside news services like Visnews for their pictures from Bosnia. Whatever the source, they are strong stuff. The message strikes like a mortar shell: Less than 50 years after the destruction of Nazism, the doctrine of racial purity is again on the rampage in Central Europe.
From Congress and from editorial and op-ed columns come reminders of the failure of democracies to act in the 1930's. Already in difficulties over the economy, President Bush must now endure being likened by the sound bites of Democrats to Neville Chamberlain. Even given the scant acquaintance with history for which Americans are famed, can Mr. Bush, who is running wishfully as the model of a manly leader of the new world order, fail to respond with some muscular action to stop the slaughter?
Just what the United States can or should do about outbursts of violence around the globe, even where American interests are arguably at stake, is complicated enough. Mr. Bush's response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, after all, was initially opposed by most Senate Democrats and remains a matter of contention. The complications are compounded by the use of television. As the Pentagon was planning its assault on Iraq, the Administration was rallying public enthusiasm with accounts, eagerly picked up by news producers, of Iraqi atrocities. Now, in a less gung-ho mood, the White House finds itself afflicted by nightly evidence of worse atrocities in a country without oil.
Using television to whip up support for military adventures or merely for political one-upmanship is a highly problematic practice. Some much publicized atrocities turn out to have never occurred. And even, as in Bosnia, where the evidence of a genocidal cleansing is appallingly apparent, trying to satisfy public emotions with actions that are bound to have broad and unforeseeable consequences may not be the best way to run a government. It is not much of a way to run a Presidential campaign either, but the candidates seem to know no other way.
The tube is a single-minded, simple-minded weapon. Iraqi babies in hospitals arouse as much sympathy as Kurdish babies in camps. That is no doubt a tribute to American soft-heartedness but it is also a constraint on policy. If Washington, possibly in consort with its equally reluctant European allies, should carry the war to Serbian centers, television pictures of dead Serbian babies and grieving mothers will replace those of Muslim babies and mothers. And if American soldiers die, the cameras will focus on their families at home. The television audience is famously susceptible to all such sorrows, and cries for war may quickly turn into simple tears.
So television can be a force for compassion, whoever the victims, when it is not stirring up hate for the latest enemy. Either way, this medium, so much better at stirring up than calming down, at delivering the present than revisiting the past or envisioning the future, cannot be counted on to offer much guidance on whether or how to deter or punish an aggressor. Particularly in the frenzy of a Presidential campaign, you can't always tell whether a report is alerting the nation to an evil that must be fought or merely manipulating easily aroused feelings for parochial advantage. But with the evil rampant in Bosnia on display every night, can this country do nothing?
It is not for a television reviewer to issue an opinion on whether the United States should go to war against Serbia or any other malefactor. Yet I can testify that those pictures on the screen have had a powerful impact even on this professionally resistant viewer. Given all the necessary cautions about the uses of television in matters of life and death, can anyone help wishing that cameras had brought pictures of German concentration camps into American homes 50 years ago? Yes, the reporting from Bosnia may be misused, but it could also turn out to be a gallant episode in television journalism.
